Life in the 30's
LEAD: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column will resume April 8.





Board Studies Rocket Failure
LEAD: A nine-member board began an investigation today into the failure of a rocket carrying a communications satellite that may have been hit by lightning.
The chairman, Jon R. Busse, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the board would review the launching then break up into smaller groups for more detailed study.

Nuclear Unit to Cut Pacific Gas Net
LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it expected its 1987 earnings to be reduced by about $470 million, or $1.25 a share, because of a change in accounting procedures related to the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.
The reduction is equivalent to almost half of the company's net income.
But the company said the accounting change would not affect its cash position and that its annual dividend would remain at $1.92.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: A new two-year contract proposal that would pay Roger Clemens a $1.5 million base salary in 1988 was rejected yesterday by the Boston Red Sox.
However, General Manager Lou Gorman said, ''We want to keep the line of communications open and see if we can work something out'' to get the right-handed pitching ace back with the team, which he left March 6.


Dropout in California
LEAD: Representative Tony Coelho, the Californian who is one of the House Democratic leaders, predicted here the other day that the party's 1988 Presidential nominee may be chosen in a ''brokered'' convention next summer in Atlanta.


Dome Reports Loss for 1986
LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the financially beleaguered Canadian oil company, said yesterday that it had lost $2.2 billion (Canadian) in 1986, about $15.5 billion (United States) at current exchange rates.
The loss appears to be the largest annual loss ever reported by a Canadian business.


KNICKS PUT END TO LOSS STREAK
LEAD: With seven seconds remaining, Chris McNealy replaced Louis Orr.
There was no particular game strategy involved in Bob Hill's move.
The Knick coach was simply looking for an ovation for Orr, the 6-foot-9-inch forward who had 28 points last night - equaling his career high - in the Knicks' surprising 128-120 victory over the Boston Celtics at Madison Square


KHAKI ATTIRE GOES TO TOWN IN A GENTLER, FEMININE GUISE
LEAD: IN the beginning, there were khaki-colored drill cloth trousers, the kind worn by the British Army when it occupied India in the 19th century.
Then came British Khaki, a clothing manufacturing company opened seven years ago by Robert Lighton, whose family owns men's stores.


U.S. Farm Exports Dip
LEAD: American farm exports dropped 10 percent in 1986, to $26 billion, an Agriculture Department report said. ''Rising grain production in importing countries cut overseas demand and U.S. exports,'' the report said.


CITIBANK RAISES ITS PRIME RATE
LEAD: Citibank raised its prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent yesterday, the first increase by a major bank since June 1984.


Baltimore Symphony Plans Tour in Soviet
LEAD: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra announced today that it would perform in the Soviet Union this spring, marking the first time in 11 years that an American orchestra had appeared before Soviet audiences.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Capitals 4, Maple Leafs 2: Bob Gould scored two goals last night to lead Washington, which was playing at home.
Washington, second in the Patrick Division, is unbeaten in its last six games with a 5-0-1 record and has allowed only 13 goals in that span.
The loss cost the Maple Leafs a chance to move into third place in the Norris Division.


Richardson Indicted
LEAD: Micheal Ray Richardson has been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on charges of illegally cashing a check for more than $9,700.
Dennis Kwasnik, an assistant prosecutor, said Richardson's auto insurance company, State Farm, gave Richardson the check to reimburse an auto repair shop for work done on a car owned by his wife.


Cone Hot in Debut With Mets
LEAD: David Cone made his debut as the newest arm on the Mets' pitching staff today, and sizzled: three innings against the St.
Louis Cardinals, two singles, no walks, no runs and five strikeouts, and just about everything thrown around 90 miles an hour.


FOUNDATION PLANS PANEL ON LITERATURE
LEAD: Wheatland, the foundation started by Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld that has sponsored conferences on the opera and on the symphony, said today that it planned also to hold conferences on literature.

LEAD: The trouble with April Fool's Day in New York City, of course, is that there's no way to tell who's kidding and who's not.

MEREDITH MONK AND PING CHONG
LEAD: AN evening-long work by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong that opened last night at the Joyce Theater, ''Paris/Venice-Milan/Chacon,'' is a magical, intricately woven and many-layered excursion through time.
Strange sounds and music and words in several languages form a haunting aural backdrop for this voyage.


Deep Six?
LEAD: Fin swimming, in which competitors use rubber fins to add a powerful boost to their kick, is a fast sport that has been making slow progress in the United States since it was imported from Europe a few years ago.
Now one version of it seems to have reached its high-water mark.


SEVEN-WEEK TRIAL TOUCHED MANY BASIC EMOTIONS
LEAD: Beyond the walls of Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's courtroom here, experts in philosophy, law and psychiatry wrestle with social, cultural and ethical questions about surrogate parents that go far beyond the Baby M custody case.

J.

A NEW SHOWCASE FOR ART BY WOMEN
LEAD: Born with a silver spoon in its mouth and bred to be noncontroversial, the National Museum of Women in the Arts will open to the public April 7 after a ceremonial ribbon-cutting by Barbara Bush, the wife of the Vice President.
The first museum devoted solely to female artists in a historical context, it occupies a handsomely renovated landmark building - formerly a Masonic Temple - at New York Avenue and 13th Street, two blocks from the White House.


Star Broker Gets 15 Years
LEAD: Leslie Roberts, who dropped out of college and became a top broker for E.F.
Hutton &amp; Company and Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for defrauding his uncle of millions of dollars.

MANAGEMENT SHIFTS AT I.B.M.
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a shuffling of its top executives yesterday, with the promotion of two longtime officials to the new position of executive vice president, and the retirement of the company's vice chairman, Paul J. Rizzo.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  Koreans in New York  There are, according to the Korean Grocers Association, about 1,000 Korean greengrocers in the city (and 1,000 Korean fish markets, 1,000 laundries, not more than 50 Korean grocery stores and about 45,000 Koreans).
This familiar and recent New York phenomenon is the subject of today's talk in the Asia Society's continuing series of Wednesday lectures, ''Discover Asia: Asian-Americans in New York City.


POPE, ON LATIN TRIP, ATTACKS PINOCHET REGIME
LEAD: Pope John Paul II bluntly labeled the Chilean Government of President Augusto Pinochet ''dictatorial'' today and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church must struggle to bring democracy to Chile.

Prime Rise Aborts Recovery
LEAD: The bond market was recovering some of Monday's sharp losses when it was shaken anew late yesterday after Citibank raised its base lending rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2 percent.
Chase Manhattan quickly followed suit.


IN PARAGUAY'S JUNGLE, NO LETUP IN BATTLE FOR SOULS
LEAD: About 30 newly converted Ayoreo Indians set off from a Protestant mission in northern Paraguay in late December to contact ''unreached'' members of their tribe whose tiny jungle settlement had been spotted from the air by a missionary pilot.

LEAD: Three Republican Senators who have been key backers of the Administration on Nicaragua have warned President Reagan that unless he makes a series of policy changes, they may no longer support his policies.

LEAD: Detectives, searching for a motive and clues in the slaying of a Parking Violations Bureau hearing officer, are focusing on about 900 cases handled by the officer in recent years, police officials said yesterday.

LEAD: The formal comments of high-level Reagan Administration officials on arms control matters are generally cleared by the White House before they are delivered.

Axing of Snowwoman Is Disorderly Conduct
LEAD: A woman who destroyed a bikini-clad snow sculpture with a hatchet because she found it sexually offensive must answer for her actions in court, the chief city prosecutor said today.


Yields 4% to 6.90% On Illinois Bonds
LEAD: Illinois yesterday offered $250 million of general obligation refunding bonds through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.


Israelis Divided About Reports on Soviet Jews
LEAD: Senior Israeli officials were divided today in their assessment of reports that Moscow would soon permit large-scale Soviet Jewish emigration directly to Israel and more freedom of religion for Soviet Jews.


RICE: THE PRIZE OF SICHUAN PROVINCE AND BREAKTHROUGH GIFT OF CALIFORNIA
LEAD: TO many Americans, rice is rice.
It comes in a box with short but intimidating directions.
When it's cooked, you eat the part that you didn't burn with some other kind of food that has some kind of taste.
The fact is, to many Americans, rice is boring.


ACADEMY AWARD CEREMONY ON ABC
LEAD: THE introduction of a trap door for handling long-winded winners was one of many improvements to be found on Monday night's 59th Academy Awards show.
Mindful, perhaps, that every year's eagerly anticipated Oscar telecast is also met with a modicum of dread, those who planned the presentation took the home audience's endurance problems into account.

3 Well-Known Towers in City Become Official Landmarks
LEAD: Three elaborate and fanciful towers that have graced Manhattan's skyline for more than 50 years became official landmarks yesterday with the designations of the former New York Central Building on Park Avenue and the San Remo on Central Park West.


JUSTICE DEPT. DISSENTS ON SPECIAL PROSECUTORS
LEAD: The Justice Department is opposing recent court orders that court-appointed special prosecutors are exempt from certain laws on conflict of interest that cover department employees.


Raytheon Contract
LEAD: The Raytheon Company has been awarded a $3.5 billion contract to provide the Army with 4,491 Patriot antiaircraft missiles over five years, the Pentagon said.
Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., ranked as the nation's seventh-biggest military contractor in 1986 with $4 billion in Defense Department business.


THE COWBOY, MAN AND MYTH ALIKE, IS ALIVE AND WELL IN NORTHERN TEXAS
LEAD: THE winter is breaking now along the Clear Fork of the Brazos River, a hardscrabble land of limestone ridges, draws and dry creek beds dotted with mesquite and prickly pear cactus.
On the vast ranches that drape over the brush-covered uplands, the annual roundup has begun.
These are hectic days, the time to bring in the new calves, vaccinate, dehorn, brand and castrate them.


Micro-victory in the Chip War
LEAD: When Samuel Johnson proclaimed that patriotism was the last refuge of a scoundrel, he failed to cast his net wide enough.
For patriotism is also the last refuge of more and more law-abiding American businessmen who can't cope effectively with foreign competitors.


Chez Stennis
LEAD: Consider, alas, the poor catfish, an estimable creature despite its humble origins.


Orders Up 4.3% at U.S. Factories
LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods, led by heavy demand for military equipment, shot up 4.3 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was the best showing in five months.


Privatized Reform in Albany?
LEAD: Albany's legislative leaders seem intent on embarrassing themselves by denying Governor Cuomo's $5 million budget request for a Commission on Government Integrity.
What do the legislators have to hide?
Their refusal to cooperate only whets public curiosity.


Audi to Offer $5,000 Discount
LEAD: Audi of America Inc., which has had bad publicity involving sudden acceleration problems in some of its earlier models, said Monday that it would give $5,000 discounts to Audi owners who buy new models.


SLAIN ADVISER THE SOLE AMERICAN AT SALVADOR BASE
LEAD: The Defense Department said today that the American military adviser killed in a guerrilla attack on a Salvadoran Army base this morning was the only American on the base.


The Editorial Notebook; Ways to Make Work, and Milk
LEAD: At the curb, a handful of airplane passengers look for transportation to downtown Bombay.
Across the way, in the airport parking lot, a hundred or so taxi drivers take the morning sun.
A naive traveler attempts to hail one but is studiously ignored.
What's the secret?


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: I WAS fascinated to read recently how Cornish hens were popularized in this country.
In the 1950's, Victor Borge, the pianist and comedian, raised the birds on a farm he owned in Connecticut and sold them dressed and ready for the oven.
They are a cross between an American fowl, the Plymouth Rock hen, and a Cornish or Bantam rooster or small gamecock.


Humanism Doesn't Mean Not to Teach Religion
LEAD: To the Editor:


C.W. MURCHISON JR. DIES IN TEXAS AT 63
LEAD: Clint W. Murchison Jr., the scion of a Texas wildcat oil family who created the Dallas Cowboys football team, died Monday night.
He was 63 years old.
Mr.
Murchison, who had been debilitated by a neurological disorder, was admitted to Gaston Episcopal Hospital here about two weeks ago, said Sandy McCoy, an associate administrator of the hospital.


RENEE GILL
LEAD: Renee Gill, a former remedial reading teacher, died Monday at her home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness.
She was 67 years old.

Offices Are Bombed in Lima
LEAD: Guerrillas bombed the headquarters of Peru's ruling party and eight party offices in Lima today, police officials said.
Dynamite thrown from a speeding car at dawn blew out windows and wrecked furniture in the headquarters of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance.
Flying glass wounded a guard.

Kidnappers Renew Offer to Swap Hostages for Jailed Arabs
LEAD: Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah of the pro-Iranian Party of God meeting yesterday with the wives of kidnapped American professors from Beirut University College.
He said that his efforts to negotiate the release of the hostages had failed.
A few hours later, the group holding the hostages, Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, said that the health of one of the hostages, Alann Steen, was ''deteriorating day by day.


FOOD INDUSTRY EYES IRRADIATION WARILY
LEAD: MORE than 500 pounds of ripe, juicy papayas were sneaked into Los Angeles last week and unobtrusively delivered to supermarkets.
The papayas had been treated with radiation to kill fruit flies, and while that is legal it is also controversial.
The growers were trying to get the fruit to shoppers without alerting the National Coalition to Stop Food

Louis Blues in a battle of playoff-bound teams.


Infant Mortality Is Part of the 'Star Wars' Price
LEAD: To the Editor:


Oscars Win, 2-1
LEAD: ABC's telecast of the Academy Awards show drew nearly twice the audience as the N.C.A.A. basketball championship on CBS Monday night, according to the ratings released yesterday.
In 13 markets in the Nielsen survey, the live telecast from Hollywood got an overall 33.8 rating and a 53 share compared with a 19.1 and a 27 share for the game.


Golf Coach to Retire
LEAD: He has won more National Collegiate Athletic Association championships than any other coach, and now, after 16 titles, Dave Williams has decided to retire.
The 68-year-old Williams announced he would leave the University of Houston on Aug. 1 after 36 years as the golf coach.
When he began at Houston in 1952, the Cougars had never won a tournament.


DOW RAISES BUT RATES POSE PERIL
LEAD: The stock market's session was over yesterday when Citibank surprised the financial community by raising its prime interest rate to 7 3/4 percent, and equity prices were thus able to recover from Monday's sharp selloff.


ECHOES OF NEW MOSCOW REACH SIBERIA, FAINTLY
LEAD: Tatyana M. Malinovskaya is the party boss in a county where reindeer outnumber people, 200,000 to 26,000.
Her office in this gold-mining town in northeastern Siberia, opposite Alaska, is closer to Washington than to Moscow.

AIDS Funds Gain in House
LEAD: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to appropriate $20 million in foreign aid money for the 1988 fiscal year to help fight the spread of AIDS in developing countries.
The action stipulates that the money be used for treatment, research and control of acquired immune deficiency symdrome.

LEAD: EVER since he was a youngster growing up in this North Texas town of 2,000, the son of a county road worker and sometime cattle hauler, Billy Gilbreath wanted to be a cowboy.
At the age of 20, on the Lambshead Ranch, he is a new recruit to an old trade.

Arch A. Moore Jr. through his two young children.


No Impropriety in Frankfurter Conversations
LEAD: To the Editor:


CHIP PANEL'S LEADER DEFENDS SANCTIONS
LEAD: As chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association's public policy committee, George Scalise has been instrumental in persuading Washington to impose trade sanctions against the Japanese.
But Mr.
Scalise, who is also senior vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Sunnyvale, Calif., chip maker, said he views the sanctions as ''incentives'' for the Japanese to comply with the trade agreement signed last July 31, not as a punitive measure.


Second Murder Charge For Philadelphia Man
LEAD: Gary Heidnik, the man charged with murder after the police found body parts in his refrigerator and women chained in his basement, was charged today with a second count of murder.


CHEVY'S CRUCIAL NEW MODELS
LEAD: A shark's fin glides through dark blue water and then a car emerges from the deep.
The clear message of the television commercial is that the 1988 Chevrolet Beretta is as sleek and aggressive as a shark - and, even more important, a break from the General Motors Corporation's recent run of undistinguished lookalike cars.


Racism: From Closet to Quad
LEAD: Crude, overt racial bigotry has again come out of campus closets and onto the quads.
Reports of public slurs, cross-burnings, even outright physical conflict now ring routinely from schools throughout the country, including some of the most prestigious.
A society's universities ought to be among its chief civilizing influences.


SOME NEW YORK STATE WINES SHINE
LEAD: FOUR New York State chardonnays and three seyval blancs shone last week at a tasting sponsored by the New York Wine and Grape Foundation.
All were 1985's, and three of the chardonnays came from Long Island.


Happy April Fool's Day
LEAD: The best bet here on April Fool's Day is that the winner of the next Presidential election will be a man whose first or second name begins with the letter B. The reason for putting your money on the buzzing B's is that there are so many of them now swarming around the greasy pole.


Customs Held Drexel Official
LEAD: Robert Kramer, a vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert, was detained last Friday by United States Customs agents as he was leaving the Bahamas for failing to declare $88,000 in cash and securities in his possession, Drexel officials confirmed yesterday.

REBELS KILL 43 SALVADOR TROOPS AND U.S. ADVISER
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas severely damaged a key army base here this morning, killing 43 Salvadoran soldiers and a United States military adviser, the first to die in combat in El Salvador.

LEAD: The First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., which suffered large losses on energy and real estate loans in 1986, said it expected operating losses to continue ''for the foreseeable future.'' Use Port Authority Toll Hikes for Mass Transit, Not Airports
LEAD: To the Editor:


An Important Idea For Today, April 2
LEAD: What this nation needs is an Official Fool. ''We have plenty,'' you say. ''The Federal Government's full of them.''


BRITISH CALEDONIAN LOSS
LEAD: British Caledonian announced today that it lost $:19.3 million, equivalent to $30 million, in the year ended last October, and atributed it mainly to American fears of terrorist attacks in Europe.
In the year before, the airline had a pretax profit of $:21.7 million.


DOLLAR SHOWS STRENGTH AFTER PRIME RATES RISES
LEAD: The dollar staged a rally against most major currencies after two major American banks yesterday announced increases in their prime lending rates for the first time since 1984.


NIEKRO NAILS DOWN YANK STARTING ROLE
LEAD: The day was going to be relatively quiet, but it turned into a morning full of revelations after Rick Rhoden's scheduled appearance in a minor-league game was called off following an overnight storm.


REPORT SAYS FUNDS FOR MEDICARE PLAN WILL LAST TILL 2002
LEAD: The Social Security fund that pays for Medicare hospital benefits improved over the past year but still faces bankruptcy shortly after the turn of the century, the fund's trustees said today.

On the Road With Senator Dole, the Campaigner
LEAD: Minutes after a private jet carrying Senator Bob Dole left Washington's National Airport for a series of Presidential campaign appearances in New York, the flight attendant told the Senate Republican leader that Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, was on the telephone.
Mr.
Dole thought for a moment, then said he would return the call on a more secure phone line once the plane landed.


Socialists Meet Amid Shifts in Italian Alliance
LEAD: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi opened a weeklong convention of his Socialist Party here today, paving the way for the possible formation of a new government in Italy.

Prices Paid To Farmers Unchanged
LEAD: Prices farmers got for raw products in March, on the average, were unchanged from a revised February index and also a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.


New Job
LEAD: Less than a month after the Tower commission wrapped up its investigation of the Iran-contra affair with a long report, at least one key staff member of President Reagan's blue-ribbon panel is heading for a job at the White House.


TRUMP REPORTS LARGE PROFIT FROM WOLLMAN RINK
LEAD: New Yorkers were grateful when Donald J. Trump finished ahead of schedule and under budget in renovating the Wollman Memorial Rink, where the city had spent six years and $12 million trying to produce ice.


HOSPITAL MAY LOSE FUNDS OVER TRANSFERS OF POOR
LEAD: The Federal Government has notified a California hospital that it plans to end Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement there because of the transfer of uninsured poor patients from its emergency ward to other hospitals.


ALL MOSCOW MARINES SAID TO FACE POLYGRAPH TEST
LEAD: The 28 Marine guards at the American Embassy here have been told that they will be asked to take polygraph tests after their return to the United States, according an American close to the contingent.


Fiero Slips After a Fast Sales Start
LEAD: If advance dealer orders are any indication, Chevrolet's new Corsica and Beretta will be hot sellers.
But even if those initial orders do translate into consumer purchases, the General Motors Corporation knows only too well that a fast start does not guarantee big sales over the long haul.


California Gets New Rape Bill
LEAD: A bill that would direct colleges to actively investigate rapes on campus even if the victims do not file criminal charges has been introduced in the State Legislature.

LEAD: The stock and bond markets began to recover yesterday from the dollar's steep drop against the yen.

HOUSING SEGREGATION: NEW TWISTS AND OLD RESULTS
LEAD: Predominantly segregated housing patterns that seemed to be breaking up in the 1960's and early 1970's have been quietly reasserting themselves in New York City and its suburbs, according to a wide range of experts and studies.


SOVIET PROPOSES ANTITERROR EFFORT TO WEST
LEAD: The Soviet Union has asked several Western governments to cooperate with it in fighting international terrorism and has suggested that they negotiate extradition treaties providing for the return of terrorist suspects, according to French and other diplomats.


A Memory Dishonored
LEAD: To the Editor:


WEBSTER TO BE QUESTIONED ABOUT MEESE'S INQUIRY
LEAD: The chairman and vice chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today they planned to raise detailed questions about Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's handling of the Iran-contra affair at hearings next month on the nomination of William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence.


COURT BACKS WIDE SEARCHES BY PUBLIC EMPLOYERS
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that public employers have ''wide latitude'' to search employees' offices, desks and files without warrants or probable cause to believe that the search will uncover evidence of wrongdoing.


SENATE, DEFYING PRESIDENT, PASSES HOUSING BILL, 71-27
LEAD: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a housing bill costing up to $38.3 billion that is strongly opposed by the Reagan Administration as too expensive.


DELTA-WESTERN MERGER BLOCKED
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco blocked the $860 million merger of Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines last night, just hours before it was to go into effect.
The court said the merger would be prohibited until an arbitrator settles a dispute over union representation.


Economic Scene; U.S.: 'Borrower Of Last Resort'
LEAD: IN their highly charged state of nervousness, financial markets initially reacted to the United States announcement that it would impose punitive tariffs, amounting to $300 million, against Japan for its failure to comply with a semiconductor agreement as though the end of civilization as we have known it might be approaching.


Thrift Unit Official Sentenced
LEAD: A third former executive of the Home State Savings Bank was sentenced today for his part in the thrift institution's 1985 collapse.


A $1.6 Billion Offering Is Set by Puerto Rico
LEAD: Puerto Rico is offering $1.6 billion of new bonds in the second-largest financing ever for the municipal market, and the largest ever backed by the full faith and credit of a local government.


McDonnell Douglas Warns Of Cracks in Some DC-10's
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Coporation has warned all airlines using DC-10's to check their horizontal stabilizers for cracks.


Rainmaking in the Aegean
LEAD: Real differences over sea boundaries and oil drilling rights no doubt carried Greece and Turkey to the edge of military conflict in the Aegean.
But the speed with which this storm erupted, and then evaporated, suggests it was artificially seeded by political rainmakers.
Certainly the spat has helped Greece's populist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou: he roused cheers on the right by denouncing Turkey, and on the left by threatening to close down an American supply depot.

ALEX L. HART
LEAD: Alex L. Hart, a transportation consultant who in the 1960's was executive director of the New York-New Jersey Transportation Agency, died March 11 in Aurora, Colo.
He was 73 years old and was a former resident of Centerport, L.I.


COMPUTERS IMPROVE THE FIT OF ARTIFICIAL JOINTS
LEAD: ADVANCES in computer-aided design and manufacturing are allowing superior custom-made bone or joint replacements, enabling many patients to live free of disfigurement or crippling disabilities.


A Gleeful Convention For Cable Television
LEAD: At the annual meeting of the Cable Advertising Bureau, which drew more than 1,000 interested parties to the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, most of the talk had to do with the positive changes that have resulted from the deregulation of the industry, the growing involvement of system operators in programming and the emergence of marketing as a strong force.


GAF OFFERS $46 A SHARE TO BUY BORG
LEAD: The GAF Corporation made a takeover bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation yesterday, offering $46 a share, or $3.17 billion.


Edwards's 'Blind Date' In Top Box-Office Spot
LEAD: ''Blind Date,'' a Blake Edwards comedy that stars Kim Basinger and Bruce Willis as her ill-fated date, took in $7.5 million in its first weekend to gain the No. 1 spot at the box office.


New Moody's Bond Index
LEAD: Moody's Investors Service yesterday introduced a new index of corporate bonds that it hopes will eventually become the basis for a new futures contract on the Commodity Exchange.


CUOMO SEEKS TOUGHER PENALTIES FOR RACIAL CRIMES
LEAD: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation today that would toughen the penalties for racially motivated acts of violence and would allow victims to sue their attackers for money.

JAZZ FESTIVAL LINEUP SET
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S annual summer jazz festival -formerly Newport-New York, then the Kool Jazz Festival, now the JVC Jazz Festival - will be back this year beginning June 19.


JAPAN PLANS TO DENY VISAS TO ALIENS WITH AIDS VIRUS
LEAD: The Japanese Government submitted legislation today that would deny visas to foreigners who are known to carry the virus that causes acquired immune defficiency syndrome and are considered ''likely to spread the virus to many people in Japan.''


RAIN, WIND AND A RECIPE FOR COPING IN NEW YORK
LEAD: On your mark - sneakers tied, galoshes pulled into place.


'A GOOD, CLEAN LIVING'
LEAD: THE son and grandson of North Texas cowboys, George Peacock was to be nothing else.
That's all he ever knew, breaking horses, roping calves and driving wagon teams even before he went to school.
He began as a wrangler, turning out at 4 A.M. to pen the horses for the other hands.
Today, at the age of 52, he is the foreman of the Nail Ranch, one of the region's most respected cowboys, punching cows by day and writing checks by night as ranch manager.


Homosexual Is Given Right to Visit Children
LEAD: A woman will allow her former husband, a homosexual, to have overnight visits with their two daughters, ending an 18-month legal battle that began when she demanded that he be tested for the AIDS virus, lawyers said today.


HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE TO OVERRIDE VETO ON HIGHWAY MEASURE
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today voted to override President Reagan's veto of the highway bill.
A yes vote was a vote to override the veto.
A no vote was a vote to sustain it.
Voting yes were 248 Democrats and 102 Republicans.
Voting no were one Democrat and 72 Republicans.

Richard J. Smith, a prominent hand surgeon, died Monday after a long illness.
He was 56 years old.

LEAD: The National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians and NBC, which employs most of that union's 2,500 members, were continuing negotiations last night in the face of a strike deadline of midnight P.S.T. (3 A.M. New York time).

In its first year, Alain Raye's new Paris restaurant, which bears his name, survived a fire in a refrigerator and a flooded basement.
Instead of packed tables and a waiting list, Mr.
Raye faced a nearly empty dining room every night.
And the Michelin guide removed the one star it had awarded him when he was at the stoves at Chez Uginet in Albertville, in southeastern

LEAD: To The Living Section:


Bridge: In New Duplicate Laws,An Old Query Is Banned
LEAD: The revised ''Laws of Duplicate Bridge,'' which come into force today in North America, will be a shock for some, particularly those who were social players before they became duplicate enthusiasts.

JERSEY G.O.P. LEADERS TO PROPOSE BILL REQUIRING AUTO-PREMIUM CUT
LEAD: Republican leaders in the Assembly said today that they would introduce legislation to require an average $90 cut in automobile insurance premiums as part of a bill intended to reduce the number of accident suits.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1987
LEAD: International A3-12  Rebels damaged a key army base in El Salvador, killing at least 43 Salvadoran soldiers and a U.S. military adviser.
It appeared to be the most important and successful rebel operation in recent years.
Page A1  The Pope labeled Chile a dictatorship and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church must struggle to bring democracy to the nation.


Henning Dismissed
LEAD: With only two games left in the regular season, Lorne Henning was dropped as coach of the Minnesota North Stars.
His replacement on an interim basis: Glen Sonmor, the team's director of personnel and a former North Star coach.
Going into last night's games, the North Stars were a point ahead of Toronto and tied with Chicago in a struggle for the last remaining playoff spots in the Norris Division.


CLOSE TEST SEEN IN SENATE TODAY
LEAD: The House of Representatives today easily overrode President Reagan's veto of the $87.9 billion highway bill, leaving the Senate as the battleground for a major test of Mr.
Reagan's power in the final 22 months of his Presidency.

KEVIN D. MURPHY
LEAD: Kevin D. Murphy, a partner of KMS Corporate Brokers, a Wall Street bond brokerage concern, died of a heart attack Friday at Bellevue Hospital Center.
He was 48 years old and lived in New York City and Newtown, Conn.

LEAD: Kenny Rice, sports director at WTVQ-TV in Lexington, Ky., after Austin Peay of Clarksville, Tenn., upset Illinois in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament: ''It's the biggest thing to happen in Clarksville since the Monkees took the last train there.''


SHOPPING CENTER IS PLANNED FOR BRONX
LEAD: When Irving Pergament started work a few years ago on the 184 houses he is now putting up in the Baychester section of the Bronx, a shopping center was not in the home builder's development plans.


Bank Machines Sought For 21 M.T.A. Stations
LEAD: Banks are being invited to install automatic teller machines at 21 commuter railroad stations in the metropolitan region as a convenience for riders and a source of income for the railroads.


DEVILS SET RECORD WITH 29TH VICTORY
LEAD: Two goals 15 seconds apart in the last period, including the third in the game for Perry Anderson, led the Devils to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.


WHO'S WHO IN THE FIGHT FOR BABY M
LEAD:  Baby M  Called Melissa by the Sterns, Sara by the Whiteheads... had her first birthday last Friday... described as happy, alert and resilient.
Mary Beth Whitehead  29 years old... dropped out of high school at 15... married at 16, had two children before she turned 19... signed a surrogate agreement with William Stern in February 1985...


CHIRAC IS ASSURED IN REAGAN TALKS
LEAD: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France met with President Reagan today and came away with the assurances he was seeking on nuclear weapons in Europe as well as a possible political boon for himself.


Along a Distant Arctic Border, Peace Reigns
LEAD: While four NATO nations conduct winter war games 300 miles to the west, peace and tranquillity prevail at this headquarters of the Norwegian border guards at the Soviet frontier.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about the sale of one of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings for $39.9 million misstated the circumstances of the artist's suicide.
Van Gogh died at Auvers-sur-Oise, France, two days after shooting himself near there and several weeks after leaving an asylum at St.-Remy.


PLAN ROOTED IN BROOKLYN
LEAD: Brooklyn's Brownsville section, which has been a synonym for urban decay, has produced an innovative effort to renew housing in the Nehemiah Plan.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave the incorrect network for the debut of ''Roxie'' tonight at 8 P.M.
The half-hour situation comedy will be shown on CBS.
Also, a cast change was announced after press time; Jack Riley, not Jerry Stiller, is featured.


U.S. AND FRANCE END RIFT ON AIDS
LEAD: President Reagan and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France ended a festering international scientific dispute today, announcing that researchers from the two countries would share credit for discovery of the AIDS virus.

FOOD NOTES
LEAD: More Spring Lamb Traditionally, consumers look for spring lamb for their Easter menus or for Passover around this time.
The official season for spring lamb, however, is considerably longer.
The period in which these lambs must be slaughtered to qualify for the Federal designation ''genuine spring lamb'' extends from March 1 through early


STUDENTS AT BLACK COLLEGES HIT HARD BY GRANT CUTS
LEAD: Students at the nation's 57 historically black private colleges are bearing the brunt of Federal grant cutbacks and are falling deeply into debt to finance their educations, according to a new study.


THIRD MARINE GUARD FROM U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW ARRESTED
LEAD: The Marine Corps has arrested a third enlisted man who served as a guard at the American Embassy in Moscow on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said today.


KNIGHT PRAISES HIS CHAMPIONS
LEAD: Nearly half an hour after Indiana had defeated Syracuse Monday night, 74-73, Coach Bobby Knight offered a perspective on the significance of winning his third national championship.


FOR APRIL SHOWERS, A BIT OF HISTORY
LEAD: 1.Operas of Old  April showers are the perfect reason to cover yourself with glory - the glory of New York's cultural past.
These elegant umbrellas in navy and gold is decorated with copies of paintings of the old Met by E. Lee Spruyt, who drew the historic opera house in 1966 before it was torn down.


ALBANY INQUIRY EXPANDING TO CAMPAIGN REPORTS
LEAD: In an apparent violation of election law, some candidates for the State Legislature did not report that some campaign workers were being paid for their services with state funds, according to a review of campaign documents and interviews with state election officials.

LEAD: In the marketplace it is rumored that Ronald A. Kovas, a director of the JWT Group, is marked for even greater greatness at the company.


HARRY G. HACKETT
LEAD: Harry G. Hackett, the first black man appointed a Federal bankruptcy judge, died here Saturday.
He was 64 years old.


Glass Company's Chief Tries Hand in Takeover
LEAD: Randall D. Hubbard has hauled ice, harvested wheat, taught school and salvaged ailing glass companies.
Now, as chairman and chief executive of AFG Industries and a partner of Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, Mr.
Hubbard is trying his hand as a takeover artist with a $2.2 billion bid for Gencorp


3 PREMIERES FOR NETWORK SITCOMS
LEAD: THIS week's headlines tell us that the number of homeless families wandering the nation's streets has reached record numbers - to mention just one current crisis - but television entertainment seems determined to assure us that everything will be all right as long as we remain adorably bubble-headed.


U.S. Retaliates on Latest Asian Export: The Flying Roach
LEAD: Imagine a New York City cockroach with chutzpah.
It has wings, a preference for bright lights and a sex drive so lusty it can produce 75 million offspring a year.
That's the Asian roach, Blatella asahinai, and it has been vacationing in Florida this winter since arriving on cargo ships from Asia.
It is expected to move north.


Commercial Credit Notes Noncallable
LEAD: The Commercial Credit Company, a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, is offering $150 million of 8 percent noncallable notes, due in 1992, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.


Oral Roberts Vigil Ends In New Plea for Funds
LEAD: The evangelist Oral Roberts, who had said God told him he would die unless he raised $8 million by the end of March, wound up a 10-day prayer vigil today with a final entreaty to followers to send money.

NOT JUST FOR VEGETARIANS
LEAD: IT has been a long time since the word ''vegetarian'' conjured images of barefoot cooks with flowing tresses and of brown rice with seaweed.
Vegetarianism has become so much a part of our culture that its definition has been expanded - erroneously - to include people who don't eat red meat but do eat fish and chicken.


Exxon to Buy Oil Company
LEAD: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $690 million for Australia's Delhi Petroleum Proprietary Ltd., giving it a 25 percent share of that country's largest onshore oil and gas production area.

Afghans Say Pakistan Shot Down an Airliner

Backer Buys Toronto Firm
LEAD: Eight-year-old Backer &amp; Spielvogel has made its first acquisition in a foreign land.
It has bought Straiton, Pearson, Martin &amp; Holman of Toronto, with which it shares two clients, Hyundai, the South Korean conglomerate and car maker, and Quaker Oats' Fisher-Price toys.


G.M. Receives Canada Loan
LEAD: In a move likely to stir opposition in the United States, General Motors of Canada Ltd. today received an interest-free loan of $220 million (Canadian) from the governments of Canada and Quebec in return for guaranteeing the continued operation of an auto plant.

It's a double bill of ''The Only Son'' (1936), the Japanese film master's first ''talkie'' (he didn't want to rush into sound without knowing how to use it), and ''I Lived, but .


ADMINISTRATION ATTACKS AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PLAN
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today renewed its attack on a local affirmative action plan involving the District of Columbia Fire Department in spite of a Supreme Court decision last week upholding the legality of such programs.


THEATER: 'BLITHE SPIRIT,' WITH BLYTHE DANNER
LEAD: IN Noel Coward's ''Blithe Spirit,'' a middle-aged novelist named Charles Condomine must contend with the outspoken ghost of his not so dear, departed wife.
The spirits who hover over the play's revival at the Neil Simon Theater are another story.
Watching this flat all-star ''Blithe Spirit,'' one can only think back to Broadway's last misbegotten all-star assault on the same playwright - the Elizabeth Taylor-Richard Burton ''Private Lives'' of 1983.


LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.7% IN FEBRUARY
LEAD: The Government's main gauge of future economic activity rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, but many economists said it was overstating economic strength.
The long-awaited rebound in growth, they insisted, will be modest at best.

LEAD: *
Burlington Industries has filed with the S.E.C. for $100 million of sinking-fund debentures, due in 2017, and $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2012.


Keeping a Name
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Testaverde Pact Near
LEAD: Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy winner, is expected within a week to sign a contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that would make him the National Football League's third-highest-paid player, according to The Associated Press.
Bob Woolf, Testaverde's attorney, said, ''I'm very optimistic of making an agreement, although we don't have one yet.


JAPAN WEIGHING STEPS TO EASE TRADE DISPUTE
LEAD: The Japanese Government has begun to consider a broad range of measures to defuse the intensifying trade crisis with the United States.


AM RADIO IS HOPING FULL FIDELITY LURES LISTENERS
LEAD: IN a demonstration of cooperation seldom witnessed in the highly competitive worlds of broadcasting and electronics, station owners and major electronics companies are banding together to save AM radio.


Emery Air Freight Bids for Purolator
LEAD: The Purolator Courier Corporation, the package delivery company that is the subject of a $35-a-share buyout offer, received a higher takeover bid of $40 a share last night from the Emery Air Freight Corporation.


VAN GOGH PRICE SHAKES ART WORLD
LEAD: The auction price of one of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings paid Monday at Christie's in London -$39.9 million, roughly four times the previous record for a work of art -brought reactions of shock and bafflement yesterday among museum officials, dealers and other art professionals.


Advertising; British Buy Rogers &amp; Cowan
LEAD: ROGERS &amp; COWAN, a major American public relations firm that specializes in show business promotions, has been acquired by Shandwick P.L.C., Britain's largest public relations operation, which bought two other American companies in December.


SHUFFLING THE SMITHSONIAN PORTFOLIO
LEAD: More than a year and a half ago, the governing board of the Smithsonian Institution divided sharply over whether to continue owning stock in companies that do business in South Africa.
Some members argued that a body as closely identified with the American nation as the Smithsonian ought to sell such stocks so as to set an example of opposition to racist policies.


CBS'S TISCH ADDRESSES BROADCASTERS
LEAD: Laurence A. Tisch, the president of CBS, today questioned the constitutionality of forthcoming Congressional hearings on the operations of the news departments of the three major networks.


Pressure on Shell
LEAD: A group of American shareholders of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group began a campaign to force the oil company to hold a special meeting to consider pulling out of South Africa.
The group holds less than 2 percent of the company's shares.
Royal Dutch said in a statement that a special meeting could be held under Dutch law only if 10 percent of its shareholders agreed.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about New York Stock Exchange specialists inaccurately described the profitability of the specialist that handles Eastman Kodak.
A spokesman for the firm, RPM Securities, said that it fulfilled all its specialist responsibilities on Monday, when Kodak and the overall market declined sharply, and that it lost money trading in


CONTRACT UPHELD; SURROGACY IS LEGAL
LEAD: A judge awarded custody of Baby M today to her father, William Stern, and stripped the child's biological mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, of all parental rights.


CHAD SAID TO WIN VAST LIBYAN BOOTY
LEAD: Western diplomats said today that military equipment abandoned by Libyan forces retreating from northern Chad was believed to be worth half a billion dollars.

Exchange to Add Hours
LEAD: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said it planned to extend its trading hours to evening sessions to correspond with prime trading hours in the Far East.
The change, expected to begin this summer, must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.


CONTRACT UPHELD; THE ABSENCE OF GUIDELINES
LEAD: The ruling yesterday in the Baby M case settled the specific question of who is granted custody of the child, but other courts and state legislatures will continue to face the larger question of whether surrogate-motherhood agreements are legal.


BOARDER BABIES FIND COMFORT IN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS' ARMS
LEAD: THREE HUNDRED abandoned ''boarder babies'' who have been living in the hospitals where they were born, some for months, while awaiting foster care may be placed by November, according to a plan announced by the city last week.
But they still wait, although not without special attention: a program giving the elderly a role in their care has recently begun.


Words You Can't Learn in Our Schools
LEAD: To the Editor:


CAJUN AND CREOLE: FRENCH
LEAD: COUNTLESS words have been written by now about the joys of Creole and Cajun cooking.
The popularity of those foods - from Cajun popcorn (deep-fried crawfish) to jambalaya and shrimp Creole - continues apace.
Blackened redfish has become an obsession for some; others consider it a plague.


Thrift Insurance Fund
LEAD: A House subcommittee voted today to pump $25 billion into the fund that insures savings and loan association deposits.
The House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions voted 23 to 20 for a proposal by Representative Thomas Carper, Democrat of Delaware, that would raise $10 billion from assessments on the industry and $15 billion from bonds sold in the capital markets.

Trial Begins for 242 in Italy In 10-Year Heroin Gang War
LEAD: Two hundred forty-two men went on trial today in connection with a 10-year gang war to control the heroin trade between northern Italy and Sicily in which 60 people were killed, officials said.
The trial is expected to last at least a year.


Panel Formed to Back Senate Bid by Dawkins
LEAD: A group of prominent New Jersey Republicans announced today that they had formed a committee to raise money for a possible campaign for the United States Senate by former Brigadier General Pete Dawkins.


Contras Cut Power
LEAD: Nicaraguan rebels destroyed two electrical towers in raids close to the country's border with Costa Rica, the Nicaraguan Energy Institute said today.
The attacks have cut off the supply of electricity to Nicaragua from Costa Rica, the institute said.
It did not provide details on the extent of blackouts caused by the attacks.


AIRLINES STRESS TEAMWORK IN COCKPIT
LEAD: On a recent United Airlines flight from Reno to San Francisco a bomb exploded in the luggage hold.


CHAMPION'S ART STAYS ELEMENTAL
LEAD: In the early 1980's, at a time when Marvelous Marvin Hagler was struggling for public recognition, he was invited to appear on CBS-TV's weekend sports anthology show.


BABY M CASE CHRONOLOGY
LEAD: Feb. 6, 1985 - Mary Beth Whitehead agrees to be artificially inseminated by William Stern.
Their pact stipulates that she will relinquish all rights to the child in return for $10,000.


METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: TOM ARMSTRONG is director of the Whitney Museum of American Art.
He and his wife, Bunty, are also weekend gardeners, currently involved in landscaping their country place.
The perfect addition to the front of their house, the Armstrongs decided, would be a pair of American beech trees.
They telephoned their nursery and were told that, yes, there were two American beeches available but one, unfortunately, had a ''serious problem.


SLEEPING ON THE JOB LEADS TO SHUTDOWN OF REACTOR
LEAD: The Peach Bottom nuclear plant in Pennsylvania was ordered shut down today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which said it found control room operators sleeping on duty.


COLD GRIPS SOUTH AND THE MIDWEST
LEAD: Farmers across the South burned tires and brush yesterday to protect blossoming peach trees and other crops as temperatures hit record lows all the way to the Gulf of Mexico.

LEAD: Construction spending, helped by a sharp jump in construction of office buildings and schools, rose 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was the first advance since last October.

LEAD: ''We used to be a sleeping giant - big in numbers but sleeping like a hibernating bear,'' said Cyril F. Brickfield, the 68-year-old executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons. ''But now the bear is awake.'' Indeed, the nonprofit colossus, with its 24 million members and $5 membership fee, has adopted an active new stance in a time of prodigious expansion.

Silver and Platinum Up As Gold Holds Steady
LEAD: Prices of silver and platinum futures rose yesterday as more banks raised their prime lending rates.
But gold did not benefit from the renewed investor interest in precious metals.
Gold closed unchanged, largely because the dollar was somewhat firmer and thus tended to dampen inflationary expectations.

Tampa Drug Test Challenge
LEAD: Water workers have sued the city, contending that surprise on-the-job drug tests violated their constitutional rights.
The suit was filed Monday in Federal District Court by eight employees of the Tampa Water Department on behalf of all city water workers.
It seeks an order declaring drug testing unconstitutional.

Boliden-Allis Deal
LEAD: Boliden A.B., the Swedish mining and metals group, said it would buy the mining machinery division of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation for 600 million kronor, or about $90 million.
The move is part of a restructuring announced by Allis-Chalmers March 4.
Allis-Chalmers, which is based in Milwaukee, said it did not expect any material gain or loss from the sale of the division, which employs 4,300.


Soviet Says Missions at U.N. Will Continue to Reduce Staff
LEAD: Valentin G. Karymov, a spokesman for the Soviet missions, said today that the missions would continue to cut their staffs to the maximum of 170 allowed by April 1988 under an American order.


MARTHA BIRMINGHAM
LEAD: Martha Birmingham, vice president and director of visual presentation for Lord &amp; Taylor, died of a stroke Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.
She was 62 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  Utah's Back in Town


New Ohio Bonds Total $120 Million
LEAD: The Ohio Public Facilities Commission is offering $120 million of higher education facilities revenue bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.


Infiltrators Called Key in Raid on Salvadoran Base
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas thoroughly infiltrated a major army base before destroying it Tuesday, according to two senior military analysts here.
They added that the American military adviser who was killed in the raid had probably been sought out by the rebels.


Aid Pledged for Mozambique
LEAD: United Nations members and voluntary agencies pledged $207 million in emergency aid for Mozambique at a conference in Geneva on Wednesday, officials said today.
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar began an appeal for more than $244 million in food and medical aid last month.
Mozambique officials say the country is continuing to suffer from starvation caused by a prolonged drought.


Greek Priests Protest Government Plan to Acquire Church Land
LEAD: Bishop Christodoulos of Dimitrias addressing a crowd of priests and lay supporters yesterday outside Parliament in Athens.
The crowd, estimated at 40,000, had gathered to protest a bill being debated in Parliament that would transfer 325,000 acres of church lands to the State. ''The church is a giant who has suddenly woken up and is demanding his rights,'' the Bishop told the crowd.

LEAD: Salvadoran rebels demolished a supposedly impregnable base Tuesday, killing scores of soldiers, including a U.S. adviser.
But the setback doesn't diminish the value or need for continued commitment to human rights and legitimate civilian rule in a country that has known little of either.

Funds to Go To Grumman
LEAD: A sum of $300 million earmarked for building the T-46A jet training planes will stay on Long Island for aircraft production by the Grumman Corporation, Representative Samuel S. Stratton said today.


Sharansky Warns the West
LEAD: Natan Sharansky said today that the West should refrain from making concessions to the Soviet Union without assurances that all Jews who want to leave will be able to emigrate.
He told 40 people who demonstrated in front of Parliament that 400,000 of the Soviet Union's 1.7 million Jews wanted to emigrate.


Share Offering From Allegis
LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, formerly UAL Inc., yesterday began offering about five million common shares in the domestic and overseas markets at a price of $56.50 a share through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.


PIANO: FU TS'ONG
LEAD: FOU TS'ONG, a Chinese pianist who has lived in London for many years, played one of his infrequent New York recitals at Alice Tully Hall Saturday afternoon.
We should hear Mr.
Fou more often; he is an artist who uses his considerable pianistic gifts in pursuit of musical goals and not for show.

Six G.M. Plants To Close for Week
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, fighting slumping car sales and loss of market share, will close six plants for a week, temporarily idling 21,600 workers, officials said.
The plants scheduled for closing April 6-13 are in Wentzville, Mo.; Pontiac, Flint and Hamtramck, Mich.; North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Oshawa, Ontario, a G.M.

Old-Timer Finishes
LEAD: A crowd cheered 81-year-old Norman Vaughan as he drove his dog team down a wet, bare street in Nome, Alaska, early yesterday to complete the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race six days behind the final official finishers.
Vaughan and his traveling companion, Carolyn Muegge of Marietta, Ga., competed unofficially after they were disqualified from the 1,157-mile race March 21 in Grayling for failing to reach Unalakleet within the required five days of the race leaders.


SALADS AND COOKING GREENS: NEW SEEDS FOR '87 PLANTINGS
LEAD: A CHILD of my time and place, born in Dallas at the height of the Great Depression, I spent my first 20 years in abysmal ignorance as regards leafy vegetables.
Lettuce meant one thing only: tight heads of iceberg lettuce, raised in California, bought at the grocery store and kept in a drawer of the refrigerator until put into a salad whose flavor owed everything to its dressing and nothing to the lettuce.

LEAD: Last week, while a judge in New Jersey weighed his decision in the Baby M case, Noel P. Keane received an anxious telephone call from an infertile woman awaiting the birth of a child by a surrogate mother.

RECITAL: BENITA VALENTA, SOPRANO
LEAD: BENITA VALENTE first broke into public awareness in the 1960's when she sang ''Der Hirt auf dem Felsen'' on a Marlboro Festival recording that is out of print but would still be worth any Schubert lover's hunting down.
Her voice was not big or extraordinarily colored but of such a spring-water purity that it perfectly matched the pastoral innocence of the music.

Atomic Post
LEAD: Another Administration appointment said to be imminent is that of Kenneth C. Rogers, a nuclear physicist, for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
He would replace James K. Asselstine, whose five-year term expires June 30.
Although Mr.
Asselstine is a Reagan appointee, as are the commission's other four members, he has been a consistent lone dissenter, often accusing his colleagues of bias in favor of the nuclear industry.

Stern Walters Is Sold To Managers by Bates
LEAD: The top management of Stern Walters/Earle Lundgin, Chicago, has bought the $30 million agency back from Ted Bates Worldwide, which acquired it in 1978.
Since last summer Bates has been a subsidiary of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi of London.
Terms of the buyback were not disclosed.


No Headline
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Canadiens 3, Whalers 2: Bob Gainey poked the puck through the legs of the Hartford goaltender, Mike Liut, with 1 minute 51 seconds to play last night to give Montreal the victory.
Montreal, playing at home, stalled the Whalers' clinching of the Adams Division title.
The Whalers, who lead the second-place Canadiens by 3 points, need only a victory or a tie in their final two games - or a Montreal loss or tie - to win their first regular-season championship.

BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 2, 1987
LEAD: Companies  Three major banks will reclassify loans to Brazil.
BankAmerica, J. P. Morgan and Manufacturers said they would account for the loans when interest payments are received, rather than on an accrual basis.
The actions came six weeks after Brazil stopped interest payments on the debt.
The move will cost BankAmerica $40 million in first-quarter net income, while Morgan will lose $20 million and Manufacturers $18 million.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.We don't like the color of the newly renovated cabinets and counter tops in the kitchen and bath of our co-op.
Since they are new, it is senseless to replace them.
Can we paint them another color?
A.You can paint them with any good quality alkyd enamel, but once painted they will have to be repainted regularly.

LEAD: The dollar rose yesterday as foreign exchange markets continued to react favorably to the prime rate increase by major American banks.

LEAD: The Juilliard Orchestra will give four concerts in China during a six-city tour of the Far East in June, the Juilliard School's president, Joseph W. Polisi, has announced.
It will be the first time a conservatory orchestra from the United States has played in China.

RECITAL: GARY WOLF
LEAD: GARY WOLF, who played a program of works by Beethoven, Franck, Barber, Brahms and Samuel Adler at Weill Recital Hall Monday night, is a sensitive and musical pianist.
He planned his program intelligently (muffling the notoriously resonant acoustics of the hall, for example, by pushing the piano into a far corner of the stage) and, for the most part, proved a careful executant as well.

IT'S IN THE CARDS: A TOPPS OFFERING
LEAD: As any owner of a 1951 baseball card featuring Mickey Mantle can attest, it pays to be a collector more than a fan.
While the Yankee legend long ago hung up his spikes, the Topps Company card of the slugger still packs a wallop: It is now worth $1,000 and up.

POWER BEFORE CONGRESS
LEAD: THE membership of the American Association of Retired Persons is 40 percent Republican, 40 percent Democrat and 20 percent independent, the organization says.
To some critics, the diversity prevents the group from engaging in aggressive advocacy.

LEAD: President Reagan today urged schoolchildren to abstain from sexual relations as the best method to avoid contracting AIDS.

CPC, Ajinomoto In Asian Venture
LEAD: CPC International Inc., the large food concern that has been restructuring since it became a takeover target, said it had agreed to sell interests in several Asian grocery businesses.
The interests - in Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand - will be sold for $340 million to the Ajinomoto Company, a large Japanese food enterprise.

LEAD: The Interfirst Corporation has disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission and a Federal grand jury are investigating $84 million in loans made to, or guaranteed by, a former director of the company's Dallas bank.

LEAD: The United States has agreed to consultations with Japan in a dispute over semiconductor chips but is unlikely to cancel sanctions due to take effect in about two weeks, American trade officials said today.


ON WALL ST. IT WAS MOSTLY UP
LEAD: In a market that has hurtled many stocks to breathtaking new heights, there were some notable losers.
A company that says it was the victim of industrial sabotage, one that dismissed more than a third of its directors to save money and a start-up company marketing a guilt-free, low-calorie dessert called the ''trufflet'' were among the stocks that fared the worst in the first quarter of 1987.

LEAD: Families with incomes significantly higher than originally announced will be eligible for apartments under the first phase of the Koch administration's 10-year plan to renovate abandoned, city-owned housing.

Gooden's Troubles
LEAD: Dec. 27, 1985 - In an incident that is not revealed until a year later, sheriff's deputies in Tampa, Fla., acting on what they described as a tip from a confidential informant that Gooden is carrying ''a large quantity of cocaine and drugs,'' trails his car for six hours and then stops him.
After he agrees to allow the deputies to search his car, with the assistance of drug-sniffing dogs, they report finding $4,000 in cash, a holstered pistol, several empty and half-empty beer cans and some baking soda - but no drugs.


Corrections
LEAD: A table in Business Day last Friday with an article about the Standard Oil Company misstated its total assets.


NEW GUIDLINES ON GIVING TESTS IN MEDICAL CARE
LEAD: Blue Cross and Blue Shield and the American College of Physicians are issuing new guidelines today for the appropriate use of medical tests.
They say the guidelines will reduce spending on medical care by billions of dollars.


Revlon Tender Bid By Perelman Group
LEAD: The dominant stockholder of Revlon Group Inc. began a bid yesterday to acquire the rest of the large cosmetics concern in an acquisition valued at about $721.5 million.

LEAD: Tomas Jonsson, the Islander defenseman who suffered a multiple fracture of the jaw in a car accident in Detroit Jan. 22, received medical clearance to rejoin the team yesterday.

LEAD: Japanese currency dealers said today that the Bank of Japan spent more than $6 billion worth of yen in March trying to prop up the dollar, an effort they called generally ineffective.

A 'Woman's Answer'
LEAD: To The Home Section:


New Chief Named By Anac and Revco
LEAD: Revco D.S.
Inc. and its parent, the Anac Holding Corporation, which operate 2,000 drugstores, yesterday named William B. Edwards, 46 years old, as chief executive of both companies.


Taiwan to Reduce Debt
LEAD: Taiwan, with $53 billion in foreign-exchange reserves, will reduce its foreign debt by about $1 billion this year, to $2.4 billion, Finance Minister Robert Chien said today.
He told Parliament the country's debt, excluding private debt, stood at $3.41 billion at the end of last year, down from $4.77 billion in 1985.

Ex-Traffic Judge Took Bribes to Fix Tickets
LEAD: A former administrative judge in the Queens traffic court has testified that he took about $1,000 in bribes to fix at least 20 traffic tickets for motorists in a scheme that also involved police officers and an unlicensed private investigator, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the chances of a reinjury to Ray Leonard's eye appeared with a section misplaced.
The first 11 lines of the continuation should have been printed at the bottom of the column in which they appeared.

Packwood returned the call immediately.


ARCHITECTURE: THE NEW MUSSEE D'ORSAY IN PARIS
LEAD: Old buildings in Paris never die -they are converted into museums.
From the Louvre, which began as a royal palace, to the grand town house that became the Picasso Museum, making a museum is the way Paris has traditionally given new life to great buildings that have outlived their original usefulness.

LEAD: THERE is a school of interior design that advocates the bold signature: immediately identifiable rooms by a designer who impresses a style on the client.

Bethlehem Prices
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had raised the base prices of its carbon, high-strength and low-alloy plate steel by $25 a ton, or about 6.5 percent, effective July 1.
The company said its composite prices for alloy plates would also increase by $25 a ton.
The company does not publish its prices for those products.


EVIDENCE FOUND LINKING JEWISH DEFENSE LEAGUE TO TERRORISM
LEAD: A search yesterday of the East Meadow, L.I., home of a member of the Jewish Defense League uncovered evidence that Federal authorities said linked the group to ''recent bombings and other terrorist acts,'' including two incidents at Lincoln Center last year while Soviet entertainers were performing.


Now Mets Know About Gooden
LEAD: For nearly a year, the Mets had wondered about Dwight Gooden, wondered why he wasn't quite the same Doctor K who at age 20 had dazzled baseball with a 24-4 record, a 1.53 earned-run average and 268 strikeouts two seasons ago.
Ever since he was shelled early in spring training, the Mets had wondered about his stride and his motion, even about his grip on the ball.

NONPROFIT HOSPITALS ASSAILED
LEAD: As Humana, the Hospital Corporation of America and other private companies have taken over hundreds of the nation's hospitals, doctors and public policy experts have worried about the impact on the health care system.
The pressure to earn money for shareholders, they have feared, would lead to less care for the indigent, less research and less commitment to high-quality health care.

LEAD: To The Home Section:


Cardinals Get Pena
LEAD: The St.
Louis Cardinals added the considerable talents of Tony Pena, the four-time all-star catcher, to their lineup yesterday in a trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
The Cardinals had to give up two first-string players, Andy Van Slyke and Mike LaValliere, as well as a minor leaguer.
Pena, 29 years old, batted .288 with 10 home runs and 52 runs batted in last season.

Metro Matters; New York City On $13 a Day: A Welfare Tale
LEAD: There are no curtains on the windows of Barbara Jiggett's 20th-floor apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens.
There are no lights in the bedroom shared by her 7- and 8-year-old daughters and only one in the living room where Ms.
Jiggett sleeps (her 4-year-old son has the other bedroom).
She has a television set and a terrace but no phone and only three kitchen chairs, which makes it difficult to join her three children at the table for meals.

Penney Stake in Beeba's
LEAD: The J.C.
Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire a 20 percent equity interest in Beeba's Creations Inc. for $18.7 million.
Penney said the agreement to acquire one million shares also called for Beeba's, a San Diego-based supplier of sportswear, to work with Penney to create junior specialty shops in about 100 Penney stores in early 1988.

LEG INJURIES LINKED TO HARDER SURFACES
LEAD: Tennis traditionalists may be disappointed as indoor carpets and outdoor cement become increasingly popular surfaces, replacing grass and red clay.
But the impact of these synthetic courts on the sport go beyond esthetics and tradition.
There are indications that they are responsible for an increasing number of leg injuries, which could deprive tournaments of some of the bigger names in tennis for weeks and months at a time.

FATHER AND SONS: A MOVIE DYNASTY
LEAD: KIRK DOUGLAS isn't at all sure he likes the idea of a tribute. ''Tributes make it sound like the end of the line, and you know how I feel about the end of the line,'' he complained, shifting restlessly in his chair as if it were a straitjacket he wanted to burst out of and looking more like the undefeated wrestling champion he used to be than the septuagenarian he is now.

S.E.C. Review Of 'Greenmail'
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission will once again consider whether to recommend legislation to eliminate the practice known as ''greenmail,'' according to Commissioner Charles C. Cox.
Greenmail is the repurchase of shares, at a premium, from unwanted suitors, in order to head off hostile takeovers.


Peter Serkin
LEAD: The pianist Peter Serkin will play his debut concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8.
The program will include works by Bach, Beethoven, Toru Takemitsu, Olivier Messiaen and Stefan Wolpe.
Tickets are $14 to $22.50.
Information: 247-7800.


ART: WORKS BY GOURFAIN AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
LEAD: THERE is much that is admirable about Peter Gourfain's exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.
It is called ''Roundabout and Other Works,'' and it consists of 56 paintings, works on paper, ceramic pots and reliefs.
The ambition is epic.
Mr.
Gourfain wants to include everything, inspire justice and transformation and compose a narrative on nothing less than the human condition.

LEAD: Four days after Sandy Lyle of Surrey, England, won the $1 million Tournament Players Championship on the men's PGA Tour, another young golfer from Surrey, Laura Davies, became the surprise first-round leader in the $500,000 L.P.G.A.
Nabisco Dinah Shore event.
Davies, a 23-year-old, 5-foot-10-inch player who hits as long a ball as anyone on the L.P.G.A.

LEAD: Denny Crum, the coach of the United States Pan American Games basketball team, has chosen Jud Heathcote of Michigan State and his own assistant coach at Louisville, Jerry Jones, as assistant coaches of this year's squad.
Crum also said that 48 players would be invited for tryouts for the team May 14-18 at Colorado Springs from which 12 players and 3 alternates will be chosen.

The NBC program examimes biomedical advances, private adoptions and the moral and legal problems of surrogate motherhood.
It is a thoughtful piece of work.

LEAD: New York Mets fans won't feel much like cheering the departure of Dwight Gooden for drug rehabilitation - it's the latest in a series of setbacks that cast doubt on the team's chance to retain the world championship.
But as the move reflects baseball's determination to discipline drug-abusing players, it deserves applause.


A FUND-RAISER UNITES THE LITERATI AND THE GLITTERATI
LEAD: New York's old guard joined forces with the new on Wednesday night, and for $750 a ticket the oldeau and the nouveau got the chance to rub elegant elbows with the city's spiffed-up literary world.
The result, at the Metropolitan Club, was a jam-packed, celebrity-studded event at which even the most blase eyes opened wide in amazement.


HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASSAIL HIGHER PHONE CHARGES
LEAD: House Democrats today assailed a Federal Communications Commission board proposal for a $1.50 increase in monthly telephone charges for households and small businesses, signaling a possible reduction.


GOODEN PROVIDED NO CLUES TO TEAM
LEAD: Dwight Gooden flew to New York today and entered a drug rehabilitation clinic, where his use of cocaine will be measured and treated.
But, from the front office to the recesses of the Mets' locker room, his employers and teammates insisted that they had neither known nor suspected that he had ever used drugs.

LEAD: Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator who has had a running dispute with CBS management over cutbacks and a writers' strike at CBS News, said last night that he would quit CBS if the strike is not soon resolved.

LEAD: The Devils are planning to move heir top minor league affiliate from Portland, Me., to Utica, N.Y., John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said yesterday.

LEAD: Governor Kean said today that he found the issues surrounding surrogate parenthood ''deeply, deeply disturbing'' and that he wanted the Legislature to take a hard look at the practice.

France Ousts 3 Soviet Diplomats It Calls Spies
LEAD: France expelled three Soviet diplomats today, after the disclosure that six people arrested here two weeks ago on charges of spying to obtain European space secrets were supervised by members of the Soviet Embassy.

LEAD: The General Public Utilities Corporation declared a dividend yesterday for the first time since 1979, when it sustained severe financial difficulties following the accident at its Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

LEAD: The last round of a Swiss Team Championship almost invariably produces tension.
Several teams are likely to have a chance of victory, and the players know it is vital to bid thoughtfully and concentrate in the play.


HART SEEKING PEACE WITH HIS PAST
LEAD: Gary Hart came home and, for a moment, he did not live up to his reputation.
He nearly cried.
Hours after he placed flowers at his parents' grave, Mr.
Hart, known for his cool intellectualism, tried to tell an audience at Ottawa University here about his father Carl and his mother Nina.

LEAD: The two-day struggle to override President Reagan's veto of the highway bill ended today as a bright victory for Democrats and a major defeat for Mr.
Reagan and his party.
But for Senator Terry Sanford, the freshman Democrat from North Carolina, it was first and foremost an education.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines pilots in uniform picketed the carrier's major terminals today to dramatize their charges that Eastern's new cost-cutting work policies could create unsafe flying conditions.


FILM: 'CLUB LIFE'
LEAD: ''CLUB LIFE'' may well be the only film ever to set a funeral scene inside a disco, with mourners lined up along the railings, and the coffin and floral arrangements set up on the lighted dance floor.
So it's original, anyhow.
It also includes a gangland murder shot in a hall of mirrors, and a love scene shot on a transparent waterbed filled with fish.


Fiddling as Economic Problems Burn
LEAD: The dollar skidded again this week, sending stocks and bonds into a brief but worrisome nosedive.
Talk persists of a trans-Pacific ''trade war'' over microchips and broken promises.
Now, unexpectedly, banks have raised their prime loan rates.
All a little unnerving.
The events showed, once again, the calamities that could lie ahead unless Washington and Tokyo stop tinkering and testing each other and address the underlying problems.

LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a memorial service for Andy Warhol misidentified Claes Oldenburg's wife.


2 Shareholders Sue Home Shopping
LEAD: Home Shopping Network Inc., the largest television shopping company, has been sued by two shareholders in Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla.
The suit accuses the company of making false and misleading statements in public filings.
The shareholders, Burton Rosenfeld and Victor P. Ganderson, are seeking class-action status.


TWO RIKERS INMATES ARE WOUNDED IN JAIL SHOOTING
LEAD: Two Rikers Island inmates were shot and slightly wounded Wednesday night, and the authorities have not determined who used the .25-caliber automatic handgun found nearby.

ANTIQUARIAN TREASURES FOR THE BIBLIOMANIAC
LEAD: BIBLIOMANIA is a mental and emotional disorder that is chronic, progressive, incurable and entirely benign.
Those suffering from this delightful affliction, which may or may not cost a bundle to treat, are urged to seek emergency relief at the New York Antiquarian Book Fair.
It opened last night and the rare-book dealers on duty will administer first aid to all bibliomaniacs through tomorrow.

LEAD: As April arrives, so does the urge to clean up the bicycle for another season of riding.
This weekend, Country Cycling Tours will offer its first guided day trips of the season.

On Sunday, the route will be along the North Shore of Long Island.


IRVING N. EPSTEIN
LEAD: Irving N. Epstein, an apparel industry executive in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sarasota, Fla.


Bilzerian Seeks Pay N Pak
LEAD: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian, seeking to take over the Pay N Pak Stores hardware chain, offered to buy all shares that he does not control for $19 each, or about $171 million.


I.R.S. Speeds Processing
LEAD: The backlog of unprocessed Federal tax returns is 18 percent lower than at this time a year ago, indicating a shorter wait for refunds, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
Through last Friday, 52.8 million couples and individuals had filed returns, down from the 54 million received during the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Citibank Card
LEAD: Citibank and American Airlines said they would offer a credit card enabling users to earn mileage points in American's frequent-flier program.
The new Citibank-American card, to be called AAdvantage, is similar to cards introduced in September by Continental and Eastern airlines, and will be available around June as either a Mastercard or Visa card.

LEAD: A secret report sent to President Reagan by his advisory panel on intelligence two years ago warned that the United States Embassy in Moscow was vulnerable to Soviet espionage, Government officials said today.

LEAD: Bryan Trottier, after insisting that there is reason for the Islanders to be optimistic, was not - at least not in his evaluation of tonight's 4-1 loss to the Nordiques that clinched a playoff spot for Quebec and left the Islanders adrift in the lower confines of the Patrick Division.

Ms.

Works by Richard Leonard are being displayed in first-floor windows.
The two artists were awarded commissions for the work, a total of 18 canvases, after being selected in a young artists' competition.
