Textron's Offer To Yield 9.50%
LEAD: Textron Inc. is offering $150 million of 9 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 1/2 to yield 9.50 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


Money Fund Assets Dip
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 380 money market mutual funds decreased $832.5 million, to $235.4 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $341.4 million, to $65.17 billion.
Assets of the 197 general purpose funds were up $1.1 billion, to $63.21 billion.


Amazing Energy From Russia
LEAD: Of all the things to be said of Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms this is one of the most telling: He has made his country exciting.
It is true, of course, that what would be unworthy of note in Paris, Rio or Tokyo is stunning when coming from Moscow.
Soviet life has been that sluggish.
Yet this is more than mere stirring from the dormant.


2 Top Officers Quit Wheeling
LEAD: The president and vice president of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest steelmaker, resigned today in a pay dispute.


Britain to Sell Off Royal Ordnance
LEAD: Britain's Defense Ministry has agreed to sell the state-owned armaments manufacturer Royal Ordnance to British Aerospace for $:190 million, or about $300 million at current exchange rates.
Defense Secretary George Younger said the sale would end a period of uncertainty for the 15 Royal Ordnance factories and open a wide range of opportunities for expansion of its business.


Britain Issues Threat to Japan
LEAD: In an attempt to put pressure on Japan to resolve a trade dispute, Britain today identified at least 58 Japanese companies for possible expulsion within weeks and threatened to deny business licenses to Japanese applicants.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov, by vigorously supporting Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has caused some disillusionment among dissidents who once regarded him as a hero of almost mythical size.


Dollar Falls Versus Yen After Yeutter Remark
LEAD: An apparently innocuous statement by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, helped send the dollar lower against the yen in foreign-exchange trading today.


AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: ''LETHAL WEAPON,'' the story of two Los Angeles policemen who try to break open a drug-smuggling ring, is a runaway hit.
By the end of last weekend, the film, which opened on March 6, had grossed nearly $33.6 million, and had been No. 1 in the country for three weeks in a row.
What's more, it actually did better in its second weekend than its first, grossing $7.1 million from 1,256 theaters the second weekend after grossing $6.8 million from the same number of theaters in the first.


WOOSTER GROUP ON LOVE, LUST AND LENNY BRUCE IN 'ST. ANTHONY'
LEAD: In the opening segment of ''Frank Dell's St.
Antony,'' the newest performance piece by the Wooster Group, images of naked flesh and spiritual obsession interact in a provocative collage of music, video and dramatic monologue.
Wearing sunglasses and a bathrobe, the actor Ron Vawter stands beneath video monitors on which members of the company are shown lounging around in the nude and engaged in desultory conversation.


ORATORIO MERGES CHRIST AND BUDDHA
LEAD: For Somei Satoh, the universe ''is a very small thing.''


AMERICAN LINKED TO POLLARD CASE REPORTS WORK FOR ISRAELI MILITARY
LEAD: An American lawyer who has been linked to the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had been a legal adviser to the Israeli Defense Ministry and that Israel had refused to allow him to be questioned in the United States.


RIVALS SAY MACHINES ARE NO 'CLONE KILLERS'
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation's competitors in the personal computer industry, who had been bracing for the worst, breathed a slight sigh of relief today.


GOODEN'S FALL FROM GRACE SADDENS AND ANGERS FANS
LEAD: On street corners and bar stools, on sandlots and subway platforms, on the ticket line and on the Shea Stadium infield where workers prepared for next Tuesday's season opener, New Yorkers yesterday dissected the latest fall from grace by an athletic hero.


Paine Webber Indictments
LEAD: A Federal grand jury indicted two more executives of Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday in connection with what was characterized as a $700,000 money-laundering scheme.
The executives - Joseph


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Margaret Whiting, the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). ''It Might As Well Be Spring,'' the title of her recently published autobiography, is also the name of Margaret Whiting's new cabaret act, in which she interweaves her musical history with anecdotes about the hotel, which she is performing in for the first time.


Bond Prices Resume Descent 8% Yield Near On Treasuries
LEAD: Bond prices resumed their downward spiral yesterday.
Securities dealers said that tepid buying early in the day was overshadowed by large sell orders in the afternoon.


TOUR GUIDES LEAD URBAN SAFARIS THROUGH CITY'S PAST AND PRESENT
LEAD: THE walking season is suddenly upon us, and all roads lead to the biggest show in town: New York City itself.
Walking tours of the city - which have become a year-round institution, with determined strollers slogging through the slushiest streets - are suddenly in full bloom.
There are more than a half dozen of them scheduled this weekend alone and the pace will continue through early autumn.


TALKS ON SPENDING EXCLUDE GOVERNOR
LEAD: As officials struggled to come up with a state budget, already two days late, Governor Cuomo acknowledged today that his administration was not part of key negotiations and that the Legislature was putting together a fiscal plan without him.


JOHN PAUL CALLS FOR CHILEANS TO MOVE TOWARD DEMOCRACY
LEAD: Pope John Paul II visited Gen.
Augusto Pinochet, Chile's military ruler, in his palace today and a few hours later called for Chile to move toward democracy in the ''not distant future.''


Israeli Court Rejects Appeal By Suspected War Criminal
LEAD: Israel's Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by the defense to disqualify the three-judge panel presiding over the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal.


Economic Scene; Behind the Rise In Prime Rate
LEAD: THE decision of Citibank to raise its prime rate of interest by one-quarter of a point, to 7 3/4 percent - a move quickly followed by other major banks - took Wall Street by surprise.


Michael Lytle
LEAD: Michael Lytle will play a solo concert of new music for clarinet today at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Spare Room, 107 Morton Street (807-6267).
Admission is $3.


ART: PAINTING IS ATTRIBUTED TO TITIAN
LEAD: AFTER cleaning and restoration at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and exhaustive research by a Met curator, a large painting attributed simply to ''Workshop of Titian'' is now attributed to the great Venetian master himself.


2 POLITICANS IN MARYLAND INDICTED IN WEDTECH INFLUENCE-BUYING CASE
LEAD: Two members of a prominent Maryland political family were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore in connection with the investigation of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor.


TROUGH TRAINING FOR DEALERS OF NEW I.B.M. PC'S
LEAD: Dealers who want to sell the new generation of I.B.M. personal computers - which the company says will be the mainstay of corporate America for the next decade - must take an advanced, expensive training course, I.B.M. officials said today.


Who Owns This Land?
LEAD: This land is not necessarily our land.
The Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service has found that the amount of land in the United States owned by foreigners is rising sharply.


PANEL BACKS MEESE ON LIMITED INQUIRY
LEAD: The Federal judicial panel that administers the law on special prosecutors ruled today that it did not have the authority to broaden the scope of a special investigation after the Attorney General refused to do so.

Moody's Lowers Chemical Ratings
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation's debt ratings were reduced yesterday by Moody's, shortly before the bank holding company announced that it was no longer accruing interest on more than $1 billion of loans to Brazil.


DEMOCRATIC, BUT DOWNCAST: CAN THIS BE BRAZIL?
LEAD: Fed by economic uncertainty and political confusion, a deep mood of pessimism appears to be taking hold of Brazil barely two years after the country emerged from more than two decades of military rule.

LEAD: When boxing champions step into the gym, more often than not they are preceded by large entourages.

STAGE: FUGARD'S 'PLACE WITH THE PIGS'
LEAD: ''A Place With the Pigs,'' now enjoying its world premiere engagement at the Yale Repertory Theater, is a surprise: an Athol Fugard play not set in South Africa.
The play takes place instead, as its title indicates, with the pigs - or, as the program says, in ''a pigsty, in a small village, somewhere in the author's imagination.


DIVIDED COURT UPHOLDS AN OLD PRINCIPLE
LEAD: New York's highest court was sharply divided yesterday over the ancient legal principle summarized by the maxim ''ignorantia legis neminem excusat'' - ignorance, or even mistake, of the law is no excuse.


KOCH IS CRITICAL OF DINKINS PLAN FOR APARTMENTS
LEAD: A recent proposal from the Manhattan Borough President, calling for a vast expansion in the number of apartments the city rehabilitates for the homeless, ''makes no sense,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.


2 Books on Philadelphia Win '87 Bancroft Prizes
LEAD: Two books about Philadelphia have won the 1987 Bancroft Prizes, awarded annually by Columbia University to honor books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history and diplomacy.


'I WILL FIGHT TO THE END,' BABY M'S MOTHER VOWS
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead vowed today to fight to overturn the court ruling that ended her maternal rights to Melissa Stern, the 1-year-old girl at the center of the Baby M custody fight.


Air Force Academy Change
LEAD: President Reagan has nominated Maj.
Gen.
Charles R. Hamm for a promotion and new assignment as superintendent of the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, the Defense Department said today.
If the nomination is confirmed by the Senate, General Hamm would receive his third star and replace Lieut.

Judge Seeks Bhopal Aid
LEAD: A judge hearing the Indian Government's suit against the Union Carbide Corporation today asked the two sides to agree on interim compensation.
Judge M. W. Deo said he made the appeal because the court case was likely to be a long struggle for victims of the disastrous leak of methyl isocyanate gas.


N.Y.U. Names Director Of Humanities Institute
LEAD: A. Richard Turner has been named director of the New York Institute for the Humanities at New York University.
An authority on Italian Renaissance painting, Mr.
Turner, a former president of Grinnell College, was most recently the dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science at N.Y.U.


FROM SMALL POOL TO BIG TIME
LEAD: The basement swimming pool at the Trinity School at 91st Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan is not exactly high technology.
It is 25 yards long and six lanes wide.
It is only 4 feet deep and the ceiling is only 12 feet high.


L.I. Man Wins Delay Of Deportation Order
LEAD: A Long Island man facing deportation to the Soviet Union as a war criminal, won a delay yesterday until at least Monday so that his lawyers could go to the United States Supreme Court.


REAGAN VETOES: 8 HAVE FAILED
LEAD: President Reagan has now been defeated by Congress eight times on legislation he vetoed.
These measures became law after Mr.
Reagan vetoed them and Congress overrode him:


Hoffman Released
LEAD: Glenn Hoffman, a seven-year veteran who missed most of the 1986 season with a cardiac problem, was cut by the Boston Red Sox yesterday in what Manager John McNamara called ''one of the toughest decisions I've ever had to make.'' Hoffman, who was Boston's regular shortstop before his illness, Kevin Romine, an outfielder, and five rookies were cut as the Red Sox got down to 25 players.


SEWER ACCORDS ADVANCE PROJECTS IN TWO SUBURBS
LEAD: So many new homes are being built in suburban areas near New York City that many municipalities are finding they are unable to keep up with the added demand put on their waste treatment facilities and sewage systems.


New York City's Cabaret Law Is Pulling the Plug on Jazz
LEAD: Not long ago, the great jazz saxophonist Lee Konitz was asked in a seminar on his work why he played so rarely in New York City. ''Nobody ever asks me,'' he said.
How tragic it is that officialdom in our city, the world's jazz center and home for the world's largest community of jazz musicians, is so unreceptive to the performance of their art.


ART: CARVINGS BY HAGUE, A MAN OF FEW ANSWERS
LEAD: CONTRIVED mystery, the kind that saves skins or enhances images, is a commonplace.
The real thing, on the other hand, is a rarity, and never more so than in the realm of contemporary art.
Raoul Hague qualifies if only as a sculptor who, at the age of 82, has but seven solo shows to his credit and who, it seems, has never taught.


SENATE VOTE ENCOURAGES WELFARE CHANGE
LEAD: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today authorizing the Federal Government to pay bonuses to states that move long-term welfare recipients into jobs in private industry.


China Opens Fifth Market
LEAD: China opened a fifth securities market this week, but expansion of stock trading is now being given a low priority because it is too ideologically sensitive, according to various officials and Chinese newspapers.


Devils Lose Bid For Fifth
LEAD: Troy Loney scored two goals to help the Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the Devils, 6-2, tonight and assure themselves of beating the Devils out of fifth place in the Patrick Division.


RJR Nabisco Sells 4 Pipe Tobaccos
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it had sold its Prince Albert, Carter Hall, Apple and Royal Comfort pipe-tobacco brands to John Middleton Inc., a family-owned tobacco concern in Pennsylvania.
Terms were not dislcosed.


BROADWAY
LEAD: LAWRENCE KASHA, a co-producer of such shows as ''Applause'' and ''Woman of the Year,'' doesn't believe that the American musical is dead.
He's got a new one coming up - or at least a workshop version of a proposed musical - and two more in the works, and if his dream comes true, he will be back on Broadway later this year.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Pistons 119, Pacers 73: Vinnie Johnson scored 25 points and Rick Mahorn and John Salley added 17 each last night to lead Detroit to victory at home over Indiana.
The margin was the greatest ever for the Pistons.
The Pistons led by as many as 49 points, 115-66, while winning for the third time in their last four games.

2 CHARGED IN CHICAGO STILL SEEK RE-ELECTION
LEAD: If Alderman Wallace Davis Jr. wins re-election here Tuesday, supporters of the West Side officeholder will have to celebrate without him.
Mr.
Davis is in jail.
And Clifford P. Kelley, a South Side Alderman seeking another term on the City Council, awaits a verdict from the courts as well as from the voters.

Lone Rangers
LEAD: In a break from the open style with which Phil Esposito has run the Rangers during the regular season, making himself and his players always available for scrutiny, Esposito will isolate the players for the first round of the playoffs, which begin next week.
The Rangers will be in one hotel, the reporters in another.


Meese Given New Evidence On Waldheim's War Record
LEAD: The Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit has given Attorney General Edwin Meese 2d new evidence on the wartime record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to bolster its recommendation that he be barred from the United States, Justice Department officials said today.


YOGI'S PITCH
LEAD: Yogi Berra, in a forthcoming television commercial for Miller Lite: ''It's got a third less calories than I probably thought it didn't have, and it's less filling than it would have been if it was more filling than they didn't want it to be.''


Dining Out Guide: New Jersey
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
ARCHER'S, #1310 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee (201-224-5652) - **(Nov. 30, 1986) Now that spring is officially here, areas outside the city seem to beckon; whether you're going to or coming from New Jersey, you might stop at this popular Italian restaurant in Fort Lee.


RESERVING A PAIR OF SEATS BEHIND THE TV CAMERAS
LEAD: ON the far reaches of West 57th Street, a line snakes into the Unitel Video studio.
Once inside, the people clamber to their seats, arced around a tiny stage that looks like a cross between a doctor's office and a living room.
Cameramen mill about as first the stage manager, then the producer and finally the co-host warm up the audience with the sort of banter that can be heard only in that province of videoland known as studio-audience television.


F.A.A. BARS USE OF DRUG-TESTING LAB
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration today barred its own medical institute from conducting alcohol and drug tests after aviation accidents.
It said it had asked the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology to conduct a ''thorough and independent assessment'' of the F.A.A. institute's procedures.


Video Venture
LEAD: National Video Inc., a leading video retailer, said it would join with the Univisa group to develop at least 600 video stores in Hispanic communities in the United States.
The joint venture marks a further demonstration of the growing significance of the Spanish-language television market.
Under the venture, Univisa, a large Los Angeles-based Spanish-language entertainment concern, would sell a minimum of 600 National Video franchises by 1992 and would provide the stores with Spanish-language tapes.


A Stronger Pound
LEAD: Comments made yesterday by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, helped push the pound upward in relation to the dollar, according to currency traders.


Reagan Rebuffed on Weapons
LEAD: A key House panel has voted to eliminate most funds for the Air Force's anti-satellite weapon and to cut sharply the funds sought by the Pentagon for President Reagan's plan to develop a system to shoot down attacking missiles.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Reports on Tuesday of a New York Times/CBS News Poll on evangelical ministers and television programs misstated the number of people interviewed.
The total was 1,392, not 1,394, and those who said they never watched evangelical ministers totaled 887, not 889.
In the accompanying article about Presidential preferences based on the same poll, percentages were misstated for Senator Albert Gore and Representative Richard A.


Tolls to Rise April 12 On Hudson Crossings
LEAD: On April 12, automobile tolls on the three Hudson River crossings into Manhattan will rise, to $3 from $2, and PATH fares will increase, to $1 from 75 cents, the Port Authority announced yesterday.


AIDS SPECTER FOR WOMEN: THE BISEXUAL MAN
LEAD: Seven years ago a Miami office worker had an affair with a bisexual man.
She recalls that his confusion about sexual orientation was one of the things that made her feel tender toward him.

LEAD: Lots of money is spent fighting over a few children in our society - Baby M, Baby Jane Doe, the sons and daughters in divorce custody wars.

WATER SUPPLIERS ARE HELD LIABLE OVER HYDRANTS
LEAD: The State Supreme Court ruled today that water companies could be sued for failing to provide adequate water pressure for fighting fires.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: FLORA WHITNEY MILLER chose art and furniture that expressed fantasy and wit for her duplex at 10 Gracie Square and her porticoed mansion in Old Westbury, L.I., her daughter, Flora Miller Biddle, recalled this week.
The offbeat artworks and antiques that Mrs.
Miller collected along with the more sedate French 18th-century furniture she inherited from her mother, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, are included in sales of the contents of these homes that will be held at Sotheby's New


Wyoming Lures Dees
LEAD: A day after he said he almost certainly would remain as basketball coach at the University of New Orleans, Benny Dees was lured away for twice the money by his alma mater, the University of Wyoming.
This was only Dees's second season as coach of the Privateers.
But he led them to a 26-4 record, their first national ranking, 16th at the end of the season, and their first appearance in the N.C.A.A.


2 at Symphony Space
LEAD: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will present a double bill containing new productions of ''Trial by Jury'' and ''The Sorcerer'' tonight at 8, Saturday at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway.
Tickets are $15 to $25; information: 864-5400.


Discovery of a Titian: A Detective Story
LEAD: A painting once attributed to ''Workshop of Titian'' that is now attributed to the Venetian master himself.
An X-ray, bottom, confirmed the authorship and showed that the painting originally had an angel at the left, which was replaced by dense shrubbery and a finch.
Page C28.

LEAD: MOVIES like Paul Mayersberg's ''Captive'' are as rare as peacocks' teeth, and even more precious.

LEAD: Six years after it began to make its personal computer as familiar in American offices as the filing cabinet, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a new, far more powerful line of desktop machines designed to carry it into the 1990's.


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: THE 21-year-old Sal Anthony's is one of those durable neighborhood institutions that have survived by cosseting a core of regulars, the type of customers who dismiss the menu with a wave and ask for ''the usual.'' Watching all the cheek-pecking and bear-hugging there one evening, I felt like an intruder at an exclusive private club.

MOST AT 7 3/4 PRIME
LEAD: Most major banks have increased their prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent, completing a move that started Tuesday.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was among the last major banks in New York to adopt the higher rate.


REPORT CARDS DUE TO DERBY CLASS OF '87
LEAD: By tomorrow evening, there should finally be some clear favorites for the 113th Kentucky Derby May 2, because almost every leading contender is making a key start tomorrow afternoon.


SOVIET DENIES ANY DEAL WITH ISRAEL AND ON JEWS
LEAD: The Soviet Union today denied Israeli assertions that there had been an agreement on exchanging consular missions.


Cigarette Output Down
LEAD: Cigarette production last year dropped about 3 percent, to 643 billion cigarettes, an Agriculture Department report said. ''Domestic use fell, but exports rose,'' the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. ''U.S. smokers consumed 584 billion cigarettes in 1986, about 2 percent fewer than in 1985.


Hagler Loses Again in Court on Title
LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler suffered his second legal setback of the week when a Federal appeals court today refused to stop the World Boxing Association from stripping him of its middleweight crown.

BUDDY RICE, JAZZ DRUMMER WITH DISTINCTIVE SOUND, DIES
LEAD: Buddy Rich, a hot-tempered musician who drummed his way through vaudeville shows and big bands, died yesterday at UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 69 years old.

Speaking about corruption, he said, ''It is going to take more than the one or two convictions that have taken place so far to change these people and the way they operate.


David Adler, 51, Physicist; Expert on Semiconductors
LEAD: Dr.
David Adler, a physicist who dealt with the nature and properties of solid matter, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Lexington, Mass.
He was 51 years old.


PHILIP COLLECK
LEAD: Philip Colleck, an antiques dealer in Manhattan and London, died Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 73 years old.


Senate Panel to Force Secord Clerks to Testify
LEAD: The Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra arms case voted today to compel the testimony of two clerical employees of Richard V. Secord, a principal figure in the affair, by giving them limited immunity from prosecution.


THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: THE rain splattering the windowpanes added some notes Handel never wrote, but the New York Harp Ensemble played on and Eva Marton lifted her glorious voice above it all at Monday night's musicale in Jenifer and George Lang's West Side apartment.
Then the guests - who included Marion and Elie Wiesel, Renate Ponsold and Robert Motherwell, Dietlinde and Lorin Maazel, Shirley and Milton Glaser, Peter Jennings, Tom Margittai and Vera Stern - trooped in the rain to the Cafe des Artistes for a dinner celebrating the restaurant's 70th anniversary.


More Reclassify Loans
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation, the Mellon Bank Corporation and the First Chicago Corporation yesterday followed other major banks in reclassifying most of their loans to Brazil.


Dow Rises 4.40 in a Wary Market
LEAD: Stock prices rose only marginally yesterday, stymied by continuing concern over the course of interest rates and inflation.


PROGRAM OF TIGHT SUPERVISION ENLIVENS PROBATION AGENCY
LEAD: Called the green berets of New York City's Department of Probation, members of the agency's 18-month-old Field Service Unit are breathing new life into an agency considered overwhelmed and ineffective by judges, prosecutors and many probation officers themselves.


Market Place; Mutual Fund Sales Charges
LEAD: MUTUAL fund sales charges were once relatively static affairs; a fund either levied a ''load'' - or front-end sales charge - or else it was no-load.
But lately a number of management companies have put into effect strategies aimed at garnering a bigger share of the booming fund business.


Coping With Japan
LEAD: When President Reagan imposed punitive tariffs on Japan because of its gains in the microchip market, I was just finishing ''The Reckoning,'' David Halberstam's fascinating book on the decline of America's auto industry and the rise of Japan's.
How ironically the President's action underlined the powerful themes of the book.


13 REFUSE TO SHIFT
LEAD: The Senate, with not a vote to spare, overrode President Reagan's veto of the highway bill today despite an extraordinary personal appeal by the President at the Capitol.


NOT GUILTY IS SIMON'S ANSWER TO U.S. EXTORTION INDICTMENT
LEAD: Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, pleaded not guilty yesterday to the Federal extortion indictment that was filed against him Wednesday.


Electronics Jobs Decline
LEAD: Employment in the American electronics industry fell 1.6 percent last year, the second annual decline, a trade group said.
The decrease contrasted with a 2.3 percent increase in overall United States employment.
The employment decline was sharpest in computers, down 5.1 percent; communications equipment, down 2.5 percent, and a grab-bag category including instruments, medical electronics and consumer electronics, down 4 percent, according to the American Electronics Association.

LEAD: To the Editor:

John W. Rockefeller, A Consulting Engineer
LEAD: John W. Rockefeller Jr., a consulting engineer who perfected and manufactured the mainspring of the Norden bombsight used in Allied fighter planes in World War II, died Tuesday at the Green Grove Health Care Center in Neptune, N.J.
He was 88 years old and lived in Asbury Park, N.J.


E.P.A. ASKS RULES TO PREVENT LEAKS IN UNDERGROUND TANKS
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed new rules to prevent leaks from underground storage tanks, half of which are used to store gasoline.

Lloyd Divorce Sought
LEAD: Citing irreconcilable differences, Chris Evert Lloyd has filed for divorce from John Lloyd, a tennis professional and her husband since April 17, 1979.
Their marriage in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was heralded by a sign saying: ''Love Match: Chris Evert and John Lloyd, A Perfect Set.'' Papers for the divorce were filed in Broward County, Florida.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Sonny Rollins, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300).
Encounters with Sonny Rollins, the reigning master of the tenor saxophone, can be positively transcendent.
They can also be frustrating, because Mr.
Rollins is one of those rare improvisers who play directly on the inspiration of the moment, and don't keep a ready fund of cliches handy for times when inspiration is in short supply.

LEAD: Friday  JUILLIARD CONCERTS  The Juilliard School will present a series of three free concerts in its first ''New Music Weekend.'' The series is entitled ''Then and Now,'' and features music by 20th-century pioneers and new composers, Tonight at 8, works by Charles Ives, Roger Sessions, Vincent Persichetti and Milton Babbitt will be played at Alice Tully Hall under the direction of Paul Zukofsky.

Shearson Drops Role
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. will no longer serve as a financial adviser for the financier Khoo Teck Puat, Shearson said in a statement.
Shearson had formulated a proposal on Mr.
Khoo's behalf for repayment of debt to the National Bank of Brunei.
The authorities in Brunei closed the bank last November, contending that 90 percent of its loans had been extended, without documentation or guarantee, to companies controlled by Mr.


GREECE VOTES TAKEOVER OF CHURCH-HELD ESTATES
LEAD: After hours of heated debate, Parliament approved legislation today, enabling the Socialist Government to take over huge estates held by the Greek Orthodox Church within six months.


Stanley for Opener
LEAD: Bob Stanley, returning to a starting role after six years in the Boston bullpen, was named to start for the Red Sox in their season opener at Milwaukee.
Stanley was picked to replace Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, who has a sore pitching shoulder.
Contract negotiations continued, meanwhile, with Roger Clemens, the team's star right-hander.

LEAD: Tommy Davis, a record-setting kicker with the San Francisco 49ers, died of lung cancer Thursday at his home in San Bruno, Calif., his relatives here reported today.
He was 52 years old.

STAGE: 'RETURN TO THE RIVER' IN AFRICA
LEAD: A few minutes after the lights go up on ''Return to the River,'' we know we are in for a consciousness-going-up session as Al Gilroy, a black attorney for an American oil company, arrives at the awareness that South Africa is his problem.
The play's problem is that of many problem-plays: characters tend to become walking pamphlets and the stage becomes a lecture platform.


Man Arrested in Torture Case Tries to Hang Himself in Jail
LEAD: A man charged with murder after the police found three women chained in his basement and body parts in his freezer tried to hang himself in jail Thursday but was not seriously injured, the authorities said.


University Names President
LEAD: John W. Shumaker, vice president of planning and development at the State University of New York in Albany, was named today to succeed F. Don James as president of Central Connecticut State University.
Dr.
Shumaker, 44 years old, will assume his new post on Aug. 1.
Mr.
James is retiring after 19 years as president of the 13,500-student school.


PERIODIC TESTING URGED FOR GOODEN
LEAD: Probation officials in Florida will recommend that Dwight Gooden be required to submit to periodic drug testing during the three years he is on probation in connection with his no-contest plea to felony charges last January.

Sewage Plant Breaks Down
LEAD: Nearly 23 million gallons of virtually raw sewage will flow into San Francisco Bay each day for the next week because of a breakdown at a treatment plant, officials say.
Preliminary tests indicate that the sewage is not poisonous and is mixing with the treated output from several other plants before being discharged into San Leandro Bay, an official of the Union Sanitary District said Thursday.

LEAD: Two months ago, tenants of a once-elegant, turn-of-the-century Harlem building were preparing to celebrate.


Clash Erupts During Papal Mass in Chile
LEAD: Two priests trying to calm the crowd yesterday as demonstrators battled Chilean policemen while Pope John Paul II was saying mass in a Santiago park.
Shots were fired and scores were injured.

How Lindsay Helped Race Relations
LEAD: The racial violence in Howard Beach has focused increased public attention on race relations citywide.
Such concern is overdue.
Tensions remain high, and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has warned of the possibility that violence will erupt in communities around the city this summer.
Howard Beach may only be the tip of the iceberg.

ROCKET FAILURE TIED TO STORM
LEAD: A pinpoint hole in a charred chunk of a failed satellite rocket was strong evidence the rocket was hit by lightning before it broke apart last week, the head of an investigation team said today.


Eligibility at Issue
LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee began its annual meeting today, but the key debate is expected Saturday on the question of eligibility.


Safeway to End Dallas Division
LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc., the largest supermarket chain in the country, said today that it would pull out of the northern Texas market, either closing or selling the 141 stores in its Dallas division by April 24.


Opponents, Not Opposition, in Chile
LEAD: Gen.
Augusto Pinochet rules Chile by default as well as by force.
He is surrounded by opponents but they, unlike those who supplanted dictators in Argentina and the Philippines, have yet to transform themselves into a viable political opposition.
Beyond the courage to speak out, these opponents need the wisdom to transcend division and establish a new pragmatic consensus.


NEW YORK HOSPITALS REPORT RISE IN NUMBER OF AIDS PATIENTS
LEAD: The number of AIDS patients in private and municipal hospitals in New York City increased by one-third during the last 12 months, taking up beds that Federal health planners said would not be needed for AIDS victims until 1990, hospital officials said yesterday.


Another Snag for the 63d Street Subway Tunnel
LEAD: Harold Cohen, an assistant civil engineer with the Transit Authority, in the 63d Street tunnel yesterday.
Federal officials said they would not release funds for the project's completion until there is proof that fire safety standards will be met.
Concern was expressed that aluminum ventilation fans, used to clear smoke in case of fire, might melt in the blaze.


EXPERTS PONDER GOODEN'S DESIRE FOR TEST
LEAD: A puzzling aspect of Dwight Gooden's misfortune is why he seemed so willing - even eager - to be tested for cocaine use when it would surely show that he had recently used the drug.


ERVING HAS BIG 6-POINT NIGHT
LEAD: It was May 12, 1976, and the Nets had just beaten the Denver Nuggets, 112-106, to win the American Basketball Association championship.


CUOMO BACKS PLAN
LEAD: A sweeping revision of the New York State tax code -lowering the maximum tax rate on wages to 7 percent from the current 9 percent - was agreed to today by leaders of the State Legislature and appeared virtually certain to become law.


FOR BIRDES, ALL ROADS LEAD TO KLEINFELD'S
LEAD: These are the times that try brides' souls.
It's 10:50 A.M. on Fifth Avenue - Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, that is.
In precisely 10 minutes, I. Kleinfeld &amp; Son, the store that is to wedding gowns what the Pentagon is to fighter bombers, will open.


10TH TITLE BY MORALES
LEAD: Pablo Morales of Stanford won his 10th national collegiate individual swimming title tonight, tying John Naber's career record.
If Morales wins the 200-yard butterfly Saturday night, he will become the leading winner in the 64-year history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's championships.


INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
LEAD: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as fears subsided that the higher prime rate would spread to other lending costs, increasing inflation.


CALIFORNIA CITY IS CHARGED IN BUTTERFLY'S DEMISE
LEAD: The combination of a rare blue butterfly, the plant commonly called locoweed and the construction of a baseball field has led to Federal criminal charges against the City of Rancho Palos Verdes.


2 MORE MARINES CALLED SUSPECTS IN MOSCOW EMBASSY SECURITY CASE
LEAD: Two more marines who served at the United States Embassy in Moscow have been implicated in violations of security rules, raising concerns that they may have allowed Soviet agents into the building, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today.


THE PERFECT WEDDING: ONLY TEARS A JOY
LEAD: Martha Stewart has a perfect life.
The exotic Araucana chickens she raises at her Westport, Conn., ''farmette'' are perfect.
The azalea bushes she planted in the garden for her husband, Andy, for Father's Day are perfect.
The herbed potpourri lying just so in her guest bathroom is perfect.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Weekend yesterday about television shows taped before studio audiences carried an incorrect time for recording of ''Best Talk in Town'' for Channel 11 in New York.
It begins Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at 4:15 P.M., not 4:45.

Company News; Sale by Occidental
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Occidental Chemical Corporation said it had sold a process chemicals division to Henkel Group of Dusseldorf, West Germany.
Terms were not disclosed.
Occidental had acquired the division as part of its purchase of Diamond Shamrock Chemicals in September 1986.
The division, which had sales of about $160 million last year, makes specialty industrial chemicals.

3 G.I.'s Die in Colorado Blast
LEAD: An explosive charge used to clear minefields blew up prematurely in a training exercise today, killing three soldiers, an Army spokeswoman said.
No one else was injured in the accident.
The victims' names were being withheld until relatives could be notified, said the spokeswoman, Specialist 4 Kim Hoppens of the Fort Carson public affairs office.


When Childbirth Is Fatal
LEAD: For women in the developing world the most worrying question about pregnancy is not ''Will it change my life?'' but ''Will it end my life?'' Reducing this maternal mortality rate - a goal recently, and commendably, set by the World Bank - depends heavily on birth control and health care services.
Sadly, over the last three years the United States Government's commitment to this noble cause has continued to diminish.

LEAD: Theater of the Riverside Church offered a rare look at Israeli experimentalist theater and dance when it presented Tmu-Na on Thursday.

LEAD: In another setback for the 63d Street subway tunnel in New York City, Federal officials said yesterday that they would not release money for the project's completion until the Transit Authority proved that it would meet fire safety standards.

LEAD: Steve Fehr, Navy's career-leading field-goal kicker, who has spent the last five years on active duty in the Marine Corps, has been signed as a free agent by the Cincinnati Bengals.
The 6-foot, 185-pound soccer-style kicker, who is 28 years old, made good on 44 of 62 field-goal attempts in his three seasons with the Middies.

HUNGARY REBUKES RUMANIA ON RIGHTS
LEAD: In an expansion of a long-smoldering dispute between two European allies of the Soviet Union, Hungary has issued a strong denunciation of neighboring Rumania.

Perry E. Nussbaum, 79, Rights Figure in South
LEAD: Rabbi Perry E. Nussbaum, a civil rights figure in the 1950's and 1960's, died Monday of cancer in San Diego.
He was 79 years old.
In 1967 Rabbi Nussbaum, a former resident of Jackson, Miss., became the first white clergyman whose home and house of worship were dynamited by racists.
His synagogue, Temple Beth Israel, was bombed in September and his home two months later.


The New Tennis House: A Net Gain
LEAD: On their toes to anticipate an architectural drop shot, some Central Park tennis players talk of resisting replacement of their familiar tennis house with a new building.
It is reasonable for New Yorkers to be suspicious of Central Park ''improvements''; many have turned out badly.
But the present stuccoed tennis house, a midget Greek Revival anachronism set in the Victorian Gothic wonderland of Central Park, deserves demolition.


Fed Money Policy Unchanged
LEAD: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in early February, but they indicated that they were ready to tighten credit if forced to by economic conditions, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

AUTO SALES ROSE 19.3% IN LATE MARCH
LEAD: Automobile sales rebounded in the last third of March, to show a 19.3 percent increase over the 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.
Sales of domestically made light trucks were strong as well.


Gulf States Utility
LEAD: The Gulf States Utilities Company said that its condition has ''significantly deteriorated'' and that its operating cash reserves would be inadequate by May unless it received additional financing or rate relief from state authorities in Texas and Louisiana.
In its newly released annual report and 10-K filing, Gulf States said that bank lenders had notified it last month that no additional credit would be granted.

LEAD: A Jerusalem dispatch on Wednesday about Soviet Jewish emigration misstated the nationality of Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress. (A dispatch on Thursday about Israeli-Soviet relations, in discussing world Jewish leaders, similarly mischaracterized him by implication.) Mr.

CHARGES REPORTED NEAR IN A NEO-NAZI INQUIRY
LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Arkansas that has been investigating neo-Nazi terrorist activity for several months appears ready to issue indictments against right-wing extremist leaders, according to officials with knowledge of the investigation.
The charges are said to include possible counts of sedition, The grand jury inquiry, in Fort Smith, Ark., as well as others in Spokane, Wash., and Denver, grew out of earlier Federal investigations that, in Seattle in early 1986, led to the conviction of 10 members of a violent anti-Semitic group calling itself the Order.


CHINA HELPING U.S. ON SOVIET A-TESTS
LEAD: The United States is using monitoring devices in China to improve estimates of the size of Soviet nuclear tests, according to Defense Department documents and interviews with Administration officials.


JAZZ: TRIO WITH BRAFF, CORNETIST
LEAD: Ruby Braff, whose lyrical cornet is rarely heard in New York these days, has turned up at an unexpected venue - Zinno, the restaurant at 126 West 13th Street where the musical instrumentation is usually piano and bass.
Mr.
Braff, with John Bunch on piano and Michael Moore on bass, is the first horn player to be featured at

WINDSOR AUCTIO: $50 MILLION
LEAD: Nostalgia continued to spur intense bidding last night in the final session of the auction in Geneva of the Duchess of Windsor's jewels.
Bidders in the tent overlooking Lake Geneva, and at Sotheby's in New York, vied for the trinkets and treasures that had filled table tops, drawers and jewelry boxes in the residences of the Duke and Duchess.


65-M.P.H. SIGNS SPROUT OUT WEST, BUT NEW YORK REGION HOLDS OFF
LEAD: The rush was on yesterday to raise highway speed limits to 65 miles an hour, but New York, New Jersey and Connecticut seem unlikely to join the stampede.


Dollar Mostly Higher And Gold Rises in U.S.
LEAD: The dollar edged higher against most major currencies in late trading yesterday.
Worried that they might have bet wrong on further declines, speculators lifted the currency by buying dollars to close out positions.


Jane E. Berentson Is Wed To Frederick R. Bleakley
LEAD: Jane Elliott Berentson, managing editor of Corporate Finance magazine in New York, and Frederick Robert Bleakley, an assistant business editor of The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in Manhattan by William G. Thymius, the executive assistant to the city clerk.


Grand National Play Moves Into the District Semifinals
LEAD: The protracted battle for Grand National Team honors, which began at club level four months ago and is to end in Baltimore in July, continues today at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Tennis  Teltscher Upsets Connors: Steady Eliot Teltscher won the battle of the baseline by mixing in a series of spectacular forehands to upset second-seeded Jimmy Connors, 6-3, 6-1, in the quarterfinal round of the $315,000 Volvo Chicago tournament yesterday.
Teltscher advanced to today's semifinal, in which he will face third-seeded Tim Mayotte.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday misstated the role of Charlotte, N.C., in expansion plans by the National Basketball Association.


PORTUGAL'S GOVERNMENT FALLS
LEAD: A censure vote on the economy today brought down Portugal's 16th Government since a military coup ended half a century of right-wing dictatorship in 1974.


GROOM AND BEST MAN KILLED IN CAR CRASH AFTER L.I. WEDDING
LEAD: A 27-year-old Long Island man, who had just been married, and his best man were killed on the way to a wedding reception in Lido Beach yesterday when a speeding car slammed into their limousine.


CARRIER-MUSEUM CALLED TARGET OF RACKETEERS
LEAD: Labor racketeering by a Manhattan gang called the Westies siphoned off extensive funds from the air-sea-space museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid, investigators disclosed yesterday.


Allied's Amphenol To Be Sold to LPL
LEAD: Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its Amphenol Corporation to LPL Investment Group for $430 million in cash.
Amphenol, which makes connectors for electrical cables, had operating income of $33 million on sales of $487 million in 1986.
That sales figure is roughly five times the 1986 revenues of LPL.


IN NEW ENGLAND, LOW UNEMPLOYMENT SPURS A NEW 'CHILD LABOR'
LEAD: Textbook and dictionary at hand, occasionally chewing on her ballpoint pen, Joy Paradis was doing her Latin homework as she sat behind a pastry wagon in the Maine Mall, pausing now and then to serve an occasional customer.


Severance Deals At Harper &amp; Row
LEAD: Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc. has entered into severance agreements, commonly known as ''golden parachutes,'' with 34 of its senior executives.
The conditions of the agreements would become effective with Rupert Murdoch's planned $300 million takeover of the New York-based publishing concern.

Baker Hughes Inc.
LEAD: The Baker International Corporation and the Hughes Tool Company said that they had agreed to a Department of Justice consent decree and had completed their previously announced merger.
The newly formed company, Baker Hughes Inc., with headquarters in Houston, will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday under its symbol, BHI, the company said.


DALLAS FACING MAYORAL RACE TODAY
LEAD: In most other cities, the prospect of four wealthy, probusiness contenders rather politely vying for the job of Mayor might make for pretty dull politics.


Letter: On The E.P.A.; A Problem of Funding, Not Priorities
LEAD: To the Editor:


5 Hurt in Explosion at Iowa Grain Elevator
LEAD: Smoke rising from the wreckage of grain silos after an explosion yesterday morning in Burlington.
Five people were injured, one of them seriously, as the explosion blew the tops out of six 10-story silos in the 12-silo complex and damaged others at the Archer Daniels Midland elevator.
The blast shattered windows for 25 blocks and forced the evacuation of downtown buildings as flames threatened an underground fuel tank.


HURDLE MAKES CLUB AS NO. , CATCHER
LEAD: The Mets, still trying to piece together the team after the loss of Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell, made a surprise move today when they cut John Gibbons and kept Clint Hurdle as the No. 3 catcher.

Libyans Said to Bomb Planes Seized by Chad
LEAD: Daily bombing raids by Libyan jets have destroyed or damaged half of the Soviet-made aircraft seized intact by Chadian troops when they captured the Libyan base of Wadi Dum two weeks ago, a French military officer said today.


Lawsuit Seeks Silver Of Convicted Killer
LEAD: A New Jersey businessman, who was sentenced to death for arranging to kill his wife, is being sued by her estate to collect silver bars he and his former lover bought, a lawyer for the estate said.


A KRESGE-McCRORY REUNION
LEAD: In 1897, Sebastian S. Kresge and John G. McCrory together opened the first Kresge store in Memphis, offering ''a variety'' of 5-to-10-cent merchandise from stationery to combs to sewing supplies.
Mr.
McCrory, who had already been operating a small chain in Pennsylvania under his own name, eventually left the partnership to concentrate on his own business.


CRIMINAL INQUIRY INTO THIOKOL DISCLOSED
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a criminal investigation of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that made the faulty booster rockets that were blamed for causing the Challenger space shuttle disaster last year, a Federal law-enforcement official confirmed today.


BID RAISED TO $110 FOR GENCORP
LEAD: An investor group led by Wagner &amp; Brown of Texas and AFG Industries of California tentatively sweetened its takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. yesterday by $225 million, raising its offer to $2.46 billion.


NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 U.S. monitoring devices in China are being used to improve estimates of the size of Soviet nuclear tests, according to Defense Department documents and interviews with Administration officials.
Page 1  Two more marines are implicated in violations of security rules at the United States Embassy in Moscow, raising concerns that they may have allowed Soviet agents to enter the building, Representative Les Aspin said.


HAGLER LOWERS HIS GUARD
LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, turned up in public today in a bright red cap modeled after the headgear worn by the French Foreign Legion, right down to the twin flaps hanging at the back of his shaven head.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:


David Watt, 55, Dies; British Political Writer
LEAD: David Watt, a British journalist and political commentator, died on March 27 in an accident at his home in Lewknor, England.
Mr.
Watt was electrocuted when he picked up a live power line that had blown down across his driveway in a storm.
He was 55 years old.


REPUBLICANS BLAME THEMSELVES ON HIGHWAY VETO
LEAD: Republicans in the Senate said today that the overriding of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill revealed a troublesome party weakness that, if not corrected, would render the party an ineffective minority.


GOODEN'S APPEAL FOR ADS LESSENS
LEAD: The appeal Dwight Gooden had for advertisers, already on the wane because of some well-publicized problems last year, has virtually vanished because of his involvement with cocaine, industry representatives said yesterday.


SCALIA ON THE LAW AND MORALS
LEAD: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court said Thursday night that the laws of the United States could suffer from an ''erosion of moral responsibility'' if Americans continued to honor what is technically legal over what is morally right.

METS' RIVALS NOT BUOYED BY DOWNFALL OF GOODEN
LEAD: There was no gloating today from the teams that stand to gain the most by the Mets' loss of Dwight Gooden, the very symbol of the club's success.
Instead, there was sympathy for Gooden as a kind of national resource that nobody could afford to lose.

LEAD: A split has developed in a major Palestinian guerrilla group over efforts to close ranks within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LEAD: The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 6.5 percent in March but job growth slowed sharply, the Government reported today.

DOWNFALL OF NAKASONE? IT COULD BE A TAX PLAN
LEAD: This rice-growing center in northern Japan is an unlikely place to start a revolt.
But if Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is forced into early retirement, as seems increasingly possible, Morioka and the rest of Iwate Prefecture is where his downward slide began.


Mellon Stock Drop Prompts Lawsuit
LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation was named in a suit filed by a shareholder in response to the sharp drop in Mellon's stock price since the banking company reported on Thursday that it would post a first-quarter loss of $55 million to $65 million.
The decline continued today, with Mellon's stock falling $3.625 to close at $40.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1987
LEAD:  Markets


White House Honors
LEAD: President Reagan and the Indiana University basketball coach, Bobby Knight, traded compliments in the Rose Garden yesterday as the President welcomed the N.C.A.A. men's championship team to the White House one day after greeting the women's champions from the University of Tennessee. ''Critics aside, one thing is certain: Bobby cares deeply about his players on and off the court,'' the President said.


U.S. Indicts 3 in Cuba Sales
LEAD: Three men were indicted today on charges of selling more than $1 million in computer equipment to a company for shipment to Cuba, violating the Trading With the Enemy Act.


A's Get Eckersley
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs traded Dennis Eckersley, a right-handed pitcher, to the Oakland A's yesterday in a five-player deal.
Along with Eckersley, the Cubs sent Dan Roan, an infielder, to the A's for three minor league players - David Wilder, an outfielder; Brian Guinn, an infielder, and Mark Leonette, a right-handed pitcher.


FILM: 'POLICE ACADEMY 4'
LEAD: The Police Academy series seems to shoot for an ever younger crowd.
The optimum viewer for ''Police Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, would be a 10-year-old boy.
Even better, it would be a whole pack of them.
That's not to say the film isn't funny; it means only that the sense of humor being addressed is very specific.

Silver Gains 8.6 Cents After Afternoon Rally
LEAD: Silver futures closed out an active week on a strong note yesterday, rising by 8.6 cents an ounce and more on the strength of an afternoon rally.
The April silver contract settled at $6.45 an ounce.


California Tornado Damage
LEAD: A tornado ripped the roofs off 16 greenhouses as it swept through a large nursery today, injuring an employee of the nursery, the authorities said.


New York State Set to Spend $375 Million on 60 Projects
LEAD: The overriding of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill will allow New York State to proceed with $375 million of road construction on 60 projects.


BEVERLY HILLS SMOKING BAN CLEARS AIR BUT ASH TRAYS STAY
LEAD: As of today, smoke-hazed lunches and dinners in Beverly Hills restaurants are a thing of the past.
In most restaurants, anyway.


NORTHWEST GIVES AIRBUS A $2.5 BILLION JET ORDER
LEAD: The European Airbus consortium announced today that it had received an order worth at least $2.5 billion from Northwest Airlines for a proposed line of passenger jets that would compete with American-made planes.
The deal bolsters the likelihood that the aircraft, still on the drawing board, will be put into production.

LEAD: In his final house call in Phoenix not long ago, Doctor J was applauded by thousands of patients wearing surgical caps and masks.

LEAD: A pilot program for group ridership in medallion taxicabs will begin Monday, formalizing a longstanding practice of riders sharing cabs from the Upper East Side to the financial district in lower Manhattan.

Murderer Is Caught 9 Years After Trial
LEAD: Nine years after he was convicted in absentia of a Queens kidnap-murder, a 34-year-old man was apprehended yesterday based on an anonymous tip that he had been seen around a Brooklyn housing project, the authorities said.


Chapter 11 For Air Atlanta
LEAD: Air Atlanta, the three-year-old airline that was the brainchild of a black businessman, Michael R. Hollis, filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
All of its flights were grounded immediately, and its workers were laid off.

Sonics' Lister Out
LEAD: The National Basketball Association playoff hopes of the Seattle SuperSonics took a severe blow Thursday night when Alton Lister, the 7-foot center who is the team's top rebounder, shot-blocker and fourth-leading scorer, suffered a fractured right foot in a 117-114 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers.
After making a layup late in the first half, he left the game with what was believed to be a sprained ankle.


A GUIDE TO MEDICAL TEST
LEAD: THE American College of Physicians and the nation's largest insurer, Blue Cross and Blue Shield, say they have developed guidelines to determine when 15 commonly performed medical tests are unnecessary.

COPORATE SECRETARY AT I.B.M.
LEAD: John H. Manningham, the newly appointed secretary of the I.B.M.
Corporation, and his wife, Patricia, were killed in a fire that swept their home in Ridgefield, Conn., early yesterday.
He was 53 years old and she was 54.


Testaverde Signs
LEAD: More than three weeks before the National Football League draft, Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback, signed a six-year contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who have the first selection.
Terms of yesterday's signing, which will make Testaverde the richest rookie in N.F.L. history, were not disclosed, but the former University of Miami star will reportedly be paid $8.2 million.


Webster Hearings to Begin
LEAD: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that hearings on William H. Webster's nomination to become the Director of Central Intelligence would begin next Wednesday.
Mr.
Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is expected to face questioning about the F.B.I.'s connection, if any, to the Iran-contra affair.


DOW INDUSTRIALS SURGE 69.89 POINTS IN RECORD SHOWING
LEAD: The stock market capped off a tumultuous week yesterday with a flourish, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared 69.89 points - its largest single-day advance ever.

Florida Battles Fruit Fly
LEAD: Four million sterile Mediterranean fruit flies were dropped over 49 square miles of Florida today as part of the state's battle to eradicate the insect, which is a threat to Florida's citrus industry.
Agriculture officials hope the sterile flies will mate with female fruit flies.
The result is infertile eggs.

THE STAGE: SEVEN ONE-ACT PLAYS
LEAD: If the prospect of seeing seven new one-act plays over two evenings seems daunting, here's a suggestion: Choose Evening A of the Class One Acts annual festival, dally over dinner and get to the Nat Horne Theater at intermission, about 9:30.
You'll be in time for ''Beirut,'' Alan Bowne's stunner about love in the plague years.


39-6 Run Tops Knicks, 126-89
LEAD: Dominique Wilkins and Mike McGee each went on hot shooting streaks as the Atlanta Hawks outscored the Knicks, 39-6, in an 11-minute span of the second half on the way to a 126-89 victory tonight.

COURT REFUSES MOTHER A VISIT TO BABY M
LEAD: A three-judge appeals court refused today Mary Beth Whitehead's request to suspend the sweeping ruling in the Baby M custody case during the appeal.


Schizophrenia Telethon
LEAD: To the Editor:


MUSIC: EUROPEAN GROUP
LEAD: The Chamber Orchestra of Europe is an interesting idea, and the first of its three New York-area concerts Thursday night in Carnegie Hall -the end of a two-week United States tour - had its moments.
But not enough moments to make for a truly memorable evening.


VIOLENT CLASHES BREAK OUT AS POPE SAYS MASS IN CHILE
LEAD: The police used tear gas and water cannons today to battle anti-Government protesters as Pope John Paul II was saying a beatification mass in a large public park.
Gunshots were reportedly fired during the clashes and scores of people were said to have been injured.


AMID SCANDALS, FUNDAMENTALISTS SEEK CONSOLATION
LEAD: ''This is terribly upsetting,'' said Ginger Harney, a 76-year-old California woman, who was sending money to the TV evangelists Jim and Tammy Bakker until the scandal involving charges of adultery, hush money and drug abuse erupted.
Ms.
Harney said she has cried herself to sleep several nights since.


RIGHT-WING VIGILANTES SPREADING IN PHILIPPINES
LEAD: A year ago in the densely populated urban shantytown of Agdao, three men gunned down a notorious Communist hit man, raised their rifles and shouted, ''Arise, masses!''

ON SOUTH AFRICA RIGHT, LIFE IS BLACK AND WHITE
LEAD: ''I would rather have a small South Africa that is white than a big South Africa that is dominated by a black majority!'' the leader of South Africa's far-right Conservative Party thundered to a packed hall in this northern Transvaal farming town on Tuesday.

Two Ways to Respond to Teen-Age Suicide

A PERMANENT HOME FOR ON-LOCATION COMPANY
LEAD: WITH its premiere play in 1985 - ''Inherit the Wind,'' which was performed in a courtroom -the New Haven-based Ensemble Theater Company established a ''site specific'' identity.
In this form of theater, any structure or setting can be transformed into a stage space, providing it is appropriate to the play.


HEARINGS IN RACIAL ATTACK FOCUS ON POLICE QUESTIONING OF SUSPECTS
LEAD: Pretrial hearings in the Howard Beach racial-assault case have focused on how the defendants were initially handled by the police.

Prison for Coffee-Spiker
LEAD: Glenwood D. Brogden, 18 years old, a student at Hammond High School in Columbia, has been sentenced to six months in jail for spiking the coffee of Janet Thurman, a teacher of home economics, with a derivative of cayenne pepper.
Ms.
Thurman has undergone minor surgery several times since she drank the coffee last October.

LEAD: If there had been proper research on when Breslau became Lindenhurst, it would not have been erroneously speculated  [ ''What's in a Name?
History,'' About Long Island, March 1 ]  that ''the same sort of wartime sentiment that turned German measles into Liberty measles may have affected the alteration.


THUNDER ON THE RIGHT
LEAD: You have to admire President Reagan's bravery at his last news conference, but you don't have to swallow his baloney.


Not His Vault
LEAD: Marvin L. Warner, who used to own the Home State Savings Bank in Cincinnati, got into trouble when he behaved as if he also owned the bank's deposits.
Mr.
Warner and a former Home State president were convicted last month on charges of illegally transferring some Home State investments to a failing Florida securities firm in return for guaranteed profits on their personal accounts at the Florida firm.

LEAD: THE 50 or so American soldiers stationed in El Salvador to train Government forces represent just one kind of potentially dangerous military commitment.

Wayland F. Blood of Orchard Lake, Mich.

No Headline
LEAD: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to take part in an ''encounter with the world of labor'' here Sunday morning.
But the fishermen of this gritty port city, like many other workers in the economically depressed south of Chile, have had to send their regrets.


Film; WHY HORROR MOVIES STILL GNAW AT US
LEAD: ''G OTHIC,'' A NEW KEN RUS-sell film, begins with music of vibrating doom, ghoulish spirits whizzing past from another world, an insane frothing-at-the-mouth flamenco.
A distant object, floating in the blackness like a murder weapon of some sort, becomes minimally clearer as it approaches, then fills the screen as a human skull while the music booms.


Mary Stuart
LEAD:  To the Editor: I very much enjoyed James Barron's article, ''The Royal Progress'' as well as the others on Mary Queen of Scots and Edinburgh.


Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


Pirate's Treasure
LEAD: LARRY McWILLIAMS, a veteran left-hander bothered in recent seasons by shoulder problems, was released yesterday by the Pittsburgh Pirates in one of the costliest contract buyouts in major league history.


Soviet Says Plane Pakistanis Downed Had Military Insignia
LEAD: The official Soviet news agency Tass today said an Afghan plane shot down by Pakistan on Monday bore military markings but was unarmed and was carrying civilians on an internal flight.


New PC's: Fast And Incompatible
LEAD: The stock market was not especially impressed, but the International Business Machines Corporation last week introduced a line of personal computers capable of tricks that most users never contemplated a few years ago.


LIABILITY STUDIES DRAW ON $6 MILLION FUND
LEAD: USING a new $6 million state trust fund, several towns are planning programs intended to reduce potential liability claims.


STORM HITS NEW YORK REGION
LEAD: Heavy rains and high winds hit the New York City region yesterday, flooding highways, bringing some rivers to flood stage and damaging power lines and trees.


BUILDING BLOCKS THAT ASK THE RIGHT QUESTIONS
LEAD: UP TO NOW, I HAVE GENERALLY believed that the best way to interest children in architecture is to let them loose in it - to let them experience soaring space, to let them look up to great height, to let them touch and feel materials and textures and decoration.
There's still no substitute for the real thing, but a close second is the exhibition, ''Building Buildings'' that was recently mounted at the Staten Island Children's Museum at Snug Harbor.


The Epidemic of Traitors
LEAD: The American Embassy in Moscow contains a chamber specially secured against Soviet eavesdropping.
But even this bug-proof bubble may not be secure enough for use by Secretary of State Shultz on his forthcoming visit to Moscow.
The Marine guards who let the K.G.B. roam the embassy may have compromised almost everything done there.


10 AMERICANS TO HEAD FOR SOVIET IN JUNE FOR FRIENDLY FISHING
LEAD: THE Russians have responded to a long cast from an imaginative band of American fly fishermen.


Urologist to Be Honored
LEAD: Dr.
John Kingsley Lattimer, chairman emeritus of the Department of Urology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, has been selected to receive the National Kidney Foundation of New York and New Jersey's first award in urology for his lifetime achievements in the field.
The award will be presented at a banquet at the New York Hilton this evening.


MEETING NEEDS OF THE POOR AND HOMELESS
LEAD: GOVERNOR O'NEILL, in his State of the State Address in January to the General Assembly, said: ''Let us create the resources to protect the homeless from deathly cold of the lonely streets, to put a roof over the struggling young family and to bring comfort of affordable shelter and care to the frail and the elderly.


Corrections; CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A map last Sunday with an article about the Pope's trip to South America misidentified the country bordering Chile, Argentina and Paraguay.
It is Bolivia, not Peru.


HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
LEAD:  Johnny Shiloh  With Brian Keith, Kevin Corcoran.
Walt Disney Home Video. 90 minutes. $69.95.


ROCK: THE NEW PRETENDERS
LEAD: FROM the Pretenders who released their first album in 1980, only one original member remains - Chrissie Hynde, the band's leader and singer.
The new Pretenders haven't spurred Ms.
Hynde to write songs as unconventional and feisty as her older material.
But on Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, opening a four-night stand, the band played the daylights out of all its songs; it has the force and tunefulness of the old Pretenders at their best.


FOLK ART WITH AN ELEGANT PRICE
LEAD: ''M ASTERPIECES OF American Folk Art,'' the exhibition that will inaugurate the new Hirschl &amp; Adler Folk gallery this Friday, has already caused both controversy and wide anticipation.
Both reactions are linked to the emphasis in the exhibition on pieces that have been auctioned in recent years for record-setting prices, and to the fact that the show of 24 paintings, weathervanes, whirligigs, painted furniture, stoneware, needlework, quilts and chalkware was organized by the temporarily homeless Museum of American Folk


MT. VERNON HOSPITAL: TRAUMA CARE CITED
LEAD: The article, ''Trauma Centers Designated''  [ March 22 ]  left a false impression that only those hospitals mentioned in the article were ''special'' based upon their total trauma-care capability.


LET'S NOT TALK DOWN TO OURSELVES
LEAD: THIS is a very strange country.
It has created an enormous university system in which flourishes, among the omnium-gatherum of things learnable and pursuable, an intense subculture of poetry and fiction writing.
The outpouring of literary work is so great as to obscure itself, too great to be attended to with the kind of care a slenderer production would allow.


Umpire Talks Make Progress
LEAD: Both sides expressed optimism yesterday that major league umpires would reach a contract agreement in time for tomorrow's opening of the baseball season instead of calling a strike.


WITH THE HUDSON AS BACKDROP, WRITER CREATES A SMALL TOWN
LEAD: THE novelist Roberta Silman cannot see the Hudson River from her home atop a steep hill in Ardsley.
This, she suggested, might not be an altogether negative thing.


COUNTY STAKE IN HIGHWAY BILL
LEAD: THE controversial $87.9 billion Federal highway bill included $389 million for Westchester County by 1992 and was crucial to the area's road-and-bridge-repair program this year, according to state and local transportation officials.


Ms. McCloskey To Wed in May
LEAD: Elizabeth Frances McCloskey, a candidate for a master's degree at the Yale Divinity School, and Peter Collins Leibold, a second-year student at the Yale Law School, plan to be married May 30.


ADOPTION MARKET: BIG DEMAND, TIGHT SUPPLY
LEAD: The legal battle over Baby M that was decided this week in a New Jersey courtroom has focused attention on a widening gap between the number of infertile American couples who want children and the number of babies available for adoption.


Mary Stuart
LEAD:  To the Editor: I would have thought it impossible but your writers, James Barron and A. L. Rowse, have done it.
They have produced a fascinating, accurate and interesting sketch of the life of Mary Queen of Scots (Travel, Feb. 8) without once mentioning John Knox.
Unbelievable but congratulations.


When Travelers Can't Get Off the Ground
LEAD: AS increasing numbers of travelers take to the skies, spurred in part by the airline industry's deeply discounted promotional fares, there has been an accompanying rise in flight delays and cancellations.
The summer travel season is expected to compound the problem.

Spock and permissiveness, it used to be said that children should be seen but not heard.
Exactly the opposite is what some people like in loudspeakers.
They want them to be heard but not seen.

TIPS ON GETTING MAXIMUM USE OUT OF A PORTABLE ELECTRIC DRILL
LEAD: ALTHOUGH a portable electric drill is probably the first power tool most do-it-yourselfers acquire, and it is one power tool that is found in almost every home nowadays, many homeowners still do not know how to get maximum use out of these tools.


ON THE TRAIL OF SHERLOCK HOLMES
LEAD: Of course, everybody knows the Great Detective never really died at all.
He managed to climb out of the Reichenbach Falls and make his way back to England where he lives still, keeping bees on the South Downs, or so his admirers say.


JAPANESE TROUPE SEEKS TO SHOCK
LEAD: WHEN AKAJI MARO was casting about for a name for his dance troupe, he hit upon ''camel.'' The animal is misshapen and unattractive -somewhat like the deliberately shocking images Mr.
Maro includes in his dances.


POTVIN REACHES THE 1,000 Mark
LEAD: It was another third-period rally for the Islanders, who this season have used them the way most performers use curtain calls.
Tonight their late-found theatrics not only forced a 6-6 tie that survived overtime, but helped Denis Potvin make hockey history as he became the sport's first defenseman to score 1,000 points.

CARAMOOR CONCERTS TAKE A TRIP INSIDE
LEAD: THE outdoor concerts at Caramoor in Katonah have long been a proud summer tradition in Westchester, but for the most part only the invited guest could partake of recitals in the sumptuously appointed Music Room of the mansion itself.
Happily, the open-to-the-public sign is now up for the indoor cycle of four ''Springtime Serenades'' that begins today at 3 P.M.


U.S. Denies New Sales Of Arms to the Iranians
LEAD: The Pentagon has denied an NBC News report broadcast Friday night that military equipment continued to be sold to Iran after the Reagan Administration had called a halt to such dealings.


The Marais
LEAD:  To the Editor: In regard to the article on the Marais section of Paris (''An Old Quarter of Paris Is New Again,'' Travel, Jan. 11), I would like to call attention to a site that was not mentioned.
It is a school at the intersection of Rue des Francs-Bourgeois and Rue des Hospitalieres St.-Gervais, about 100 yards from the intersection of Rue des Rosiers and Rue Vieille-du-Temple.


Gabrielle Gelzer Becomes a Bride
LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in Greensboro, N.C., yesterday evening, Gabrielle Valerie Gelzer and Donald Hanna McCree 3d were married by the Rev.
Dr.
Charles Reckard.
The bride is an urban affairs banker at Chemical Bank in New York, where her husband is an officer in the agribusiness unit.


SAMPLIG SCRAPPLE AT THE SOURCE
LEAD: Scrapple, as its name suggests, is made from scraps - the odds and ends of pork-butchering, boiled into broth and bulked out with grain.
It is a thrifty farmers' food, brought from the lower Rhineland, in the late 17th century, to Pennsylvania.


If You're Thinking of Living in:; PLEASANTVILLE
LEAD: IN Pleasantville, it has long been the custom around Christmas for villagers to gather at the gazebo near the railroad station to sing carols.
A few years ago, a woman who was the guest of a local family watched as the man leading the singing paused to ask who had been there before.

8,900 Line Up for 200 Jobs in West Virginia
LEAD: For many residents of West Virginia's chemical-manufacturing area, the lure of good pay and steady work remains far stronger than the fear of any potential dangers from a job at a plant.


PIANO: BRUCE WOLOSOFF
LEAD: BRUCE WOLOSOFF'S evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday was perhaps more imaginative for its planning than its execution.
There were, for example, two interesting pieces, one old, one new: the Busoni F-minor Sonata and a new sonata by Richard Danielpour.


ABSCAM IS RECALLED IN DAILY NEWS BIAS TRIAL
LEAD: For the last three weeks, lawyers for The Daily News have presented evidence to a Federal jury intended to show that four black employees were victims of their own limitations or improper behavior, not racial bias.

Social Events; Exotica and Make-Believe
LEAD: For Educational Aid  April 6 - The estimated 150,000 Sephardic Jews in this country are aided by the youth-education programs of the American Sephardi Federation, which will benefit from a 7 P.M. premiere showing of the movie ''Sweet Lorraine,'' starring Maureen Stapleton.
Following the movie at the Paris Theater on 58th Street, just west of Fifth Avenue, there will be a buffet supper at the Plaza.


Commercial Property:The Garment Center; A New Zoning Shelter for Harried Manufacturers
LEAD: SAVERIO PRINCIPATO may finally find his ideal landlord - someone who leaves him alone - now that city officials have agreed to restrict office conversions in Manhattan's garment district.


MAKING DO AT NEWARK
LEAD: The good news about infamous Terminal B at Newark International Airport is that gigantic Terminal C is on the way.
The bad news is that the New York hub of Continental Airlines, still struggling to digest the People Express whale, will continue to be Terminal B during the height of this year's travel season.


DOLLOPS OF DROLLERY BY NOEL COWARD
LEAD: NOEL COWARD.
THE NAME STILL CONJURES up images of unsurpassed elegance, sophistication and drawing-room wit.
It encompasses an age and an attitude that were, after all, very much part of this century.
All the more startling, then, to find the effervescent Coward fading still further into the fuzzy dimensions of period pieces, still demonstrating his talent to amuse but, more's the pity, looking somewhat quaint and at times perfectly silly.

A LA CARTE
LEAD: ROBINS and crocuses spell spring for many.
But for serious eaters on Long Island and elsewhere, asparagus symbolizes spring.


Corrections; CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A music listing today in The Guide (Section 2A) gives an incorrect time for the Philadelphia Orchestra concert Tuesday at Carnegie Hall.
It is at 8 P.M., not 7.

LEAD: A HARVARD PSYCHIATRIST recently testified in Federal court that during the last eight years she had been unable to teach or write because of her distress over the film version of Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar.''

The oven conks out before dinner.

Cinema Verite
LEAD: Mordecai Richler can add to his list of movie-production errors the final scene in Woody Allen's ''Radio Days'': there was no Great White Way in New York on New Year's Eve during the war years (1940's); there was a brownout!
JEROME AGEL  New York City

Focus: Apartments; The Glut Benefits The Renter
LEAD: FOR apartment-seekers in many sections of the country, this is a season of satisfaction, a time of landlord deals and vacant apartments in abundant supply.


TAILORED FOR SUCCESS
LEAD: PAUL J. HANLY JR.'S APPRECIATION of finery is as evident as the tailor-made suit on his back. ''Feel this,'' he urges, extending a sleeve.
And he is right; it does seem unlikely that any off-the-rack facsimile could approximate its softness.


The Palme Investigation
LEAD: I lived for two years in Sweden, studying its politics and culture, and I found Richard Reeves's somewhat sardonic report, ''The Palme Obsession'' (March 1), flawed in its street-smarts certainty.


FISH STEAKS OFFER ADVANTAGE OF SIMPLICITY
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up in England we ate grilled fish often.
But our choice was limited.
Mostly it was mackerel or herring, the inside spread with mustard and the outside rolled in oatmeal.
The fish were grilled until crisp and served with a mountain of boiled potatoes and butter.
For special occasions there was trout or salmon.

LEAD: WOULD Rupert Murdoch's News America Holdings Inc. - or any other corporate giant - publish the next e.e. cummings?
What about Charles Darwin?
Karl Marx?

LEAD:  To the Editor:

A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN
LEAD: WILHELMINA HOLLIDAY, touring a museum in Vienna years ago with her husband, was taken with the work of Clara Peeters.
Returning to the United States, she attempted to find out more about Peeters.
What she found was not only that Peeters was absent from H. W. Janson's ''History of Art,'' but that no other woman artist was included either.

He is a natural middleweight.

A Rise in the Prime Ends a Long Slide
LEAD: Major banks raised the prime rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2, an indication that interest rates have bottomed out after a long, slow slide.
The increase, started by Citibank, was the first in nearly three years.
The prime's importance has faded and is now mostly symbolic, and most analysts said the increase will not be fully felt at the consumer level for some time.
