TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT: THE AVOIRDUPOIS COLLECTION
LEAD: A CASE can be made for diet books as vessels of one of the great spiritual movements of our time - gospels of the American cult of thin.
There is the promise of salvation through short-term deprivation, supplemented, naturally, by vitamins.
There is the evangelical style, shimmering with such visions as ''painless'' and ''quick'' and ''forever'' (as in slim forever).


IN SHORT
LEAD:  AMERICA'S HEALTH IN THE BALANCE: Choice or Chance?
By Howard H. Hiatt. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper &amp; Row, $18.95.) Health care in the United States is already rationed, Howard Hiatt argues; the country urgently needs a fairer apportioning of resources that will never be limitless.
Those whose bills are paid with the help of private or Government health insurance get more than their share, he contends, while more than 35 million Americans - one-third of them children -are left to scramble for medical attention.


Judge Says Reporter Need Not Name Sources
LEAD: A newspaper reporter need not disclose his confidential sources for an article about possible legal violations in a Nevada gambling casino owned in part by former Senator Paul Laxalt, a Federal judge has ruled.


REIT's as a Hedge Against Hard Times
LEAD: SOME analysts were afraid that last week's news about real estate investment trusts was, to quote Yogi Berra, like deja vu all over again.
Of the seven biggest quarterly decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, three were realty trusts.
A dozen years ago, such trusts littered the losers' lists on the major exchanges, as the industry was plagued with scores of bankruptcies and other problems.

JAZZ: JOE WILLIAMS FOR 3 WEEKS
LEAD: IN fine vocal shape at the age of 68, Joe Williams is also a witty and articulate repository of jazz lore.
The former Count Basie singer, who grew up in Chicago where he worked professionally in the late 1930's and 40's, recently opened a three-week engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.


WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
LEAD: AT THE first-ever Kosher Food and Life Expo at the Jacob Javits Convention Center last month, more than 50,000 people eagerly noshed their way through everything from gefilte fish to kosher tacos.
For the plain old hungry folks in the crowd, the day represented great fun.
But to Irving Silverman, the show's ebullient organizer, and to the food industry executives milling about, the huge turnout branded kosher food as a blockbuster sales item.


THE GOLFING MACHINE
LEAD: SCATTERED ROUND the sixth green at Torrey Pines golf course, just outside San Diego, are some of the most noble mugs and beloved shapes in golf: Andy Bean, golf's Li'l Abner; Raymond Floyd, shoehorned into beige polyester; sweet, sad Tom Kite, and ''the Walrus,'' Craig Stadler.


Sterling Forest Sale Off
LEAD: THE insurance company that owns Sterling Forest and has been trying to sell the 30-square-mile tract of mountains, lakes and woodlands straddling the New York-New Jersey border has announced that it no longer is actively marketing the property and instead is studying alternatives to a sale, including developing up to 3,000 housing units while still preserving large sections of land.

Prepayment Penalties
LEAD:  Question: I own shares in a co-op in New Jersey.
When the building was converted in 1981 the sponsor took back a $2.5 million mortgage for 10 years at 11 percent interest, which he subsequently sold to Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank of New York.
The mortgage calls for a prepayment penalty of 5 percent up to the fourth year and subsequent penalties which would decline by 0.5 percent annually.


WHERE HIEDI BELONGS
LEAD: The location scouts for the 1978 remake of the film classic ''Heidi'' had a hard time finding a remote alpine hamlet embodying Dorfli, Heidi's little village.
After visiting dozens of sites, they finally discovered exactly what they were looking for: Grevasalvas, a rough farming village tucked away in the Alps.

FINDING COMFORT IN YOUR OWN LANGUAGE
LEAD: WHEN I was a young child, every old person I knew, without exception, spoke English with a foreign accent.
My grandparents and great-aunts aunts and uncles.
The Chinese laundryman.
The Italian candy-store owner and my friend's Irish auntie.
All came from somewhere else and spoke with the cadence of tongues accustomed to other sounds.

LEAD: After two years of negotiation, the state has approved a Boston plan to integrate all new housing built with any government assistance, beginning with more than 1,300 units that were started in 1986.
Officials are predicting that the plan will have a significant effect on housing patterns.

Heavy rains in New York metropolitan region flooded roads and brought some rivers to flood stage.

Moscow, in Retaliatory Step, Expels 6 Frenchmen
LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today it was expelling four French diplomats and two French businessmen in retaliation for the expulsion of three Russians from France after the French said they had uncovered a high-technology spy ring.

IN SHORT
LEAD:  CRUSADE: The Official History of the American Cancer Society.
By Walter S. Ross. (Arbor, $18.95.) Within memory of many Americans the word ''cancer'' was once almost taboo.
In obituaries the deceased ''died of a long illness.'' Everyone knew that meant cancer, but it was not polite to say so.
The American Cancer Society has been a major force in erasing that taboo, in bringing cancer forcefully to public attention, in convincing physicians that some cancers can be cured, others prevented, and that many lives can be saved by trying.

LEAD: Some members of Congress and intelligence officials say they believe that a new United States Embassy building under construction in Moscow is contaminated with Soviet eavesdropping devices and that the entire $190 million project should be scrapped.

In Basic Black and White, Chanel to a T
LEAD: CHANEL NO. 5.
First the perfume.
Now . . . the T-shirt?
This, of course, is no ordinary T-shirt.
If nothing else, its price - $80 at Chanel boutiques - sets it far apart from anything with bunches of fruit on the label.
And it has to be one of the few T-shirts that is just as much at home under a full-length mink coat as it is over sweatpants.


Iowa Gas Facility Explodes
LEAD: An explosion ripped through a natural gas storage terminal here today, sending flames high into air and forcing evacuation of about 75 homes within 2 1/2 miles, the authorities said.
No injuries were reported.
Civil defense officials said they were contemplating expanding the evacuation area fearing further explosions at the site, a Mid America Pipe Line Company facility here.

Six Homes in a Florida City Damaged as Ground Shifts
LEAD: Six homes damaged by a sudden ground shift Thursday have been condemned by officials in this central Florida city, and residents will have to pay for repairing cracked ceilings, walls and floors before they can move back in.

Cityscape: The Metropolitan Club; A Gilded Heritage Marred by Financial Troubles
LEAD: THE recent proposal by the Metropolitan Club to sell the air rights over its landmarked clubhouse is but another chapter in the history of a club with perennial financial problems.
The rights would be used by a developer to erect a 37-story apartment house over the the rear section of the club, originally built as a ladies' annex.

U.S. Reservists Build Key Road in Honduras
LEAD: IN a remote valley in northern Honduras, United States Army Reserve engineers, supported by National Guard maintenance technicians and military policemen, are working from sunup to sundown to build a gravel-topped road south from the town of Jocon.
With each mile pushed through the rough terrain, the road gives Honduran peasants easier access to the port of Trujillo to the north.

Haiti Approves A Constitution
LEAD: In the giddy 14 months since the overthrow of the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, Haiti has often seemed on the brink of skidding into anarchy.
But fears were allayed last week when the citizens of the hemisphere's poorest country overwhelmingly approved a new constitution that promises freedom from the tyrannies that have prevailed for most of its history.

LEAD: The provincial newspaper Shaanxi Daily has reported that 19 people died and 28 were injured when a bus plunged off a cliff on March 29 in Shaanxi Province.

Entering the Postnuclear Age
LEAD: Long before Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev started talking about abolishing nuclear weapons, the trend moving us step by step toward a ''postnuclear era'' was clear and relentless.
To be sure, there are more nuclear weapons around than ever before.
But the effect of nuclear weapons on the military balance has continued to diminish.


FISH STEAKS OFFER ADVANTAGE OF SIMPLICITY
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up in England we ate grilled fish often.
But our choice was limited.
Mostly it was mackerel or herring, the inside spread with mustard and the outside rolled in oatmeal.
The fish were grilled until crisp and served with a mountain of boiled potatoes and butter.
For special occasions there was trout or salmon.

Japanese attitudes are hardening as well.

KYOTO'S HANDMADE BRUSHES
LEAD: Because Kyoto was spared the bombings of World War II that devastated Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka and other Japanese cities, streets of dark old houses remain intact, pretty much as they were in the 19th century.
House-proud Kyoto-ites take care of their seemingly fragile wood, paper and plaster houses and the furnishings within the same way their ancestors have for hundreds of years, often using the same types of equipment, some of it still made by hand within the city.

STAGE: WOMAN AS ADJUNCTS, IN 'OURSELVES ALONE,' FROM IRELAND
LEAD: Men fight and women wait - and while they wait, they act as couriers and clerks, wives, mothers and mistresses.
As Anne Devlin observes in ''Ourselves Alone,'' a new Irish play having its American premiere at the Arena Stage, women in Ireland today are no more and no less than adjuncts to the lives of husbands, lovers and fathers.

LEAD: WHEN the national televison talk show host Sally Jessy Raphael moves her morning show to New Haven in June she will create a lot of firsts.


MAINE CATS HAVE LETTER-WRITING FANS
LEAD: State Representative Paul Jacques has been called a two-legged slob, a rat and an ailurophobe.
One person said he ought to be shot.
Another suggested neutering.


The Price of Prejudice
LEAD: 'The stiff criminal penalties and civil remedies provided for in this bill represent our recognition of the particularly serious consequences to victims, the community and the public order when violent acts motivated by prejudice and hate are committed.'  Robert Abrams  New York State Attorney General, commenting on legislation proposed by Governor Cuomo to increase penalties for racially motivated violence.


Thatcher Leaves Moscow Hopeful For Arms Accord
LEAD: Margaret Thatcher and Mikhail S. Gorbachev got together again last week, with mutually beneficial results.
The British Prime Minister flew home after five days in Moscow, telling reporters she ''would implicitly accept'' the word of the Soviet leader.

LEAD: Gone West, Cryptoclearance and Temperate Sil scored upset victories in major 3-year-old prep races around the country yesterday, deepening the list of contenders but also scrambling the outlook for the Kentucky Derby May 2.

LEAD: THE Russian voice at the other end of the phone line is unknown, the proposal tantalizing. ''I have interesting information for you, can we meet?''


EVEN WITHOUT GOODEN, THE METS CAN STILL WIN
LEAD: The best thing the Mets can do for Dwight Gooden is hope and pray he finds the answers to why he chose to self-destruct just before the baseball season, which has been the core of his identity.
The next best thing the Mets can do for him is go on without him.

A WORD ON FACILITIES, PARTICULARLY IN YONKERS
LEAD: Your article on trauma centers was in general highly informative; however, certain facts require clarification.
Residents of southern Westchester may be under the impression that most of the Westchester medical facilities are located in one hospital.
This is not so; all the hospitals in this area have equal total-trauma-care-facilities designations.

LEAD: There will be no Howard Johnson's blocking the bay, nor a fancy shopping mall nor any condominiums if most people here can help it.

Brief Alaska Fishing Period Brings Big Profits
LEAD: It was not exactly a crap shoot, only something like one, but everyone hoped there would be no losers.
Fifty-two fishing boats and their crews were poised to go after 3,600 tons of herring that would take about four hours to net and bring the fishermen perhaps $4 million.

LEAD: California's capital, which ripped out the rails of a far-flung trolley network more than 30 years ago, opened a new trolley line recently, and suddenly the familiar old streetcar is being heralded as a symbol of the future, not the past.

Afternoon Naps, Morning Doses
LEAD:  To the Editor:


Digging a Bucket of Diamonds a Day
LEAD: MILES and miles from anywhere, this inhospitable lunar landscape in the northwestern corner of Australia is home to six-foot-high anthills, kangaroos, baobab trees - and the world's largest diamond mining operation.


SUFFOLK FILLS POSTS IN NASSAU STYLE
LEAD: THE designation of Frank R. Jones as the new interim supervisor of Islip demonstrated anew the continuing power of Anthony Pace, the Islip Republican leader, and represents a Suffolk version of the recent political ups and downs in Nassau County.


I.B.M. Inaugurates a New Standard
LEAD: I.B.M. dropped the other shoe last week.
Its first line of personal computers imprinted on the industry a standard that was to become international, a standard copied, cloned or counterfeited by countless other firms.
Now I.B.M. has about-faced, deserting its own criterion for a brand-new one, albeit one that is also of its own devising.


RECITAL: PETER SERKIN
LEAD: IF the progress of music can be defined in terms of a slowly advancing army - one that continually occupies new ground but must look to its flank for nourishment - than many of today's worthwhile composers have leaped perilously ahead of their line of supply.


MUSIN: BLUE GENE TYRANNY
LEAD: BLUE GENE TYRANNY, by which name the composer Robert Sheff usually bills himself, was born in Texas in 1945 and has had a lively career.
He was an active figure in Midwestern new music during the 1960's, at Mills College in California in the 70's and in downtown New York experimentation of the 80's.


Music
LEAD: Although Wagner hardly intended it, ''Parsifal'' and the Easter season have become inextricably linked, and it's that time of year again.
While the Metropolitan Opera's 1970 production of the opera is not exactly news, it's still highly recommendable (it will be staged Monday evening and Saturday afternoon, with two more performances next week).


FRENCH FARE IN BETHEL
LEAD: FROMISES, promises - too many restaurants promise too much.
But attractive decor, agreeable service and an appealing menu do not satisfy if the food misses the mark.


NEW ISSUES DISPLAY HISTORIC TRADITIONS
LEAD: AUSTRALIA'S stamp program for this year begins with its Australia Day issue.
The national holiday celebrates the official beginning of European settlement in Australia in 1788.
The event has been marked by Australia Post each year since 1978.


Talking: Jumbo Loans; FINANCING 'ALL-CASH' CO-OPS
LEAD: SOME of the most desirable apartments in New York City are in fewer than 100 in New York City are in fewer than 100 tives along Park and Fifth Avenues from the East 60's to the East 90's.


Cinema Verite
LEAD: During my ''Hollywood press relations'' days, I called Stanley Donen's production company to ask whether anyone there had noticed the goof made in the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ''North by Northwest'' - in the scene in which Cary Grant is being pursued by a small aircraft.
The crop-duster gets closer to him with every exciting fly-past.


A New Therapy For Parkinson's
LEAD: The adrenal hormone norepinephrine and the neurotransmitter dopamine are chemically very similar.
And so scientists have wondered if they could cure Parkinson's disease, a neurological disorder thought to be caused by a dopamine deficiency, by transplanting tissue from the adrenal glands into the brain.


Indonesia Plane Crash On Sumatra Fatal to 26
LEAD: A passenger plane struck high-voltage electric lines on its landing approach to Sumatra today and exploded, killing 26 people, Government officials said.


PROGRAM TEACHES WAYS TO MANAGE STRESS CAUSED BY SCHOOL 'AND STUFF'
LEAD: Stress comes from many sources: tight travel schedules, competitive sports and even elementary school, say participants in a new stress management course for children 5 to 12 years old.

LEAD: TWO plays by Ibsen are in local theaters.
The Arena Players Repertory Company of East Farmingdale is presenting ''Ghosts,'' while the innovative Victory Repertory Theater of Great Neck is producing ''A Doll's House.''

LEAD: THE morning after the Senate overrode President Reagan's veto of an $88 billion highway and mass transit bill, Democratic leaders and Administration officials expressed the same exhausted conclusion: Let's not go through that again any time soon.

How Medicare Causes Hospital Horrors
LEAD: To the Editor: Dr.
William L. Roper's disclaimer of Government responsibility for the medical atrocities being inflicted on Medicare hospital patients under his department's diagnosis-related-group program is a priceless example of how a literal truth may conceal a monstrous falsehood (letter, March 26).


THE ELUSIVE LANGUAGE OF PLEASURE AND PAIN
LEAD: RILKE was probably right when he wrote that the events of the human body - pain, orgasm, taste, smell -are indescribable.
These are events and experiences for which language offers no solution.
They cannot be conveyed.
The writer falls back from his assault upon these citadels of sensation and contents himself with encircling the body with an array of sentences, besieging it with paragraphs in the hope that he will awaken a connection, however dim, between what his character is feeling and what the reader has felt in his own lifetime.


A War That None Can Afford to Win
LEAD: SEVERAL weeks ago, Art Buchwald suggested that Japanese executives be sent en masse to the Harvard Business School.
There they would unlearn all they know about manufacturing and receive instruction in how to focus on the next quarterly dividend.
In no time at all, Japanese productivity would deteriorate, trade surpluses would vanish and we would all be friends again.


The Danger of Disarming
LEAD: The very concept of ''A World Without Nuclear Weapons'' is an illusion.
Assume for a moment that all nuclear weapons have been destroyed.
Unless the means for building them are also destroyed, or placed under some airtight supervision, a number of nations would still be able to produce them quickly.


DESIGN TRENDS NARROW THE GAP
LEAD: The marketing mavens have long made a distinction in 35-millimeter camera sales between potential buyers of single-lens-reflexes (SLR) and those more likely to buy fixed-lens, auto-focusing, point-and-shoot cameras.
They assume, with some logic, that SLR users are a more advanced breed, interested in the controls and options that can make photography fun and possibly even creative.

LEAD: HE found his way to the familiar chair at the desk in his one-room apartment at a Fairfield County retirement home. ''Shall we read the mail?'' he asked me. ''I have two days' mail here,'' he said, fumbling with a pile of unopened letters.

AQUARIUS REVISTED
LEAD:  DO YOU BELIEVE IN MAGIC?
The Second Coming of the Sixties Generation.
By Annie Gottlieb. 418 pp.
New York: Times Books. $19.95.
PART history, part handbook, part manifesto and part bugle call to action, Annie Gottlieb's ''Do You Believe in Magic?'' takes a stern but affectionate look at the 1960's and then tries hard to reconcile that era with the present.


Sydney
LEAD:  To the Editor: We were pleased to read about the Sydney Opera House, which brought back memories of our visit in 1984.
We had bought the package ''An Evening at the Sydney Opera House'' before we left.
We enjoyed the visit but did have a problem with the guided tour.
For those of us who are older and/or arthritic, the numerous steps are an obstacle.

IN 'SAFE SEX,' HARVEY FIERSTEIN TURNS SERIOUS
LEAD: ''I WAS TRYING TO COME TO terms with the situation, with AIDS, that's why I wrote it,'' said Harvey Fierstein of ''Safe Sex,'' the trio of one-act plays that will open tonight at the Lyceum Theater.
He was speaking softly, and his somber demeanor had none of the inspired outrageousness that theater audiences have come to expect on stage: Harvey Fierstein the streetwise imp, Harvey Fierstein the Jewish mother from Bensonhurst, Harvey Fierstein the drag queen with a heart of gold who overcomes life's absurdities with an industrial-strength voice and a face of India rubber.

That information was not correct.

LEAD: THE LONG-AWAITED OPEN-ing of the Toscanini family archives - thousands of scores, books, letters, records and items of memorabilia that have waited 17 years unsorted in a basement while the conductor's heirs dickered with the New York Public Library, and now at last acquired by the library for the benefit of researchers - comes at a moment of something like high drama in the saga of the great Italian conductor's posthumous reputation.

Cinema Verite
LEAD: I, too, suffer from Mordecai Richler's obsession with finding errors in film and literature, but I do it for a living (''Cinema Verite,'' Guest Observer, March 8).
As continuity supervisor for a television soap opera, part of my job is to make sure the clocks on the wall show a passage of time, insuring the gas tank reads above ''empty'' when we're going to drive a car somewhere, and watching to see if the actor dials enough numbers when making a call.

1,091 Furs Lead to 1 Arrest
LEAD: Shortly after 2 A.M. yesterday, on the rain-soaked roof of a garment-district building, the police said, they found 1,091 fur pelts, one sable coat and George Koutsakis of Astoria, Queens.


Correction
LEAD: The Week in Business column last Sunday incorrectly described how the proceeds from the sale of 40 percent of Shearson Lehman Brothers, to Nippon Life and the public, would be distributed.
Shearson is expected to receive about $600 million in new capital.
American Express, Shearson's parent, is expected to receive about $650 million from the sale of shares to the public.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday.

Demystifying The Bomb
LEAD: If we look into the past, we can find many occasions on which nuclear weapons have actually been abolished.
We used to have nuclear antiaircraft missiles - Nike-Hercules and Bomarc - scattered widely around the United States.
They are not there now.
We used to have nuclear intermediate-range missiles - Jupiter and Thor - deployed in Italy and Turkey.

LEAD: ARTHUR MITCHELL, ONE OF George Balanchine's stars, founded the Dance Theater of Harlem in 1969 with the late Karel Shook.

The chief difference, presumably, would be that the dancers were predominantly black rather than white.

The Japanese Left Us With Little Choice
LEAD: WHEN President Reagan announced that he would impose sanctions in response to Japan's failure to comply with last year's semiconductor agreement, it created shock waves around the world.

FISH STEAKS OFFER ADVANTAGE OF SIMPLICITY
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up in England we ate grilled fish often.
But our choice was limited.
Mostly it was mackerel or herring, the inside spread with mustard and the outside rolled in oatmeal.
The fish were grilled until crisp and served with a mountain of boiled potatoes and butter.
For special occasions there was trout or salmon.

All around the country - in San Francisco, Chicago and Minneapolis, as well as at last night's New York Music Awards - hometown performers are acting proud to be provincial.

LEAD: A March 1 article about the town of Lebanon  [ ''Book Tells of the Life of a Town'' ]  stated that the Jonathan Trumbull House was maintained by the Lebanon Historical Society.

AFTER A CENTURY, TURNER GETS HIS WING
LEAD: AS OF TOMORROW MORNING, visitors to the Tate Gallery in London will at last be able to enjoy the J. M. W. Turner bequest to the British nation as Turner meant them to enjoy it - in a separate building named after him and devoted entirely to his work.
That this should be done was a condition of the bequest, which was made in 1851 and consisted in all of no fewer than 19,331 works of art, large, small and tiny.

WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
LEAD: The laws of kashrut, as the Jewish dietary laws are more formally called, constitute a complex set of requirements.
The two best-known are the proscriptions against eating pork and shellfish, and against eating milk and meat at the same meal.
For food manufacturers, that means that they must not use both dairy foods and meat products in the same item; they are forbidden even to use the same machinery to make milk and meat products unless it has been thoroughly cleaned between uses.


NEW LAWS IMPACT MOST AT THE SLAM LEVEL
LEAD: THE new Laws of Duplicate Bridge, which came into force on April 1, have no impact on social players.
Many of the changes will be unnoticed by the duplicate community.
But the law on claims and concessions has been strengthened, requiring any clarifying statement to be made immediately rather than, as happened in a recent national tournament, after prolonged thought.

LEAD: THIEVES have stolen our peace of mind.
Returning home one afternoon last week, my little boy and I discovered our door wide open.
A muddy sneaker print on the door showed clearly what had happened.
In the middle of the afternoon on a clear sunny day a stranger had kicked in our side door.

Argentine Debt Talks
LEAD: Economy Minister Juan Sourrouille was heading for Washington for talks with creditor banks on rescheduling part of Argentina''s foreign debt.
Officials at the Ministry of the Economy said Mr.
Sourrouille hoped to reach an agreement rescheduling $30 billion of private foreign debt.
Argentina, which seeks $2.15 billion in fresh loans from private international banks to meet 1987 growth targets, has been negotiating with the banks' steering committee since February.

You discover the bathroom has no soap.

Don't Take the Police Academy Out of Manhattan's East 20's
LEAD: To the Editor:


PILOTS OFFER $4.5 BILLION FOR UNITED
LEAD: The pilots' union of United Airlines, which has been at odds with management for some time, made an offer yesterday to buy United from the Allegis Corporation for $4.5 billion in cash, subordinated notes and assumed debt.


GLOBAL TV NEWSCASTING MAY BECOME A REALITY
LEAD: Planet 3, described by its creators as the first global television news program, could be appearing weekly on television stations from Peoria to Prague by next spring, according to the British-American partnership that is trying to find the money to begin it.


Chicago Mayoral Candidate Drops Bid in 4-Way Contest
LEAD: Thomas C. Hynes, the Cook County tax assessor who was one of three candidates bidding to unseat Mayor Harold Washington, dropped out of the race today, saying he did not want to dilute opposition to the Mayor.

Dwight Makoff and Dr.

Robert Silbey of Short Hills, N.J.
Judge Ronald Schoenberg of the Municipal Court of West Los Angeles performed the ceremony at the Beverly Hills (Calif.)

LEAD: Pope John Paul II heard an anguished cry against Chile's ''culture of death'' today from an Archbishop who complained of terrorism by both the military Government and its opposition.

LEAD: ''We were told there was a high level of radiation.
We knew about this.
But we saw lots of flames - that was our main job.
We are firemen.
We are supposed to fight fires.''


Rise in Oil Use Seen Easing
LEAD: The rise in the use of oil by Western nations is likely to slow this year, the International Energy Agency said today.
It said growth in oil consumption in the Western industrialized nations is likely to be around 1 percent, down from 2.3 percent in 1986.


LIVELY, AFFORDABLE FASHION
LEAD: The clothes and the shows themselves were casual and informal as the fall and winter fashion openings began in New York last week.
Two Philadelphians opened the new season with lively young clothes that also were affordable.


KOCH PLANNING 1,000 MODERATE-PRICED CONDOMINIUMS FOR QUEENS
LEAD: The Koch Administration is planning to build up to 1,000 new condominium apartments for middle-income New Yorkers on 14 acres of vacant, city-owned land in Astoria, Queens, the City Housing Commissioner said yesterday.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Guns and Past Echo at Shiloh
LEAD: The armies of the Blue and the Gray gathered again this weekend on the fields near Shiloh, Tenn., in a re-enactment of the battle that, 125 years ago this week, marked a turning point in the Civil War.


Grace Wieder Plays Schubert and Brahms
LEAD: The pianist Grace Wieder is at her best in straightforward, songful material.
Or so it seemed late Saturday afternoon, when Ms.
Wieder played works by Schubert, Brahms, Faure and Wallingford Riegger at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.


Writers Read for Columbia
LEAD: Susan Minot, Mona Simpson and Katha Pollitt are among the writers to read from their works in a benefit for Columbia: A Magazine of Poetry and Prose, on April 16 at 8 P.M. at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street.
Held in conjunction with The Writer's Voice, the benefit is also to include readings by John Fox, Henri Cole and Nancy Schoenberger.


Refiguring Arms Debts
LEAD: Paying for weapons is a problem for many developing countries, and last December the United States offered 38 foreign governments the option of deferring payments on the difference between current interest -then about 7.4 percent - and the higher rates of up to 14 percent at which their loans had been made.

LEAD: The West German economy, which has managed about 50 months of inflation-free growth, is beginning to show signs that trouble may be brewing for the year ahead.

LEAD: William E. Phillips, 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group and chairman of its Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide subsidiary, has relinquished the latter title to Kenneth Roman, 56, who has been president of O.&amp;M.
The agency, which is the country's fifth largest, is dropping the president's post.

FOOTE'S 'COURTSHIP'
LEAD: A WEEK or so ago, at Circle in the Square Theater in Greenwich Village, my eye was caught by a youngster in the audience trying mightily but unsuccessfully to stay awake.
The play was Horton Foote's ''Widow Claire.'' Here, I thought, was a perfect example of the younger generation, attention span whittled away by television, failing to appreciate the old-fashioned virtues of gentle, thoughtful drama.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Blues 3, Red Wings 2: Rob Ramage's goal at 3 minutes 49 seconds of overtime last night lifted St.
Louis to victory over Detroit, capping a week-long comeback that gave the Blues their second Norris Division regular-season title in three years.
The Blues won the title by a single point over the Red Wings, who finished at 34-35-11, for 78 points.

OS/2 System: No Free Lunch
LEAD: When I.B.M.'s first generation of personal computers came out, the cost of buying the operating system - the program that acts as the computer's internal traffic cop, directing the flow of data and instructions - seemed inconsequential.
I.B.M. charged about $40 for it; many computer dealers threw it in for free.


Stage-Fright Seminar at Y
LEAD: ''Conquering Stage Fright,'' a one-day seminar, is to feature the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne on Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
Ms.
Horne will discuss her own feelings on the matter during the session, which will be led by Barbara Keller, a pianist and teacher.
Admission is $10.


CHILE'S OPPOSITION GROUPS TRADE BLAME FOR CLASHES
LEAD: The clashes that marred Pope John Paul II's visit here have heightened disagreement within the Chilean opposition over the use of violence.


GOLD MUTUAL FUNDS LED FIRST QUARTER'S WINNERS
LEAD: ''Gold shares became the hedge, or precaution, against such uncertainties as the fear of inflation, the fall of the dollar, Federal Reserve policy -even the sustained rise in most other equity prices.'' That is how John Van Eck, portfolio manager of the top-performing mutual fund in the first quarter of 1987, explained the latest glitter in precious metal stocks.


Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION:  Has anybody ever played for all four major league teams in New York City - the Mets, the Yankees, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants?
It's never happened, and the person who probably came closest was Sal Maglie, who pitched for the Giants, Dodgers and Yankees in New York before ending his career in 1958, four years before the Mets were born and the first year that the Dodgers and Giants were no longer home teams in New York.


Ted and the Tax Man
LEAD: Memories of yesteryear's stars have always provided an appealing context in which to treasure a new baseball season.
But as the 1987 campaign opens today, few fans have as much reason to recall former players as Ted Turner, owner of the Atlanta Braves.

LEAD: Cuba has allowed 20 former political prisoners to emigrate to the United States in the last 10 weeks at the rate of two a week, United States officials say.


COMFORTED BY WHAT YOU WEAR
LEAD: THEY are generally the type of clothes only a mother could hate: the scuffed shoes that have molded to our feet; the slouchy hat that creases just so; the oversize cotton shirt that, after umpteen washings, is soft and cuddly; the baggy trousers that don't bind.
They are comfort clothes.

LEAD: Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political adviser, has told a Senate subcommittee that he will invoke the Fifth Amendment and refuse to testify about $780,000 he has received as a lobbyist for the Long Island Lighting Company.

LEAD: She will not be able to sign her letter of intent until Wednesday, but Shola Lynch, the star middle-distance runner from Hunter College High School, is verbally committed to attend the University of Texas in the fall, her mother said yesterday.

Metro Matters; The Legislature, Payroll Padding And the Future
LEAD: In 1975, payroll padding charges against a former Assemblyman from Long Island were dismissed by a judge who declared: ''This defendant has been singled out and indicted for his participation in a practice that has prevailed in this state for decades.'' In short, Albany County Judge John J. Clyne said, the legislator was a victim of selective prosecution.


NONPROFIT GROUP TO NOURISH ONCE-SHABBY PROSPECT PARK
LEAD: When Tupper W. Thomas became the Prospect Park administrator seven years ago, ''we had the opposite problem from Central Park,'' she recalled. ''People were just not using the park.'' Since then, the city has poured $17 million into Prospect, and the number of park visits has tripled to more than 5 million annually.

LEAD: More than 45,000 baseball-starved Washington fans bought tickets for a meaningless exhibition game today between the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies, largely to demonstrate that, after 16 years in the wilderness, the nation's capital and its prosperous suburbs deserved and would support a major league team.

LEAD: The center of a 540-foot bridge on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed without warning this morning, sending at least two cars and a truck plunging into a swollen creek.
The cause of the collapse was unknown, but it followed two days of heavy rains.

2 Killed in Miami Explosion
LEAD: A bomb exploded outside a house about 3 P.M. today, hurling a fireball into the air.
The accident left two teen-agers dead and at least four other people injured.
The authorities initially attributed the blast to a liquid petroleum tank but later said they found fragments of a military-type bomb at the site.


BRIDGE WAS REPAIRED 5 YEARS AGO AND PASSED INSPECTION IN 1986
LEAD: The 31-year-old bridge that collapsed yesterday into the Schoharie Creek was rehabilitated five years ago and last inspected in April 1986, when it was found to be in good condition, according to the deputy chief engineer of the New York State Thruway Authority.

Study on Scimed
LEAD: Scimed Life Systems Inc. said Friday that the Bristol-Myers Company was analyzing the pending lawsuit brought against Scimed by Advanced Cardiovascular Systems Inc. to determine whether to continue with its previously announced plans to buy Scimed.
The company said it was served with the suit here Tuesday, the day after it announced its definitive merger agreement with Bristol-Myers.


Joint Space Efforts Planned
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday.
Both missions will be launched from the space shuttle, the officials said.

Meese will submit the list to President Reagan, who then will choose a nominee.


Is a Hoosier a Hayseed?
LEAD: New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, is a graduate of Syracuse University, which was about to play Indiana University for the N.C.A.A. basketball championship.
Taunting his Senate colleagues from Indiana, he noted that Webster's Third New International Dictionary defined ''Hoosier'' as the nickname for an Indianan but also as ''an awkward, unhandy or unskilled person; esp: an ignorant rustic.


Diocese Loses in Move To Evict Vietnamese
LEAD: Vietnamese Roman Catholics fighting the Diocese of San Jose for a separate parish cannot be evicted from the church they have occupied since last summer, a judge ruled Friday.


UNFLAPPABLE OJEDA ACCEPTS NEW ROLE FOR SEASON OPENER
LEAD: ONLY one thing bothers Bob Ojeda about his role as the understudy who will replace Dwight Gooden tomorrow afternoon in the big show at Shea Stadium.


SEASON WILL OPEN NORTH OF THE BORDER
LEAD: Jimmy Key of the Toronto Blue Jays is scheduled to throw the first pitch of the baseball season this afternoon, the first time opening day has started outside the United States.


A Sure Sign of Spring In the Capital
LEAD: A couple sitting on a bench last week under a canopy provided by a blossoming cherry tree across the Tidal Basin from the Jefferson Memorial.


Hans Ericson of Sweden Dies; Longtime Chief of Teamsters
LEAD: Hans Ericson, former longtime leader of Sweden's teamsters union and one of the country's most controversial labor figures, died Saturday at the age of 59, a doctor reported.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Aetna Life and Casualty Co. has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a $200 million offering of debt securities.


Another Car Is Sought In Fatal L.I. Collision
LEAD: A Buick automobile that collided with a wedding party's limousine near here, killing the groom and best man and critically injuring the bride and maid of honor, may have been in a race with another car, the Nassau County police said today.


Corrrections
LEAD: A map Saturday with an article about right-wing vigilantes in the Philippines incorrectly located Baguio, a resort city that has been a site of vigilante activity.
It is on the island of Luzon, north of Manila.


DESPITE CHANGES SAME OLD RANGERS
LEAD: The coach who was hired to replace the dismissed coach is not coaching.
The new general manager who swore that the last thing he wanted to do was coach is coaching.
The big-name acquisition of the season did not produce and is gone.
He was replaced by a bigger name who is not producing either.
And it turns out that a minor trade has given the team one of their most important players.


Initial Phase Of Chip Talks
LEAD: American and Japanese officials will begin the groundwork Monday for formal meetings about a dispute over computer chip trade.
The talks are aimed at heading off millions of dollars of penalty tariffs on certain Japanese exports.


PAKISTAN EXPECTS RISING PRESSURE AS FIGHTING GROWS IN AFGHANISTAN
LEAD: With heavy fighting expected in the next few months in Afghanistan between Soviet forces and Afghan guerrilla armies, Pakistan is anticipating a period of heightened military and psychological pressure from Kabul and Moscow, according to official and independent analysts here.


3 White Youths Seized In Racial Assault Case
LEAD: Three white teen-agers were arrested Saturday night in a ''bias incident'' on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said yesterday.


DEVILS' GOAL: NEXT SEASON THE PLAYOFFS
LEAD: The Devils missed the playoffs once again and management points to financial restraints, but there seems some validity to the claim that there are better times ahead.


Barbara Lea Sings At Jan Wallman's
LEAD: When Jan Wallman, the veteran cabaret owner, recently relocated from a snug Greenwich Village hole-in-the-wall to better-appointed quarters at 49 West 44th Street, she took with her a roster of loyal performers who rarely appear anywhere else in New York.
Topping the list is the jazz singer Barbara Lea, who is appearing at Jan Wallman's Cabaret Saturday nights through April with programs inspired by ''The Melody Lingers On,'' Roy Hemming's history of songwriters and movie musicals.


Lawn Boy Assigned To Bozell, Jacobs
LEAD: The Lawn Boy Product Group, the Memphis-based unit of the Outdoor Marine Corporation that makes mowers, has decided after a review to assign its advertising to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon &amp; Eckhardt, Atlanta.


THINKING THE UNTHINKABLE IN TEXAS: STATE INCOME TAX IS ON THE HORIZON
LEAD: State Senator Roy M. Blake, a deeply conservative Democrat from Nacogdoches, was long a staunch foe of a state income tax for Texas, even sponsoring a constitutional ammendment to ban it in 1985.
But now, as he travels his district in rural East Texas, he says he senses a profound shift.


Northern Telecom Insert In the Fortune 500
LEAD: The Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, meanwhile, has been busy preparing a 21-page, one-shot ad for publication as an insert in Fortune's 500 issue of April 27 for its client Northern Telecom.
It will probably cost around $1 million, judging by the magazine's page rates.


OPPOSITION TO SEOUL REGIME IS VAST BUT BADLY SPLINTERED
LEAD: In a small, private room of a coffee house here, several young men and one woman spoke of democracy, firebombs, torture, America, and what they see as other related subjects.


Creamed Corn
LEAD: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' shortstop, plans to stock up on peanuts and ears of corn this season.
He won't eat the stuff, though.
Better to swing at it.


Illness of Two in Navy Is Linked to a Monkey
LEAD: Two animal handlers at a Navy research laboratory are critically ill, one of them in a coma, after catching what is believed to be a rare monkey brain disease almost always fatal in humans.


INDEPENDENT FILMS MAKING IT BIG
LEAD: When all the cheers were cheered and all the Oscars arranged on mantelpieces and Academy Award hyperbole boxed away until next year, one thing remained: Hollywood's yearly orgy of self-congratulation had been subverted by movies that were produced and financed outside the major studio system.

STAGE: HARVEY FIERSTEIN'S 'SAFE SEX'
LEAD: HARVEY FIERSTEIN, playwright and actor, wants an audience to adore him.
In ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' his breakthrough plays about a professional drag queen, and now in ''Safe Sex,'' a lumpy trilogy of one-act plays about the AIDS crisis, Mr.
Fierstein pushes love - love for himself and, of course, love for all humanity.


Single-Issue Illusions
LEAD: Single-issue foreign policy is bringing the same kind of trouble as single-interest lobbies, and for a similar reason.


Six-Shooter
LEAD: At a baseball memorabilia show in Iowa the other day, Minnie Minoso said he would suit up again for a brief stint with the Chicago White Sox in 1990 and thus become the first player to make major league appearances in six different decades.
Minoso, still his sinewy self at age 64 and a frequent participant in old-timers' games, was serious.


Education Tree in Brooklyn
LEAD: To most people, a quality undergraduate education means big bucks and, probably, a private institution.
But Brooklyn College of the City University of New York defies that stereotype.
In 1984, it was cited by the National Endowment for the Humanities, in an otherwise dismal report, as one of the few ''bright spots'' in American higher education.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Alert Issued Over Chemical Fire
LEAD: Officials warned residents today to wash exposed eating utensils and clothing and avoid the residue left when a chemical warehouse fire spewed a toxic cloud Saturday that caused an estimated 10,000 people to flee their homes.


350 DISPLACED BY THE FLOODING OF JERSEY RIVER
LEAD: The Passaic River, swollen by Saturday's rain, crested early today in Wayne, and local officials said they did not expect serious flooding, despite the occasional showers forecast for later today.


JAPANESE EASING STANCE IN PHONE CABLE DISPUTE
LEAD: The trade dispute over telecommunications has brought threats of retaliation against Japan from Britain and strong protest from the United States.


SOUP KITCHENS: STUDY PORTRAYS THE TROUBLED
LEAD: A private study of people who use soup kitchens in New York City has found that more than 40 percent survive on one meal or less a day and that most of those eligible for government benefits are not getting them.

LEAD: Caesars World Inc. announced a sweeping recapitalization plan yesterday that would award shareholders a special one-time, $25-a-share dividend plus some equity in the restructured company.

LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc., the owner of Madison Square Garden, and Olympia &amp; York, the largest real-estate developer in New York, are on the verge of an agreement to convert a 12-block strip from Pennsylvania Station to the Hudson River into a mammoth office and entertainment center, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

LEAD: The marriage of Wendy Jill Coleman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs.
Benjamin Coleman of Roslyn, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Myron R. Nadler, a son of Anne Nadler of Bardonia, N.Y., and the late Louis Nadler, took place yesterday in New York.

OIL GIANT IS BUFFER FOR BARTLESVILLE
LEAD: The four buildings that make up the world headquarters of the Phillips Petroleum Company in Bartlesville can be seen for miles, even to the rolling Osage Hills that enclose much of northeastern Oklahoma's Greene County.


OUTDOORS: SECOND SHOT AT TURKEYS
LEAD: NEW YORK State turkey hunters are being given a better chance to bag a second bird in the forthcoming spring season that runs through May.


Signs of Life for the Paralyzed Budget
LEAD: For six years, President Reagan has practiced desperation budgeting.
By crushing Congress between the rock of a swelling defense budget and the hard place of his hostility to new taxes, he has worked to deny it any room for domestic spending.
Now, his design for budget paralysis is unraveling.
The spotlight last week was on overriding the President's veto of the highway bill.


SWISS VOTERS BACK CURB ON REFUGEES
LEAD: Swiss voters gave overwhelming approval today to Government-backed proposals to tighten restrictions on refugees and make political asylum more difficult to obtain.


COLLAPSE OF THRUWAY BRIDGE RECALLS CONNECTICUT TRAGEDY
LEAD: The collapse of a bridge in Fort Hunter, N.Y., yesterday recalled the cave-in of a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge spanning the Mianus River near Greenwich, Conn., on June 28, 1983.

Tourist Bus Wreck Hurts 22
LEAD: A double-decker tourist bus crashed into a stone overpass Saturday, shearing off the vehicle's second level and injuring 22 people, four of them seriously, the authorities said.
The bus was carrying 62 passengers, apparently to George Washington's homestead, when it slammed into the Morningside Lane overpass on the George Washington Parkway about 7:25 P.M., the authorities said.

JOSEPHINE BAKER'S STORY
LEAD: SHE was not a great dancer or singer, nor was she ravishingly beautiful.
Yet Josephine Baker became one of the show-business legends of this century.
With a combination of monumental impudence and enormous energy, she evolved into the consummate entertainer, forging the kind of special bond with her audiences that spells stardom.

STAGE: SHAKESPEARE REVUE
LEAD: ''STAND-UP SHAKESPEARE'' is, as its subtitle indicates, ''a motley musical'' - heterogeneous rather than homogeneous.
As directed by Mike Nichols at Theater 890, the show is, alternately, a felicitous musical entertainment and a self-conscious attempt to lead Shakespeare to make fun of himself.


Arms Sale Challenged
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell artillery shells made of depleted uranium to Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Bahrain, but it has not notified Congress.
Why?
Because the sales total less than $14 million and the law requiring that Congress be notified of arms sales abroad does not cover sales of less than that amount.

Past Perfect
LEAD: Often the things people treasure have no intrinsic Value whatsoever.
Report cards, photographs, bridal bouquets, menus, matchbooks, letters, locks of hair - they are everything to their owners but nothing to anybody else.
But let time pass, and such items turn into evocations of the past.
Then their magic is universal.

LEAD: As Czechoslovakia prepared to greet Mikhail S. Gorbachev with praise for his policies of change, a Government spokesman suddenly announced today that the Soviet leader was delaying his expected arrival Monday until late in the week because of a ''slight cold.''

SPACE STATION LINK ABORTED BY SOVIET
LEAD: An unmanned, 11-ton space research module failed to link up with the orbiting Mir laboratory today, according to Tass, the Soviet Government official press agency.


Chamber Symphony Plays at 92d Street Y
LEAD: The New York Chamber Symphony introduced an appealing new piece by Nicholas Thorne, for bass trombone and orchestra, at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening. ''Songs of Darkness, Power and Radiance'' is the unpromising title (evoking familiar, better ones without achieving their authentic ring, and sounding all too much like a list of the attributes the composer hopes listeners will find in the work), but the concerto impressed as a candidate for wide circulation.


Standard Oil's Reply Expected
LEAD: The Standard Oil Company, which is considering an $7.4 billion offer from the British Petroleum Company for the 45 percent of Standard Oil it does not already own, will issue a statement about the offer today, according to persons close to the deliberations.


13-Day Ordeal in Snow Ends
LEAD: A couple trapped in their car by roof-high snowdrifts after taking a wrong turn in a blizzard in Norton, Kan., were rescued Saturday after living for 13 days on Girl Scout cookies, diet soda and water from snow, the authorities said.

Emirates Oil Output Down
LEAD: Oil output in the United Arab Emirates dropped 10 percent in March from February, to an average 1.05 million barrels a day, mainly because of customer resistance to fixed prices of Abu Dhabi oil, industry sources said today.


Morris Amchan, a Prosecutor At Nuremberg, Is Dead at 76
LEAD: Morris Amchan, a senior prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II who was also an attorney for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Navy Department, died Friday in Washington after suffering a heart attack.
He was 76 years old.

Young Hunters Electrocuted
LEAD: Three Midland boys hunting in a field were electrocuted Saturday when wind blew a metal irrigation pipe they had picked up onto a 7,200-volt power line, the authorities said.
The boys were evidently trying to flush out a rabbit hiding inside the pipe.
A passer-by told deputies he had seen a pipe in the air with three figures below and then ''saw a big flash,'' said Sheriff Gary Painter.


Builder's Stake In French TV
LEAD: A consortium headed by the construction group Bouygues S.A. has been awarded a 50 percent controlling stake in France's oldest and most widely watched television network, the Government-owned Television Francaise-1.

LEAD: It has been the kind of season that the Islanders, along with their exasperated rookie coach, would like to disown.


U.S. IS EXPANDING AMNESTY PROGRAM FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
LEAD: President Reagan's Administration, expansively interpreting the new immigration law, plans to offer legal status to illegal aliens who have been harvesting fruit, vegetables and ''other perishable commodities'' such as Christmas trees and tobacco.


Egypt Opposition Cites Pre-Voting Detentions
LEAD: On the eve of national elections, an opposition alliance that includes Moslem fundamentalists today accused the police of rounding up hundreds of its supporters whom it designated to monitor polling places.


White, Yankelovitch
LEAD: White, Yankelovich, Skelly Consulting Group of New York and Stamford, Conn., announced its existence last week and reported that it is made up of three units.
They are the Futures Group of Glastonbury, Conn., and Washington, D.C., which does strategic marketing studies among other things; Stockman &amp; Associates of Greenwich, Conn., consultants in international marketing, technology transfer, brokerage and distribution, and Van Dyk Associates of Washington, consultants on public policy and government affairs.


Nuclear Slumber
LEAD: The operators of Philadelphia Electric's Peach Bottom nuclear reactor have given new pungency to the phrase asleep at the switch.
Those working the night shift regularly nod off while the reactor boringly zaps the energy of neutrons into boiling water.
While Pennsylvania sleeps, the reactor operators slumber in big, comfortable chairs with their feet up on their desks, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has learned.


Patricia A. Alpert Weds Charles A. Weil, a Lawyer
LEAD: Patricia Ann Alpert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
William Alpert of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Alfred Weil, a son of Dr. and Mrs.
Otto Weil of Plandome, L.I.
Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: WHERE IS NICARAGUA? By Peter Davis. 349 pages. Simon &amp; Schuster. $18.95.


LEFTIST LOSE POWER TO THE CONSERVATIVES IN FRANKFURT REGION
LEAD: The Social Democratic Party lost control of the state of Hesse today for the first time since World War II as a coalition led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats won control of the state parliament.

LEAD: The Barnum Wood Elementary School seems almost to be squirming with activity today.
Some pupils are trooping to lunch; others are cheering in the gym.
But in the library, second graders sit, listening raptly, as a librarian reads from Dr.
Seuss:


FALLEN BRIDGE ON A NORTHERN LIFELINE, EXPECTED TO AFFECT TRUCKERS THE MOST
LEAD: For hundreds of companies that depend on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway as a lifeline to the rest of the nation, the collapse of a Thruway bridge yesterday will mean more than a year of detours and disruptions, according to state officials.


KING WINS PLAYOFF ON 2D EXTRA HOLE
LEAD: Betsy King gained her first victory in a major tournament today when she parred the second hole of a sudden-death playoff to beat Patty Sheehan in the $500,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore event at Mission Hills.


Big Bat in the Basement
LEAD: Rick Rhoden, the best-hitting pitcher in baseball, had a higher batting average with runners in scoring position last season than did Don Mattingly, .318 to .305.
When someone at the Yankee camp pointed this out to him the other day, Rhoden, who finished in the cellar with Pittsburgh each of the last three years, merely shrugged and said, ''I needed the runs more than he did.


WITH NEW PC'S, I.B.M. COURTS THE CORPORATIONS
LEAD: With the International Business Machines Corporation's introduction of a new generation of personal computers last week, analysts and large computer purchasers said the company focused its attentions on the corporate marketplace and largely turned away from more casual users of PC's.


It's Julius, Not Doctor J
LEAD: HE knew how to ''float'' on the basketball court, but carrying himself outside the arena was the real trick.


OUSTED AS LESOTHO HEADIN A COUP
LEAD: Chief Leabua Jonathan, Lesotho's Prime Minister for 20 years before he was ousted in a military coup in January 1986, died today in a hospital in Pretoria, the South African Government reported.
He was 72 years old.

LEAD:  Gorbachev Misses a Date


Black Choreographers In Brooklyn Program
LEAD: The Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center is to present ''Solos and Duets by Black Choreographers'' on April 24 and 25 at 7:45 P.M. at the Church of St.
Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section.
The choreographers for the program, directed by Larry Phillips, include Clarence Teeter, Sylvester Campbell, Talley Beatty, Andy Torres, Walter Rutledge, Alfred Gallman, Kevin Hunt, Eugene Little and Roman Brooks.

LEAD: Victoria Paula Moskowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
George Moskowitz of New York, was married yesterday to Lee Hadas Glickenhaus, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Walt Glickenhaus of New York.
Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.


UMPIRES MAY NOT REQUIRE CONTRACT
LEAD: The lawyer representing major league baseball umpires said they might work today's season-opening games even if no contract agreement was attained.


RASMUSSEN ON TOP, BUT UNDER SCRUTINY
LEAD: PICTURE this: The Yankees' opening-day pitcher this afternoon at Tiger Stadium won 18 games last season, pitched 202 innings, kept opposing hitters to a collective .217 batting average and became the father of twins during last summer's stretch drive.


Mayor of San Antonio Elected to Fourth Term
LEAD: The Mayor of San Antonio, Henry G. Cisneros, has won re-election to a fourth two-year term.


Flaw in Physics Theory
LEAD: Since its development in 1947, the theory of quantum electrodynamics has enabled physicists to make accurate predictions about the interaction of atomic particles and to develop important electronic technology based on these interactions.
But a team of scientists at the University of Michigan has uncovered evidence that the theory may be fundamentally flawed.

LEAD: WITH its announcements in New York and Miami Beach last week, I.B.M. finally put an end to many months of speculation about its new family of personal computers.
Now, in turn, there will be many months of speculation about what it all means.


Antitrust Lawsuit Against Coastal
LEAD: The Trans-American Natural Gas Corporation filed a $100 million lawsuit in Federal court, charging the Coastal Corporation and its chairman, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., with antitrust violations.

MOSCOW OFFERING TO PUT OFF A BAN ON ATOM TESTING
LEAD: The Soviet Union, in a shift, has offered to postpone its demand for a total nuclear test ban and to concentrate first on intermediate testing limitations.


Fewer European Jobless
LEAD: Unemployment in the European Community dipped in February to 11.7 percent of the civilian work force, from a record 11.8 percent the month before, the community said today.
The number of jobless people dropped by slightly more than 100,000, to 17 million, the community's statistics office said in its monthly labor market report.


A Creedmoor Escapee Gives Up in California
LEAD: A 26-year-old man who fled from the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens last month has surrendered to the authorities in California, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

LEAD: At first sight this place looks untouched by time.
Farmers bend over their rice fields.
Women gather by a small stream, washing clothes with an occasional thump of a wooden stick.

NEXT MOVE IS IN COURTS OF TEXAS
LEAD: The fight between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company moves back into the Texas court system now, with both companies saying today that they want to find a way for Texaco to secure its potential liability without crippling itself.


A PAC 'Hello Sucker'
LEAD: The Conservative Coalition, which consists largely of Republicans, is trying to raise money for its political action committee by attacking the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the bonuses it paid officers and consultants last year.


BEFORE COLLAPSE,. A RECORD WATER RUSH
LEAD: Twelve hours before a bridge over the Schoharie Creek collapsed Sunday on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, the rush of water through a dam 40 miles upstream hit a ''historic high,'' a vice president of the New York Power Authority said yesterday.


Czech Jumper Defects
LEAD: Jan Cado, a Czechoslovak triple jumper who competed in last month's world indoor track and field championships in Indianapolis, has defected to the United States, according to a published report.
Cado finished fourth in the European Indoor Championships in February with a distance of 55 feet 7 3/4 inches and was 10th in the world championships with a distance of 53-7.


TRANSIT AUTHORITY RELAXES REGULATIONS ON DRUG TESTING
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority has revised its policy on drugs, to limit the circumstances under which 45,000 employees can be ordered to take drug tests.

She has been deaf since birth.

Group Riding Plan for Taxi Riders Begins
LEAD: Commuters lining up at a taxi stand at York Avenue and 79th Street for rides to lower Manhattan.
Test program made formal a longtime practice of cab-sharing from Upper East Side.
Fare to Wall Street for four riders is $3 each.
Service from second stand, between 70th and 71st Streets, begins on Monday.

LEAD: HURRICANES 40 to 50 percent more destructive could be a byproduct of the gradual warming of the earth expected over the next half-century, according to new calculations by a climate modeler at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LEAD: The dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company centers on which of the companies first reached a binding contract to purchase all or part of the Getty Oil Company early in 1984.

LEAD: Wall Street showed a clear preference yesterday for a recapitalization plan proposed on Sunday by Caesars World Inc. over a $28-a-share offer made by Martin T. Sosnoff, the gambling concern's largest shareholder.


Blues Sign Collegian
LEAD: Tony Hrkac of the University of North Dakota, named the outstanding college hockey player in the country this season, was signed yesterday by the St.
Louis Blues.
Hrkac, 21, said he decided early last week that he was going to skip his last two years of eligibility.
Hrkac, a center, led North Dakota to the National Collegiate Athletic Association title this season.

SMILES AND DOUBTS FOR REAGAN OVER STATEMENT ON ACID RAIN
LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney responded with obvious pleasure today to President Reagan's statement that he would consider an acid rain agreement between Canada and the United States.


KUWAITI PROPOSAL ON GULF SHIPPING
LEAD: Kuwait has proposed an indirect way to allow the United States to protect Kuwaiti-owned ships from attack in the Persian Gulf - by transferring the registration of some tankers to the American flag.


Takeover Law Rejected
LEAD: The Supreme Court said today that it had declined to review a ruling that struck down Ohio's takeover law.
The case involved the Fleet Aerospace Corporation's bid to acquire Aeronca Inc., a maker of aerospace parts and electronics.
A Federal appeals court last June ruled the law was unconstitutional because it placed an impermissible burden on interstate commerce and because it conflicted with Federal takeover laws.


KOCH QUESTIONED BY U.S. ON MYERSON
LEAD: Federal investigators questioned Mayor Koch for more than an hour last Friday about Bess Myerson and her companion, Carl A. Capasso, the Mayor said last night.


NICARAGUA SAID TO SEEK MORE SOVIET HELICOPTERS
LEAD: Nicaragua is negotiating with the Soviet Union to obtain new helicopters in anticipation of increasing warfare, according to Western intelligence reports.


The Wrong War
LEAD: It is often said, by President Reagan among others, that Mikhail Gorbachev needs an arms control agreement for economic reasons.
If limits were put on the arms race, the Soviet Union could devote more resources and talent to solving the severe problems of its civilian economy.


HAGLER CONTENDS HE WAS ROBBED
LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler was robbed, he contended in the news conference held about an hour after he lost his World Boxing Council middleweight championship title tonight in a split decision.


Shades of Teheran
LEAD: Bruce Laingen, who spent 444 days as a hostage of Iranian revolutionaries in 1979-80, finds his first duty after retirement from the State Department curiously reminiscent of part of his diplomatic career.
The former charge d'affaires in Teheran is spending much of his time at the department's career counseling center, which happens to be situated in Annex 20, the former Iranian Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue that was seized by the United States in retaliation for Iran's taking of the American Embassy.

Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Dennis Boyd, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to March 29.


Why Paid Parental Leave Makes Sense
LEAD: Should companies be required by law to allow parents up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newly born or seriously ill children?
As Congress prepares to vote on the Family and Medical Leave Act, opinion polls show that most Americans favor the idea.
With a majority of mothers in the workforce, including more than half of all new mothers, leaves of absence offer many parents a new opportunity to reach an old-fashioned goal: time with young children.

LEAD: ALICE TULLY HALL, which has a medium-sized seating capacity, looked only about two-thirds full for Sunday afternoon's duo piano concert by Katia and Marielle Labeque, whom this writer had always supposed to be deliriously popular.
Was the presence of Bartok on the program poison for their public?
Or have they perhaps been overexposed locally?

UMPIRES ACCEPT CONTRACT
LEAD: Major league umpires were on the job yesterday, working for about 25 percent more money than they earned on opening day last year.
The pay increase - and their presence on the field - resulted from an all-night negotiating session that produced an agreement two hours before the first scheduled game.


JAGUAR'S U.S. SALES FALL
LEAD: Juguar P.L.C. said today that its United States car sales in March came to 1,545, down 21.5 percent from 1.968 a year earlier.
But the company said it expected sales of the luxury cars in the United States to climb as part of a 10 percent to 15 percent rise in global sales this year.


CALIFORNIA STUDIES DATA ON PRISONS
LEAD: As California struggles to relieve crowding in its prisons, a study by the State Attorney General's office found that more than one of every three young men in California was arrested at least once from 1974 through 1985.

LEAD: Relief supplies were allowed into the Palestinian district of Shatila in southern Beirut today, the first big shipment since the siege of the area by Shiite Moslem militiamen began five months ago.

LEAD: Striking nurses picketed the American Red Cross in two counties today, idling bloodmobiles and seven of 10 donation centers.
The union and the nonprofit agency disagreed about how long blood supplies would last.

LEAD: William Bowers, a screenwriter who received Academy Award nominations for his scripts for ''The Gunfighter'' (1950) and ''The Sheepman'' (1958), died of respiratory failure March 27 at the Woodland Hills Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Los Angeles.
He was 71 years old.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Is it possible to make fuel from old tires, and if so how?
A.
Several recycling companies have developed procedures for turning scrap tires into high-energy fuel for use in generating electricity.
For example, Waste Recovery Inc. of Dallas shreads worn out tires into small pieces about two inches square.


A Phone to Screen Calls
LEAD: The Sanyo Electric Company of Japan said today that it would market a telephone that can be instructed to accept calls only from certain numbers.
A Sanyo official, Shigehiko Masuda, said that when the ''selection'' system was turned on, callers reaching the phone would be asked to dial the last four digits of their own phone numbers.


MISSILE CAPABLE OF LINGERING OVER RADAR SITES IS UNVEILED
LEAD: A missile capable of circulating over enemy radar systems while waiting for the systems to send signals and thus reveal themselves was displayed for the first time today as the Northrop Corporation broke ground for a $100 million plant here that will build the weapons.

LEAD: A picture yesterday with a biographical sketch of Kim Young Sam, a critic of the South Korean Government, was published in error.

A second picture of Kim Dae Jung also appeared, correctly, with the sketch of him.

LEAD: Argonaut Group Inc., a property and casualty insurer that was spun off by Teledyne Inc. in November, said Clarendon Group Ltd. had made an unsolicited proposal to acquire it for $37 a share.

TEXACO SET BACK BY SUPREME COURT IN PENNZOIL CASE
LEAD: In a major setback to Texaco Inc.'s battle for survival, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Federal District Court should not have excused the company from posting a bond of more than $10 billion while it appealed a damage award that the Pennzoil Company won against Texaco in 1985.


Eleanor Burke Leacock, 64, A Professor of Anthropology
LEAD: Eleanor Burke Leacock, a professor of anthropology at City College of the City University of New York, died of a stroke Thursday at the Straub Medical Center Hospital in Honolulu.
She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Seoul to Trim 83 Tariffs
LEAD: South Korea, seeking to avoid more trade friction with the United States, will reduce tariffs on 83 manufactured and farm products by 5 to 20 percentage points July 1, the Finance Ministry said today.
The cuts average 6.6 points.
The products include television sets, home appliances, beer, lemons, newsprint and automobiles - but not trucks or buses.


Texaco Bonds Drop Sharply
LEAD: In the bond market, where worries about the Pennzoil Company's lawsuit had already reduced prices of the bonds of Texaco Inc., the Supreme Court ruling yesterday led to another sharp drop in Texaco issues.


Death Penalty Bill Vetoed
LEAD: Governor Cuomo announced today that he has vetoed legislation that would have restored the death penalty in New York.
Mr.
Cuomo, who vetoed the measure Friday, said that to bring back the electric chair would be to fight ''evil with evil.'' It is the 11th consecutive year that legislation to restore the death penalty in New York has been vetoed.


YANKEES WIN OPENER ON HENDERSON'S DOUBLE IN 10TH
LEAD: It almost seemed eerie, as if this was a game being played in the middle of September, not early April.
They could have been two teams huddled near first place, caught in the midst of a decisive and emotional stretch run.
But there was a persistent chill throughout the day, and the rain and storm clouds that had settled over the weekend refused to quietly fade away.


Sun Microsystems
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., a leading manufacturer of computer work stations based in Mountain View, Calif., has lowered the price of its entry-level model, the Sun-3/50M, to $4,995, from $7,900.
The move puts Sun more directly in competition with new personal computers for technical users, including those from Apple Computer Inc.


A.I.D. Head Is Expected To Get Treasury Post
LEAD: President Reagan will appoint M. Peter McPherson, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, to succeed Richard G. Darman as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Administration sources said yesterday.
An announcement is likely today, they said.


State Utility Write-Off
LEAD: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it expects to write off $294 million in the first quarter to reflect costs from two nuclear power plants.
As a result, the company said, it expects a loss for the quarter, in contrast to a profit a year earlier of $79.6 million.


CUTS BY JAPAN NOW SPUR FEARS OF CHIP SHORTAGE
LEAD: Japan's moves to cut the production of computer chips could lead to a shortage of the vital semiconductors, some computer and semiconductor industry executives said today.


Webster's Checkup
LEAD: Tom Webster, the Rangers' head coach, had a re-evaluation yesterday of the ear infection that has kept him from coaching full-time.
He was told that the infection still exists and he was given a new medication.
Webster will be examined again in two weeks, at which time the Rangers may be forced to make a decision regarding his future.

NOTES ON FASHION
LEAD: SCANT days after the end of the showings of European ready-to-wear collections for fall, lesser-known designers began to show their lines in New York.
The buyers and press who are invited to these early shows sometimes know very little about these designers, but curiosity is often rewarded.


PETER TAYLOR IS AWARDED RITZ-HEMINGWAY PRIZE
LEAD: Peter Taylor was named winner today of the Ritz-Hemingway award, one of the richest literary prizes in the world, for his novel ''A Summons to Memphis,'' a family drama set in the author's native Tennessee.


Market Place; The Significant First Half-Hour
LEAD: THE first half-hour of trading on the Big Board is of growing significance, because it captures the impact of a growing volume of orders from Japan and Europe.
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average marched onto new high ground in the 30 minutes after its 9:30 A.M. opening.

Satellites and Disease
LEAD: Orbiting satellites might seem a strange tool for predicting widespread outbreaks of a viral disease, but Federal scientists report evidence that the view from space can be valuable for just that purpose.


SILVER EXTENDS RALLY; LIVESTOCK AND MEAT UP
LEAD: Silver futures advanced yesterday, extending a rally that has raised prices nearly 20 percent in two weeks.
In contrast, gold futures declined.
Silver settled 13 cents to 15.2 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the May contract at $6.58 a troy ounce.
At one point, however, silver was up as much as 25 cents.

Chess: Ree Shows How to Destroy A King's Indian at Ter Apel
LEAD: The Klooster International Tournament in Ter Apel, the Netherlands, ended in a tie for first place among the Dutch grandmasters Hans Ree and John Van der Wiel and the West German grandmaster Eric Lobron.
Each scored 3 1/2-1 1/2 in the six-man round robin celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Ter Apel Chess Club.


16 CHARGED WITH ILLEGAL DUMPING
LEAD: W. Cary Edwards, the New Jersey Attorney General, announced indictments today against 16 individuals, including three former North Bergen township officials, and 11 trucking companies on charges of conspiring to illegally dump New York construction debris at several sites in New Jersey.

SPACE STATION IS STUDIED BY MILITARY
LEAD: THE Pentagon is eyeing NASA's proposed space station for a bevy of projects and missions that would propel the Department of Defense into a new era of space operations in the 21st century.
The military's vision, while offering a new source of political support for the embattled space agency, also promises to heat the simmering controversy over plans for a manned station in space.


NEUTRINOS: NEW VIEW INTO SPACE
LEAD: THE nearby explosion of a star and a lucky succession of scientific accidents are combining to create a new branch of astronomy, in which new instruments sensitive to streams of neutrino particles could serve as the counterparts of light-gathering telescopes.

Congress Talks Trade
LEAD: While President Reagan is engaged in international trade negotiations with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada in Ottawa, members of Congress are approaching the same question on a more limited basis.
For what is believed to be the first time, a dozen members of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition in the House will sit down this morning with a delegation from the Ontario Provincial Legislature to discuss trade on the state-to-province level.


TEXACO'S SUPPLIERS BEGINNING TO WORRY
LEAD: Some of Texaco's suppliers said today that they were growing increasingly concerned that the nation's third-largest oil company would seek protection from creditors in bankruptcy court.


Consolation Prize
LEAD: Three members of the Devils -Pat Verbeek and Kirk Muller, both forwards, and Bruce Driver, a defenseman - were named to the Team Canada roster for the World Hockey Championship tournament, which begins April 17 in Vienna.
Driver, however, has a sore shoulder and will need a checkup before it is determined whether he will be able to play.

LEAD: A Queens lawyer who has been described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes was sentenced yesterday to five years in Federal prison, given five more years on probation and ordered to pay nearly $413,500 in fines and restitution.

LEAD: Calm returned to the credit markets yesterday as bond prices rose modestly and short-term interest rates fell slightly.

Deere Job Cuts
LEAD: Deere &amp; Company announced it would reduce its work force by 6 percent, or up to 700 people.
The company said it would consolidate some agricultural sales branches and merge the administration of its component and tractor factories at Waterloo, Iowa.
The program will be coupled with early retirement incentives and is expected to be completed by the end of July.

LEAD: A federally required inspection of the bridge that collapsed Sunday morning on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway did not cover crucial underwater portions of the structure, state authorities said today.


TWO ACQUITTALS IN EXTORTION CASE
LEAD: A Federal jury today acquitted a City Councilman and his aide of three counts but deadlocked on 11 others in an indictment alleging that the men tried to extort $1 million from a riverfront developer.

LEAD: A discovery of natural gas in the Amazon region has increased.
Brazil's estimated reserves 61 percent, to 150 billion cubic meters, from 93 billion cubic meters, a spokesman for the state oil company, Petrobras, said today.
