Dow Average Over 2,400  The Dow Jones industrial average exceeded 2,400 for the first time, rising 15.20 points, to 2,405.54, after soaring nearly 70 points on Friday.


Aftermath of Storm in New Jersey
LEAD: Residents of Wayne using a boat to navigate a flooded street.
More than 350 people there were forced to leave homes over the weekend because of flooding from storm Saturday that dropped three inches of rain on northern New Jersey.
Governor Kean declared a limited state of emergency for the Passaic River basin, which includes parts of Passaic, Bergen and Morris Counties.


Bring Back the Stork
LEAD: Here are some money figures that have been in the news lately: $50 million - This is roughly the amount various bidders paid for the Duchess of Windsor's jewelry. $39.9 million - This is the sum paid for a Van Gogh sunflower by somebody who doesn't want to be identified. $11.75 million - This is the minimum payment guaranteed Marvin Hagler for appearing in a boxing match last night with Sugar Ray Leonard.

SALVADOR REBELS AT TOWN MEETING
LEAD: As thousands of Government troops swept northern El Salvador over the weekend seeking leftist rebels who destroyed one of the army's most important bases last week, the guerrillas themselves nonchalantly held a town meeting in this village just four miles from the devastated fort.


BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1987
LEAD:  Companies


Cable vs. Free: The Pastime Split
LEAD: Cable-less Yankee fans in the outer boroughs had cause to kick their sets anew yesterday, when the team's opener, no less, was televised locally only by SportsChannel.
The game was the first of 100 allocated by the Yankees to cable this year, in a reversal of the portioning the last two seasons, when cable got just 40 games and WPIX got 100.


BUDGET SNAG DELAYING $1.3 BILLION IN SCHOOL AID
LEAD: With no state budget in place six days after the deadline, the State Comptroller reported today that New York would not be able to meet on time $1.3 billion in payments to local school districts.


Delta-Western Merger Allowed
LEAD: The Supreme Court, rejecting an emergency request by a Western Airlines union, refused to interfere with the $860 million merger of Western and Delta Air Lines.
The court, without any recorded dissent, let stand an order issued last Wednesday by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that cleared the way for the merger.


Aquino Stops Moore in 5
LEAD: Lupe Aquino, a junior middleweight from Santa Paula, Calif., defeated Davey Moore of the Bronx tonight in a bout before the Sugar Ray Leonard-Marvelous Marvin Hagler fight.

LEAD: They came to pay tribute to the tall, lanky kid from Long Island who went on to change the way basketball is played, adding a brand of personal flash that has spawned an entire generation of acrobatic specialists.

THEATER: 'DAY SIX,' TWO-CHARACTER DRAMA
LEAD: IN the first minutes of Martin Halpern's play ''Day Six,'' Len Cariou unleashes an oratorical torrent in which the actor-singer's musical and dramatic skills fuse into a moment of thunderous intensity.
Improvising an inspirational tirade on the sin of pride, he condemns ''proud blaspheming cynics,'' who he warns are joining sides with Satan.


More Layoffs Set by G.M.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would temporarily lay off more than 6,200 workers as it converts assembly plants to make new models and adjusts its production to meet slumping auto sales.

LEAD: The Army is setting up a program with a toll-free telephone number that is intended to help catch spies, discover possible security risks and train soldiers to identify both, Army officials said today.

The budget, according to the agency, will be from $2 million to $3 million.


Police Dismiss Officer Who Shot Man Dead
LEAD: A police officer who fatally shot a man on a Bronx subway platform two years ago and who was acquitted last year of criminally negligent homicide in a jury trial, was dismissed from the force yesterday because of the shooting.

Snelling Declines Senate Bid
LEAD: Former Gov.
Richard Snelling said today he does not plan to be a candidate for the United States Senate next year.
Mr.
Snelling, the Republican Senate nominee last year in the unsuccessful effort to defeat Patrick Leahy, a Democrat, announced his decision in a letter to friends and supporters.
He had indicated after his 1986 defeat that he might run again in 1988 if Senator Robert Stafford, a Republican, retired.

WRITING STUDIES: BEYOND MECHANICS

LEAD: Dr.
C.
Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, said today that AIDS is a growing menace to the nation's children and reiterated his call for early sex education as part of the general effort to halt its spread.


Cannon Will Sell Home Video Stake
LEAD: The Cannon Group said it would sell its 50 percent interest in HBO/ Cannon Home Video to Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, its partner in the venture.
Analysts said the deal, valued at $20 million, would give the financially troubled Cannon enough capital to continue its curtailed production schedule.

LEAD: Mack McCarthy, basketball coach at Tennessee-Chattanooga, on the 92-73 loss to Cleveland State in this year's National Invitation Tournament: ''I knew we were in trouble when they showed up and even their cheerleaders had knee braces on.''

LEAD: Japanese Communists, searching in the Library of Congress here, have uncovered documentary evidence of a secret agreement that permits the United States to take nuclear arms into Japan.


Marchers in East Jerusalem Back Inmates' Hunger Strike
LEAD: Protesters marched through East Jerusalem today in support of a hunger strike by Palestinian prison inmates.

LEAD: *

USX-Armco Unit
LEAD: The USX Corporation and Armco Inc. have merged their oilfield-equipment divisions, after failing to find buyers for the businesses last year.
Armco said a new company, National-Oilwell, was being formed from Armco's National Supply Company and USX's Oilwell division.
Its headquarters will be in Houston.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in the Business People column yesterday listed one company erroneously among those that are leaders in vision care.
The SmithKline Beckman Corporation's Allergan unit belongs in the group, but not Becton, Dickinson &amp; Company.

LEAD: Albert H. Newman, a war correspondent, magazine editor and author, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Grand Strand Hospital in Myrtle Beach, S.C.

Boeing Jet Order
LEAD: British Airways has ordered two new Boeing 757 aircraft for $68 million.
The planes, to be delivered in about a year, are in addition to four jets, scheduled for delivery between September 1987 and March 1988, that the airline previously ordered.
The 757's will be powered by Rolls-Royce PLC RB211 engines, the company said.


JEWLERY MIRRORS ITS DESIGNER
LEAD: As the son of an Air Force officer, Robert Lee Morris traveled a circuitous path through childhood, growing up in such exotic lands as Brazil and Japan.
It was in the latter country that his artistic inclination first flowered, when he studied floral arranging - not an interest calculated to appeal to a father in the military.


Pitcher's Gallery
LEAD: Much like the most ardent of fans, a number of major league players collect baseball bubble-gum cards themselves.
The cards are generally tacked or taped to the player's dressing stall, and each usually has a special meaning to the collector.

Tektronix to Buy Estate's Shares
LEAD: Tektronix Inc., a manufacturer of electronic measurement and test equipment based in Beaverton, Ore., said it had agreed to buy about 2.1 million shares of its common stock from the beneficiaries of Howard Vollum, a company founder who died in February.
The price is $35.875 a share, or about $75 million.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he had ''agreed to consider'' a proposal by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that Canada and the United States negotiate a ''bilateral accord'' controlling acid rain.

Postage Going Up
LEAD: To the Editor:


Johncock Coming Back
LEAD: Gordon Johncock, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner who retired in 1985, will attempt a comeback in this year's race, officials at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced yesterday.
Johncock, 50 years old, will drive a March-Cosworth entered by Gold Racing of Lincoln, Neb., for the May 24 race.
He last drove at Indy in 1984, when he finished 25th after a crash on the front straightaway.


Careers; Summer Jobs: Many Sources
LEAD: THE search for summer jobs has begun.
The International Business Machines Corporation recently helped start Summer Jobs '87, the New York City area's seventh annual program, as this year's corporate sponsor.

Pension Fund Help Is Asked
LEAD: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today to make ailing Rust Belt industries that raid their pension funds pay annual premiums of up to $150 per worker to insure monthly benefits for millions of retirees.


Taco Bell Raises Its Stake in Calny
LEAD: The Taco Bell Corporation, a fast-food subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., has raised its stake in Calny Inc. to 14.6 percent, from 9.9 percent.
Calny, which has 145 Taco Bell restaurants and is the chain's largest franchiser, recently rejected an $11.50-a-share, $49 million takeover bid from Taco Bell.


Citicorp Recruits Mergers Director
LEAD: Citicorp, pushing hard to become a major force in the mergers and acquisitions field, said yesterday that its investment bank had hired Gordon R. Wolf, an executive who most recently was responsible for identifying takeover targets for an investment firm owned by the Belzberg family.


2 HURT IN SHAFT FALL AT THE HOLLAND
LEAD: A man and a woman were seriously injured when they accidentally fell eight floors down a freight elevator shaft in a Times Square welfare hotel last night, the police said.


Jean-Baptiste Doumeng, 68, Wealthy French Communist
LEAD: Jean-Baptiste Doumeng, a businessman who has been called France's wealthiest Communist, died last night at his home in Noe near Toulouse, his company reported today.
He was 68 years old.


Wright Takes His Leadership by the Horns
LEAD: Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House of Representatives, enjoys going out on a limb.


Petrofina Price Inquiry Ended
LEAD: The Energy Department in Washington has quit seeking a fine of $841 million from American Petrofina Inc. over alleged violations of oil price control regulations, Petrofina S.A. said today.


BOOM TIME IN SOUTH KOREA: AN ERA OF DIZZYING CHANGE
LEAD: For Chong Yong Hi, a 35-year-old housewife, her country's phenomenal economic growth means an apartment of her own after years of scrimping and living five to a room.

LEAD: A Government prosecutor yesterday asked a Federal jury to convict Jay L. Turoff, the former chairman of the city Taxi and Limousine Commission, and three co-defendants, charging that they conspired to commit fraud against the people of New York City in a ''greedy'' and ''arrogant abuse of power.''


U.S. LEGISLATORS INSPECT EMBASSY IN MOSCOW
LEAD: A United States Congressman said today that he and a colleague had made an unannounced night inspection of the American Embassy here and that Soviet agents had ''fully compromised'' it.
He said it would cost tens of millions of dollars to make it secure again.





2 Lost From U.S. Navy Sub
LEAD: Two sailors were swept from the deck of the Navy submarine Ulysses S. Grant in rough weather today.
One man was pronounced dead at a hospital 90 minutes after being plucked from the ocean by a Coast Guard utility boat.
Rescuers briefly sighted the second man, but he disappeared.
Ruth Dow, a spokeswoman for the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here, said neither sailor's name would be released until their families were notified.

New York's Competitive Edge
LEAD: Albany's discussions on how to forgo the bonanza expected from a change in Federal tax law now bear fruit: a long-term plan to reduce state income taxes.
The plan was inspired by a desire to make the state more competitive with its neighbors in keeping and wooing business.
It's a constructive compromise, but improving competitiveness does not depend on low taxes alone.

LEAD: The Giants may be pro football's Super Bowl champions, but Coach Bill Parcells warned yesterday that some players who started last season might not start next season.

FOR PASSOVER, ADVENTURES IN GEFILTE FISH
LEAD: THERE'S more than one way to stuff a fish - a gefilte fish, that is.
Often the first course for Jewish holiday dinners, especially the Passover seder, gefilte fish means ''stuffed fish.'' Today, it is the stuffing alone that we know as gefilte fish, but that stuffing can go far beyond the traditional round dumpling-in-gelatin form that is so familiar.

LEAD: A $2.2 billion hostile takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. ended yesterday, three weeks after it began, with the bidding group at least $75 million richer.

LEAD:  International A3-18


A Former Official of Turkey Is Given 11 Years in Prison
LEAD: A Turkish military court today sentenced former Deputy Prime Minister Alpaslan Turkes to 11 years in prison on charges of forming an armed gang, officials said.
Five supporters were reported sentenced to death for murder.

LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc. said yesterday that Allan R. Fields had resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer of its Madison Square Garden Corporation subsidiary.


Boston Museum Picks Chief
LEAD: Alan Shestack, the director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts for only 20 months, has been named director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.
He replaces Jan Fontein, who will retire after serving as Boston's director for 12 years.
Mr.
Shestack, a specialist in northern European graphic arts of the late Gothic and Renaissance periods, was director of the Yale University Art

LEAD: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned today of ''substantial risks'' to the American economy, including recession, if the United States relied on further depreciation of the dollar to redress its trade deficit.


BUSINESSMEN AS HEAVIES
LEAD: BUSINESSMEN are not nice on television; they lie, steal and murder.
A businessman (consider it a nonsexist, generic word) is ''Hollywood's Favorite Heavy,'' which is the title of the documentary on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.
Watch it; it is juicy and provocative.

LEAD: ''WE drive because we love our freedom,'' Sylvia Leisengang, who is 70 years old, told her class of 40 students, all in their 50's or older.

LEAD: South Korea's main opposition party virtually collapsed today as its two dominant figures broke away and formed a new political party.

Arrests Made in Long Island Drug Ring
LEAD: Federal agents taking custody of suspects yesterday at a state police office in Farmingdale, L.I.
Twenty people were arrested in early morning raids yesterday on Long Island in the culmination of a seven-month joint Federal and state investigation.
A Federal spokesman said those arrested had imported about 500 pounds of cocaine in the past month, with a wholesale value of $7 million.

A BUILDING BLOCK OFF THE OLD CHIP
LEAD: Silicon atoms, the foundation of today's computer industry, have been captured on film for the first time by photographers and researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
The atoms, magnified a billion times, appear as ''hills'' on a silicon crystal.
This photograph, made with a scanning tunneling microscope, is among 50 that make up a collection called ''Micro Scapes: The Hidden Art of High Technology,'' now on display in the Market at the Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street at Lexington Avenue.

LEAD: Bond prices declined sharply yesterday as the specter of a weaker dollar continued to weigh heavily on the minds of investors and speculators.

Conrail Loses on Arbitration
LEAD: A Federal district judge today rejected Conrail's petition for binding arbitration of its dispute with Amtrak over liability arising from the Jan. 4 train crash that killed 16 people and injured 175.
The judge, Oliver Gasch, said the courts, not an arbitration panel, should decide who was responsible for paying damage claims arising from the crash, which occurred after the crew of a Conrail freight engine ignored a series of traffic signals.

Austrian Privatization
LEAD: The Austrian state oil company OeMV A.G. said today that 20 percent of its shares would be sold to the public this fall, making it the first large candidate to be taken private under a Government plan to reduce the large number of nationalized businesses.
OeMV's general director, Herbert Kaes, told a news conference that half of the 20 percent stake would be sold on the Vienna Bourse and the rest through financial institutions abroad.

THE MAN AND THE IMAGE IN 'LONDON JOHNSON'
LEAD: THERE'S a ''television theory'' about Lyndon Baines Johnson.
Instead of being his own bigger-than-life, irascible self on camera, the theory goes, he kept giving the public an earnest, soft-spoken statesman.
The image adjustment may have cost him an enormous amount of crucial support.
Television viewers might well have preferred a down-home Lyndon to the decidedly artificial Mr.

LEAD: CHEERS, bravos and thunderous applause greeted Calvin Klein as he walked down the runway in a gray double-breasted suit after the best fall collection shown on either side of the Atlantic.
It was brilliantly thought out and thoroughly modern, and it sported no extraneous detail.
Woven into a fresh composition were all the separate threads that contributed to the widely heralded change fashion is undergoing for the new season; the result was enchanting.

LEAD: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday misstated the number of senior executives of Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc. who have agreed to severance packages known as ''golden parachutes.'' Twenty would get such payments, of whom six would receive 2.99 times their ''base amount'' of salary and bonus.

LEAD: DO you suffer from depression, fatigue, memory lapses, skin disorders, headaches, irritability, hyperactivity, breathing difficulties, abdominal pain, prostatitis, menstrual problems, impotence, muscle or joint pain, vaginitis, urinary disorders, numbness, recurrent sore throats, heartburn, constipation or other digestive problems?

Angolans and U.S. Officials Confer on Cuban Withdrawal
LEAD: The State Department said today that senior United States and Angolan officials had met in Congo to discuss ways of breaking the impasse over the presence of Cuban troops in Angola.


ORGANIZING PAYS OFF AT FILOFAX
LEAD: The product has been around for three-quarters of a century and can lay claim to no proprietary technology.
A generous estimate of the cost to make it would probably be $30, yet the company has the cheek to charge Americans an average of $160 apiece for its product.


Meeting Is Set for Next Week To Pick Bronx Borough Chief
LEAD: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he would convene a meeting of City Council members from the Bronx next Wednesday to elect a borough president to succeed Stanley Simon.

West Virginia to Close Its Colleges for a Week
LEAD: The West Virginia Board of Regents ordered state colleges and universities today to close for a week and furlough all employees for five days to save $10 million, as ordered by the Governor.

Hinckley Said to Plan To Live With a Friend
LEAD: John W. Hinckley Jr. says he wants to live with a woman who once killed her sleeping daughter and is now ''the biggest influence in my life,'' according to court papers filed today.


KIRK DOUGLAS HONORED WITH GIBES AND PRAISE
LEAD: With affectionate gibes and exuberant praise, colleagues and other admirers of Kirk Douglas gathered at the Majestic Theater on Broadway on Monday night as the American Academy of Dramatic Arts honored the man and his career of nearly 50 years as an actor, producer and director.


Know Your Cholesterol
LEAD: Those people walking around Captiol Hill this week with paper hearts on their lapels are not tardy celebrants of Valentine's Day.


Why Duck the Califano Commission?
LEAD: Without making a move, Governor Cuomo's Commission on Government Integrity has done wonders in Albany.
It has caused a usually tone-deaf Legislature to hear cries for reform and even rush to pass an ethics bill similar to one requested by the Governor.
And now the commission has caused the legislative leaders to bend themselves out of shape trying to avoid its scrutiny.


CHICAGO RE-ELECTS WASHINGTON AS MAYOR
LEAD: Mayor Harold Washington, attracting considerably more support among white voters than his main challenger could win among blacks, won re-election here today.


FIGHTING ACID RAIN: THE NEW RESEARCH
LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN's promises this week in Canada and his pledge last month to seek $2.5 billion for the development of commercial technologies to combat acid rain have generated a wave of excitement among researchers.


New York Open Chess Tournament Begins
LEAD: Boris Spassky, left, with Lev Alburt before the opening matches yesterday at the Penta Hotel.
Mr.
Spassky, a former world champion, was one of more than 50 grandmasters who were to take part in the international section of the tournament.
About 1,200 players are expected to take part in the various competitions, which have total purses of $60,000.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Deep down inside, it takes a lot out of you not seeing number 16 on the mound.
It was frustrating.
It makes you wonder about life in general.''  Darryl Strawberry,  speaking of Dwight Gooden.  [ B10:3. ]


A Job Can Be a Home
LEAD: Homelessness is often a function of joblessness.
That's why, after considerable prodding, New York City's Department of Employment last year began trying to place homeless men in permanent jobs.
Now the agency deserves credit for a small success.


Halas Gets Lion Bid
LEAD: Wally Halas, who took Clark University of Worcester, Mass., to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament this season, has been offered the job as Columbia's head basketball coach.
Halas, a grandnephew of the late Chicago Bears' owner, George Halas, was selected from a group of eight on the final list to replace Wayne Szoke, who resigned a week after the season to become head coach at Monmouth College in New Jersey.


TWO UPSTATE WINERIES ARE EXPECTED TO MERGE
LEAD: GLENORA WINE CELLARS in Dundee, N.Y., and Finger Lakes Wine Cellars in nearby Branchport, boutique wineries with reputations for premium wines, are expected to announce today that they are merging, a move they hope will increase their marketing power.


Hanover Buys Building
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that its OFP Inc. subsidiary had acquired a Dallas building, Allied Bank Tower, through foreclosure.
The building, with 1.2 million square feet of space, was owned by William and Sharon Criswell.


Alzheimer Services Criticized
LEAD: Medical and social services for victims of Alzheimer's disease and their families are disorganized, incomplete and often not available, says a Congressional study made public today.


MUBARAK PARTY WINS IN EGYPT'S VOTE
LEAD: The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak retained its overwhelming control of the Egyptian legislature in elections Monday, but an alliance including Moslem fundamentalists established itself as the most powerful opposition party, according to preliminary results disclosed today.

THEATER: 'CRACKWALKER,' CANADIAN URBAN DRAMA
LEAD: JUDITH THOMPSON'S ''Crackwalker'' (at the Hudson Guild Theater) is an excessively bleak urban drama about two married couples who are down and almost out in a city in Canada.
This new Canadian play is a heavy storm cloud.
When a mentally retarded young woman (Elizabeth Berridge) stops at the end of the play and accuses the other characters of not knowing her, her words have an echo.

Compulsive Eating
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Buddhist Leader Dies; Started Centers in U.S.
LEAD: Chogyam Trungpa Rinpoche, the Buddhist leader who founded the Naropa Institute in Boulder, Colo., died Saturday at a hospital in Halifax, Nova Scotia, of cardiac arrest and respiratory failure, officials said.
He was 47 years old.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.B.A.
Cavaliers 107, Celtics 83: Ron Harper scored 30 points, and the Cleveland defense limited Boston to its lowest output of the season last night as the Cavaliers handed the Celtics their eighth loss in the last nine road games.
Boston, whose starting center, Robert Parish, missed the game because of a sore elbow, led by 69-68 after Larry Bird made a driving layup with about two minutes to play in the third quarter.


Live, From Secaucus: It's NBC!
LEAD: Any day now, NBC could transmit a devastating signal to the City of New York: an announcement that it is moving out.
The move might only be across the Hudson to northern New Jersey, thus inflicting no loss on the economy of the region.
Nonetheless, NBC's departure would send a shiver through a city tied to communications, entertainment, financial services and tourism.


15 Writers to Receive Arts and Letters Prizes
LEAD: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has named 15 poets and writers to receive the organization's annual literary awards, the chairman of the awards committee, Irving Howe, announced yesterday.


HOUSE RUNOFF SEEMS LIKELY IN WEST
LEAD: Nancy Pelosi, a former state Democratic Party chairman, led Supervisor Harry Britt, a leader among homosexuals here, as votes were counted tonight in a special election to fill the unexpired term of the late Representative Sala Burton.


Todd Shipyards In Loan Talks
LEAD: Todd Shipyards Inc. said its banks have agreed to negotiate the terms of its existing loans.
The company said it requested the changes to insure that credit remains available.
Todd recently reported a loss, which could result in a breach of the loan contracts under their current terms.


OPERA: FIRST 'PARSIFAL' OF THE SEASON AT THE MET
LEAD: NO one has ever described the contradictory genius of Richard Wagner more clearly than Thomas Mann, who late in life summed up his love of Wagner's music as a ''love devoid of belief.'' Mann's description of the characters who inhabit ''Parsifal'' as ''an assemblage of extreme and repellent oddities'' is, if anything, an understatement.


The U.N. Today: April 8, 1987
LEAD:  SECURITY COUNCIL


Mets' Opener Brings Back Glory of '86
LEAD: Up on the message board, it was happening all over again: Len Dykstra leaping, Mookie Wilson levitating, Bill Buckner groping, Jesse Orosco kneeling.


About New York; Where the Deals Are a Side Order With the Kasha
LEAD: In the V.I.P. area of ''the Polish Tea Room,'' select customers are pampered with plastic placemats and, sometimes, they do not even have to ask for ketchup because the bottles are already on the tables.


Xerox Venture
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation and E.I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company said they plan to form a joint venture to develop and manufacture electronic imaging products.
The new firm, called DX Imaging, would combine the existing technology of both companies.
The companies said they had already invested a total of $80 million in this technology and expect to invest another $40 million in 1987 to support the joint venture.


JAPAN TRIES POLICY SHIFT ON GROWTH
LEAD: In a move that could signal a major shift away from this nation's tight-spending policies, Japan's ruling party today outlined a $34 billion plan to stimulate the economy and ease trade frictions with the United States.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL  The Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, warned of recession and other ''substantial risks'' to the economy if the U.S. relied on a further fall in the dollar to trim its record trade deficit.
Instead, he said, the U.S. should cut its budget deficit.
Mr.
Volcker's remarks were seen by some analysts as an attempt to focus attention on American shortcomings and thus to minimize the chances of a trade war.


C. H. Butcher Pleads Guilty
LEAD: C. H. Butcher Jr., the financier, ended his five-week-old bankruptcy fraud trial today by pleading guilty to conspiracy and banktruptcy fraud charges stemming from the collapse of his banking empire.


Friends of Poindexter And North Raise Funds
LEAD: It will be another month at least before the public hears from Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North and Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter about their roles in the Iran-contra affair.


Death of Tampa Black Evokes New Violence
LEAD: Dozens of youths pelted cars with stones and bottles in a predominantly black neighborhood Monday night, hours after the police announced the fourth death of a black man involving white officers since November.


COLLARS OF LACE ADD DASH
LEAD:  1.Neck Lace Lace collars will be sprouting in the spring.
This one, for $17, is part of a collection of pretty collars that can give a brand-new look to dresses or sweaters you have been wearing for ages.
They are in the accessories department on the main floor at A&amp;S, 420 Fulton Street, at Hoyt Street, Brooklyn, and in some branch stores.

Investment Banker Joins Hutton Finance Group
LEAD: Kendrick R. Wilson 3d, an investment banker who advised the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. when it was nearly sold to the American Express Company last year, has been hired to head Hutton's corporate finance department.


In the Midst of His Creation
LEAD: James Bassler, bottom, setting up his work, ''Charlatan's Web,'' with the aid of Clifford LeCuyer at the new American Craft Museum at 40 West 53d Street.
The work, which is 60 feet tall, is made of plastic-coated white cardboard of the type used to make milk cartons.
The museum opens Saturday. (NYT/Jack


SENATOR DURENBERGER STIRS NEW CONCERN WITH OUTSPOKENNESS
LEAD: In a city where there is no shortage of circumlocution and obfuscation, Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota has occasionally shocked his Senate colleagues with remarkably blunt talk, even about his personal life.


Club Leader Won't Testify at His Murder Trial
LEAD: Attorneys for Joe Hunt, founder of a group of young investors calling themselves the Billionaire Boys Club, have rested their case in his murder trial without calling him as a witness.

LEAD: TEXASVILLE. By Larry McMurtry. 542 pages. Simon &amp; Schuster. $18.95.


PRESIDENT ORDERS INQUIRY IN MOSCOW INTO EMBASSY SITE
LEAD: President Reagan ordered his intelligence review board today to determine whether a new embassy building in Moscow had been so compromised by Soviet eavesdropping devices that it must be demolished and rebuilt.


WINE TALK
LEAD: BROOKLYN, like Bordeaux, is wine country.
Stephan Siciliano can prove it.
He is cellar master of Sunset Hills Vineyards, a home winery only three minutes from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
First, he treats you to the panoramic sweep of his backyard vines - both of them.
Next, as at any chateau, you tour the winery; here it is reached by going down the basement stairs and turning left at the clothesline.


Korea on the Brink
LEAD: South Korea is at once experiencing economic takeoff, wrenching political transition and continued military tension with North Korea.
This may be, as made clear by the series of Times articles concluding today, the most critical year in its modern history.
The United States, with a significant stake in the outcome, would be wise to resist the illusory temptation to engage in long-distance management and to use its good offices to encourage


Apple Shifts Managers
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. today announced management changes that the company said would ''broaden the breadth and depth of Apple's executive leadership.''

STUDY SAYS PAC'S PLAY GROWING ELECTION ROLE
LEAD: Political action committees are playing a growing role in financing elections and accounted for more than one-third of the $227 million collected by candidates for the House of Representatives last year, according to a study released today.


Stadium Strike Looms
LEAD: The union representing the Yankee Stadium grounds crew voted yesterday to authorize a strike that could begin as early as Monday, when the Yankees face the Cleveland Indians in their home opener.
Howard Chaiken, president of Local 54 of the Service Employees Union, said there had been no progress in contract talks with Ogden Allied Services, the contractor at the stadium.

LEAD: ''THE MAKE-BELIEVE BALLROOM,'' the radio program on WNEW-AM that has been a bellwether of mainstream, traditional pop music for half a century, from its beginnings with Martin Block to the curatorship of the late William B. Williams, may be in for a change of emphasis under its new host, Steve Allen.


SYRIANS ENDING SIEGE IN A BEIRUT DISTRICT
LEAD: Syrian troops moved into a Palestinian refugee district in southern Beirut today, ending a five-month siege by Shiite Moslem militiamen.

AVON PRODUCTS TO ACQUIRE GIORGIO
LEAD: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $185 million to buy Giorgio Inc., the Beverly Hills, Calif., company that turned a single overpowering fragrance into a $100 million-a-year business.

Bridge: Roy Welland of Manhattan Is Nation's Leading Beginner
LEAD: Each year the American Contract Bridge League uses its master-point records to identify the country's most successful beginner.
The Rookie of the Year title goes to the player who begins a calendar year with fewer than five master points and has the best record at the end of the year.


SOVIET AIDS CAMPAIGN DENOUNCED
LEAD: The Soviet Union has begun a campaign aimed at convincing the world that the AIDS virus originated in an American military laboratory, American officials assert.


McDonnell
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it received nine down payments of unspecified amounts to reserve future launching dates for commercial satellites on its Delta II medium-launch vehicle.
McDonnell said it would begin launching satellites for commercial customers in late 1988 or early 1989 and would have the capacity to launch up to 12 commercial satellites a year in the early 1990's.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: SERVING freshly cooked warm or hot preparations on a bed of cold salad greens is a fairly recent practice in the United States, borrowed perhaps from Asian cuisines.
Yet it has quickly established itself in restaurants and now home kitchens.
In America and France, the combinations take many forms: roast breast of duck, for example, or sweetbreads or even preserved goose, confit d'oie.

Dollar, at Low in Tokyo, Is Little Changed in U.S.
LEAD: The dollar was basically unchanged in late trading in the United States yesterday after falling in Tokyo to a new 40-year low against the Japanese yen.
The dollar traded in New York at 145.59 yen.


Questionnaire Used In Genovese Trial
LEAD: A questionnaire that asked prospective jurors their views of the Mafia was used in jury selection yesterday for the racketeering trial of a convicted Mafia boss, Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, and 11 co-defendants.


PENTAGON SECRETLY PREPARES PLAN FOR MISSILE DEFENSE IN MID-1990'S
LEAD: The Pentagon is secretly preparing a detailed plan showing how defenses against nuclear missiles could be deployed in space in the mid-1990's, two Senators who oppose the plan disclosed today.

EXPLORING THE WORLDS OF FIVE LATIN WRITERS
LEAD: ''SMITHSONIAN WORLD'' explores tonight the worlds of five Latin-American writers.
Call it audacious.
Can you translate the words and thoughts of a 17th-century Mexican nun, for example, into visual images?
It's hard, and ''Smithsonian World'' can't always quite make it.
When the program succeeds, however, it's gorgeous.

TAKEOVER TALK LIFTS UAL STOCK
LEAD: Shares of UAL Inc. soared $6.25, to $72, yesterday amid intense speculation that a takeover of the company that owns United Airlines could be in the making.


Gasoline Contracts Sag Amid Growing Supplies
LEAD: Gasoline futures fell sharply and other energy futures also retreated yesterday on indications that supplies of refined products were far outpacing demand.


TEXACO'S TOP OFFICERS GATHER
LEAD: Texaco Inc.'s top executives huddled with lawyers and financial advisers in Houston today, reviewing legal positions, including a potential bankruptcy, according to people close to the embattled oil giant.


Septien Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of indecency with a child in an agreement with prosecutors that brought him a sentence of 10 years' deferred probation and a $2,000 fine.

LEAD: J. P. Morgan &amp; Company, the nation's fourth-largest bank holding company, said yesterday that its net income in the first quarter had dipped 3.2 percent from a year ago - a somewhat smaller decline than analysts had been expecting.

INVESTIGATORS SAY GROUP RAISED $2 MILLION FOR CONTRA ARMS AID
LEAD: A conservative, tax-exempt organization raised at least $2.28 million in an operation that Congressional investigators say was apparently intended to buy arms for the Nicaraguan rebels.
The group says the funds were used to buy Christmas gifts for the rebels' children.


Woman and Girl Slain In a Queens Apartment
LEAD: Three people were shot, two fatally, in a Bayside, Queens, apartment last night where the police found paraphernalia for making illegal drugs, the authorities said.


Bakker Case Decided By Church Leadership
LEAD: The leadership of the Assemblies of God in North Carolina emerged from a 10-hour closed meeting early today saying it had reached a decision on the resignation of the Rev.
Jim Bakker and a chief aide.


MUSIC: A . LEROY'S SONGS
LEAD: THE compositions A. Leroy presented on Monday, in the first of four performances at Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, took an ironic, out-of-kilter look at some American stereotypes. ''Move To,'' for wind instruments and percussion, lurched along like an inebriated marching band.
The trumpets, trombones, reeds and flutes blew heraldic fragments that neither developed into fanfares nor resolved harmonically, while bass drum and cymbals crashed on off-beats.


NEW SUPERCONDUCTORS OFFER CHANCE TO DO THE IMPOSSIBLE
LEAD: American industry is embarking on a frantic competition to turn a few gray-black chunks of ceramic into impossibly efficient electric transmission lines, impossibly small computers and impossibly fast levitating trains.


Dole Still Smarting
LEAD: When Senator Bob Dole, the sometimes sharp-tongued minority leader, went to New York City on Monday to speak at Columbia University's Business School, he was evidently still smarting from the Senate's override last week of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill.


Vandals at Lincoln's Tomb
LEAD: Five teen-agers who told the police they acted out of boredom have been arrested here for spray-painting racist slogans and symbols on Lincoln's Tomb, the police said.
Three 16-year-old boys and two 15-year-old girls were charged Tuesday night in the vandalism.
Their names were not released.
The vandals also knocked over about 30 tombstones, the police said.


POOL TABLE HOSPITAL
LEAD: YOUR family doctor may not make house calls, but if the family pool table is in need of repair - if the billiard cloth is frayed, the leather pockets ripped or the ball-return system broken -Blatt Billiards will send one of its four two-person crews to your home to fix whatever is needed.


RANGERS 3 FLYERS 0
LEAD: Psst.
Remember those Rangers who stunned the Flyers and a lot of other people a year ago?
It seems they are back.


DOW, IN REBOUND, ADVANCES BY 11.22
LEAD: A stronger dollar and a mild improvement in Treasury bond prices combined to lift the Dow Jones industrial average 11.22 points, to 2,372.16 yesterday, one day after its fifth-worst decline ever.


KEAN FAULTED ON HELICOPTER PURCHASE
LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee said today that the Kean administration had bought a $4.3 million helicopter for the Governor by disguising it as a medivac helicopter and by transferring money from one state account to another to avoid alerting the Legislature.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: FOR years home painters -amateurs and professionals alike - have used paint rollers to coat walls, ceilings, floors and exterior siding.
But pressure-fed paint rollers have recently come on the market, fed with a constant supply of paint.


QUEENS JAIL ESCAPEE IS CAUGHT
LEAD: One of three inmates of the Queens House of Detention for Men who staged a spectacular escape through a ventilation duct on March 1 was apprehended Tuesday evening in an apartment in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, the police reported yesterday.


LEGISLATIVE ACCORD EMERGING ON STATE'S $7.2 BILLION SCHOOL BUDGET
LEAD: State legislative leaders neared agreement late today on more than $7.2 billion in spending for public schools, a step that could clear the way for an overall accord on a new state budget as early as Thursday morning.


U.S. THEORY IS THAT FLOOD CAUSED THRUWAY BRIDGE'S FOOTING TO SHIFT
LEAD: The swirling floodwaters of the Schoharie Creek may have dislodged gravel and silt around the footings of a bridge on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, causing the center to collapse Sunday, Federal authorities said today.


Plea to Protect Baldness Drug
LEAD: The Upjohn Company, trying to protect its exclusive rights to sell minoxidil for treatment of baldness, asked Federal regulators today to halt imports of the drug by 20 companies in the United States and six other countries.


WHALERS PREVAIL IN OVERTIME, 3-2
LEAD: Paul MacDermid tipped in a shot by Randy Ladouceur at 2 minutes 20 seconds of overtime as the Hartford Whalers came back from a two-goal deficit to beat the Quebec Nordiques, 3-2, in a fight-marred Adams Division playoff opener tonight.


Rolls Jet Unit's Sales Rules Set
LEAD: The British Government, giving the details of its previously announced plan to sell the state-owned Rolls-Royce Ltd. to the public next month, said today that each investor would have to buy a minimum of 400 shares.
The price will depend on market conditions.

LEAD: The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners yesterday revoked the license of Dr.
E.
Wyman Garrett, a Newark obstetrician-gynecologist and former Newark school board member.

The Worm and the Apple: Walks of Life; Escalation
LEAD: The Day-Glo green sticker looks ugly, and that's the point.
It's the New York City Sanitation Department's newest weapon against parking violators.
Department agents plaster the stickers on the windows of cars that block the routes of its mechanical brooms.
The hope is that humiliation and the annoyance of scraping off the stickers will deter violators where ticketing fails.

LEAD: Italy's Government coalition collapsed today, and the caretaker Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, is expected to resign Thursday.

The waves, gulls and white beach overwhelm sleazier man-made vistas.
Now the boardwalk, newly redone, brightens the scene, thanks to a 12-year rebuilding program that's almost finished.

LEAD: Canadian Airlines International has agreed to buy six advanced-technology Boeing 767-300ER airplanes and take options on eight additional planes for more than $1.6 billion, the company said.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. A roof leak caused a 12-inch corner of our bathroom wall and the wallpaper to swell and bubble out.
The leak has been repaired but the wallpaper remains puffed out.
Can we repair it?
A.
Usually even after the wall has dried, the gypsum board (if it is drywall) or the plaster has to be replaced, so the ''bubble'' might be part of the wall.

LEAD: Scientists reported yesterday that widespread, advanced cancers disappeared completely in nine patients after experimental treatments with interleukin-2, a drug whose promise has been the subject of intense interest and controversy.

PIANO: RUDOLF SERKIN IN BEETHOVEN PROGRAM
LEAD: RUDOLF SERKIN playing Beethoven's last three piano sonatas is like a diver who finds with experience that he can drop deeper and deeper, always finding new levels that would be inaccessible to the young, no matter how brave.
At age 84, Mr.
Serkin knows where the dangerous reefs and coral beds lie in these mighty works, and he does not so much avoid them as dare them to block his descent into the depths.

Profit Up 7.9% at Dow Jones
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company, which publishes The Wall Street Journal and Barron's, a weekly financial newspaper, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 7.9 percent, to $66.7 million, or 69 cents a share, from $61.8 million, or 64 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenue rose 10 percent, to $285.6 million, from $259.7 million.

Office workers, by the hundreds, had apparently made quick and complete recoveries from the disease that kept them away from their desks on Monday afternoon.
The Yankees went on with the business of their season, away from opening-day pomp but into the trying circumstance that is expected to create problems all summer.


Big 3 Car Makers Extend Incentives
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it had extended its buyer incentive program on light trucks to April 30 from April 6, the program's previous expiration date.
Under the program, customers have a choice of 3.9 to 9.9 annual percentage rate financing or a cash rebate of $300 or $600, depending on the type of transmission chosen.

LEAD: If Texaco Inc., which is fighting a multibillion-dollar legal battle with the Pennzoil Company, were to file for bankruptcy protection, it would be the largest company ever to do so.
The action could impede Texaco's ability to operate and could cause hardship for creditors, customers and shareholders, bankruptcy experts and analysts said yesterday.

LEAD: An official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration conceded today that taxpayers would spend about $20 billion for the first phase of the space station, or one and a half times what it was to have cost under a plan approved only last week by President Reagan.

LEAD: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would propose legislation that would dramatically alter the corporate takeover process by requiring would-be investors to disclose their intent to purchase more than 3 percent of a company's shares before they made the purchase.

LEAD: New York City's police and transportation departments deserve a bushel of apples for improving the mortality of every pedestrian.

LEAD: When the International Business Machines Corporation merged the sales and service organization of its Rolm Corporation subsidiary with its own marketing corps last month, analysts predicted the imminent departure of Dennis D. Paboojian, a Rolm veteran who had been president.


Natural Gas Bill Cleared
LEAD: The Senate unanimously approved legislation today to lift a ban on the construction of natural gas-fired power plants and other large industrial gas-burning plants.
The bill, sponsored by Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana and chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, would repeal mandatory incremental pricing of natural gas, which was designed to protect residential consumers from sharp price rises by forcing some industrial users to pay prices higher than the market dictated.

LEAD: In shutting out the Flyers in the opening game of the playoffs tonight, John Vanbiesbrouck displayed the same brilliance that took the Rangers a long way in the playoffs last season.

LEAD: FOR 20 years Marian Miller, above, has been a dealer in antique Turkish kilims.

Beginning in 1900 the weavers of such rugs gradually abandoned vegetable dyes for chemical ones.

New Office Set Up to Review Eligibility for Asylum in U.S.
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced the creation of a new Justice Department office to review eligibility for political asylum.
He took the action in the aftermath of a Supreme Court ruling that made it easier for applicants to gain asylum.


Suns' Inquiry Reported
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns are reportedly being investigated for drugs by the National Basketball Association, and one of the team's owners said yesterday that the club has been told not to comment.


MICHAEL REDSTONE
LEAD: Michael Redstone, founder of National Amusements Inc., and the Northeast Theater Corporation, operator and owner of 400 movie theaters in the Northeast and the Midwest, died Saturday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla.
He was 85 years old.

Better the Contras
LEAD: The official McGovernite villain of 1987 has emerged at the head of the Nicaraguan resistance.
He is Adolfo Calero, described by Newsweek as a ''political boss'' who has taken charge of the contras ''only two months after he was forced out by the advocates of democracy and civilian control.''

WITH VICTORY IN CHICAGO MAYOR FINALLY IN CONTROL
LEAD: After a rocky first term spent battling a hostile opposition, Mayor Harold Washington will return to office here supported by a majority in the City Council that includes some former foes.


JAZZ SINGER WON TONY IN '79
LEAD: Maxine Sullivan, whose cool, precise and rhythmic singing of the Scottish folk song ''Loch Lomond'' in the late 1930's gave her an identity that remained with her throughout her career, died of heart failure Tuesday at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx.

Acquisition of Alexander's Studied
LEAD: Donald J. Trump and Interstate Properties, already the owners of 41 percent of Alexander's Inc., said yesterday that they were considering the acquisition of the rest of the 14-store retail chain.
The stock soared on the news.


REAGAN WILL ALLOW INVESTIGATORS TO SEE DIARY ITEMS ON IRAN AFFAIR
LEAD: The White House and the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair announced an agreement today under which the Congressional investigators and the special prosecutor will be permitted to review some parts of President Reagan's personal diary.


Health Care Ad Agency To Open Soon in SoHo
LEAD: Edward J. Holland, 55 years old, and his wife, Karen, 40, are half of the title of a new health care ad agency named Holland Holland Metelenis Lynch, which is hoping to open its doors at 155 Spring Street in SoHo in a couple of weeks.

Dance Festival To Mark 10th Year in Durham
LEAD: The American Dance Festival will celebrate its 10th year in Durham, N.C., with a seven-week season of performances by 15 American and foreign companies, starting June 4.


Pan Am Will Hire More Pilots
LEAD: Pan American World Airways Inc., the eighth-largest American carrier, said it had begun hiring pilots and flight engineers for the first time in 19 years.

Dollar Drops in Tokyo, Then Moves Higher
LEAD: The dollar dropped in early trading this morning amid speculation that the United States and its trading partners had failed to take specific measures to protect the dollar.


BUSH FAVORS REQUIRING AIDS TEST FOR MARRIAGE LICENSE APPLICATION
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that all couples applying for marriage licenses should be required to undergo a laboratory test to detect infection with the AIDS virus.

Gorbachev Is Due in Prague Today After Putting Off Visit
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said here today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would arrive on Thursday.


STREET CLOSINGS NEAR CITY HALL DISRUPT TRAFFIC
LEAD: Traffic in lower Manhattan ground to a standstill yesterday morning after city officials had closed several approaches to the Brooklyn Bridge.


ANXIOUS NEIGHBORHOOD WATCHES RESCUE EFFORT
LEAD: On the block where an earsplitting blast turned two buildings into a cloud of white smoke and then a hill of rubble, rescue workers searched brick by brick last night for survivors as crowds waited to see whether friends and relatives would emerge dead or alive.


On Argentine Swing, Pope Plays Many Parts
LEAD: Barnstorming eight cities of the Argentine hinterland in 60 hours, Pope John Paul II has performed a succession of his favorite roles: country preacher, world statesman and meditative philosopher.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced the resignation of Al Campanis, vice president of player personnel.
Named Fred Claire vice president of player personnel.


HOUSE RACE IN WEST GOES TO RUNOFF
LEAD: Nancy Pelosi, a former state Democratic chairman, outpolled five fellow Democrats and eight other candidates in a special election Tuesday to fill the unexpired Congressional term of Sala Burton, who died Feb. 1.


WISCONSIN VOTERS AUTHORIZE LOTTERY AND PARIMUTUEL BETS
LEAD: Voters in Wisconsin amended the State Constitution Tuesday to authorize a lottery and parimutuel betting, while Missourians approved a gasoline tax increase to 11 cents a gallon, from 7 cents, to raise $113 million a year for highway and bridge work.


CALENDAR: PLANTING, CERAMICS, NUTRITION
LEAD: Gardening for Children, Queens Botanical Garden, 43-50 Main Street, at Dahlia Street, Flushing, 718-886-3800.


King Returns to Lineup
LEAD: After being sidelined for more than two years, Bernard King will make his long-awaited return to basketball tomorrow night when the Knicks face the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.
To make room on the roster for the return of King, who tore up his right knee in a game against the Kansas City Kings on March 23, 1985, the Knicks placed Jawann Oldham on the injured list.


WATERFORD TO BROADWAY: WELL-TRAVELED 'FENCES'
LEAD: The out-of-town tryout has been a part of Broadway at least since the days when George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart spent months on the road writing, rewriting and re-rewriting their comedies before bringing them into New York.
But August Wilson's ''Fences,'' which opened last week to resounding critical acclaim and long lines at the box office, was nurtured over a four-year period in productions from New Haven to its initial commercial run in San Francisco.

'Miserables' Interrupted
LEAD: A matinee performance of ''Les Miserables'' at the Broadway Theater was interrupted yesterday when the house manager smelled smoke and ordered the theater evacuated, according to Frederick Olsson, facilities director for the Shubert Organization, which owns the theater.
No fire was apparent, Mr.
Olsson said, and the show resumed after 15 minutes.


DARLING IS READY TO CLOSE GOODEN GAP
LEAD: On many April afternoons when he was president of Yale, A. Bartlett Giamatti would sneak over to the baseball field, nest in his seat in the dugout and watch Ron Darling pitch for the varsity.


'SUNFLOWERS' BUYER: JAPANESE INSURER
LEAD: The new owner of the van Gogh ''Sunflowers'' that is the most expensive artwork in the world - it was sold for $39.9 million on March 30 at a Christie's auction in London - is the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Tokyo.


James Baker Likes the Odds of Staying Where He Is
LEAD: James A. Baker 3d seemed playfully content, striding about the anteroom to his third-floor corner office of the Treasury Building last week, the shriek of a bird filling the air.
The racket came from a little wooden box, a turkey caller, that Mr.
Baker, a well-known Texas turkey shooter, had in his hands.


GUINNESS THINKS FUNDS WENT TO EX-CHAIRMAN
LEAD: Guinness P.L.C. said today that it suspected its deposed chairman, Ernest Saunders, had secretly received $4.8 million of the company's money during a corporate takeover battle last year.

LEAD: The public and private agencies that run New York City's besieged foster care system are deeply split over who should control the system and whether major changes are needed in its structure.

Hong Kong Stocks Soar
LEAD: Share prices surged in Hong Kong today as investors took heart from a stock exchange ruling barring the issue of controversial new shares by Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., the large trading firm.
The Hang Seng Index, the market's main indicator, climbed 64 points, to 2,729.55, for its best one-day gain since March 18, when it rose more than 94 points.


RCA Lifts G.E. Profit; Net Up 16%
LEAD: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 16 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, a reflection of the company's recent acquisition of the RCA Corporation and its subsidiary, the top-rated NBC television network.


LEGISLATURE BARS EMPLOYEES FROM SOME POLITICAL WORK
LEAD: New York lawmakers, under pressure to respond to allegations of payroll abuses in the Legislature, today approved a resolution to prohibit legislative employees from working full time on political campaigns.
However, the resolution confirmed the right of those employees to do political work on a part-time basis.


Dow Plunges 32.96 Points, to 2,339.20
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 32.96 points yesterday, battered by a sharp increase in interest rates and rekindled concern about the weakening dollar and the trade frictions between Japan and the United States.


Hasidic Leader Celebrates 85th Birthday Today
LEAD: The Lubavitcher leader, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, giving coins to youngsters for them to donate to charity after services at the Lubavitcher headquarters at 770 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn.
Rabbi Schneerson, world leader of the Chabad- Lubavitch Movement, is 85 years old today. (NYT/Edward Hausner)


Mitchell-Lama Occupants Have a Right to Sell
LEAD: To the Editor:


ART: WHITNEY BIENNIAL'S NEW LOOK
LEAD: FEAR not the 1987 Whitney Biennial.
Instead of the rowdy installations of TODT and Group Material, we now have the Conceptual precision of Joseph Kosuth.
Instead of the pop figures of Kenny Scharf - remember him? -running amok over telephone booths and restrooms, we now have a sober, earth-colored, abstract mural of Sol LeWitt in the basement.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: IT'S an unlikely restaurant in an unlikely location.
C.
J.
Blanda, a friendly and fastidious little spot done in natural wood and earth tones, clings to the eastern fringe of Chelsea along commercial Seventh Avenue at 22d Street.
The remarkably inexpensive menu carries seven rustic pastas, a half-dozen meat and poultry entrees and a smattering of appetizers and desserts.


THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: ''MY grandfather was once discovered looking at roses by bending over to see them through his legs,'' Sir Adam Courtauld Butler recalled. ''He said that when the blood rushes to your head, the colors seem so much brighter.''


ISRAEL SENDS COPTERS AGAINST PALESTINIAN POSITIONS
LEAD: Israeli helicopter gunships attacked Palestinian positions today on the outskirts of the port of Sidon in southern Lebanon.


Financial Corp. Assigned Adviser
LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America confirmed that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. as a financial adviser to find new capital for the company and its major unit, the American Savings and Loan Association.

SOUNDS OF EASTER MUSIC FILL CHURCHES AND HALLS
LEAD: EASTER is music's time for storytelling.
Thus Holy Week - the unfolding narrative of Jesus' passage to the cross - evokes powerful musical drama that, in turn, enriches the power of the event itself.


LAWSUITS, AND WORRY, MOUNT OVER BIC LIGHTER
LEAD: The Bic Corporation is facing mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been burned - and in some cases killed - by fires they say were caused by defects in the company's disposable butane lighters.


METS ARE POWERED BY STRAWBERRY, 4-2
LEAD: So far, so good.
For the second time this season, the Mets played without Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell, and for the second time, they won.


CAR FOUND WHERE BRIDGE FELL
LEAD: Divers searching Schoharie Creek today found a car crushed under a concrete slab from the bridge on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed Sunday.


HOUSE APPROVES BUDGET FOR 1988 WITH MORE TAXES
LEAD: The House of Representatives today approved a trillion-dollar budget that challenges President Reagan by raising taxes and cutting his Pentagon budget.


Leave Set for Boston U. Head
LEAD: John Silber, president of Boston University since 1971, will begin a six-month leave of absence on July 1, ''in order to read and study and to examine and address the wide range of public issues that will affect higher education and the society at large in the next decade,'' the university announced today.


2 G.M. Closings To Affect 9,000
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said that it would close its Chevrolet-Pontiac-G.M. of Canada plants in Oklahoma City and Doraville, Ga., next week for inventory adjustment, temporarily laying off 9,000 workers.


Ursa Major and Ursa Minor, Polar Style
LEAD: Russia, who tips the scales somewhere near the 1,000-pound mark, with her as yet unnamed, unweighed and unsexed cub who was introduced yesterday at the Bronx Zoo.
The youngster was born in November and now weighs about 30 pounds. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


JANE COOP, PIANIST
LEAD: Jane Coop, a Canadian pianinst, will present a program of works by Mozart, Brahms, Chopin and Jean Coulthard, a Canadian composer, at the 92nd Street Y Sunday afternoon at 3.
Admission is $7.50 to $10; information: 427-4410.


CALIFANO IS WILLING LEAVE PANEL TO SETTLE EHTICS DISPUTE IN ALBANY
LEAD: Clearing the way for a compromise on the most contentious issue of this legislative session, Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today that he would be willing to step down as chairman of a commission appointed by the Governor to investigate possible unethical conduct in New York government.


DOLLARS FOR DAYCARE
LEAD: Few dispute the need for decent day care, but decent salaries are another thing.
Day care jobs pay so poorly -$5 to $9 an hour - that the annual turnover is 50 percent.
Some centers have had to close because they couldn't keep a staff.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Lloyd Advances Easily: Chris Evert Lloyd advanced to the quarterfinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup at Hilton Head Island, S.C., yesterday by defeating Debbie Spence, 6-3, 6-0.
The match lasted only 54 minutes.
The best third-round match was between Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, a 23-year-old West German, and Katerina Maleeva, 17, from Bulgaria.


European Airlines Busy
LEAD: The Association of European Airlines said today that passenger traffic in February increased 11 percent from a year earlier.
A revival continued on the North Atlantic route, where passenger traffic grew 16 percent.


HOSPITAL FINED FOR TOXIC FLOW FATAL TO PATIENT
LEAD: A Queens hospital was fined $4,000 yesterday in the case of a kidney dialysis patient who died after the water supply to a dialysis unit was mistakenly connected to the hospital's air-conditioning system.


Soviet Trade Gap $4 Billion
LEAD: The Soviet trade deficit with the West soared past the $4 billion mark last year, according to official figures released today.

U.S. ISSUES RULES ON WATER FOR WEST
LEAD: The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation issued final rules today for limiting the amount of subsidized water for large farms in the West.


Three Newark Teen-Agers Die When Stolen Car Hits a Tree
LEAD: Three teen-agers were killed when the stolen car in which they were riding hurtled into a tree and was cut in half, the police said today.


GOLDEN PALOMINOS
LEAD: The Golden Palominos, led by Anton Fier on drums and featuring Syd Straw and Michael Sweet on vocals, Bernie Worrell on keyboards and Jody Harris on guitar, will perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800).
Rude Buddha will open at 11 P.M., followed by Richard Lloyd at midnight and the Golden Palominos about 1 A.M.


Head of Pilots Unit Has Goal for United
LEAD: Frederick Charles Dubinsky, who is leading an effort by United Airlines pilots to buy the airline, is no stranger to risk.


New Push by Teheran Reported in Gulf War
LEAD: Iran began an offensive north of Baghdad today while its forces made major advances on the southern front of the Persian Gulf war, capturing an important defense line east of Basra.

FEWER YOUTHS IN SOVIET THAN IN U.S. SAID TO FEAR ATOM WAR
LEAD: Russian teen-agers fear a nuclear war much less than American teenagers do, according to a survey conducted last fall by poll takers in both countries.


PRESIDENT OF MEXICO PROMISES TO PROTECT ANCIENT MAYAN SITES
LEAD: President Miguel de la Madrid has promised that any dam built along the Mexican-Guatemalan border ''would have to preclude damage to our archeological sites and to ecological conditions on both sides of the frontier.''


If Competitiveness Is to Succeed
LEAD: Policy makers of both parties are finally asking how American industries can become competitive in the global economy.
Just in the nick of time: The decline of America's semiconductor production illustrates how quickly industrial decay can spread.


Dining Out Guide: Connecticut
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.


Italian Premier Resigns
LEAD: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi resigned tonight, a move widely expected after Christian Democratic ministers withdrew from his Cabinet on Wednesday.
Mr.
Craxi handed his resignation to President Francesco Cossiga after a debate in the Chamber of Deputies.
Mr.
Cossiga is expected to appoint an interim government to administer affairs until early elections can be held, probably in June.


TRIAL OPENS FOR AMY CARTER AND 14 OVER A PROTEST
LEAD: Amy Carter and others arrested at rally against the Central Intelligence Agency committed minor crimes to avoid the greater one of allowing agency recruiting, an attorney for the daughter of former President Carter told a jury today.


ART: MODERN MASTERS AT SIDNEY JANIS GALLERY
LEAD: ONE of the great paintings of our century has come into town for just a few weeks and can be seen through April 25 at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street.
It is ''Nude in Tub,'' painted in 1925 by Pierre Bonnard.


CUOMO AND LEGISLATORS AGREE ON BUDGET OUTLINES
LEAD: The outlines of a $41.6 billion state budget that cuts taxes, increases welfare benefits and sharply raises aid to education were agreed to tonight by leaders of the State Legislature and Governor Cuomo, although some details remained to be worked out.


SOLISTI IN BRAHMS
LEAD: Solisti New York, under the direction of Ransom Wilson, will present an all-Brahms concert at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, tomorrow night at 7:30.
Admission is free; information: 662-2133.

ISLANDERS 3, CAPITALS 1
LEAD: The Islanders, seeking the best strategy for beating the Capitals, looked no further than the first game of this series to plot a method for tying it up in the second.


Marty Ehrlich Trio
LEAD: Marty Ehrlich, a saxophonist, will lead a trio tonight at First on First, First Avenue at First Street (982-9310).
Sets are at 10 and midnight; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.


TRANSPLANT IS FIRST IN NATION
LEAD: Doctors transplanted adrenal gland cells into the brain of a 42-year-old woman today in an effort to curb Parkinson's disease symptoms.
Officials said it was the first time the operation was performed in the United States.


Shots Wound Member Of a Chinatown Gang
LEAD: A member of a Chinatown gang whose sister was kidnapped and killed last year was shot on a crowded street in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the police said.
A 6-year-old girl was also wounded.


Jets Sign Johnson
LEAD: Only a few years ago, the Jets were known as a team that never wanted other teams' veterans.
But yesterday, the Jets continued departing from type when they signed Richard Johnson, the career leader in receptions for the United States Football League, which has suspended play the last two years.
Last week the Jets signed three former regulars on N.F.L.


Bridge: Regional Tournament on L.I. Will Draw From Wide Area
LEAD: The biggest tournament of the year for Long Island players begins today, attracting players from many parts of the Northeast.
It is the Long Island Regional at the Physical Fitness Center of Hofstra University in Hempstead, and the schedule is: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams, 8 P.M.


Soft Landing for the Dollar. So Far.
LEAD: Just 15 months ago, policy makers in the industrial countries were scrounging for ways to let the air out of the high-flying dollar without provoking a crash.
Against the odds, they've managed the soft landing they hoped for.
The dollar, which sagged again yesterday, has now lost more than a third of its exchange value without inducing panic.


SCARFO INDICTED IN '78 SLAYING OF JERSEY JUDGE
LEAD: Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed boss of a Philadelphia-based organized-crime family, and an associate have been indicted for the 1978 killing of a municipal court judge in New Jersey, state officials said today.


HOMOSEXUAL'S LOVER LOSES HOUSING BID
LEAD: An appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a homosexual whose lover died of AIDS had no right to the rent-stabilized apartment the two men shared because his name was not on the lease.


President Resigning At Lord &amp; Taylor Chain
LEAD: Harold Leppo, the president of Lord &amp; Taylor, is resigning after 10 years with the retail fashion chain.


Philippine Peace Talks Suspended After Clash
LEAD: Government negotiators announced the indefinite suspension of peace talks with Moslem rebels today after a reported firefight earlier this week.


THE DANCE: EUROBALLET AT THE RIVERSIDE CHURCH
LEAD: UNPRETENTIOUSNESS may not be one of the great attributes of art.
But there is a lot to be said for the quality, which seems in rather short supply these days in the increasingly solemn world of dance.
The Euroballet Theater, which breezed into the Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday night, had adept technique and good-looking dancers going for it.


Key Streets Reopened To Brooklyn Bridge
LEAD: Most of the key Manhattan streets leading to and from the Brooklyn Bridge were reopened last night, two days after falling masonry from the top of the Municipal Building had forced their closing.


Scouting Report
LEAD: Dick Vitale, the TV analyst, when drafted as a territorial pick by the Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League: ''I can't play a lick, but I can talk a good game.''


HOUSING IN CHELSEA EDGES INTO A COMMERCIAL BLOCK
LEAD: Some of Chelsea's loveliest apartment buildings, now partly concealed by cherry trees and dogwood, line the 20's between Ninth and 10th Avenues.
But the district extending that far west is a checkered one, with gritty industrial strips alternating with residential streets significant in history and architecture.


Market Place; The Prospects For Texaco
LEAD: WITH prospects for a bankruptcy filing looming, investors in Texaco Inc. could be facing very rough seas ahead, according to some analysts.


British Duke Selling Old Master Drawings
LEAD: The Duke of Devonshire, owner of one of the largest art collections in the world, will sell 16 Old Master drawings by Raphael, Veronese, Barocci, Lorenzo di Credi and Rembrandt in order to raise money to maintain the art at Chatsworth, his ancestral home in Derbyshire, Christie's in London announced Wednesday.


SIMON TO DECLARE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDACY IN MAY
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois today announced his intention to enter the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, presenting himself as a candidate rooted in the party's ''traditional values.''


RETAIL SALES MIXED IN MARCH
LEAD: The nation's largest general retailers reported yesterday that March sales were mixed.
Store owners and industry analysts blamed bad weather and a late Easter season.


GUARNERI QUARTET
LEAD: The Guarneri String Quartet will play music by Schubert, Bartok and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8.
Admission is $15; information: 570-3949.


Lloyd's Will Help Defrauded Backers
LEAD: Lloyd's of London, in an effort to put a five-year scandal behind it, offered today to help investors in its insurance underwriting syndicates meet losses suffered partly through fraud.

LEAD: The European Community said today that it had shelved threatened legal action against three European airlines after they agreed to change practices that restrict competition.

HOLES FOUND IN GAS METER AT BLAST SITE
LEAD: Three bullet holes and the aluminum jacket of a pistol bullet were found yesterday in the gas meter of a South Bronx grocery store where six people died in an explosion Wednesday, the police said.


LOSS OF SHOE LEADS TO JAIL
LEAD: A Brooklyn man who was arrested after losing a shoe at the scene of an attempted robbery was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail by a judge who said a ''quirk of fate'' had brought the man to justice.


CONCERN ON BIG SUPPLY OF GASOLINE
LEAD: Concern over high gasoline inventories continued for a second day yesterday, as prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved slightly lower in brisk trading.


Canon Will Team With Chip Maker
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation and Canon Inc. said they intend to cooperate on development of computer chips and software for Canon laser printers.
They said they might also team up on other products.
Canon's laser printer will use National Semiconductor's microprocessor and other National chips, an important victory for the company, based in Santa Clara,


Fund Assets Increase
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds increased $1.39 billion, to $236.77 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 93 institutional funds rose $481.8 million, to $65.65 billion; the 197 general purpose funds rose $625.5 million, to $63.80 billion, and the 93 broker-dealer funds rose $285.3 million, to $107.31 billion.

FILM: 'THREE FOR THE ROAD'
LEAD: ''THREE FOR THE ROAD,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters, has no fewer beer cans or car chases or know-nothing jokes than the usual teen-age adventure-comedy.
But it does have a lot less personality than most, which is peculiar.
The director, B. W. L. Norton, and the writers, Richard Martini, Tim Metcalfe and Miguel Tejada-Flores, display no idea whatsoever of how to keep a film moving or how to hold an audience's interest.


Assessing Intelligence Breaches
LEAD: He shuns the word ''vindication'' and is too much the patrician to say, ''I told you so,'' but James J. Angleton, who directed United States counterespionage efforts for two decades, is mightily stirred by the latest disclosures of breaches in the defenses of American intelligence operations.

LEAD: Flood waters receded slowly in the Northeast yesterday as the flood damage estimate climbed to $113 million.

Caustic Fumes Send 59 People to Hospital
LEAD: An overheated experiment at a chemical plant spewed caustic fumes into the air in southern Westchester County today and 59 people were sent to the hospital for treatment, officials said.


Physician Refuses to Cut Off Patient From Feeding Tubes
LEAD: A doctor has refused to obey a court order to cut off a 92-year-old semicomatose woman from the feeding tubes that are keeping her alive, saying it violates his professional beliefs and Jewish faith.

Bankers Trust Deposit Notes
LEAD: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 7 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


PROBLEMS WITH SOVIET SPACECRAFT
LEAD: The Soviet Union's new Kvant space module failed today to link up completely in a second docking attempt with the manned space station Mir, and Soviet scientists were deciding whether the mission could be saved.


Driesell's New Post
LEAD: Lefty Driesell, the former University of Maryland basketball coach who stepped aside after the controversy over the death of Len Bias and took a post as assistant athletic director, has been put in charge of sports information by the school.


A Demolition For the Derby
LEAD: There are plenty of ways to lose the Kentucky Derby, but owners have naturally always cherished those that excuse defeat without diminishing their own opinion of their 3-year-olds: the supposedly hard and cuppy Churchill Downs track, the traffic problems caused by the huge fields, the distractions posed by 100,000 noisy spectators.

PAN AM PILOT AVOIDS COLLISION WITH CARGO JET
LEAD: The pilot of a Pan Am Express turboprop airliner took sharp evasive action Wednesday to avoid hitting a four-engine military cargo jet near McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: ''Who am I to be judgmental of Micheal?'' said Coach Dean Meminger of the Long Island Knights after making Micheal Ray Richardson his first-round pick in the United States Basketball League draft Wednesday. ''We all have skeletons in the closet.
Being a former member of that player's fraternity, maybe I'm a little more willing to give him one more chance.


SPYING OUTRAGEOUS, REAGAN SAYS
LEAD: President Reagan said today that Soviet espionage efforts against the American Embassy in Moscow were ''outrageous'' and that he would take whatever action necessary to correct the violations.


FLYERS 8, RANGERS 3
LEAD: Finally there were breakaways from Philadelphia and goals from in close, and the Flyers restored their series with the Rangers back to order.


'POLICE ACADEMY 4' FIRST IN BOX-OFFICE SALES
LEAD: ''Police Academy 4'' sold $8.5 million in tickets during its first weekend of release to take top spot at the box office for the week.


'Perls' Are Offered By Westinghouse
LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday began offering $40.05 million of principal exchange rate linked securities due in 1990 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
The securities, call ''Perls,'' in the debt market, carry a 13 1/4 percent coupon and are offered at a price of par.


DOLLAR PLUMMETS A DAY AFTER ALLIES SET STABILITY GOAL
LEAD: The dollar plunged to new lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, just one day after the United States and its economic allies had pledged to stabilize currency rates.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Music and Dance of the Fulani People of Senegal, the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street (619-1980).
Most of the Senegalese music that has reached the United States has been by Mandingo griots (historian-troubadours) and such Wolof rock musicians as the singer Youssou N'Dour.
Now, four musicians from Senegal's third major tribal group, the Fulani, are making their first appearances in the United States, playing music that can be traced to the 11th century.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d misstated his age.
