The U.N. Today: April 10, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


'THE SECRET OF MY SUCCESS'
''THE SECRET OF MY SUCCESS,'' directed with a lot of panache by Herbert Ross, is a comedy about the meteoric rise in the Manhattan business world of Brantley Foster (Michael J. Fox), who, when he leaves the Kansas farm, tells his worried mother, ''I want to have a meaningful experience with a beautiful woman.''
His mother remains uncertain.
Did Brantley pack an iron? ''You don't want to walk around wrinkled in New York.'' Says Brantley, who manages to implicate everybody in his own schemes, ''I'm doing this for you, Mom, as much as for myself.''


MUSIC: BERNSTEIN AND THE PHILHARMONIC
LEAD: Most discussions of the music of Ives bear down heavily on his prodigal use of quotation and it is true that in a work such as the Symphony No. 2 he seems to be trying to bring the ancient technique of pastiche to new levels of incongruity.
However, listening last evening to the New York Philharmonic's superlative performance of the piece under Leonard Bernstein one was struck more forcibly by the artistic unity that Ives achieved than by the diversity of his materials.


FROM CASUAL TO CONTINENTAL CUISINE ALONG THE SPRUCED-UP 46TH STREET
LEAD: THE gangly young ginkgo trees are about to blossom along 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, marking two causes for celebration: The onset of spring and the fruition of a 12-year-old effort to rejuvenate one of the theater district's premier blocks, known as Restaurant Row.


FILM: JOHN MALKOVICH IN 'MAKING MR. RIGHT'
LEAD: AS the credits for ''Making Mr.
Right'' roll by, the film's barefoot heroine is seen driving her bright red convertible to the sound of a high-voltage pop song, shaving her legs and painting on lipstick as she goes.
This is the kind of hot-blooded, fun-loving moment that Susan Seidelman, who also directed ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' and ''Smithereens,'' manages best.


2 AIRLINES ACCUSED OF 'UNREALISTIC' SCHEDULING
LEAD: The Department of Transportation accused two airlines today of deceptive scheduling at the Atlanta airport and said it was expanding its investigation of airline scheduling practices to three other major airports.


New Ad Drive: Call It 'A Fistful of Leaves'
LEAD: If you were in charge of the country's parks and other public lands, and a bunch of punks were trashing them, what would you do?
Hire Clint Eastwood, of course.
Make his day.


A Guest at Plaza Hotel Is Raped in Her Suite
LEAD: A 29-year-old woman was raped at gunpoint in her bed at the Plaza Hotel Wednesday night by a masked man who followed her into her suite and robbed her of more than $150, the police said yesterday.


France Pardons Chinese Spy Who Pretended to Be Woman
LEAD: A Chinese man jailed in France last year for espionage activities has been pardoned by President Francois Mitterrand, judicial officials said today.


Redeeming a Promise
LEAD: Belatedly, New York City and State officials are beginning to make good on a decade of broken promises to the mentally ill.


Argentina Faults Banks
LEAD: Argentina's Economy Minister, Juan Sourrouille, said today that the ''narrow interest'' of creditor banks was holding up an accord to stretch out debt repayments.
He warned Argentina might break off negotiations.


Chip Orders Rose in Period
LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator improved for the sixth consecutive month, a trade group reported today, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported their highest levels of orders and shipments since 1984.
The Semiconductor Industry


Massachusetts Agency In America's Cup Role
LEAD: Mullen Advertising of Beverly Farms, Mass., has been named the core ad agency to prepare for the next America's Cup competition, in 1991.


STAGE: 'TENT MEETING,' REVIVALIST REBALDRY
LEAD: WITH almost daily reports about sexual peccadilloes among the believers, revivalism is a most suitable subject for theatrical ridicule.
Because of its theme, ''Tent Meeting'' would seem to be even more topical than when it was first presented at the 1985 Humana New Play Festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., (after its initial engagement in Atlanta).

College Stars May Have Been Ineligible
LEAD: Court documents filed as part of an agent's suits against several of the nation's top college football players contain promissory notes for several thousand dollars signed by the players.
If the signatures are valid, the players violated college rules and should have been ineligible to play.


AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: KEN RUSSELL'S ''Gothic'' (review on page C16) is a horror story with phantoms that might have sprung from the opium-clouded half-crazed minds of a group of 19th-century British writers, including two of England's greatest poets, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Lord Byron.
Ken Russell, another English artist, has tried to re-create on film a stormy night in Lord Byron's mansion in Switzerland, in which a group of friends starts to tell one another ghost stories and then decides to create a ghost - each concentrating on bringing his worst fear to life.


QUOTE OF THE DAY
LEAD:  ''There are certain times in history when the creative forces in a society try to break through the contradictions.
This is such a time in Moscow and 1968 was such a time here.''  Jiri Hajek, former foreign  minister of Czechoslovakia,  on the visit of Mikhail S.


Bess Myerson and the Public Trust
LEAD: Mayor Koch, who has been criticized for insensitivity, now finds himself charged with softness.
He allowed Bess Myerson, an old acquaintance and a political colleague, to resign as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, instead of dismissing her peremptorily before receiving a report on her conduct from former Federal Judge Harold Tyler.


Triple Crowns
LEAD: In beating Marvelous Marvin Hagler last Monday night, Sugar Ray Leonard was added to this list, now 10 names long, of fighters who have won world titles in three different weight divisions.
BOB FITZSIMMONS - middleweight, 1891-97; heavyweight, 1897-99; light heavyweight, 1903-5.
TONY CANZONERI - featherweight, 1928; junior welterweight, 1931-32, 1933; lightweight, 1930-33, 1935-36.

LEAD: Al Campanis is an honorable man, so are all the white baseball club owners and executives, all honorable men.

LEAD: For two weeks the mood here has been as in Mudville after Casey's last at-bat.


Christine Lavin Songs
LEAD: Christine Lavin will perform her songs tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with O. J. Anderson opening.
Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.


BAKER ASKS 3D WORLD DEBT ACTION
LEAD: Saying there were no quick fixes for the third-world debt problem, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d called on commercial banks today to develop a ''menu of alternative new money options'' to assure continued financing for poorer countries.


TREASURIES TOP 8%, A 13-MONTH HIGH
LEAD: Treasury bond yields rose above 8 percent yesterday for the first time in 13 months, as renewed weakness in the dollar created consternation throughout the credit markets.


MYERSON QUITS AFTER FINDING OF MISCONDUCT
LEAD: Bess Myerson, accused in a specially commissioned mayoral report of ''serious misconduct,'' resigned yesterday as Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.


BROADWAY
LEAD: WILL wonders never cease!
Another American musical in the works and apparently a lot further along than the ''planned'' and ''hoped for'' stage.
This one is called ''Teddy and Alice,'' and if a little bell rings, it's because some time ago, it was a ''hoped for'' that never happened.


CURB ON PRETORIA DEFEATED AT U.N.
LEAD: The United States and Britain today vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have banned all trade and other ties with South Africa because of its occupation of South-West Africa.


Jimmy Smith, Organist
LEAD: Jimmy Smith, an organist, will lead his trio, and Houston Person, a saxophonist, and Etta Jones, a singer, will lead their quartet, in a double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).
Shows begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $7.50 music charge at the bar.


Dollar Tumbles Again in Tokyo
LEAD: The dollar continued to plunge in Tokyo this morning, hitting a low of 142.90 yen before rallying slightly to close morning trading at 143.15 yen.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  HUNGARIAN FILM VIEW Over the past two decades, Gyula Gazdag, a Hungarian film maker, has produced a wry and iconoclastic body of work unusual in the carefully controlled artistic milieu of Eastern Europe.
This evening at 6:30, Mr.
Gazdag will appear at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, to introduce his 1974 operatic parody ''Singing on the Treadmill,'' a satire of the Socialist Realist works of the 1950's.


PERES WINDS UP TALKS WITH SOVIET AIDES
LEAD: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel concluded three days of talks with Soviet officials here today, and he described the talks as ''the first serious and direct dialogue'' between the two nations.


New Play by Howard Fast
LEAD: The premiere of ''Triptych,'' a new play by Howard Fast, will be performed at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, tonight at 7:30.
The play will be performed only once.
Mr.
Fast is to introduce the play and read some of the poetry of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winning author.
The cathedral is at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.


MAX J. ETRA
LEAD: Max J. Etra, a lawyer and philanthropist, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 83 years old.


JUSTICE DEPT. CHANGES STANCE ON SPECIAL PROSECUTOR ETHICS
LEAD: The Justice Department today announced a compromise in which it would permit special prosecutors to continue representing their old clients before the department but would regard it as a violation of ethics laws for the lawyers to take on new cases related to the department after today.

LEAD: Columbia College will hold a gala celebration of its bicentennial at the Metropolitan Opera House Sunday at 8 P.M.
The celebration, to be hosted by Walter Cronkite, will feature performances of musical works composed and arranged by Columbia alumni.
The performers are to include Ben Vereen, Robert Merrill, Roberta Peters, Marvin Hamlisch, the ''Chorus Line'' company and Tony Bennett, as well as such alumni as John Kander and Fred Ebb, the lyricist-composer team, who are to perform their own works.

VW Keeps Payout After Fraud Loss
LEAD: Volkswagen gave its shareholders the same dividend as last year's, despite a suspected currency fraud that may cost it as much as 480 million marks ($260 million).
Volkswagen's supervisory board set an unchanged dividend of 10 marks ($5.50) a share.

LEAD: To the Editor:


GRETZKY BREAKS MARK, SO DO OILERS, 13-3
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky and the Edmonton Oilers set playoff scoring marks tonight in a 13-3 victory that evened their Smythe Division semifinal series against the Los Angeles Kings at one game apiece.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: ROBERT DE BELDER, a retired diamond dealer who lives near Antwerp, Belgium, assembled over 30 years one of the finest collections of botanical color-plate books in private hands -holdings that Sotheby's in London is to auction April 27 and 28.
The 388 volumes include many of the monuments of botanical illustration, dating from 1600 to 1900, that document the evolution of botanical art.

SPORTSWEAR: A MORE FORMAL SLANT FOR FALL
LEAD: Sportswear, that typically American fashion form, dominated the fall openings yesterday and it was clear that sable and sequins are part of the casual scene.
There are plenty of blazers, and at most houses it is still possible to find trousers.
But the new formality that suffuses fashion means that fur hats, cashmere, elegant leather jackets and skirts, and plenty of glitter at night have become an integral part of the sportswear field.

LEAD: Shamrock Holdings of California Inc., an investment concern controlled by the Roy E. Disney family, said today that it was considering an offer to buy the one million shares of the Holly Sugar Corporation that it does not already control.


ART: WORKS BY LOIS LANE
LEAD: THIS season has seen shows of early and recent work by a number of the artists who have emerged under the ''New Image'' painting heading.
The latest to be heard from is Lois Lane, whose exhibition at the Willard Gallery (29 East 72d Street) is one of her best.
For this particular outing, on view through tomorrow, the artist is exhibiting three earlier paintings (two from 1977, one from 1981), alongside four canvases made this year, and the cumulative effect indicates that she has gone forward by going backward, returning to her earlier work in order to amplify certain devices and themes.


FILM: SHELLEY, BYRON AND FRIENDS, IN 'GOTHIC'
LEAD: DURING the summer of 1816, while he was in residence in a villa on the Swiss shore of Lake Geneva, Lord Byron, then 28, was host to his fellow poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, 24; Mary Godwin, Shelley's 19-year-old mistress, whom he later married; Mary's stepsister, Claire Clairmont, 18, who was pregnant with Byron's child, and John William Polidori,


EX-DIRECTOR ACCUSED OF FED LEAKS
LEAD: A former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has been accused of repeatedly leaking market-sensitive interest-rate information to a brokerage firm.


BASE IS MAKESHIFT HOME TO RELOCATED WORKERS
LEAD: Camp Smith, a key training site for ground combat units of the state's Army National Guard, assumed a new support role this week: housing General Motors Corporation workers transferring to this region.


NIEKRO, CARLTON WIN AS TEAM
LEAD: Cory Snyder hit a first-inning grand slam, and Steve Carlton recorded his first save since 1967 and the second of his career as the Cleveland Indians routted the Toronto Blue Jays, 14-3, today.


STAGE: IN 'MISALLIANCE,' SHAW'S CLASSIC CLASHES
LEAD: STAMFORD, Conn., April 4 -Any company that undertakes ''Misalliance'' has to find a style to deal with the play's unbalanced design.
The plot is close to invisible and what action there is - a plane crash, the appearance of a man with a gun - occurs in the second half.
The first hour is devoted to what George Bernard Shaw called conversation, a brilliant airing of most of his favorite themes.

Cecil Payne Quartet
LEAD: Cecil Payne, a baritone saxophonist, will lead a be-bop quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300).
Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.
Barry Harris and Chris Anderson will each play piano solos Sunday between 6 and 10 P.M.
Admission is $8; $5 for students and the elderly.


RACIAL TENSIONS PERSIST IN CROWN HEIGHTS
LEAD: About 1:30 A.M. on Feb. 26, someone placed a cardboard orange-juice box and a can containing petroleum in the basement of Willie Mae Reddish's house in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn and set them afire, according to the police.


Seoul Backs Conditional Overtures to North
LEAD: A senior Foreign Ministry official said today that South Korea endorsed recent conditional overtures made to North Korea by the United States, but he expressed doubt that the American moves would yield positive results.


Fish Story?
LEAD: As a conservation measure, many fishing tournaments, especially those involving large saltwater species, are of the so-called catch-and-release variety.
Bound more or less by the honor system, competitors radio the time of their catch, its measurement and other details to tourney officials and then throw the fish back.


A Different Color Bar
LEAD: Perhaps after another 40 years, no one will have to ask why there are no black managers or executives in major league baseball.
But this year, the 40th since Jackie Robinson became the first black player in the majors, the question remains regrettably appropriate.


U.S.SEEKS TO END 2-YEAR CHECKS OF BRIDGES
LEAD: The Federal Highway Administration has proposed eliminating a requirement that all public bridges in the nation undergo safety inspection at least once every two years.


Why Worry?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Britain's ''Allo, 'Allo,' A New Comedy Series
LEAD: '' 'Allo, 'Allo'' is not Noel Coward; actually, it is less subtle than Benny Hill.
Undeniably, however, it is British, the kind of series that the British seem able to mass-produce.
Bathroom jokes are in abundance, along with mugging and grimaces.
You thought British television was ever so tasteful?


UAL Is Silent As Stock Rises
LEAD: The price of UAL Inc. shares, which soared $6.25 Wednesday, climbed $1.25 yesterday, to $73.25, on reports that Coniston Partners of New York, a money manager, was a major buyer.
Coniston would not comment.

LEAD: A major expansion of Medicare to cover the costs of catastrophic illnesses seems highly likely in the wake of a vote today by a key subcommittee of the House of Representatives, approving new health benefits for millions of elderly people.

LEAD: For six years President Reagan and his Administration have carried on an obsessive campaign for secrecy in government, trying to keep information from the press and the American public.
Meanwhile, real secrets - intelligence secrets - were pouring out to the Soviet Union in a flood.


RESTAURANT
LEAD: CINCO DE MAYO, or the Fifth of May, is the day in 1862 when Mexico won a famous battle (but ultimately lost the war) against French invaders near the city of Puebla; closer to home, it is the name of a flamboyant SoHo restaurant that in 1983 unleashed the first salvo in the great guacamole invasion of Manhattan.

FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1987
LEAD: Markets  The dollar plummeted to a new low against the yen just a day after the U.S. and its economic allies pledged to stabilize currency rates.
The decline followed statements by Treasury Secretary Baker that were interpreted by traders as an endorsement of further declines.
Early today in Tokyo, the dollar was trading as low as 142.90 yen, after falling to less than 144 yen in New York.





BUREAUCRACY QUELLS SHOPKEEPER'S SPIRIT
LEAD: For nearly three decades, Gershon Mamlak has been dodging the bulldozers of urban renewal.
An upholsterer and furniture maker, Mr.
Mamlak has been forced to move his business three times since 1958 -each time, stores he was renting were condemned to make way for progress.


TWO YOUNG MODERN-DANCE MASTERS
LEAD: Cydney Wilkes and Nelson Zayas have struck out on their own and made names for themselves as promising modern-dance choreographers of a new generation.
They share a program at the Kitchen this weekend, tonight through Sunday, with each contributing a new work that takes human interaction as its departure point.


Canadian Trade Surplus
LEAD: Canada's trade surplus soared to its highest level in more than five months in February, fueled by record automobile exports, Statistics Canada said today.
The surplus with the rest of the world rose to $1.25 billion Canadian (about $950 million United States), from an revised surplus of $623 million ($474 million) in January and $189 million ($144 million) in February last year.


CLUBS AND GREENS ELUSIVE FOR COOK
LEAD: John Cook lost all of his golf clubs as well as his golf bag during a flight from Tampa, Fla., to New Orleans on March 17.
He arrived at the New Orleans airport, as did his other baggage, but his clubs still haven't turned up.


17 AT COLOMBIAN AIRLINE ACCUSED OF LARGE-SCALE MONEY SMUGGLING
LEAD: A scheme that used Avianca Airlines flight engineers and flight attendants to transport illegally $10 million or more in United States currency to Colombia over a 15-month period has been broken up with the indictment of 17 employees of the airline, Federal authorities announced yesterday.


Doner Gets 'Good Guys' For Pride in America
LEAD: Although W. B. Doner &amp; Company is frequently involved in doing public service advertising in Baltimore and Detroit, where its two offices are situated, it has not until now done an Advertising Council campaign.


U.S.-Japan Meeting
LEAD: A senior Japanese trade official met with American negotiators today in an effort to avert the new American tariffs on selected Japanese electronic goods that are scheduled to go into effect on April 17.
An American official said the talks seemed inconclusive and that no American statement was planned.


Bakker Decision Delayed
LEAD: Officials of the State Assemblies of God say they want more information before deciding on the resignations of the Rev.
Jim Bakker and a top Bakker aide, according to a spokeswoman, Juleen Turnage.
Mr.
Bakker and the Rev.
Richard Dortch resigned from the Pentecostal denomination March 19 and Mr.
Bakker also stepped down as president and chairman of PTL, acknowledging a 1980 sexual encounter and payment to ''blackmailers.


AFGHANS AWAY FROM HOME: RUGS, GUNS AND FEAR
LEAD: An Afghan garrison town is rising here on bare, stony hills whose access roads are mainly the gullies of nearly waterless streams.


COURT RESTORES BABY M VISITS BY WHITEHEAD
LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Mary Beth Whitehead could resume visits with Melissa Stern, the year-old girl who was the central figure in the landmark Baby M custody case.


A 'CAKE' MINUS THE CALORIES
LEAD: Someone has finally made the dream of every calorie-counter come true.
Now you can have your birthday cake and eat it, too.
Last week I was introduced to a ''cake'' that contained no sugar, no artificial sweetener, no flour, no cream and no butter.
It was beautiful and, of course, low in calories, and it was made entirely of fruit.


'70 Bombing Figure Sought
LEAD: A man who participated in a fatal antiwar bombing at the University of Wisconsin in 1970 has been charged with helping operate a narcotics factory.
The suspect, Dwight A. Armstrong, and four other people were being sought today after a raid at a Bloomington apartment described by investigators as a methamphetamine laboratory.


PRODUCER PRICES ADVANCE 0.4%
LEAD: A key Government price gauge rose broadly in March, tending to confirm expectations that inflation is returning to at least the 4 percent level that prevailed before last year's sharp drop in oil prices.


FRENCH EMBASSY CLERK WAS SPY
LEAD: A clerk who coded and decoded messages in French Embassies in the Middle East worked for a decade for the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, French officials said today.


B.Y.U. Expels 2
LEAD: Two Brigham Young football players who were charged in December with altering drug prescriptions were expelled yesterday after being arrested and charged with similar offenses, school officials said.

LEAD: The dynamism and cleverness evident in the Danny Grossman Dance Company, on view tonight and tomorrow afternoon at Davis Hall at City College (134th Street and Convent Avenue), should come as no surprise to those who remember Mr.
Grossman in Paul Taylor's company.


HERBERT A. GOLD
LEAD: Herbert A. Gold, the founder and president of Jayme Products, a developer and supplier of premiums and promotional merchandise to major marketing companies, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 80 years old.


BIC SAYS ITS LIGHTERS ARE SAFE
LEAD: The Bic Corporation denied yesterday that it faced mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been injured or killed by malfunctioning Bic disposable butane lighters.
Reports of the lawsuits were included in an article in The New York Times.

LEAD: Shortly before high noon, just as the Masters leaders were beginning to go off the first tee, a gray-haired man in a green shirt turned to his bald friend in a white visor. LEAD: If Shea Stadium can be likened to a theme park, then the emphasis after three games of the season is on the home run.
The symbol of the Mets' power surge is Darryl Strawberry.

LEAD: Less than a week after New York City's Parks Department, in a major cleanup project, removed garbage and auto wrecks from Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, officials discovered a new crop of smashed cars.

HURST BLANKS JAYS AT FENWAY
LEAD: Bruce Hurst today became the first Boston Red Sox pitcher to throw a shutout in a season opener in Fenway Park since 1921, allowing only two hits in a 3-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.


Correction
LEAD: An article on April 3 about new efforts to strengthen the New York City Department of Probation misidentified the handgun issued to officers.
It is a .38-caliber revolver.


KIDDER SAID TO WEIGH SETTLING
LEAD: Executives of Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company and its parent, the General Electric Company, have decided that they would be willing to settle civil insider trading charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to several people familiar with the company and the Government's investigation.


New Job for Unemployment Insurance
LEAD: The national effort to put more welfare recipients to work could learn a useful lesson from California, where an innovative job retraining program shows results without spending new money.
The key is unemployment insurance.
By applying it inventively to job training, it can reduce and even prevent unemployment.


WOMAN IS TO HEAD EDITORS' SOCIETY
LEAD: Katherine W. Fanning, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, today became the first woman to be named president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, a 65-year-old organization whose members include editors of the largest daily papers in the United States.

Cotton Rises the Limit; Oil Prices Slump Again
LEAD: Cotton futures advanced the limit allowed for daily trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, reflecting a Government report showing that worldwide stocks were far below expectations.
New crop deliveries set contract highs.

LEAD: Asian and American


DOW'S LOSS IS 0.42 AFTER BONDS DROP
LEAD: Stock prices fell a bit yesterday, depressed again by the weak dollar and sharp climb in interest rates.


U.S. BRINGING HOME MARINE GUARD UNIT AT SOVIET CONSULATE
LEAD: The entire detachment of six Marine guards stationed at the United States Consulate in Leningrad will be replaced in May as a security precaution, the Reagan Administration said today.


Spanish Strikes Snarl Transportion System
LEAD: Strikers protesting a Government pay plan paralyzed state-run transportation and curtailed the national health service today.


Celtic Fantasy on Stage As a Dream Unfolds Nearby
LEAD: One member of the audience created his own fantasy yesterday as a troupe of fairies, druids and other mythical characters marched across the stage at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.


Earthquake Shakes Tokyo
LEAD: An earthquake shook the Tokyo area today, rattling buildings and interrupting train lines, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
Meteorological Agency officials said the quake measured 5.3 on the Richter scale.





Stern Briefed on Inquiry
LEAD: David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said today that the authorities here have told him that a drug investigation might touch the Suns organization.


Investment Group Buys Robins Stake
LEAD: An investment group led by the New York financier Michael H. Steinhardt has purchased a 5.5 percent stake in the A.H.
Robins Company.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Steinhardt said that he had bought the shares for investment purposes only.


2 Blair Units Sold; Name Is Changed
LEAD: Reliance Capital Group L.P., part of the investment empire controlled by the financier Saul P. Steinberg, said it had sold two more divisions of its John Blair &amp; Company subsidiary, leaving the unit free to focus on its Spanish-language television operations.
Reliance also said that Blair's name would now be changed to that of its Spanish-language television subsidiary, Telemundo Group


School Reinstates Girl Who Wore a Swimsuit
LEAD: A teen-age homecoming queen who was expelled from a church school for modeling swimsuits can keep her title and go on working when she returns to school under a settlement reached today.

LEAD: A couple sitting near the fountain, but not close enough to catch the spray, at City Hall Park yesterday.

EVAUATING THE FALLING DOLLAR
LEAD: The dollar - whose steep decline in the last few weeks has upset global markets and preoccupied the world's finance ministers - could fall still further, possibly 5 to 10 percent, a number of top United States economists and financial officers said in interviews yesterday.

BURR LEAVING TEXAS AIR
LEAD: Donald C. Burr, who co-founded People Express and built it into a major carrier, is on his own again.


KNICKS ARE HUMILIATED
LEAD: For two years, Bernard King refused to concede to logic.
Instead, he went into seclusion and worked with a relentless passion to return from a knee injury so severe that no player has ever completely recovered from it.
Last night, his efforts resulted in the comeback that few people believed would ever occur.

Sabatini to Face Graf In Semifinal Round
LEAD: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina struggled a bit against Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany today, but prevailed, 7-6, 6-4, to gain the semifinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup.


STRANGE RIDES EAGLE TO LEAD
LEAD: Curtis Strange, who blew his chance to win the 1985 Masters, eagled the par-4 fifth hole today with a 185-yard 6-iron shot into the cup and went on to take the halfway lead in the 51st Masters.


BEENE AND KARAN REDEFINE TODAY'S LUXURY
LEAD: Two weeks of fall fashion openings ended triumphantly yesterday morning as Geoffrey Beene and Donna Karan gave a new, modern interpretation to the idea of luxury in clothes.
From Beene's gossamer gilded laces to Karan's cashmere and baby llama woolens, the fabrics formed the opulent base for clothes that wrapped the body in brilliance and warmth.


Makers of War Toys Criticized
LEAD: Groups opposed to war toys today condemned the laser gun game a teen-ager was playing when he was shot to death by a sheriff's deputy.


'SAFE SEX' TO CLOSE
LEAD: ''Safe Sex,'' a trilogy of one-act plays by Harvey Fierstein on the subject of AIDS, will close after the Sunday evening performance.
The play, which was produced by the Shubert Organization, opened Sunday at the Lyceum Theater.
It will have played for 22 preview and nine regular performances.


Amazing! The Thing Is Bugged!
LEAD: I sit way out in what used to be the country waiting for developers to come and ugly everything to death.
Why are they called ''developers''?
Since their job is creating blight, ''blighters'' would be more logical, but maybe too British.
If we quit calling their work ''development'' and called it ''uglification,'' we could call them ''uglifiers.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, said it had received approval from the Florida Comptroller's Office to merge with Home Federal Bank of Florida, but the company said approval by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was required before Home Federal Bank could be converted to a state-chartered bank.


PLANS FOR DOMED STADIUM IN QUEENS IN DOUBT
LEAD: New York's plans to build an 82,000-seat domed stadium in Queens are ''pretty much dead,'' and with them, the city's hopes of luring a professional football team back to New York, the head of the state's Urban Development Corporation said yesterday.


Coetzee, Getting Prize, Denounces Apartheid
LEAD: J. M. Coetzee, the South African writer, called on his country yesterday to dismantle apartheid, its system of racial segregation.
The 47-year-old author spoke after accepting the $5,000 Jerusalem Prize for the Freedom of the Individual in Society from Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem.


EMBASSY IN MOSCOW: A FUROR GROWS
LEAD: In other circumstances, Secretary of State George P. Shultz's departure for Moscow this weekend for talks on arms control might have evoked strong expectations of a fresh start on improving Soviet-United States relations.


Company Returns To Wharton Name
LEAD: Just 10 days ago, Wharton Econometrics agreed to merge with Chase Econometrics, forming a company that was to be called WEFA-CEIS.
But the two companies, which are among the nation's leading economic forecasting and consulting concerns, acknowledged yesterday that the new name was a bit unwieldy.
Lawrence Chimerine, Wharton's chairman and chief executive, said the merged company would be known instead as Wharton


3 Bullet Holes in Meter Blamed for Gas Leak
LEAD: Three bullet holes caused a gas leak in the gas meter of the South Bronx grocery store where six people died in an explosion Wednesday, police investigators said yesterday.

Aftermath of Mine Explosion in South Africa
LEAD: A victim of the South African coal mine disaster recovering in a hospital in Ermelo, in the eastern Transvaal.
The explosion, which occurred Thursday, killed 34 mine workers.
Black labor-union leaders reacted angrily yesterday, saying accident showed that the company's health and safety standards were inadequate.


LEADERS OF 3 JUDAISM BRANCHES SEEK COOPERATION
LEAD: In an unusual joint effort, rabbis from the three major branches of Judaism have used the eve of Passover to issue a statement calling for Jews to put aside religious differences and cooperate on common concerns.


WARHOL RECEIVED INADEQUATE CARE IN HOSPITAL, HEALTH BOARD ASSERTS
LEAD: The New York State Health Department charged yesterday that Andy Warhol was given inadequate care by New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center from his admission to near the time of his death two days later after gall bladder surgery.


Enrico Caruso Jr., 82; Actor and Son of Tenor
LEAD: Enrico Caruso Jr., an actor, singer and the last surviving son of the great tenor, died after suffering a heart attack Thursday at his home in Jacksonville, Fla.
He was 82 years old.


Anni Frind, Soprano, Is Dead; Performed in 20's and 30's
LEAD: Anni Frind, who sang leading soubrette soprano roles in both opera and operetta in the 1920's and 30's, died Wednesday in New Orleans.
She was 87 years old.


Towle Accepts Bid
LEAD: The Towle Manufacturing Company, a maker of silver and crystal tableware that filed under bankruptcy codes last year, agreed to be bought by the First Republic Corporation of America.
Under the merger agreement, a wholly owned unit of First Republic will merge with Towle in exchange for newly issued shares of Towle common stock equal to 80 percent of Towle's then outstanding common stock, the companies said.

Japan Called Stock Leader
LEAD: Japan's stock market became the world's largest in terms of capitalization this past week, partly because of the falling dollar, according to estimates released yesterday by a unit of Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, the investment banking house.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Campaign for Managers
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson said that his Operation PUSH hoped to meet with major-league owners and Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in an effort to increase the number of blacks in baseball management positions.


G.M. Gives Details Of Repurchase Plan
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation plans to use $1 billion in dividends from its finance subsidiary, a $900 million tax refund and deferred tax payments to generate more than $2 billion this year to fund its stock repurchase program.


ARMS HOPES RAISED IN REAGAN'S TALK AND GORBACHEV'S
LEAD: With high-level Soviet-American talks imminent, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave speeches today expressing hope for agreement soon on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.


FRANCE APPROVES ARMS PLAN LINKED TO EUROPEAN ALLIES
LEAD: Parliament overwhelmingly approved a major five-year rearmament program Thursday night.


SOIL EROSION PLAN IS AMENDED
LEAD: The House on Thursday unanimously approved a compromise designed to exempt alfalfa farmers from certain provisions of the nation's soil erosion program.

2,000 Officers Planned For March in Brooklyn
LEAD: The Police Department will deploy 2,000 officers to Brooklyn today to patrol a planned march by blacks protesting what they assert is harassment of blacks by all-white private security patrols operated by Hasidic Jews in the Crown Heights section.


Defendant in Iran Arms Plot Goes Free on $1 Million Bail
LEAD: An arms dealer accused of plotting to ship military equipment to Iran and other countries was released yesterday on $1 million bail despite objections from a Federal prosecutor.


SABERHAGEN ON 2-HITTER
LEAD: The continuing failures of the Yankee pitching staff were overshadowed for one night by Bret Saberhagen's brilliance.


SAUL MILLER
LEAD: Saul Miller, former information director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died of a heart ailment at a hospital here Thursday, the labor federation said.
He was 68 years old Mr.
Miller retired from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1981 after serving two years as its chief spokesman.


DIAL PAPERS TO RETURN TO YALE, FOR GOOD
LEAD: The Dial papers, among the most important literary collections of the 20th century, have been acquired by Yale University - one month after they were removed from Yale's Beinecke Library, where they resided for almost 40 years and were scheduled to be sold at auction in June.


Inquiry on Columbia Fight Stalls
LEAD: The Police Department said yesterday that an investigation into a campus fight March 22 between black and white Columbia University students had reached an impasse because the black complainants had refused to be interviewed after making a written complaint.


JURY SPLITS VERDICT IN TRIAL OF EX-CHIEF OF NEW YORK'S TAXIS
LEAD: Jay L. Turoff, the former chief of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, was cleared last night of using his office to enrich himself by promoting a taxi meter company formed by his friends and of accepting a bribe.


Military Suspends Cargo Airline
LEAD: The Military Airlift Command today temporarily suspended Southern Air Transport Inc. as a cargo hauler for the Pentagon pending a safety investigation after the fatal crash of a cargo plane earlier this week.


Paul E. Gay Dies at 48; Realtor in Manhattan
LEAD: Paul E. Gay, a realtor in Chelsea and Greenwich Village, died of a stroke Wednesday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 48 years old and lived in Chelsea.


No Headline
LEAD: N.B.A.  76ers 98, Bulls 96: Maurice Cheeks hit a foul-line jumper with two seconds remaining in overtime last night to defeat the visiting Bulls.
Cheeks, sidelined since March 20 with a finger injury, scored the game-winning basket after Michael Jordan completed a 3-point play with 15 seconds remaining to tie at 96.

LEAD: Doctors who had never heard of AIDS when they embarked on their careers now find it consuming a widening share of their lives, presenting stresses they never before contemplated.

LEAD: The dollar slid again today even though central banks were buying dollars and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d offered his assurances that the United States and other countries were ''fully committed'' to stabilizing currencies.

LEAD: Saying ''I'm finished with drugs,'' Micheal Ray Richardson signed a contract yesterday to play for the Long Island Knights of the United States Basketball League.

TV: 'EYE ON DANCE' FEATURES LOIE FULLER
LEAD: TERE O'CONNOR'S ''In and Around Your House,'' presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, starts out very promisingly.
The visual imagery is exquisite as three young women and two young men cross and recross an eloquently lighted stage.
The women wear loose white dresses and pale green pinafores, their hair tied back in buns, and the men are dressed in loose white shirts and green breeches.

LEAD: The President of Italy asked Interior Minister Oscar Luigi Scalfaro today to try to form a government to replace Bettino Craxi's five-party coalition, which collapsed in political feuding.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union freeze any deployment of short-range missiles while they discuss limiting and removing such weapons from Europe, independently of current talks on medium-range nuclear arms.

LEAD:  FAST LANES. By Jayne Anne Phillips. 148 pages. E. P. Dutton. $15.95.


Horner Near Japan Deal
LEAD: Bob Horner is reportedly close to signing a contract to play baseball in Japan this season.
The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday that Horner's agent, Bucky Woy, scheduled a meeting yesterday with Kazuo Souma, president of the Yakult Swallows, to reach final details on a one-year contract.


I.R.S. Criticized for 'Bully' Tactics
LEAD: A Congressional subcommittee, considering legislation to give taxpayers greater rights in disputes with the Internal Revenue Service, heard testimony today of abusive tactics employed by I.R.S. enforcement agents.


Rise in Mexican Inflation
LEAD: Inflation in Mexico grew at a rate of 23.6 percent in the first three months of 1987, the Government's central bank said today.
The rate exceeds the 19 percent reported for the first three months of 1986, a year in which inflation grew a record 105.7 percent for the entire year.
The Bank of Mexico figures indicated that the consumer price index had gone up 114 percent during the last 12 months.


Mystery of the Littered Auto Wrecks Unraveled in Upper Manhattan
LEAD: View along Edgecombe Avenue at 167th Street after two enforcement officers from the Parks Department found 31 smashed automobiles there.
Less than a week before, a major cleanup project removed auto wrecks from adjacent Highbridge Park.
Those had been discarded by car strippers; the new ones were left there by a city contractor.

CASHING C.D.'S THAT ARE I.R.A.'S
LEAD: LAST Monday a New Yorker's $4,000 certificate of deposit at Citibank matured.
He and his wife had bought the C.D. as an Individual Retirement Account two years ago when Citibank's rate for a two-year C.D. was 10.75 percent.
When the rate fell to its present 5.75 percent, they wanted to find another type of investment for their I.R.A.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Okamoto Leads by 3: Ayako Okamoto of Japan, making three straight birdies on the back nine, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead entering the final round of the $200,000 L.P.G.A.
Kyocera Golf Classic in San Diego.
Okamoto, holding the lead for the third straight day, had a three-round total of 205, 11 under par on the par-72 course and three strokes ahead of Pat Bradley and Betsy King, who each shot 71.

ROYAL RETREATS OF GREENERY AROUND PARIS
LEAD: The kings and emperors who ruled France knew the phenomenon well.
A hot summer's day in Paris laden with the prospect of thunderstorms.
The unpleasant smells of the steets and the Seine wafted over the quays and into the windows of their palaces.
They dreamed of green grass, trees and the quiet of nature.

LEAD: AMONG my reflections on this 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's successful integration of organized baseball is a cherished memory of Jack and me as an effective working pair.

Marriages, partnerships, organizational dyads, and friendships all offer an opportunity to achieve the above.

Our standard of living is the highest in the country.

BUYING TIME FROM THE TAX COLLECTOR
LEAD: IF you are still struggling with your tax return, but it is becoming clear that you will not meet the Wednesday filing deadline, there is a hope of reprieve.
It is called Form 4868, and if you file it by April 15, the Internal Revenue Service will automatically grant you a four-month extension to get your tax return in.

Efficient Space
LEAD: If design were judged by the square inch, some of today's tiny kitchens, bathrooms and closets would be near the top of the list.
These rooms, when transformed by architects and designers, become studies in efficiency, and often display a good deal of style as well.
Filled with Lilliputian appliances, they can be as functional as their larger counterparts.

PUTTING A STOP TO RAPID CURRENCY SWINGS
LEAD: JUST about everyone is dissatisfied with the wildly fluctuating currency values - euphemistically called ''floating'' or ''flexible'' exchange rates - that characterize today's international monetary system.
Without a common monetary standard, under which exchange rates could be stabilized, the remarkable economic integration of Western Europe, North America and East Asia in both commodity trade and financial flows has become less efficient, and is becoming untenable.


Performance Art
LEAD: The recent work of John Jesurun, the avant-garde director, writer, designer and film maker, provocatively explores the confusion between filmed and ''live'' reality by featuring actors who compete, interact, and even trade places with filmed characters.


DESIGN: THE RISKS OF RAZZLE-DAZZLE
LEAD: AS THE BROADWAY MEGA-SPECTACLE ''Starlight Express'' moves toward its finale, the extravagant melange of flashing lights and moving trusses, bridges, ramps, platforms and turntables that is the show's set begins to shift and turn and rise and fall.
The set's gyrations are at first puzzling, and then it becomes clear: a moment or two before the cast will take its final bows, the set is having its curtain call.

Rockers' Message

Mannes Trio Plays Haydn and Schnabel
LEAD: In the wake of its Naumburg International Chamber Music Award last year, the Mannes Trio came to Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night.
If this interesting program of Haydn, Schnabel and Brahms showed anything, it was the intelligence, ardor and technique of these three young women.
They are also beautifully rehearsed, and each seems to know and sense what the others are going to do.

BREAKING THE CYCLE: SUCCESS STORY IN THE STATES
LEAD: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system.
This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle.

LEAD: A TYPICAL ONE-PERSON BROAD-way show is a hyperbolic star turn in which a performer is escorted by an entourage onto a glitzed-up stage for an evening of self-congratulation.
But Barbara Cook, who is opening her one-woman show Wednesday at the Ambassador Theater, will not be cavorting with a chorus or ducking in and out of a flashy set.

Intangible But Attainable
LEAD: Silence, light, space and a view are the earth, air, fire and water of homes - elements that are basic to building desirable environments.
There are, however, few apartments or houses with them all, and none, it seems, with too much of them.
Especially in apartments in crowded and expensive urban areas, they have often become luxuries.

LEAD: ''If it ain't broke, and it makes money, don't fix it.'' That altered axiom demands that neither the N.H.L. nor the N.B.A. change any aspect of their playoff format.
LAWRENCE S. FOWLER  New York


SHORT (BUT NOT TOO)
LEAD: ON the runways at the recent couture collections, a lot of leg has been showing.
On the street, a little less of it is in evidence.


Winner, by a Surprise
LEAD: Perhaps no punch thrown in the middleweight championship boxing match last week was as stunning as the outcome.
Confounding sportswriters who scoffed at his chances and gamblers who took the 3-1 odds against him, Sugar Ray Leonard, who had not fought in nearly three years, won a split decision over Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who had not lost a bout in 11 years.

He is an American fashion independent in the genre of Charles James and Rudi Gernreich (victims both!), and that can be brutally frustrating.


LUXURY TODAY
LEAD: Who would have thought that the sight of a walk-in closet would inspire sighs of envy?
Or that a gardener's cottage, charming though it may be, would seem as precious as plover's eggs in a porcelain basket?
Indeed, many aspects of the home that once were taken for granted now seem like life's greatest luxuries.

What about a wild shot in the dark?
Investors have heard all those opinions in the last week, as Texaco's price slumped by $5 after a legal setback

LEAD: FOR two days last week, customers in a South Bronx grocery store smelled gas.
On Wednesday, the second day, the distinctive odor was so strong the manager sprayed air freshener around the checkout counter in the afternoon and told a clerk to call Con Edison.


OPERA: 'CARMELITES' CAST CHANGES
LEAD: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Francis Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' is among the company's very finest, and I cannot imagine anybody interested in music, theater, history, theology or a half-dozen other disciplines allowing himself or herself to miss it.
John Dexter's spartan production, the performances of Jessye Norman, Regine Crespin, Florence Quivar and the conducting of Manuel Rosenthal have already been discussed in these pages.

LEAD: Israeli military helicopters rocketed roads near Shiite Moslem villages in southern Lebanon today, killing two people and wounding four others, according to the state-controlled radio.


WHAT CAPITAL INFLOW?
LEAD: IN article after article, economists and journalists lament the United States' growing dependence on foreign capital.
They raise the terrifying possibility of disgruntled foreign investors rising up en masse, refusing to underwrite our profligate ways, thus raising interest rates and throwing America and the world into recession.

LEAD: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has chosen 273 artists, scholars and scientists as winners of its 1987 fellowships.
The awards, which this year total $6,336,000, are given on the basis of unusually distinguished past achievement and exceptional promise for the future.


Digital Finds
LEAD: The good life, these days, generally carries a higher price tag than it once did.
However, there is at least one exception to the mounting cost of good living, and that is the exuberantly expanding field of electronic home entertainment.
In a dramatic reversal of the usual spiral, prices for stereo and video equipment have been going down, and shoppers are happily searching for these affordable luxuries.


SHOULD PRO HOCKEY AND BASKETBALL ALTER PLAYOFF FORMATS?
LEAD: Professional basketball should begin the playoff season the first week of April, immediately following the N.C.A.A. basketball championship tournament, when interest in basketball is at a fever pitch.
The N.B.A. should also cut down on the number of teams eligible for the playoffs - preferably allowing only the top two in each division to compete - thus making the regular season meaningful again.

ITALIAN COMFORT IN NEW HAVEN
LEAD: MRESCA'S RISTORANTE in New Haven is something of a sleeper.
It is in a quiet, tree-shaded residential area in the Italian section of town, where one expects to find a typical neighborhood eatery.
Not so.
Although the premises are storefront-tiny, the space is well-utilized, with four smartly napped tables in the ground-level bar and the main dining area up a few steps.

LEAD: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before.
Recently, new colors and styles have enabled homeowners to put down floors that rival those of professionals, and improvements in adhesives and flooring materials have made installation simpler and more foolproof than ever before.

Voices of Spring, Faster and Louder
LEAD: The thawing brooks sounded almost like birdsong, flowing into gray creeks still cuffed with ice which debouched into rivers swelling green with the spring - where phoebes rode down the currents on little ice cakes to grab the first stoneflies.
As the snow melted off the fields, skunks and coons snapped up voles and moles whose tunnels had been exposed; and crows did the same, when they weren't pairing off, stalking around chatting shoulder-to-shoulder, while courting killdeer wheeled in the air overhead as agile as terns.

Not only was he re-elected by a comfortable margin, soundly defeating the alderman who had been a thorn in his side all through his first term; he also won a majority in the City Council.

No Excuses
LEAD: Taxpayers still puzzling over their 1986 returns might think twice before telephoning the Internal Revenue Service for help.
A recent study by the General Accounting Office found that the agency gives wrong or incomplete answers to 37 percent of those calling its toll-free help lines.

DOES THE HOLOCAUST DEFY DRAMATIZATION
LEAD: IT'S DIFFICULT FOR A TELEVISION dramatization to come to grips with the Holocaust.
Documentaries are better equipped.
A dramatization, no matter how thoughtfully done, is still make-believe.
A documentary need only show us, say, a pile of children's shoes.
We feel a terrible sorrow then; the unimaginable has been expressed.

The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue

Yonkers Condo
LEAD:  To the Editor:


THE ELUSIVE ART OF MULTI-TASKING
LEAD: ''CONFUSION to the enemy'' seems to be the main theme of the International Business Machines' long-awaited announcement of a new line of personal computers.
As it turned out, the machines, which were introduced two weeks ago, were not the clone killers they had been previously rumored to be.
But their built-in graphics chips, their improved structure for transporting data within the computer and their monitors, which forsake the digital standard and function more like television sets, will certainly make the job of would-be duplicators more complicated.


Art
LEAD: Daniel Buren, a Frenchman, and Sol LeWitt, an American, are painters who have in common that they work on an environmental scale and in an idiom in which there is no trace of an individual hand.
Buren works primarily with broad vertical stripes that can turn up anywhere, anytime.
Though perfectly at home in museums and galleries, they also have a way of insinuating themselves into metropolitan landscapes the world over.

The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
LEAD: One can empathize with Halston's loss of the right to his name.
However, he did receive some compensation.
There is no compensation for any person who buys a ''Halston'' fashion at J.C.
Penney, thinking that the designer at least reviewed, if not actually designed, the garment.
It borders on fraud to market under the name of someone who had no connection.

No Headline
LEAD:  SUBLET IN A CO-OP  Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a Manhattan building that has been converted to a co-op.
In the next year I expect to be out of the country for six to eight months.
I would like to sublet my apartment.
How would I do this? . . .
V.
A., Manhattan  Answer: Nonpurchasing tenants in buildings that have been converted to cooperative residences who have the right to remain in their apartments also have the right to sublet their apartments.

Wall Street has succumbed to scandal.
Military contractors have admitted to overcharging the Pentagon.

Airport Security
LEAD: To the Editor: As a professional photographer, I always have my camera and film bag hand checked at airport security gates.
At the Newark, St.
Louis and Detroit International Airports the procedure varies widely.
However, I was pleasantly surprised recently at the United Airlines security check at Los Angeles International Airport when the guard asked me to take the cameras and film out of my bag and put them on a tray on the counter.


ADDING VINYL TILE: IT'S EASIER THAN IT USED TO BE
LEAD: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before.
Recently, new colors and styles have enabled homeowners to put down floors that rival those of professionals, and improvements in adhesives and flooring materials have made installation simpler and more foolproof than ever before.

Joseph P. Temple of Naples, Fla., took place yesterday.
The Rev.
Ralph Warren Jr.

If You're Thinking of Living in:; MURRAY HILL
LEAD: THE perception of the Murray Hill district on Manhattan's East Side as a genteel turn-of-the-century residential enclave is becoming as faded as an 1890s guerreotype as many of the area's old brownstones are converted into commercial space and residents are forced to move eastward into new high-rise apartment houses.

LEAD: The following multiple-choice questions are from the 1983 National Teachers Examination.
The sampling is taken from the section dealing with professional knowledge.
Answers appear at the bottom.  1.
Because of energy conservation measures in the school district, classroom thermostats have been lowered to 68 degrees.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  SUBSEQUENT PERFORMANCES.
By Jonathan Miller. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $25.) In this valuable contribution to a longstanding debate, Jonathan Miller marshals his two decades of theatrical experience and his considerable knowledge of art and science to make the case for messing around with the classics.


FLORENCE
LEAD: Florence in springtime puffs up its feathers and struts, like the million pigeons roosting on the city's cinnamon-colored cupolas.
The hillsides are scattered with daffodils and red tulips, the almond and cherry trees are the first to blossom followed by yellow clouds of mimosa, while the irises, swathed at dusk in shimmering fireflies, grow along the cypress-lined avenues leading up to the Piazzale Michelangelo.


PINE TREE LANE, ONLY FILLY IN RACE, WINS IN BOLD RULER
LEAD: Pine Tree Lane, the only filly in a field of seven outstanding sprinters, outran the boys at every call to score an impressive 1 1/2-length victory in the $172,800 Bold Ruler Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.


WATERFRONT RACE DRAWING TOP NAMES
LEAD: WTH a large budget and a host of elite American runners, the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon is quickly being established as one of the country's premier races of its kind.


ACCEPTABLE TV/VCR ON A BUDGET
LEAD: IF UNITED STATES GOVERN-ment plans for a 100 percent tariff on a variety of Japanese electronic products go into effect, the price increases that would likely result would strain the resources of many budget-minded television and VCR buyers, making it essential to seek models that offer acceptable performance at the lowest price.

LEAD: ''Abyssinia,'' the new gospel musical, begins with a miracle.
Moments before Patience Jackson (Cheryl Freeman), a young, recently widowed sharecropper, is about to give birth in an Oklahoma cotton field, the sky darkens, and a tornado descends from the heavens.
Just as the laborers are about to be swallowed up, Mother Vera (Tina


Sports of The Times; TAKING A POLL ON MULLIGANS AT THE MASTERS
LEAD: FOR every green coat that a Masters champion wears, two or three green coats remain empty.
During the final holes at Augusta National, several green coats are brought from the champions locker room or the pro shop to the white cabin near the clubhouse where the television ceremony occurs.
Various sizes are selected to fit the golfers in contention out there on the treacherous back nine where the Masters is always won, as it will be today.


ERSATZ TOMBSTONES REPLACE THE HISTORIC
LEAD: IN an increasing number of Connecticut cemeteries, he who steals a historic gravestone steals a fake.
Cemetery associations around the state are replacing old gravestones with concrete copies, saving the originals from thieves, vandals and the weather.

LEAD: The photograph of Lauren Bacall is not from ''Applause,'' but ''Woman of the Year.'' The gown she is wearing was designed by Theoni Aldredge, who designed the entire wardrobe for the production.
Ms.
Bacall did eventually wear a red Halston suit as a replacement for a gray ensemble in ''Woman of the Year.

Brothers Aim for Trans-Atlantic Mark
LEAD: Bruno and Loick Peyron, world-class multi-hull sailors from France, know what it is to compete against each other as brothers.
But never has the rivalry been so intense as in their current duel.
The two ocean racers are attempting to break the trans-Atlantic speed record, each in his own boat.

ENCOUNTERS OF ANOTHER COLOR
LEAD: Junior year abroad, 1980: I am an American in Madrid.
More specifically, I am a black American in Galerias Preciados, a downtown department store.
I don't shop, however, for very long.
In typical tourist fashion I am all over Spain's most cosmopolitan city.
I traverse the Retiro, an elegant, formal garden with a lagoon.

How to Privatize Big-Time College Athletics
LEAD:  To the Editor:


A Transit Officer Kills Man During a Dispute
LEAD: An off-duty transit police officer last night shot and killed the former husband of a woman described by authorities as a friend of his.
The woman was injured by a shot as the officer and the former husband struggled, the police said.


Getting Honest
LEAD: Reading and rereading D. Gary Phelps's article ''Getting Honest'' (About Men, March 15), I found it uncannily like my own experience, for I, too, left a marriage and two children at midlife in order to live my life as a homosexual.
Unfortunately, Mr.
Phelps has yet to shed all the persistent prejudices about homosexuality that led him (and, I might add, myself) to hide in the ''closet'' for so many years.


CHRISTIANS SHARE JOY OF SEDER T&gt;By CHARLOTTE LIBOV
LEAD: ''BARUCH atah Adonai Eloheinu melech ha-olam borei p'ri hagafen,'' chanted Cantor Deborah Katchko-Zimmerman, beginning a blessing said in Hebrew before the drinking of the four ritual glasses of wine at the Passover seder.


U.S. Denies Reported Accord On Nuclear Arms With Japan
LEAD: The State Department has denied reports by Japan's Communist Party that a document the party discovered was proof of a secret American-Japanese nuclear arms agreement.


CURED NEW HERRING OF THE NETHERLANDS
LEAD: Every year on a Saturday in late May, the Dutch herald the new herring season with a festival.
It's called Vlaggetjesdag, or Flag Day, and in the harbor at Scheveningen, a resort and seaport two miles from The Hague, ships large and small are festooned with rainbows of fluttering flags.
Local people from nearby fishing villages don traditional costumes; there are folk-dancing exhibitions, and folk orchestras play favorite local tunes.


RECORDS INDICATE FLAWS IN INSPECTIONS OF THRUWAY BRIDGE THAT COLLAPSED
LEAD: State records indicate that a number of required procedures were ignored or circumvented during the most recent inspection of the bridge on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed last Sunday, apparently sending at least 10 motorists to their deaths.
Two more bodies were recovered yesterday, bringing the total to six.


BUSING'S AFTERMATH: CHILDREN IN YONKERS HIT BY MOTORISTS
LEAD: In the seven months since a court-ordered school integration plan introduced extensive busing to Yonkers, this city of 190,000 people has recorded an alarming number of children being hit by motorists improperly passing halted school buses.


Vermont Legislators Approve Increasing Speed Limit to 65
LEAD: A bill raising the speed limit to 65 miles per hour on nearly all of the Interstate highways in Vermont has been approved by the State House of Representatives.

LEAD: A late Easter is usually good for business: Balmy weather helps retailers sell their spring merchandise.
But this year's late Easter won't be enough to get overall consumer spending to bloom.

BILL IRWIN CLOWNS AROUND AT THE BEAUMONT
LEAD: WHEN BILL IRWIN'S ''THE Regard of Flight'' opened in New York in 1982, critics called it the most refreshing innovation in theater since air-conditioning - and also said they didn't know whether to categorize it as theater or as a clown show.
Since then it has been around the country, and around the world, most recently in Sydney.


KING RETURNS, BUT NOT AT TOP FORM
LEAD: Trent Tucker peeked out of the shower and surveyed the scene.
A gathering crowd in front of a locker on the other side of the room had begun to swell onto the area in front of the adjacent stall, his stall.
The group made it nearly impossible for the Knick guard to towel off and dress in peace.
But Tucker was not annoyed.


WHALERS LIFT HOPES FOR TITLE IN HARTFORD
LEAD: HARTFORD is reveling as its Whalers participate in the National Hockey League playoffs.
Although the team has made the playoffs for the second year in a row and the third time since it joined the league in 1979, the Whalers have reached a new height - capturing the Adams Division title.

LEAD: AS headlines go, this one was particularly prescient. ''Red Creek Ridge: 'It's the Thing of the Future,' '' a newspaper in the Hamptons said of a proposed Hampton Bays development about five years ago.


GORBACHEV ALLUDES TO CZECH INVASION
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew home today after alluding to the Soviet decision to end the liberalization movement of 1968.


PARENTS GO SHOPPING FOR TEACHERS
LEAD: THERE is a spring phenomenon that, for many teachers, has become tradition.
Soon, if it has not already begun, ''concerned parents'' will be filtering in and out of elementary-school classrooms, ''observing the teaching styles'' of their childrens' teachers for the next year, picking and choosing which one will be ''just right'' for little Johnny.

EDMUND WILSON AMONG THE 'DESPICABLE ENGLISH'
LEAD: I MET Edmund Wilson, I think, sometime in the early spring of 1946, after I had come back from Moscow to finish the job I was doing at the British Embassy in Washington.
I had been in Washington during the war years, and my friend the Russian composer Nicolas Nabokov, who, like his cousin Vladimir, was a friend of Wilson's, thought that he might like to meet me (I had expressed my intense admiration for ''Axel's Castle'' and ''The Triple Thinkers'') and talk about Russian literature and other topics.

LEAD: Primo Levi, whose autobiographical writings drew on his experiences as an Auschwitz survivor and his training as a chemist, died today in Turin.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD: BUXTEHUDE'S BIRTHDAY Legend has it that Johann Sebastian Bach walked 200 miles from Arnstadt to Lubeck to hear Dietrich Buxtehude play, so strong was Buxtehude's influence on young Johann.
Yale University School of Music will celebrate the 350th birthday of the Danish composer and church organist with a symposium of concerts and other events today through Tuesday.

Next Week; How Big A Problem Is Racism In Sports?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: INVINCIBLE COURT is a vintage apartment building of 1920's Harlem, a brick dowager with a dainty sitting area in the lobby and 53 brass mail boxes that still close and lock.


SIZING UP BASEBALL SALARIES
LEAD: Fifty-seven players began the baseball season assured of earning $1 million or more this year.
Sixty-six players of the 663 who were on opening-day major league rosters or the disabled list will earn $62,500, the minimum salary.


LEGACY OF A MOTHER'S MURDER
LEAD: THE ORDER OF THE New Jersey Superior Court on Sept. 19, 1985, was explicit.
Philip Andrew Taylor, 15 months old, would be in the custody of his deceased mother's sister and her husband from ''September 1 each year to June 30 of each following year.''


Meeting Offers Hope for Fewer Animal Tests
LEAD: Efforts to use fewer animals for testing the safety of chemicals and consumer products are progressing, but they are still facing important technical and regulatory obstacles, according to top industry scientists.

LEAD:  WOMEN AND MEN  By Joseph McElroy. 1,192 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.


Rev. Michael Peterson, Hospital Founder, Dies
LEAD: The Rev.
Michael R. Peterson, a priest of the Archdiocese of Washington who was the founder of St.
Luke Institute, a psychiatric hospital for priests and brothers and sisters of the Roman Catholic church, died Thursday of complications resulting from the AIDS virus.
He was 44 years old.


7 ARTISTS IN NEW BRITAIN SHOW
LEAD: THE double-barreled title explains as well as identifies the show that it is conferred on but does so slowly, as if its readers were chronically inattentive.
It's a device that, notwithstanding a long career as a structural cliche, few curators can resist.
The reason may be the commentations of solemnity that the construction has acquired.


Separatists Kill 5 in India
LEAD: Sikh separatists in the north Indian state of Punjab have killed five people and burned more liquor, tobacco and barber shops, the police said today.
The militants have burned and looted more than 150 shops in the last month.
Alcohol, smoking and the cutting of hair are forbidden by the Sikh religion, but the campaign is also seen as an attempt to destabilize the state's Sikh Government.

I am also in agreement with Gloria Acerra re ''Loving the Acres but Seeing the Flaws''  [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, March 22 ] .

THINGS THAT GO BUMP IN THE KITCHEN
LEAD: ONE of the nicer things about living in the 1980's is the enormous variety of time-saving appliances and gadgets available.
It's easy to learn how to use them; the difficult part, I find, is to know which sound from which is signaling, ''I'm all finished, dear.''

Marianne Savare Plans to Marry Ronald A. Walter
LEAD: Mrs.
Leo Savare of Memphis, Tenn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Marianne Savare, to Ronald Anderson Walter, a son of Norris O. Walter of Memphis and the late Estelle Anderson Walter.
A June wedding is planned.
The future bride, the daughter also of the late Mr.
Savare, is a science teacher, and her mother, Elsie Savare, is an elementary-school teacher in the Memphis school system.

LEAD: With all Halston's ''power'' friends, he should be able to do something for the good of our New York City art and design schools.
He could give lectures to design students who would pack auditoriums for some free words of advice.


DODGERS FINALLY FIND A PLACE IN VICTORY COLUMN
LEAD: Pedro Guerrero and Mike Scioscia hit bases-empty home runs in the second inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers ended a five-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
The defeat was the first for the Giants, who had won their first five games for the first time since 1962.

LEAD: While she is awaiting the outcome of her appeal, Mary Beth Whitehead will be allowed to visit the child she was hired to bear.


Japan Denies Dumping Chips
LEAD: A Japanese trade official denied today that Japan had ''dumped'' computer chips at prices below true value and reaffirmed that Tokyo would take countermeasures if Washington went ahead with its sanction plans.

LEAD: Behind the pre-Passover calm that traditionally envelops Israel this time of year some time bombs are ticking away beneath Israel's political establishment, and they have within them the power to change the face of Israeli politics.

LEAD: NOAA, the short title for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is nearly the perfect acronym. ''This is NOAA Weather radio,'' the voice begins, and the listener envisions Noah himself, dispatching a dove to see if the Flood has abated.

Signs of Spring
LEAD: NO QUESTION ABOUT IT, spring is a season that seems to unleash a certain carefree spirit-in designers as well as in customers.
The former are apt to come up with merchandise and ideas on the romantic, whimsical, even saucy side.
The latter, on the other hand, aremorelikely to spendmoney on something that is not needed but simply gives a boost to the morale.

LEAD: A Federal jury has awarded $2.5 million to Carroll J. Moore Jr., who was severely scalded while showering at the Venice Inn and Motel in Hagerstown in November 1982.
Mr.
Moore, 40 years old, suffered extensive burns and respiratory injury in the 162-degree shower.
The jury found April 2 that the Watts Regulator Company of North Andover, Mass., which makes a valve that the motel had installed to regulate water temperature, was liable for damages.

SHOULD PRO HOCKEY AND BASKETBALL ALTER PLAYOFF FORMATS?
LEAD: It doesn't matter.
The regular seasons of hockey and basketball are just a mediocre form of entertainment anyway.
By the time the long, drawn-out seasons lead into the long, drawn-out playoffs, baseball is around to rescue real sports fans from the doldrums of winter. (But I suppose that if there are fans of pro hockey and basketball, then a shorter road to the championship is in order.)

LEAD: IS reality necessary?
Lighthearted, lightfooted reader, do not flee!
Our subject is no tough ontological rind. (Philosophers, go home.) It is, rather, the mazy gossamer of make-believe; the desire to be invisible; the longing for strange histories that never were; the urge to slip loose from one's own life.

Bridge Research
LEAD: James W. Baldwin Jr., a civil engineering professor at University of Missouri at Columbia, standing by a section of a bridge near Columbia.

Mr.
Baldwin puts the span under stress with weights and hydraulic devices in hopes of finding why bridges fail.

LEAD: MY father worked at a news agency, so we often heard the big news before it was on the radio or in the papers.

Everyday Artifacts

Both sides want to clear the way for a summit in Washingon, where President Reagan and Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev can sign the arms control agreement that has eluded them so far.


ARE EMBASSIES CHRONICALLY INSECURE?
LEAD: AFTER radical Iranian students climbed over a wall and overran the United States Embassy in Teheran in 1979, investigators found that only 13 lightly armed Marines and a few civilian security officers had been guarding the 27-acre compound.

BOUNCING BEEPS, FROM COAST OT COAST
LEAD: DAVID HODGEMAN'S trucking company, Southern Pride, transports jet engines for some 40 airlines to airports all over the country.
When a plane needs a replacement engine - and Mr.
Hodgeman receives calls for such replacements more than once a day - his trucks are expected to arrive at the airport quickly enough to keep the flight schedule relatively intact.

PHOTOJOURNALISM LAYS CLAIM TO THE REALM OF ESTHETICS
LEAD: FIFTEEN YEARS AFTER THE DE-mise of Life as a weekly magazine, photojournalism is reclaiming its former glamorous, legendary status.
Pictures that were taken on assignments for magazines and newspapers now regularly reappear - in frames - on the walls of museums and galleries.
The photojournalists of yesteryear are being enshrined in biographies and celebrated with retrospective exhibitions.

U.N.'S WAR CRIME FILES AT ISSUE IN NEW DEBATE
LEAD: THE United Nations War Crimes Commission, which was established during World War II, went out of business in 1948 without establishing clear guidelines for access to the 36,800 files it had compiled on alleged war criminals, suspects and witnesses.
The files were shipped to the fledgling United Nations Secretariat, which consulted with former commission officials and ordered them closed, except for ''United Nations purposes.

LEAD: A POPULAR television quiz show, ''Jeopardy,'' provides answers and leaves contestants groping for questions.
Something of the same sort was happening at bridge tables throughout North America at the beginning of this month.
Assume that the answer is: ''Four - double yesterday's number.'' What is the question?

Golf; Masters Field Has a Hard Time With Greens
LEAD: Take a wool blanket with a short nap and lay it over a dining room table.
Then lift one end of the table and place a brick under each leg so the table tilts just slightly.
Then put a golf ball on the high end and try to stop the ball before it goes over the edge.


Sally-Jane Heit In Comedy and Music
LEAD: The characters that the comedian and singer Sally-Jane Heit portrays in her one-woman show are mature urban women up to their necks in complications and generational contradictions.
Her most fully realized character is a woman in her 40's who has finally earned her law degree.
In a matter of minutes she learns that her daughter, who has just been accepted into Princeton University, is pregnant and would rather get married and work in a supermarket than go to college.


Topeka Wins Segregation Suit
LEAD: More than three decades ago, Oliver Brown, a black railroad worker, sued the Topeka Board of Education and its ''separate but equal'' system, in which black and white children were required to attend different schools.
He won the case in a landmark 1954 U.S.
Supreme Court decision, Brown v.
Board of Education, which set in motion the desegregation of the nation's public schools.

LEAD: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before.
Recently, new colors and styles have enabled homeowners to put down floors that rival those of professionals, and improvements in adhesives and flooring materials have made installation simpler and more foolproof than ever before.

A GOLDEN RULE FOR SOFTWARE
LEAD: IN THE classroom and elsewhere, educational floppy disks are entitled to the same copyright protection as the more traditional textbooks.
But while illegally duplicated books are easy to spot, the same is not true of software; Once tucked inside a personal computer, the disks are invisible.
And many publishers say they fear their material is being copied by student hackers and teachers, for reasons ranging from the fun of breaking a manufacturer's copy-proof code to undersupplied courses that rely on software.

Hunting Down An Eagle Slayer
LEAD: THE slaying was done with ''a small-caliber projectile'' that tore through the neck and right lung, officials said.
The body was found last Dec. 23 in the Heislerville Wildlife Management Area in Maurice River Township, Cumberland County, N.J.
The victim: a young bald eagle.
Since then pledges of rewards for information leading to conviction of the killer have grown to about $10,000, says Gregory Huljack, deputy chief of the Bureau of Law Enforcement in the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife.

Ford is the latest automaker to do that, and the company's Lincoln-Mercury division has a new baby called the Tracer, a good idea that has started, shall we say, inauspiciously.

A BRIDGE FALLS, AND NO ONE KNOWS WHY
LEAD: LATE last week, the swift currents of Schoharie Creek receded enough to let the state police divers work.

Creature Comforts
LEAD: My litany of household luxuries is simpler than most - I don't really want to live with taffeta curtains that puddle on the floor, with walls tinted by layers of hand-rubbed lacquer or even with a roomful of 18th-century museum-quality antiques.
Luxuries like these are too costly and too obvious for my tastes.

Unemployed, With Compensation
LEAD: Being fired as chairman of CBS Inc. last September may have cost Thomas H. Wyman some pride and power, but it appeared to be no financial hardship.
A CBS proxy statement released last week showed that Mr.
Wyman received a settlement of more than $4.3 million and would get annual payments of $400,000 for life.

ADDING VINYL TILE: IT'S EASIER THAN IT USED TO BE
LEAD: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before.
Recently, new colors and styles have enabled homeowners to put down floors that rival those of professionals, and improvements in adhesives and flooring materials have made installation simpler and more foolproof than ever before.
