Sons on Sidelines
LEAD: TO keep the new basketball coaching staff at Washington State straight, you don't need a program so much as a genealogy.
Kelvin Sampson, a former Cougar assistant who was named head coach, is the son of a former high school coach in North Carolina.
One of his assistants is Dave Harshman, a former high school and junior college coach, whose father is Marv Harshman, a long-time coach at both Washington and Washington State.


MEN'S STYLE
LEAD: THE THREE-BUTTON suit, long perceived as an emblem of decorum, is quietly making a comeback.
Spurring its revival are lean, uncluttered lines and a patrician appearance evocative of more gracious times.
These days, fans of the style can choose from a wealth of interpretations, all of which, to some degree, retain a traditional look.

Building in the Classic Style
LEAD: Once upon a time, luxury meant one advantage above all others - space.
Sure, a grander house had more elaborate architectural details, finer construction and more bathrooms, but the real plus it had to offer was room.
Ceilings were higher, rooms were bigger and there were more of them.
It's no news that this kind of luxury is rare today.


WHAT WE TELL NATURE AND WHAT IT TELLS US
LEAD: ''THE greatest delight which the fields and woods minister is the suggestion of an occult relation between man and the vegetable,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson said in an essay on nature.
I would like to think I know what he means.


The Purpose of Lifting
LEAD: I BEGAN LIFTING A few weeks before my 16th birthday, in May 1949.
My closest friend and next-door neighbor had bought a used York barbell set and constructed a pressing bench from a slatted wooden cocktail table left unclaimed in the cellar of the Bronx apartment building in which we lived.
Frankie had dropped out of high school a month earlier and was bound for Parris Island and the Marine Corps at the end of September.

POPE'S MESSAGES COVER DEMOCRACY AND DOCTRINE IN CHILE AND ARGENTINA
LEAD: WHEN Pope John Paul II spoke last week of democracy and dictatorship in Latin America, more often than not he was addressing a debate within his own church.
In Argentina, the Pope met bishops who used his presence to condemn human-rights violations by past military regimes, and other prelates who were equally determined not to reopen old wounds.

ANCIENT PRAGUE'S MODERN DISKS
LEAD: PRAGUE, THAT ANCIENT, golden city where the beer is strong and the gravy thick, has long been a center of musical composition and performance.
Two hundred years ago, Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' and ''Don Giovanni'' had their first performances there.
In the more recent past, Czech composers such as Dvorak, Janacek and Smetana have gained international repute, and the strong tradition continues to this day, with a cohesive musical life that is among the most vital in

THEY STILL DON'T DO WINDOWS - YET
LEAD: UNTIL fairly recently, beepers were primitive sorts of contraptions.
They were conspicuous, too weighty to carry comfortably, and a pain to use.
In fact, they did not even beep.
To receive a message, you had to hold the beeper to your ear, press a button and listen to an operator reiterate a bunch of numerical codes.

THE OLD SCHOOL TIE: O! THOSE HALCYON PREPARATORY DAYS
LEAD: MY father is one of the most stoic men I have ever met.
He rarely embraces when a hand-shake will do or otherwise lets the world know how he is feeling.
I can remember, however, one occasion when tears of emotion streamed down his face.
It was not a death, birth or any other momentous occasion; rather it was as he was watching ''Old Yeller.

HORACE ADALI SAWYER
LEAD: Horace Adali Sawyer, a former president and chairman of the Lone Star Cement Company, now Lone Star Industries, based in Greenwich, Conn., died last Wednesday in New Orleans, where he had moved after his retirement.
Mr.

Zimbabwe Reported to Buy 12 Advanced Soviet Fighters
LEAD: Zimbabwe, in a challenge to neighboring white-ruled South Africa, has secretly bought 12 MIG-29 interceptor aircraft, the Soviet Union's most advanced warplane, the Sunday Telegraph reported.


WILLIAM MORTON
LEAD: William Morton, a star quarterback for Dartmouth in the early 1930's and a member of the College Football Hall of Fame, died Saturday.
He was 77 years old.


More to Learn From the City Volunteers
LEAD: Two years ago, with talk of a need to foster a ''spirit of altruism'' in the young, Mayor Koch boldly launched New York's City Volunteer Corps.
It was to be a three-year experiment and a potential model for a system of national youth service.
Now, just into the third year, the Mayor seems ready to declare the experiment a failure and cut its funding from $10 million to $6 million.


Inflation Up In Mexico
LEAD: Inflation in Mexico hit 23.6 percent for the first three months of 1987, the central Bank of Mexico announced Friday.


Sosnoff Is Seen Raising His Bid
LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor who has offered about $735 million for Caesars World Inc., raised his bid yesterday from $28 a share, to $32 a share, in the hopes of edging out a management counter-offer valued by the market at around $31, according to a source close to Mr.
Sosnoff.


Islands in Alien Seas
LEAD: The American Embassy in Moscow is an island under constant assault.
Laser beams probe the windows for echoes of conversations.
Tunnels have been bored below, and antennas thrust up its chimneys.
Cocktail bars and swimming pools are alive with ''swallows,'' seductive women who lure the susceptible into ''honey traps.

How to Keep Greece and Turkey Apart
LEAD: Not for the first time, Greece and Turkey barely managed to pull back from the brink of violence recently.

Yet none of the basic causes of the crisis have been removed.

LEAD: The impact of the loss of Bernard King to a serious knee injury two years ago cannot be overstated.

But what the Knicks also missed was the respect he commanded, an aura that benefited the entire team.

LEAD: City auditors accused the City University of New York yesterday of perpetrating ''a farce'' in its method of selecting collection agencies to obtain overdue bills from students, but the university denied the charge.


Tax Anxiety
LEAD: Of the 105 million taxpayers who will file personal tax returns for 1986, 30 million haven't yet.
Millions put it off because they owe the Government and prudently don't pay until the Wednesday midnight deadline.
But other millions just don't want to face the music until they have to.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas is expected to rule Tuesday on whether to allow the Placid Oil Company, one of the Hunt brothers' major holdings, to proceed with a major deep-water drilling effort in the Gulf of Mexico that is known as the Green Canyon project.

LEAD: The Libyan bombers appeared as silver flashes in the blue sky.
Their falling bombs exploded nearby and sent plumes of sand, smoke and red-hot metal shards into the desert air.
Chadian gunners fired hand-held antiaircraft missiles, but the circling planes flew too high to be hit.

Canadian Joblessness
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate held steady in March at 9.6 percent as modest growth in the number of people employed was offset by expansion of the labor force, Statistics Canada said Friday.
The Government agency said the number of employed in March, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose 23,000 from the previous month, to 11.8 million.

Nathan Smith, a former superintendent of Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx, died Saturday in Miami.

Music Noted in Brief; David Van Tieghem, A Performance Artist
LEAD: Experimental music and downtown showmanship have rarely been blended more delightfully than in the early solo performances of the debonair young percussionist and composer David Van Tieghem.
In ''A Man and His Toys,'' the show Mr.
Van Tieghem toured around Europe and the United States, he played a cheerfully eccentric scientist of sound effects, eliciting an extraordinary range of amplified thuds and squeaks from a laboratory of household objects.

Stephen R. Lieber of New York.
Rabbi George Schlesinger performed the ceremony.
Mrs.
Lieber, a graduate of Rutgers University, as is her husband, is an agency finance specialist in Newark, and her husband is an estate and financial planner in New York, both for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company.

Charles Aznavour's rueful vignettes about marriage and the late Harry Chapin's psychological portraits of loners and losers were also conceived for theatrical performance outside of a narrative dramatic context.

Kim Kashkashian Offers Viola Recital
LEAD: Kim Kashkashian's viola recital Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum was pristine and deeply satisfying.
The viola is too often played as if it were a slightly hoarser version of a violin; less often (and usually more grotesquely) it is treated like a surrogate cello.
In fact, of course, at the risk of sounding obvious, it is itself - an instrument of patrician expressivity, with a burnished luster to its alto tone, its somewhat closeted sound made up of wonderfully variegated shades of gray.

This is the story: Stephen Penchina and Arthur Selkowitz founded Penchina Selkowitz in 1982, and it really flourished, thanks largely to one account: the Burroughs Corporation.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone apparently suffered a political setback Sunday as his party's candidate lost a closely watched gubernatorial election.


Sudan Cuts Sentence for Aide Who Helped Ethiopian Jews
LEAD: A court has reduced the sentence given to former Vice President Omar el-Tayeb for his role in transporting thousands of Ethiopian Jews through the Sudan to Israel.


ON ISLE WHERE MANY WEEP, PLANS TO LIFT SPIRITS
LEAD: Fifteen minutes by ferry from Dakar lies a low, sun-washed island that was the last bit of Africa seen by millions of people before they crossed the ocean to a lifetime of slavery.


DDB Needham Gains Schering-Plough Task
LEAD: Schering-Plough in Memphis has decided to give creative responsibility for most of its Mabelline brand to DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.
The assignments are coming out of Ted Bates Advertising/New York and the Bloom Agency, Dallas.


ZEVULON AVSHALOMOV
LEAD: Zevulon Avshalomov, a composer and performer of traditional Persian and Caucasian music, died on April 4.
He was 77 years old and lived in New York City.


MIZE MASTERS 140-FOOTER TO WIN TITLE IN PLAYOFF
LEAD: Larry Hogan Mize, born and raised within a few miles of the Augusta National Golf Club, fulfilled a boyhood dream today when he won the 51st Masters by beating Greg Norman with a historic shot.


C. F. Louis DeWild, 86, Dies; Longtime Painting Restorer
LEAD: C. F. Louis DeWild, for many years a leading professional in the field of painting conservation and the restorer of great paintings that are now in the Metropolitan Museum, the National Gallery of Art, the Frick Collection and elsewhere, died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on April 2.

LEAD: Unwilling to raise taxes for new social programs, Congress is moving to require employers to provide many additional health and welfare benefits to employees and their families.


Car Bombs Injure 13 in East Beirut as Fighting Flares Across Green Line
LEAD: Rescuers aiding an injured boy after a car-bomb explosion, one of two in the largely Christian quarter that wounded at least 13.
Moslem and Christian forces fought with artillery and tanks across the Green Line, striking residential areas nearby.
It was third day of clashes in Beirut and the nearby hills.

LEAD: AN awkward and unexpected obstacle to the Government's proposed $4 billion supercollider, a giant particle accelerator meant to extend the experimental reach of modern high-energy physics, has emerged from a recent series of scientific breakthroughs.

LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City was prepared to take over a private concrete plant that it had helped establish in an effort to force down prices charged by other concrete suppliers.

LEAD: It is easy to see, at first glance, just how far blacks have come since Jackie Robinson shattered baseball's color barrier four decades ago.

LEAD: In a town normally given to hyperbolic response to the smallest, most distant hiccup, the bankruptcy filing on Sunday by the nation's eighth largest industrial company made virtually no impression on official Washington.

LEAD: As Elizabeth M. Cosper changed lenses on a microscope and focused it, she cautioned a visitor to the Marine Sciences Research Center here not to expect too much.

LEAD: A youth who clung to a raft as it drifted off the southern tip of Staten Island was missing yesterday, but his companion swam safely to shore, officials said.
The search for the missing youth, Brian Omundsen, 16 years old, of 356 Richard Avenue, Princes Bay, Staten Island, was called off shortly before 10 P.M.

What to do?

LEAD: General Partners, an investment group consisting of Wagner &amp; Brown and AFG Industries, has sold all but a tiny fraction of its 8.6 percent stake in Gencorp Inc.
Last week the investors terminated their $100-a-share, or $2.2 billion, hostile takeover bid after Gencorp announced that it would pay $130 a share for 54 percent of its stock.

LEAD: Heavy selling of mortgage-backed securities plus fears that the Federal Reserve was tacitly encouraging higher short-term interest rates led to sharply lower prices for notes and bonds yesterday.

LEAD: The conditions could not have been less desirable for a home opener in the Bronx.

LEAD: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed Claus von Bulow's $20 million countersuit against his estranged stepson, who has accused the Danish socialite in a civil suit of trying to kill his mother.


MERRILL LYNCH EXPANDS NET 25% IN BUSY QUARTER
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company yesterday reported a 25 percent increase in its first-quarter net income, helped by the new tax law and higher earnings from interest on margin accounts.


Puerto Rico Floods Kill Man
LEAD: Up to six inches of rain fell in eastern and northern Puerto Rico on Sunday, causing flash floods that killed a 45-year-old man, civil defense officials reported.
The officials said the man's body was recovered after his car was carried away by floodwaters as he tried to cross a bridge in Guaynabo.


UAL Said to Study Pilot Buyout Plan
LEAD: Directors of UAL Inc. were reported to have met in Chicago yesterday to consider a $4.5 billion United Airlines buyout proposal offered by its 7,000-member pilot union.
The company refused to confirm or deny that meetings were under way.
In Cleveland and Denver, meanwhile, union leaders met with employees in the first of several sessions to explain the plan, which the company is believed to oppose.


SENATE DEMOCRATS WANT TOP-LEVEL DRUG FIGHTER
LEAD: Senate Democrats are quarreling with the Reagan Administration again over the creating a Cabinet-level post for the direction and coordination of Federal efforts to combat illegal drugs.

LEAD: Senior White House officials said today that President Reagan was virtually certain to issue a proclamation Friday that doubles the import prices of some Japanese electronic products and predicted that the action would lead to a ''difficult'' trade situation with Japan.


Whale Fossil Found in Antarctica
LEAD: Ewan Fordyce, foreground, a paleontologist from New Zealand, and Judd Case of the University of California at Irvine examining fragments from a whale fossil said to be 40 million years old.
The National Science Foundation announced that the fossil, the largest ever found in Antarctica, was that of a 30-foot-long flesh eating whale.

LEAD: Since Britain withdrew from the eastern half of Nicaragua in 1894, the region has been known as Zelaya Province, named after the Nicaraguan president at the time, Jose Santos Zelaya.

LEAD: The White House counsel has asked President Reagan's senior aides to give him all internal documents related to the Iran-contra affair, including any records that might exist from Mr.
Reagan's first term, according to a White House spokesman.


OFFICIALS TRY TO PREPARE FOR NEW IMMIGRATION LAW
LEAD: Less than a month before the sweeping new Federal Immigration Law takes effect, officials are scrambling to prepare for the estimated 750,000 illegal aliens in the New York metropolitan region who are expected to seek to legalize their status.


ARCHITECTURE: NEW LLOYD'S IN THE CITY OF LONDON
LEAD: The City of London is a dense web of classicism, a tightly knit mass of low, masonry buildings that in its intricacy feels something like Venice with automobiles.
Although plenty of new architecture has come to this old part of London in recent years, no building has arrived with the hoopla that has surrounded the new headquarters for Lloyd's of London, the insurance marketplace.


MAGADAN'S RETURN TO METS IMMINENT
LEAD: The Mets did not retrieve Dave Magadan from the disabled list yesterday, the first day he was eligible to return to active duty.
But they were expected to restore him to the team by the end of the week, and Magadan reported from Florida: ''I consider myself back to normal.''


2 May Bid For Dome
LEAD: Two European-based oil companies, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the British Petroleum Company, emerged today as possible bidders for the assets of Canada's troubled oil giant, Dome Petroleum Ltd.


THE METHOD, STILL DISPUTED BUT NOW UBIQUITOUS
LEAD: Forty years after the founding of the Actors Studio - and after years of controversy - the Method has become an accepted and, many would argue, a necessary instrument for the actor, whether or not he is appearing in a naturalistic play.
In the 1940's and 1950's, the Method was the predominant influence on American acting, and then went through a period of eclipse as other acting techniques flourished.


ISLANDERS RELISH BEING IN A CORNER
LEAD: The night before had verged on being ugly.
There was the 4-1 loss to the Capitals in a game full of penalties.
And at the end, the ice was littered with crumpled cups hurled by irate fans who didn't like the notion of their team's limping off to Washington to face elimination.


Tariffs Seen as Harmful
LEAD: Users of Japanese electronics today warned of financial losses, layoffs and even a negative impact on public safety if certain targeted goods are hit by punitive tariffs that the Reagan Administration is preparing to impose later this week.


Connecticut Sniper Sought
LEAD: The police searched today for a sniper who struck three cars, slightly injuring one man, on Interstate 95 on Saturday.
The first shot, which occurred about 5:30 P.M., shattered the windshield of a northbound pickup truck near Exit 18.
Its 30-year-old driver, whose name was not available, was treated for minor cuts and released from Norwalk Hospital.


William Stoneman, 83; Foreign Correspondent
LEAD: William H. Stoneman, former chief European correspondent for the Chicago Daily News, died Saturday in Paris.
He was 83 years old and lived in a suburb of Paris since his retirement in 1969.


QADDAFI IS FACING UNHAPPY COUNTRY
LEAD: A year after the American raid on Libya, Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have taken more power into his own hands but faces a nation unhappy with his costly defeat in Chad and economic chaos at home, according to diplomats here.

LEAD: The Yankees were all geared up for their home opener yesterday.
The loudspeakers were turned on high.
Ba-boom!
The organ was filled with high-test.
Dum-dum-dum-dum!
And the tapes were tastefully selected.
Whoop-whoop!

LEAD: In even the most tranquil times, the first night of Passover is full of turbulent emotions for the Jews who have been trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union.
The words ''next year in Jerusalem,'' pronounced during the traditional seder, have both a hopeful and a hollow sound.


Building of Ark Allowed to Continue
LEAD: A Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that Kea Tawana can keep working on the 125-ton ark she has been building for five years in Newark's Central Ward.


BOTH STOCKS IN OIL FEUD ARE DOWN
LEAD: The stock price of Texaco Inc. fell in very heavy trading yesterday as the large oil company tried to soothe the frazzled nerves of investors, lenders, suppliers and business partners in the wake of its bankruptcy filing on Sunday.


PACT IS REACHED ON OWNERSHIP OF A HOSPITAL
LEAD: The operators of North General Hospital, the only minority-run voluntary hospital in New York State, have reached an agreement that would give them complete ownership of the Harlem center and significantly ease the financial problems that have dogged its eight-year existence.


MORE INMATES SEEN UNDER NEW RULES
LEAD: The number of inmates in Federal prisons would rise substantially under a new set of sentencing guidelines issued today by a Congressionally created commission.


Jacques Francois, Civilian on Haiti Junta
LEAD: Jacques A. Francois, the civilian member of the three-man National Governing Council, died today.
He was 78 years old.


Business and Health; Blue Cross Vs. Hospitals
LEAD: IN several places in the country, Blue Cross/Blue Shield is bickering with local hospitals.
The traditionally friendly relationship between the nation's largest insurer and the hospitals has been breaking down as both sides have expanded beyond their historic roles - and, in some areas, have begun to be competitors.


Big Pentland Gain From Reebok Sale
LEAD: The London-based Pentland Industries P.L.C. said it would report a substantial capital gain from the sale of part of its holdings in the athletic footware maker Reebok International Ltd.
The sale will trim Pentland's stake in Reebok to 32.2 percent from 36.7 percent.


Stray Bison
LEAD: Firefighters in Montgomery County, Md., trying to coax a buffalo Sunday from a lawn in Bethesda.
The animal was tranquilized and taken to a nearby farm until its owner could be located. (AP)


EUROPES ANTI-TERRORISM TIED TO U.S. LIBYA RAIDS
LEAD: The American raids against Libya that a year ago stirred widespread protests are today widely acknowledged to have galvanized Western European countries to intensify their own anti-terrorist efforts and to coordinate police operations across borders.


Ex-Guinness Head's Denial
LEAD: The former head of Guinness P.L.C. today denied allegations that he had ordered files, appointment diaries and correspondence shredded in December after the Department of Trade began investigating the company.


JURISDICTIONAL ISSUE IS RAISED ON A SCHOOL MEDITATION LAW
LEAD: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that a 1982 New Jersey law requiring one minute of silence daily in public schools was valid, but that for procedural reasons the Court could not rule on it.


AT MACY'S, ALL IS ABLOOM
LEAD: The woods have come to Herald Square: to Macy's, to be precise.
The store's 13th annual flower show began its weeklong run Sunday, with rustic fences and all manner of greens and blossoms decorating the windows and spilling over showcases throughout the main floor.


Rig Count Falls Slightly
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week to 749 from 752 the week before, the Hughes Tool Company said today.


EX-M.T.A. CHIEF AND OTHERS ACCUSED OF FRAUD IN A SUIT
LEAD: Harold L. Fisher, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who has long been active in city and state Democratic affairs, and 17 other people have been accused in a civil lawsuit of defrauding two defunct Long Island insurance companies of $16.4 million.


COOPERATION VS. COMPETITION
LEAD: Scientists often say that as much as they learn from highly technical presentations at meetings, they learn even more about trends in their field from discussions in hallways and over meals and cocktails.
A scientific conference here last week was no exception.

THREAT TO TENANTS' SUBSIDIES STIRS CONCERN OF U.S. OFFICIALS
LEAD: Officials around the nation are concerned that over the next decade more than half a million low- and moderate-income families may be ousted from federally subsidized apartments built in the 1960's and 1970's.
Hundreds of families already have lost their homes and the numbers are likely to increase rapidly.

LEAD: A cool, damp day in early April could not diminish the warmth Willie Randolph feels on these occasions.
After 12 years, he said that the first home game of the season is still preceded by a restless night before, the anticipation building for the annual reunion of a ballplayer and the fans.


PHYSICIST AIMS TO CREATE A UNIVERSE, LITERALLY
LEAD: PHYSICISTS often probe the workings of nature on a cosmic scale, but Prof.
Alan H. Guth and his colleagues at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology may have set themselves the ultimate research goal.
They are seeking a mechanism by which humans might create a new universe from scratch.

LEAD: The Government appeared to retreat somewhat today from a complete ban on protests against detention without trial, saying that it would not apply to religious services.

LEAD: The scores of nine complete Mozart symphonies, handwritten by the composer, will be auctioned at Sotheby's in London on May 22.
The manuscripts, which will be sold as one offering, are expected to bring $1.5 million.


LASER LESSENS THE TRAUMA OF SURGERY IN UTERUS
LEAD: LASER surgery, which has revolutionized the treatment of several sight-threatening eye disorders, now promises to do the same for many common gynecological problems, including one - abnormally heavy uterine bleeding -that is usually treated by hysterectomy.


ABC MAY TRANSFER SALINGER
LEAD: ABC News, trying to cut costs in its overseas operations, plans to cut its Paris bureau staff of 25 people by more than half and may transfer its chief European correspondent, Pierre Salinger, out of Paris, according to network officials.

LEAD: A drive to recruit Hispanic college students for mid-level Civil Service jobs in New York State government will begin in the late spring, the executive director of Governor Cuomo's Office for Hispanic Affairs said yesterday.

LEAD: Primo Levi, the writer who fell down the stairwell of his apartment on Saturday in an apparent suicide, was buried today in a simple ceremony attended by family friends and members of Italy's Jewish community.

RECITAL: CHRISTA LUDWIG
LEAD: NOTHING quite satisfies in the same way as a program of German song offered by artists of true understanding and skill to a knowledgeable and receptive audience.
There was no question about the audience Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall: In ''Lob des hohen Verstandes,'' Christa Ludwig made the gentlest of double-entendres out of the German word for ''wait,'' addressing it both to the contestants in the song and, sort of, to James Levine at the piano.

NEW FOSSIL IS FORCING FAMILY TREE REVISIONS
LEAD: WHEN the discovery of the provocative ''black skull'' was announced last summer, the small, contentious fraternity of paleoanthropology was stunned into a rare state of unanimity.
Everyone agreed that the skull was the most significant early humanlike fossil to be found in more than a decade.
Everyone agreed it would necessitate a major rethinking of the human family tree.

LEAD: DINIZULU and His African Dancers, Drummers and Singers have always known how to put on a good show.

This was theater that gracefully taught one about history and world cultures, with commentary provided throughout the evening by Amadoma Bediako, the program's narrator and a compelling storyteller.

LEAD: For four months now a prominent black South African editor, Zwelakhe Sisulu, has been held alone in a cell in Sandton, near Johannesburg.

LEAD: Convergent Technologies, a computer manufacturer based in San Jose, Calif., said it expected results for the quarter ended March 31 to show a loss of more than twice the $4.8 million reported in the fourth quarter of 1986.
The company predicted declines in both operating groups: its traditional business of supplying computers under other company names, and its business systems group of companies, which supply specialized computer systems to business users.

'FRONTLINE' EXAMINES 'SECURITY RISK' OF 1946
LEAD: PENN TOWNSEND KIMBALL, journalist, professor and sometime political aide, was labeled a security risk by the State Department in 1946.
The label, based on flimsy evidence, has apparently never been removed. ''The Secret File,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary on Channel 13 at 10 tonight, examines Mr.
Kimball's case.

LEAD: To the Editor:


HART, STRESSING IDEALS, FORMALLY ENTERS THE 1988 RACE
LEAD: On a wind-swept rock formation in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, Gary Hart formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, declaring that the country was falling far short of its ideals and urging the revival of a sense of national purpose.


Jackson Stirred
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson, an undeclared contender for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, has fired off a testy letter to Impac '88, a group of major party fund-raisers.


Officer Is Dismissed For Evading Queries
LEAD: A New York City police officer who has been indicted on charges of stealing nearly $18,000 from his estranged wife's bank account after she disappeared mysteriously last summer was dismissed from the force without a pension yesterday.

Careers; A Broker's Training at Giant Firm
LEAD: HIGH on a 40-foot pole a blue flag with a bull outlined in white flaps in the breeze.

Figures Disclosed in Esposito Bonus
LEAD: Phil Esposito, general manager and interim coach of the Rangers, stands to earn $110,000 in bonuses if his team wins the Stanley Cup.
Esposito's contract, copies of which were obtained by The Associated Press, show that the bonus provisions call for $10,000 if the Rangers win their first-round playoff, an additional $20,000 if they win the Patrick Division, $30,000 more if they win the Wales Conference and a $50,000 bonus if they win the Stanley Cup.


U.N.L.V. Player Killed
LEAD: A Nevada-Las Vegas football player was shot to death during a drug deal in Fresno, Calif., the police said yesterday.
Andre Dwayne Horn, 21 years old, was shot during a dispute Sunday night, then staggered two blocks where his assailants caught up with him and shot him again, the police said.
No arrests were reported.

U.S. ENTERS CASE OF JULIAN BOND
LEAD: Federal agencies are investigating cocaine abuse allegations against former State Senator Julian Bond and other prominent Atlanta residents, a Federal prosecutor said today.


STAGE: 'BLACK MARIA,' A PLAY OF FILM
LEAD: ENTERING La Mama Annex, rearranged to accommodate John Jesurun's ''Black Maria,'' one immediately wonders where the stage is.
The seats are facing in all directions and fill the floor space.
The fact is there is no stage.
With ''Black Maria,'' Mr.
Jesurun has moved a step beyond ''Deep Sleep'' and ''White Water,'' the previous plays in his theater-movies-television cycle.


Sosnoff Raises Bid For Caesars World
LEAD: The New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff, as expected, sweetened his unsolicited takeover bid for Caesars World Inc., raising his offer by 14 percent, to $32 a share.
In a communication to Caesars' chairman, Henry Gluck, Mr.
Sosnoff said that shareholders ''will be best served by our entering immediately into good-faith, friendly negotiations.


Kristiansen Plays Beat the Clock
LEAD: In the last 20 years, while the men's world-best time in the marathon has been improved by less than two and a half minutes, the women's has dropped by more than three quarters of an hour.
Now a milestone in the women's steady gains may be at hand.
Ingrid Kristiansen, preparing for the London Marathon next month, is taking dead aim at what was once considered an unattainable quest: a time under 2 hours 20 minutes.


BankAmerica Fills Job at Unit
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that Richard M. Rosenberg had been appointed vice chairman and head of its newly designated California Banking Group.
Mr.
Rosenberg, who has worked in banking for 28 years, has been president and chief operating officer of the Seafirst Corporation, a BankAmerica subsidiary and parent of the largest bank in the state of Washington, since December 1985.


Man, 77, Who Killed Ill Wife Loses One Bid for Freedom
LEAD: A Federal magistrate today recommended denial of a petition seeking freedom for Roswell Gilbert, the 77-year-old man convicted of killing his terminally ill wife.


Kent Taylor, 80, Dies; TV's 'Boston Blackie'
LEAD: Kent Taylor, who portrayed the dapper, crime-stopping detective in the television series ''Boston Blackie'' in the early 1950's, died Saturday at the Motion Picture and Televison Hospital.
He was 80.
As ''Boston Blackie'' from 1951 to 1953, Mr.
Taylor played a dashing former crook who became a detective.

LEAD: To stop the spread of AIDS, President Reagan advises virginity unto the marriage altar and monogamy ever after.
That would probably do it, all right, but the President has yet to follow through with advice on how to bring back those two old lifesavers.

LEAD: The FMC Corporation's lawsuit for damages against three Wall Street firms and four figures involved in insider-trading scandals was dismissed in a United States District Court in Chicago yesterday.
The Chicago-based company had sought $260 million from Ivan F. Boesky; Goldman, Sachs; Shearson Lehman/American Express; Drexel Burnham Lambert, and three investment bankers employed at those firms in 1985: Ira B.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Maps accompanying reports about Chad on Jan. 18, March 26, April 3 and April 5 incorrectly located Wadi Doum, the Libyan airfield that fell to Chadian forces in March.
A map showing the correct location appeared yesterday; Wadi Doum is about 85 miles northeast of Faya-Largeau.

Market Place; Canada Stocks Outpace Dow
LEAD: AFTER being dormant throughout 1986, Canada's stock markets not only sprang to life this year but, as measured by the popular averages, have also been outpacing the spectacular gains posted on the American equities exchanges.


Interfirst Posts Loss in Period
LEAD: The Interfirst Corporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it had a loss of $18.9 million in the first quarter of 1987, in contrast to earnings of $2.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.
The company said the loss included $20.4 million in gains from securities sales.


The '88 Non-Campaign in Korea
LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan has radically simplified South Korea's political choices.
For a time, it looked as though the issue was how much democracy he would allow to succeed him.
Now the contest seems to be between him and democracy - and he is winning.
By suspending national debate over how to choose his successor, he contradicts the spirit, if not the letter, of his own promises.


TEACHING AS 2D CAREER: TAPPING THE SCIENTISTS
LEAD: RETIRED scientists, engineers and technically trained military personnel could combat the shortage of mathematics and science teachers and many are ready to do so, according to a new study by the National Executive Service Corps.


U.S. RELIEVES AIDE WHO RAN DRUG TESTS IN AMTRAK CRASH
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration, which is investigating reports of irregularities at its drug and alcohol testing unit in Oklahoma City, has relieved the unit supervisor pending the outcome of the investigation, agency employees familiar with the situation said today.

LEAD: It took only three games for Bernard King to return to his familiar form.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch center for St.
John's, is on crutches and wearing a walking cast over his left ankle.
Baldi, who played with tendinitis in his left heel last season, has been informed by doctors that he must take weight off of the foot for at least two weeks. . . .
The 76th and apparently final entry in the Indianapolis 500 was named yesterday when Rick Miaskewicz, a rookie from Denver, was named to drive a new Cosworth-powered Lola race car.


AGENT FOR MANY TOP ACTORS
LEAD: Bruce Savan, a leading New York theatrical agent whose clients included such artists as Sam Waterston, Bernadette Peters, Vanessa Redgrave, Peter Allen and Mary Tyler Moore, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
Mr.
Savan, who was 59 years old, had been suffering for several months from acquired immune deficiency syndrome.


RANGERS MAY GET EDGE FROM DEPTH
LEAD: If it should happen again that the Rangers eliminate the Flyers it would be called an upset, a fluke.
But by now it should be clear that there is at least one tangible factor at work for the Rangers in the playoffs: They have depth; the Flyers do not.


Baseball's Racial Hypocrisy
LEAD: For sheer hypocrisy, the baseball hierarchy's reaction to the discrimination-in-management issue is hard to beat.
The same goes for those suddenly expressing outrage at a condition they have silently tolerated for nearly 30 years.


NO SIGN OF SLOWING DOWN AS JET ENGINE MARKS 50TH
LEAD: Just 50 years ago, on April 12, 1937, a device so common today that it is taken for granted roared to life for the first time in a laboratory in Rugby, England, and, although it was not known at the time, a new age in aviation had begun.
The jet engine had worked.

LEAD: John W. Hinckley Jr., who attempted to assassinate President Reagan and is now trying to convince a Federal judge his mental illness is in remission, wrote sympathetically to one multiple killer and kept the address of another, Charles Manson, a psychiatrist testified today.

Boeing-707 Cargo Jet Crashes, Killing Three
LEAD: A Boeing-707 cargo jet crashed in light fog tonight as it was preparing to land at Kansas City International Airport, killing three people aboard the plane, the authorities said.


Chicago Merc Rebuffs Shift
LEAD: Members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange soundly rejected a petition yesterday to ban dual trading in Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts.
Dual trading allows traders to trade for their own accounts as well as for clients.

LEAD: Shortly after the first American ambassador arrived in Moscow in 1933, Stalin asked him over dinner whether there was anything he could do for him.
Yes, the envoy, William C. Bullitt, replied, he would like ''that lovely bluff overlooking the Moscow River'' for an embassy site.

LEAD: The aunt and uncle of a 4-year-old girl whose father has been charged with trying to sell her were ordered today to surrender their passports to prevent them from fleeing the country to avoid a custody fight with the girl's stepmother.

LEAD: The three principal shareholders in the Taft Broadcasting Company, formerly viewed as rivals in their efforts to acquire the company, have joined to make a bid of $155 a share, or about $824 million.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed ridding Europe of all short-range nuclear missiles along with medium-range missiles, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

JUDGE SUPPORTS G.M. ON BRAKES IN 1980 X-CARS
LEAD: A Federal District Court today dismissed a Government lawsuit aimed at forcing the General Motors Corporation to recall more than a million cars because of what safety officials said were defective brakes.


First Baby M Visit Under New Ruling
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead visited her year-old daughter yesterday for the first time since she was stripped of her parental rights.

LEAD: They are two of New York's more notable invalids, Joe Klecko and Roger McDowell.

LILCO SEEKS SUMMER USE OF SHOREHAM
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company asked the Federal Government today for permission to generate commercial levels of electricity at its Shoreham nuclear power plant for the first time.


WHEN THE DODGERS IGNORED ROBINSON
LEAD: The reincarnation of Jackie Robinson resumes.
Out on Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn at noon today, in front of the Ebbets Field apartments, the Brooklyn Dodgers Hall of Fame will honor baseball's first black major leaguer on the 40th anniversary of his first game.
And on Friday a three-month exhibit of Jackie Robinson memorabilila will open at the New-York Historical Society at 170 Central Park


Don't Raise the Minimum Wage
LEAD: Democratic legislators are right to search for ways to help the working poor, but wrong to think that raising the minimum wage is one of them.
To do that would hurt many low-income workers, something legislators need to grasp before ramming a bill through Congress.

A Bit of Old Queens Saved From the Wrecker - for the Time Being
LEAD: Bulldozer tearing down former trolley station in Woodside.
Demolition was ordered halted, because of the lack of a proper permit, just as century-old, red-brick clock tower was about to be torn down.
Site was being razed for a shopping center.
Although it is not a designated landmark, preservationists hope the structure can be integrated into the new center.

The Pope and the Victims
LEAD: Pope John Paul II showed the power of moral leadership in his recent trip to Chile.
He defended the Chilean church in its mission of solidarity with victims of government persecution.
He stood up to Chile's dictator.
And he gave hope to a martyred people.

Canceled: A Vital Child Welfare Data Service
LEAD: To the Editor:


Gencorp Settles TV Station Sale
LEAD: Gencorp Inc. said that it had reached an agreement for the previously announced sale of its television station KHJ-TV of Los Angeles to the Walt Disney Company.
Gencorp also announced the settlement of a Federal Communications Commission proceeding involving the station.
As previously reported, Disney agreed to pay a base price of $320 million to buy the independent television station.


In Remote Nicaragua, Cuban Ships Refill Shelves
LEAD: Normally, residents of this isolated coastal area of northeast Nicaragua are entitled to buy one pound of low-priced beans and a like amount of rice every 15 days.
But in the second half of March, supplies ran low and residents were put on half rations.


The Making of a Presidential Announcement
LEAD: Some contenders announce their candidacy for President.
Others announce that they will announce their candidacy.
Still others announce the formation of ''exploratory committees,'' which is usually a way of announcing an intention to announce, eventually.


U.S. LABOR OFFICIAL
LEAD: Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the Department of Labor from 1946 to 1965, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md.
He was 90 years old and lived in Washington.

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: MY grandmother was rather vain, and I loved her for it.


BOND DENIES WIFE'S INITIAL STORY AND SAYS HE NEVER USED COCAINE
LEAD: In his first public response to reports that his estranged wife had told the police he was a cocaine abuser, former State Senator Julian Bond categorically denied today that he has ever taken the drug or committed any crime.


Sales of U.S.-Built Cars Fall 15 Percent in Period
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars fell 15 percent, to 193,139 units, in the first 10 days of April, the eight manufacturers reported today.
Sales of light trucks rose 1.5 percent, to 97,687, partly offsetting the decline for automobiles.

Tests Find No PCB's In 5 Wells in Jersey
LEAD: The United States Environmental Protection Agency has told the residents here that final tests have found no detectable traces of PCB's in their water, an agency spokesman has said.


SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
LEAD: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives.
Business executives make and unmake deals over food.
Statesmen negotiate treaties over food.
Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes.
Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Cavaliers 113, Nets 95: Ron Harper scored 21 points, and Cleveland held New Jersey to 4 points in the first 6 minutes 20 seconds of the fourth quarter last night in Richfield, Ohio.
The Cavaliers shot 66 percent in the first half as John Williams, who finished with 20 points, scored 15 and Harper 14.


Mantle Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Mickey Mantle, the former Yankee star, was released from the hospital in good condition today after tests that showed chest pains he suffered probably stemmed from stress syndrome, a hospital spokesman said.


Japan Bond Sale Studied By Los Angeles County
LEAD: Los Angeles County might raise up to $1 billion in yen-denominated bonds in the Japanese bond market this year, according to a county official who was in Tokyo as part of a local economic development mission.

AIDS IS NOW SPREADING TO POPULOUS WEST AFRICA
LEAD: Africa's AIDS epidemic is spreading from its stronghold in central Africa to a previously untouched area - West Africa, home to almost half of sub-Saharan Africa's population, health experts in the region say.


SUICIDE RATES OF TEEN-AGERS: ARE THEIR LIVES HARDER TO LIVE?
LEAD: EVERY 1.1 seconds a teen-ager tries to commit suicide.


AVERAGE SIZE OF HOUSEHOLD IN U.S. DECLINES TO LOWEST EVER RECORDED
LEAD: The average number of people per household in the United States declined last year to 2.67, the least ever recorded, the Census Bureau reported today.


NEW FUND FOR SMOKING BAN IS SOUGHT
LEAD: The new smoking restrictions in New York State can be imposed despite the denial of a $300,000 legislative appropriation, state health officials said yesterday.


SABERS AND LASERS MEETING AT WEST POINT
LEAD: The United States Military Academy, showing its age as the oldest of the service schools, has begun a $48.2 million renovation program to accommodate a new generation of technologically advanced officers.

STAGE: POLITICAL HOPES IN 'AS IT IS IN HEAVEN'
LEAD: IF Obies were given out for timeliness, ''As It Is in Heaven'' would walk away with this year's prize.
Joe Sutton's new play, which opened last night at the Perry Street theater, lets us in on a weekend meeting of the staff of an aspiring Republican Presidential candidate while a deal is being worked out with an unctuous television evangelist named Rat Paterson.


A BULLDOZER STARTS, BRIEFLY, ON QUEENS TROLLEY STATION
LEAD: Two century-old towers from which a web of Queens trolleys once spun provided the setting yesterday for a dramatic showdown as preservationists waited - moment by moment - for the city to halt demolition of the former New York and Queens County Railway terminal in Woodside.


Argentine Loan Accord
LEAD: Argentina said today that its creditor banks had agreed to refinance a major portion of its $50 billion foreign debt and to provide about $1.8 billion in fresh funding.

Kickoff Classic On a Sunday
LEAD: The first college football game of the season, the Kickoff Classic between Iowa and Tennessee, will be played at 1 P.M.
Sunday, Aug. 30, instead of Monday night, Aug. 31, so it can be televised nationally by ABC.


The Rarest Kind Of Ball Club
LEAD: When it comes to ''necessities,'' the most fateful word Al Campanis ever spoke, Tracy Lewis would appear to have all she needs.
She is the 25-year-old president of the Savannah (Ga.) Cardinals, a Class A St.
Louis affiliate that is unique as a black-operated professional baseball team, and she has begun turning around what used to be a dismal franchise.

How Do We Make It Fashionable to Save?
LEAD: To the Editor:


EXPERTS ASSESS IMPACT OF MOZART MANUSCRIPT
LEAD: Scholars and dealers in New York and London excitedly assessed the importance yesterday of a 500-page manuscript of nine of Mozart's early symphonies, a bound work that has not been seen or handled widely in this century by scholars and musicians and that is to be auctioned next month.


Pleasant Surprise for Flyers
LEAD: Pelle Eklund played a secondary role in the regular season for the Flyers, but he emerged as a protagonist in tonight's fifth game of the playoff series against the Rangers.


Shipshape
LEAD: Kent Biggerstaff, the Pirate trainer, responding to word that Pittsburgh's portly Rick Reuschel had gained four pounds since last season: ''That's like putting just another suitcase on the Queen Mary.''


Real Estate; Downtown Revival in Jersey
LEAD: LIKE lots of other older towns, Hackensack, N.J, saw its downtown wither in the 1960's as suburban shopping centers siphoned off many of the Main Street shoppers, diners and moviegoers.

Economic Scene; Trade Deficit: Strains Grow
LEAD: THE huge United States trade deficit - and the huge surpluses of Japan, West Germany and the newly industrialized countries of Asia -could become the focal point of the 1988 Presidental campaign.
The trade imbalance, which widened to $15.06 billion in February despite the falling dollar, is already imposing severe strains on international relations.


Oilers Wrap Up Series With Kings, 4-1
LEAD: Esa Tikkanen and Glenn Anderson each scored his second goal of the game in the third period to lead Edmonton to a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight that advanced the Oilers to the Smythe Division final.


New Haven Concern Is Fined on Dumping
LEAD: Uretek Inc., embroiled in a bitter strike over health and safety conditions at its New Haven plant, was fined $250,000 Monday for illegal storage and dumping of hazardous waste, the authorities said.

LEAD: Like survivors poking their heads out after a tornado has passed, economists, bankers and business leaders have begun looking for signs of an economic pickup in the oil-producing states, which were battered by last year's collapse of energy prices.


Marking Another Death From Violence in Ulster
LEAD: Funeral procession for Robert McLean in Portrush, Northern Ireland.
Mr.
McLean and another reserve officer with the Royal Ulster Constabulary were slain Sunday while on patrol in Portrush, about 50 miles north of Belfast.
The Irish Republican Army has claimed responsibility for the slayings. (Reuters)

TOXIC CHEMICAL SPILL IN UTAH CAUSES A DEATH AND 6 INJURIES
LEAD: About 2,000 gallons of a toxic chemical spilled from a ruptured pipe today, killing one man, injuring six other people and forcing the evacuation of about 1,000 people from an industrial park here, officials said.


When Telephone Solicitation Is the Best Way
LEAD: To the Editor:


Prime Computer's Two New Models
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. said it had introduced a more powerful minicomputer that executes 11.8 million instructions a second and can run applications previously used by mainframes and minicomputer networks.
In addition to the new computer -the 6350 system - Prime showed its ''dual processor'' version, the 6550, which combines two processors in one computer.

LEAD: One of Burma's leading painters, the muralist U Ba Kyi, has just completed an unusual assignment.


UAL's Adviser To Discuss Bid
LEAD: UAL Inc., apparently bowing to Wall Street pressure, instructed its investment banker today to discuss an unsolicited offer that it had received from its pilots' union.

LEAD: THE problem was emphasized tragically in New York last week: Almost half of the bridges in the United States are structurally deficient, no longer able to carry the loads for which they were designed.

60-MINUTE GOURMET

Retiree Returns To Fill In at MCI
LEAD: V. Orville Wright came out of retirement yesterday to become acting chief executive of the MCI Communications Corporation.
Mr.
Wright will fill in for William G. McGowan, who is recovering from a heart attack.
Mr.
McGowan, 59 years old, will retain the title of chairman.


SOVIET OFFER PUTS U.S. IN A QUANDARY
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to eliminate short-range missiles in Europe seems to put the United States in a quandary.


U.S. TRADE GAP WIDENS, ADDING TO DOLLAR STRESS
LEAD: The United States deficit in international trade grew to $15.06 billion in February, the third-biggest monthly imbalance on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

Ambassador Perkins's Prayer
LEAD: It's finally possible - how long has it been? -for Americans to take pride in some Reagan Administration conduct in South Africa.
Washington has rightly and promptly condemned the Pretoria Government's sweeping new rules barring protests against mass detentions without trial.
Better still, Edward Perkins, America's new Ambassador and a black, made a point of participating in an ecumenical service in Cape Town that offered defiant prayers for the detained.


U.S. Marines Shouldn't Guard the Embassies
LEAD: To the Editor:


ROOTS OF YOUNG MARINES IN SPY CASE: LITTLE HINT OF THE UNUSUAL
LEAD: There is little in the lives of three marines accused of allowing Soviet agents into the Moscow Embassy while they were on guard duty there to distinguish them from others of their age and background who enlisted in the Marine reserves while still in high school.


NBC Leads TV Ratings For 11th Straight Week
LEAD: NBC led the television ratings for the 11th week in a row, according to figures released yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.
The victory represented the 26th time this season NBC has won the ratings, more than any network since ABC won 27 weeks in the 1977-78 season.


SOUTH KOREA CHURCH LEADERS FAULT CHUN
LEAD: South Korean church leaders attacked President Chun Doo Hwan today for his decision to shut off debate on changing the constitutional method of selecting the next national leader.


CONTEL SEEKS TO PULL OUT OF COMSAT MERGER DEAL
LEAD: The Contel Corporation said today that it was seeking to end a proposed $2.4 billion merger with the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat.


CLUB CHIEF'S MURDER CASE NEAR CALIFORNIA JURY
LEAD: The possibility that a jury could send a man to death only to learn later that his purported victim was alive was raised today in final arguments at the murder trial of Joe Hunt, leader of the Billionaire Boys Club, a group of young men from wealthy families.


Standard Board Defers on B.P. Bid
LEAD: The board of the Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it would follow the recommendation of its special committee and not take a position on a bid by the British Petroleum Company, its major stockholder, to buy the rest of the company.
The board, after a daylong meeting at Standard Oil headquarters in Cleveland, said the special committee would make a recommendation on the offer to the board by April 23.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


AFTER THE KIWI? PASSION FRUIT, OF COURSE
LEAD: PASSION fruit and the intricate flower that blossoms before the fruit develops are as suitable as the lily at Easter.
The passion flower was first named by 17th-century Jesuit missionaries who discovered it in the jungles of South America and related parts of the flower to the Passion of Christ.


Bridge: Player, Rushed to Hospital, Returns to Help Team Win
LEAD: Many players struck by illness have had to be taken to a hospital in the middle of a tournament.
On one memorable occasion a declarer who had suffered a slight heart attack and was lying on the floor while awaiting an ambulance insisted on being handed his cards.
He happily completed his three no-trump contract from the floor and made it.


The U.N. Today: April 15, 1987
LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL  Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Smoke Bomb in a Dormitory Leads to Death of a Student
LEAD: A fire in a college dormitory was started early Sunday by a smoke bomb that was apparently set off as a prank, and an 18-year-old student died after being overcome by smoke, the police said.

MORTON WILFRED BLOOMFIELD, HARVARD MEDIEVALIST, IS DEAD
LEAD: Morton Wilfred Bloomfield, a professor of medieval literature at Harvard University, died here today after a short illness.
He was 73 years old.


SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
LEAD: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives.
Business executives make and unmake deals over food.
Statesmen negotiate treaties over food.
Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes.
Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward.


DRUG DEFENDANT BELIEVED DEAD IN BOMB BLAST IN COURTHOUSE
LEAD: A man on trial for selling drugs was apparently killed today when a briefcase he was carrying exploded in the Howard County courthouse, and at least 15 other people were injured, including the sheriff, the authorities said.

The Economic Tangle
LEAD: The collapse of that Interstate Highway bridge over Schoharie Creek in New York dramatizes what the Federal Highway Administration recently told Congress - that it will cost $50.8 billion, $13 billion of it needed immediately, to make all the nation's bridges safe again.


DOLLAR FALLS IN SPITE OF FED ACTION
LEAD: The dollar tumbled further against the Japanese yen yesterday after the release of disappointing United States trade figures, but recovered slightly in early trading in Japan today.

A Humorous Touch Wins Radio Ad Drive
LEAD: Because it will surely be a great showcase for their talents, the annual radio industry self-promotion ad campaign attracts many creative volunteers.


Borg Gives GAF Confidential Data
LEAD: Lawyers and investment bankers for the GAF Corporation have begun reviewing confidential data provided by the Borg-Warner Corporation to help GAF decide whether to pursue its interest in the industrial company, Wall Street sources said.


PROFITS AT TIME INC. FELL BY 8% IN FIRST QUARTER
LEAD: Time Inc. said yesterday that its earnings fell 8 percent in the first quarter.
Profits came to $46 million, or 76 cents a share, down from $50 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year ago.
Revenues rose 7.4 percent to $939 million, from $874 million.

MOSCOW WEIGHING NAVAL ESCORTS
LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today that it would rent three tankers to Kuwait to transport oil through the Persian Gulf, and raised the possibility that Soviet warships might escort them.


TESTS URGED FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
LEAD: The director of the space shuttle program has recommended a practice countdown and test-firing of the main engines of the shuttle Discovery before the first shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster, an exercise that could delay the launching by up to two months, the space agency said today.

HE WARNS OF VETO
LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that a bill passed overwhelmingly by state lawmakers last week establishing ethics rules for themselves was unacceptably weak.
He threatened to veto it if legislative leaders did not recall it by Wednesday evening.


Hart Discusses Rumor Sources
LEAD: One day after opening a Democratic Presidential campaign that he said would highlight ideas and issues, former Senator Gary Hart moved on to more political matters today, saying he had heard that workers in other campaigns were spreading rumors about his personal life.

LEAD: Two accidents within days at French nuclear installations have prompted new concern about this country's ambitious nuclear power program.


Accounts
LEAD: * Princess Tours, Seattle, to Tracy-Locke, Los Angeles.


MOVE TO PAROLE RAPIST FOUGHT
LEAD: The impending parole of a convict who cut the arms off a 15-year-old rape victim has caused so much anger that state prison officials are considering changing the parole location, a State Deputy Attorney General said today.


Citicorp Auction Rates Up Sharply
LEAD: Rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.7842 percent, up from 6.2415 percent last week.


Zimbabwean Denies Reports Country Bought 12 MIG-29's
LEAD: A Zimbabwean Government official today denied reports that the country had bought 12 MIG-29 jet fighters from the Soviet Union.


Aluminum Led Loss at Kaiser
LEAD: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, based in Oakland, Calif., today reported a net loss of $29.3 million for the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $17.4 million, or 37 cents a share, a year before.

IN GREEN ON RED'S NEW 'KILLER,' A NOD TO FILM NOIR
LEAD: GREEN ON RED, a rock quintet with Arizona roots, a Los Angeles home base and a dedicated European following, doesn't believe in ''the good old days,'' those legendary times when America was standing tall and everything worked the way it was supposed to.


Cuomo to Release His Taxes
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, after initially balking, said today that he would follow through on a campaign promise to make public his income tax returns and a list of honorariums.
Mr.
Cuomo, who made the pledge in his last year against Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican, said at first that he did not want to make the information public now because of his dispute with the Legislature over an ethics bill he has said he will veto.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A Washington dispatch on Friday about President Reagan's reaction to a Soviet proposal to limit nuclear testing misstated American policy on negotiations over the issue.
The United States says it will not negotiate additional limits on the number or size of tests until the Soviet Union agrees to new monitoring measures for two unratified treaties limiting underground explosions.


A Construction Worker Dies in Cave-In of Ditch
LEAD: A 37-year-old construction worker died and a 24-year-old colleague was hurt yesterday in a series of cave-ins in a drainage ditch at a construction site in Ronkonkoma, L.I., the Suffolk County police said.


FILM: BECKETT AND BLIXEN
LEAD: TO ask that a documentary capture the vision of a great writer is to ask too much.


VIOLENCE GROWS IN CROWDED NEW YORK JAILS
LEAD: Life in New York City's increasingly overcrowded jails is descending deeper and deeper into the circles of toughness, danger and despair, in the view of inmates and those who run the jails.

Gypsum Offers 10-Year Notes
LEAD: The National Gypsum Company is offering $300 million of 11 3/8 percent priority senior subordinated notes due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


Northrop Net Climbs 3.3%
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation's first-quarter profit grew 3.3 percent, to $40.6 million, or 87 cents a share, from $39.3 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenues rose 9 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.3 billion.


Purolator Nod To Emery Bid
LEAD: The board of the Purolator Courier Corporation today recommended that company shares be tendered to the Emery Air Freight Corporation.
Emery, based in Wilton, Conn., has offered to buy 6.3 million Purolator shares, or 83 percent of the company's stock, for $40 each in cash.
It would purchase the remaining shares for 13 percent junior subordinated debentures with a face value of $40.


PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: ''IT takes years to get skin cancer.
Most of us get an early start.'' This is the message on two potentially life-saving posters being distributed by the Skin Cancer Foundation in an effort to halt a fast-growing health threat.
The posters depict children playing on the beach, their tender skin exposed to the searing sun.


53 Dance Groups to Get Philip Morris Grants
LEAD: Philip Morris Companies Inc. has announced grants totaling $1 million to 53 dance organizations and performance centers.


Market Place; Pennzoil Price Defies Analysis
LEAD: ''DETERMINING the worth of Pennzoil's stock is like trying to catch a slippery eel.'' That's how Earl Lester, oil analyst for the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation, describes the high-stakes battle between the Pennzoil Company and Texaco Inc.
Suddenly, a tantalizing game on Wall Street has become the placing of bets on Pennzoil's fast-moving shares.


STATE JUDGE ORDERS DUVALIER ACCOUNTS IN NEW YORK FROZEN
LEAD: A judge in Manhattan has rejected arguments by Haiti's former President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, and his wife that their personal fortunes should be protected under a theory of international law from seizure by Haiti's new Government.

16 NASSAU PRISONERS WERE FREED BY MISTAKE
LEAD: Sixteen convicted felons were mistakenly freed from the Nassau County Correctional Facility between March 24 and April 5, but 15 of them were recaptured when the error was discovered Monday, officials said today.

GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: Home Sweet Mansion A premier off-the-beaten-track attraction is the house that since 1942 has been home to this city's mayors, Gracie Mansion, on East End Avenue at 89th Street.
The mansion, built in 1799 as Archibald Gracie's country home, was subsequently owned by two private families.
In 1896 the city acquired it along with its grounds, most of which became Carl Schurz

LEAD: The Rev.
Charles E. Curran, who was suspended as a professor of theology from Catholic University of America for his dissent on sexual issues, will take a post as a visiting professor at Cornell University, the university said today.

It will be spending just shy of $100,000 to do it.

MUSIC: GOLDEN PALOMINOS
LEAD: THE Golden Palominos are essentially the splendid rock drummer Anton Fier and a shifting cast of supporting players.
But lately the shifting has been minimal, and a real band has been emerging.
Driven by Mr.
Fier's deftly architectural drumming, the Palominos have coalesced around Syd Straw's riveting vocal presence and urbanized-country soul, the luminous clarity of Jody Harris's lead guitar, Robert Kidney's energy and rock-and-roll attitude and Peter Blegvad's incisive songcraft.


DROP IN SEAT-BELT USE CITED AS STATE'S ROAD DEATHS RISE
LEAD: More people died on New York's highways last year than in the previous year, the state reported today, blaming in part a decline in compliance with New York State's seat-belt law.

APRIL 15 TOLLS FOR REAGANS, TOO: THEIR 1986 TAX BILL IS $123,517
LEAD: Last June President Reagan sold a tractor he bought in 1962 and reported the $1,500 sale as a $373 capital gain on his 1986 Federal income tax return.


Horner Chooses Japan
LEAD: Bob Horner, the free agent who was the Atlanta Braves' first baseman last season, yesterday signed with the Yakult Swallows of the Japan Central League.
The contract will pay $1.3 million for a year plus all of Horner's travel and living expenses, Horner's agent, Bucky Woy said.
Horner rejected offers of $4.5 million for three years and $3.9 million for two years from the Braves.


KILLING OF A PANTHER: INDIAN TREATY RIGHTS VS. LAW ON WILDLIFE
LEAD: The Justice Department today charged the chief of the Seminole Indian tribe with shooting and killing a Florida panther in violation of the Endangered Species Act.
But the chief's lawyer says hunting panthers is part of the Seminoles' religious and cultural tradition and is protected under the Constitution and by treaty.

LEAD: In the nation's capital, where the agenda and frustrations of April 15's are born, bureaucrats will be having a much less harrowing day Wednesday than the millions of taxpayers around the country who are struggling to meet the midnight tax filing deadline.

Howser Is Honored
LEAD: The Florida Legislature voted unanimously yesterday to rename the baseball stadium at Florida State in honor of its most famous baseball alumnus, Dick Howser, former manager of the Kansas City Royals.
Gov.
Bob Martinez has said he would sign the bill.
The 50-year-old Howser, ill with brain cancer, stepped down from his manager's post in February.


Behind the Smoke, an Arms Deal
LEAD: The vacillation had to perplex expert and casual observers alike.
First, the United States childishly bewailed Soviet spying.
Moscow followed with silly complaints about American policy toward Afghanistan.
On Monday, Tass reported Mikhail Gorbachev's unhappiness about Secretary of State Shultz's reaction to his new proposal on medium-range missiles.

Septien Is Waived
LEAD: The veteran place-kicker, Rafael Septien, who pleaded guilty last week to a charge of sexual assault involving a 10-year-old girl and was placed on 10 years' probation, was waived by the Dallas Cowboys. ''I knew we would receive adverse public reaction when we did not take this action immediately, but we wanted to investigate all the ramifications of our decision,'' said the Cowboys' president, Tex Schramm.

LEAD: The campaign literature reads like boilerplate out of Pravda: ''The magnificent successes of the socialist world and the happy and prosperous life of the common people prove to the international community the superiority of the socialist system. . . .'' But the enduring success of the Communist Party of West Bengal, democratically elected to rule one of India's poorest states, owes more to clever politicking than it does to the theories of Karl


4 WOMEN IN FASHION: TRUE TO THEIR VISION
LEAD: WERE it not for her quickly stated age, 44, Betsey Johnson would be a prototypical young woman in fashion design.
Her hair is spiky and dyed red.
For a recent interview in her Seventh Avenue showroom, she wore earrings dangling plastic dolls, a studded black leather wristband and a cropped tank top over a striped bodysuit, miniskirt, tights, electric turquoise socks and white high-top sneakers.

Coca-Cola Posted Rise In First-Quarter Profits
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company, whose big worldwide soft-drink operations make it a leading beneficiary of the declining dollar, said today that its first-quarter profits rose 15 percent.


EVERS WIDOW LOSES BID FOR LOS ANGELES POST
LEAD: Myrlie Evers, the widow of slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, lost her bid for a Los Angeles City Council seat Tuesday, and voters sent one of two Council incumbents supported by Mayor Tom Bradley into a runoff.


MARTIN DWYER Jr.
LEAD: Martin Dwyer Jr., the chairman of JWP Inc. of Lake Success, L.I., a technical industrial services company, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Jupiter Island, Fla.
He was 65 years old and also lived in Mantoloking, N.J.

Guilty Plea by Jefferies Seen
LEAD: Boyd L. Jefferies, who earlier settled civil charges that he participated in an illegal stock ''parking'' scheme and manipulated the price of a stock, will plead guilty today to two felony charges, according to court documents and his lawyer.


Japan to File a Protest to GATT on Tariffs by U.S
LEAD: Japan formally warned the United States today that an imposition of American tariffs, expected to occur on Friday, would result in a Japanese protest to the international body that governs world trade.


GAINS AGAINST CANCER SINCE 1950 ARE OVERSTATED, CONGRESS IS TOLD
LEAD: Gains in treating cancer over the last three decades have been small and overstated by Federal health officials, according to a detailed analysis completed by a Congressional investigative agency.


REPORT SHOWS SEAT BELT USE ROSE SHARPLY IN LAST 2 YEARS
LEAD: Americans' use of seat belts has risen sharply, especially in the 23 states that have adopted legislation requiring their use in the last two years, according to a nationwide survey made public today.


A.&amp;P. Profit Is Up 9%
LEAD: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said today that its fourth-quarter rose about 9 percent, to $20.7 million, or about 55 cents a share, from $18.9 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago.
Fourth-quarter sales rose to 48.1 percent, to $2.34 billion, from $1.58 billion.
James Wood, chairman and chief executive, said the fourth-quarter results were better than expected and attributed the improvement to the acquisition of Waldbaum Inc.

Killer Sentenced in Montana
LEAD: A 19-year-old janitor convicted in the shooting deaths of the parents of Patrick Duffy, the actor who plays Bobby Ewing in the television show ''Dallas,'' was sentenced today to 180 years in prison.
Kenneth Miller of Helena was sentenced to 75 years in state prison for each murder in the deaths of Terrence and Marie Duffy, in addition to 20 years for robbery and 10 years for assault.


AFTER HU, CHINA'S RELATIONS WITH JAPAN MAY BE COOLING
LEAD: Relations between China and Japan have cooled in the last few months, partly because of the resignation of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader in January, Japanese and Western diplomats and business executives say.


U.S. AND SOVIET SIGN A PACT OVER EXPLORATION IN SPACE
LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union signed an accord today on cooperation in space exploration.

Returns Show Koch Paid $58,240 in Tax
LEAD: Mayor Koch earned a gross income of $177,730 last year and paid a total of $58,240 in city, state and Federal taxes, according to tax returns released yesterday by Mr.
Koch.


NAVY SECRETARY REINSTATES OFFICER PROMOTIONS
LEAD: For the second time since taking office on Friday, Navy Secretary James H. Webb Jr. has overturned one of his predecessor's decisions, this time by reinstating a list of officers who were recommended for promotion to the rank of captain, the Navy said today.


Moorgate Group Offers Help on Publications
LEAD: The Moorgate Group, the United States arm of a publicly held British communications firm that generally serves financially oriented companies, will be offering its blue-chip clients help in creating publications.

WILLIAM V. SHANNON
LEAD: William V. Shannon, senior vice president of Gannett National Newspaper Sales, died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
He was 57 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.


Apple Net Up 6.6%
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc., aided by the strong sales of its new Macintosh SE computer, recorded surprisingly high sales and earnings in its second fiscal quarter ended March 27.


Window Falls 40 Floors in Midtown
LEAD: Police officers examining broken window on the 40th floor of the Newsweek Building, on Madison Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.
Glass from the window was spread over half a block, but no one was hurt. ''It came down like hail,'' said a security guard. ''A lady who works here dropped her bag and ran inside.


FOR A NEW LOS ANGELES STYLE, A PLACE IN THE SUN
LEAD: THE guests at the recent opening of a new Los Angeles restaurant called Kate Mantilini thought they had come for the food, but many simply abandoned their chicken potpies and grilled swordfish and strolled around, wine in hand.
First they gazed up at a huge metal ''sundial'' apparatus suspended like a centerpiece beneath the skylight, and then they walked over to a long, gently bowed mural of a boxing match.


FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL IS INDICTED
LEAD: The former chief of staff at the Department of Health and Human Services was indicted today for mail fraud, lying and engaging in a conflict of interest by using his official position to promote a company in which he was a director.

CBS NET NEARLY TRIPLES
LEAD: Buoyed by the strong performance of its record division and reduced interest expenses, CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its net income nearly tripled in the first quarter.


Tornado Kills Florida Woman
LEAD: A tornado ripped a mobile home from its foundation here today, fatally injuring the owner who was tossed 50 yards into a field.
Seven other people were injured.
The victim, Charlotte Staples, 68 years old, died about three hours after the tornado struck, officials said.
Tornadoes hit two other parts of Lake County and the Bevilles Corner area of neighboring Sumter County around 11 A.M.

FINDING TREASURES IN COMMERCIAL TABLEWARE ON THE BOWERY
LEAD: FOR those who like durable, moderately priced china and glassware, and who also like to entertain, the restaurant equipment shops dotting the Bowery from Canal Street north to Bleecker Street are a resource to be treasured.


SHULTZ OPEN ON SOVIET TV
LEAD: Soviet television broadcast an interview today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in which he defended American arms positions, complained about Soviet espionage and criticized the Soviet presence in Afghanistan.


USE OF AN AIDS VIRUS DRUG CURBED ON THE BASIS OF DATA
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has told a California pharmaceutical company that there is not yet enough evidence to justify more widespread use of its antiviral drug ribavirin to treat patients with early symptoms of infection with the AIDS virus.


17.2% Gain At Gannett
LEAD: The Gannett Company, citing advertising gains at its local newspapers, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 17.2 percent from a year earlier on a 14 percent gain in revenues.


Officer Struck by Object
LEAD: A uniformed police officer on anti-drug patrol in the Bronx was struck in the head by a brick or rock apparently thrown from the roof of a building near her post yesterday, the police said.
The officer, Victoria Mills, 23 years old, was conscious and in serious but stable condition at Jacobi Hospital after the incident, which occurred at about 2 P.M.


George W. Kennedy, 96, Dies; Pioneer Maker of Car Parts
LEAD: George W. Kennedy, retired president and chairman of the Kelsey-Hayes Company in Romulus, Mich., an early manufacturer of wheels and brake components for automobiles, died Sunday at his home in Del Ray Beach, Fla.
He was 96 years old.


Hunts' Plan Approved
LEAD: The Hunt brothers won a significant legal battle Tuesday night, when a Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas ruled that the Placid Oil Company could proceed with a Gulf of Mexico drilling operation known as the Green Canyon project.

Puff the Tragic Dragon
LEAD: Except for three brief sightings since being stopped by Larry Holmes five years ago, Gerry Cooney seemed to have disappeared in a puff of smoke.
And when introduced yesterday in the glitz of the Empire State Ballroom at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, he literally reappeared in a puff of smoke.
In his dramatic entrance, the 30-year-old sometimes heavyweight was wearing a shiny gray sharkskin suit, a burgundy-and-gray tie on a white shirt, and black suede loafers that matched his trimmed black beard.


Group Head Retires At Morgan Stanley
LEAD: Richard A. Debs, who initiated Morgan Stanley's international business arm 11 years ago, plans to retire June 30.

LEAD: The bodies of two AIDS patients who died in Brooklyn hospitals in February were mistakenly consigned to the state medical school in Brooklyn while the patients' families made repeated efforts to find out if they had died.

REQUEST FOR HINCKLEY LEAVE WITHDRAWN
LEAD: The Federal mental hospital where John W. Hinckley Jr. is a patient today withdrew its recommendation that he be permitted an unescorted visit to his family for Easter.
The hospital said it needed to assess the ''clinical significance'' of Mr.
Hinckley's correspondence and other materials that it had not examined before.
