U.S. JUDGE CONFIRMS F.B.I. INQUIRY IS RELATED TO EXPLOSION OF SHUTTLE
LEAD: A Federal criminal investigation of a company that makes solid-fuel booster rockets for the space shuttle is ''directly related'' to the explosion of the shuttle Challenger in 1986, a Federal district judge confirmed in an opinion issued today.





LONDON DISPLAY EVOKES 1800'S ELEGANCE
LEAD: When it was carved in Vienna nearly 140 years ago, the enormous Gothic bookcase was described as ''a cathedral in wood, massive, bold and well adapted to a palace.'' Appropriately enough, it was presented to Queen Victoria by Emperor Franz Josef of Austria.
But before that, the bookcase, adorned with spires and figures of angels, was displayed in London at the Great Exhibition of 1851.


YOUTHS' GOAL: CORNER OFFICE
LEAD: A poll of teen-agers indicates that they would rather be presidents of companies than President of the United States.
More than half said they would like to become entertainers.


RULES FOR PUPILS WITH AIDS UPHELD
LEAD: The State Supreme Court today upheld state regulations that permit children with AIDS or AIDS-related complex to attend public school.


'Heartbeat' Works for Chevrolet
LEAD: WHEN Chevrolet broke its new ad campaign in the fall, it was returning to a modified umbrella effort that it had not used for a decade.

FLORIDA POWER OFFERING
LEAD: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $125 million of 9 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2017 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The bonds are nonrefundable for five years and yield about 1.28 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury issue due in 2016.

THE POLLARD AFFAIR: SPEAKING FRANKLY
LEAD: Mark Saltzman is a 35-year-old New York songwriter who always considered himself Jewish, but needed a trip to Israel to establish that identity ''beyond maztoh ball soup and even beyond religion.'' Philip Heimowitz, a Wall Street lawyer, has been secure in his Orthodox Judaism all his life.

YANKEE IS DOWN BUT NOT OUT
LEAD: Under more normal circumstances, the less successful games do not take as long to replay when Bob Tewksbury goes home at night and turns on the video cassette recorder in his mind.
The good days and nights are studied for enjoyment and reinforcement. ''When I don't pitch as well,'' Tewksbury said as he stood in front of the space in the Yankee clubhouse that belonged to him until late yesterday afternoon, ''I go over a few things, but I try to forget it as fast as I can.


Bic Lighter Inquiry in House
LEAD: The chairman of a House subcommittee said today that he was beginning an investigation into the safety of disposable lighters made by the Bic Corporation.


DESPITE ACCORD ON DEBT, MANILA SEEKS RATE CUT
LEAD: In an unexpected setback for the global debt situation, the Philippines said yesterday that it would seek to renegotiate its recently completed debt restructuring accord in an effort to obtain the same favorable interest rate won by Mexico and Argentina.


San Miguel To Sell Stake
LEAD: The San Miguel Corporation said today that it had accepted a bid from Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia for 13.9 percent of its shares.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Mecir Advances: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, playing his first match 24 hours after his arrival in Tokyo, trounced Tsuyoshi Fukui, Japan's No. 1 player, 7-5, 6-1 yesterday to advance to the third round of the $605,000 Japan Open tournament.
In another men's match, Ramesh Krishnan of India, seeded 11th, defeated Ben Testerman, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4.


CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
LEAD: THE highlight of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was a propulsive, streamlined performance of Arnold Schoenberg's ''Kammersymphonie'' for 15 solo instruments (Op. 9), conducted by Gervase de Peyer.
This is music at the threshold of atonality, full of chromatic tension, yet its gestures and rhetoric remain fully grounded in Brahms and the 19th century.


IN INSTRUMENTAL WORLD, MODERN IS ALSO ANTIQUE
LEAD: THE early-instrument movement proceeds apace, the pace being that of a small hurricane.
We are now at the point of having not just original-instrument recordings of Beethoven symphonies, but competing recordings of the whole Beethoven cycles undertaken by the top-dollar record companies.
Original-instrument Berlioz is on the way.


DESIGNERS' WARES FOR FLAIR AT THE TABLE
LEAD: THE interior designers Bob Patino, near left, and Vicente Wolf have designed their first collection of china, glass and flatware for Sasaki. ''We often found that clients didn't want traditional floral-patterned bone china,'' Mr.
Patino said.
The designers like the idea of having mismatched dishes and flatware for an eclectic, rather than a homogeneous, look.

LEAD: WHEN Texaco Inc. filed for bankruptcy last Sunday it looked as if all hope was lost for a quick settlement of the $10.3 billion judgment the Pennzoil Company had won against Texaco.

Different Rat Race
LEAD: Frank McConville, a 23-year-old securities trader, and Gillian Horovitz, a 31-year-old bookkeeper, won the first Wall Street Rat Race as they and 938 others scampered over a two-and-a-half mile course through the financial district wearing business suits and carrying brief cases.
McConville won the men's division in 11 minutes 31 seconds.

THREE (OR MORE) FOR THE MAJORS
LEAD: When Jim Paciorek hooked on with Milwaukee as a utility man this season, his family became the 16th that has sent at least three brothers to baseball's major leagues.
The players, listed alphabetically, and the span from the time one brother broke in until the last retired:  ALLEN - Dick, Hank, Ron, 1963-77.

THE STAGE: 'DRIVING MISS DAISY'
IN ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Alfred Uhry has taken familiar material - the growing friendship between a crotchety, aged Southern lady and her black chauffeur - and treated it with renewed sincerity.
The play, which opened last night in the small studio theater at Playwrights Horizons, is enhanced by Dana Ivey and Morgan Freeman, character actors convincingly assuming the mantle of old age and offering twinned, revealing performances.

Packer Has Changed
LEAD: After spending 28 days in an alcohol-abuse treatment center, Charles Martin, the Green Bay Packer nose guard who drew a two-game suspension last fall by body-slamming Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears quarterback, after the whistle, says he's changed. ''I had alcohol in my life last year and it was a problem for me,'' said the 6-foot-4-inch, 280-pound Martin.


Markets Shut Tomorrow
LEAD: American stock and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday.
Most foreign markets will also be closed.
Banks, most businesses and Government offices will be open.

Standard Holders Told Not to Tender
LEAD: The Standard Oil Company, which this week decided to study the tender offer by the British Petroleum Company for the 45 percent stake of Standard Oil that the British company does not already own, said it had urged its stockholders not to tender their shares until it takes a position.
British Petroleum last month offered $70 a share, or $7.4 billion, for the minority stake.

Their Spies, Our Spies
LEAD: The Russians spy on us and we spy on the Russians.
Win some, lose some and why all the fuss when they win one, as in the American Embassy in Moscow?
Actually, except for the marines, it is rather funny and just goes to show that the two superpowers are a lot alike when you get down to it.

Gossage Disabled
LEAD: The San Diego Padres placed Rich (Goose) Gossage, a veteran relief pitcher, and Stan Jefferson, a rookie outfielder, on the disabled list.
Jefferson, who was hitting .286, was placed on the 21-day disabled list with a badly swollen left ankle.
He was replaced by Luis Salazar, who was signed as a free agent in April.


SCOTT 1-HITTER STOPS DODGERS
LEAD: Mike Scott threw a one-hit shutout, and Billy Hatcher hit a homer, a double and a single to continue his torrid start as the Houston Astros downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, tonight.
Hatcher has hit in all nine games for Houston this season, and is 17 for 36.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. The paint is peeling off two of my bathroom walls down to the original plaster (the walls are solid, not plasterboard).
These walls contain no pipes, and have had only four or five coats of paint.
The exposed plaster is powdery.
What is causing this problem?
Can it be stopped ?


Is It Real?
LEAD: A youngster using the touch test yesterday with Brad Zupp's nose during a visit to the Ringling Brothers and Barnum &amp; Bailey Circus at Madison Square Garden.
Mayor Koch played host as about 1,000 youngsters watched clowns and other performers.
The children, from the foster-care program of the Human Resources Administration, Special Services for Children, were guests of the circus.

Addendum
LEAD: *
Elle magazine is raising its circulation rate base and its rates 21.7 percent with the September issue.

Exhibition Honoring Jackie Robinson to Open Tomorrow
LEAD: Rachel Robinson, widow of the first black major league baseball player, touching a picture of her husband and his teammates in the Dodgers' clubhouse in 1951.
The multimedia depiction of Jack Roosevelt Robinson's life will be at the New-York Historical Society through July 15.
The show includes photographic murals from various times of his life, electronic baseball cards on large screens, taped testimonials and a biographical movie from the early 50's in which Robinson played himself.

The Trade War
LEAD: Specialists from a half-dozen Federal departments and agencies are working overtime this week trying to come up with a list of electronics products that President Reagan is expected to impose sanctions on tomorrow in a dispute with Japan on computer chips.

SIGNS OF ECONOMIC FRAGILITY
LEAD: The economy, after performing better than expected during the first few months of 1987, is showing signs of fragility.


Swiss Aid VW In Fraud Case
LEAD: Swiss investigators said today that they had seized documents in connection with a suspected currency fraud that cost Volkswagenwerk A.G., the West German auto maker, as much as $260 million.
VW has said computer programs were erased and documents faked.


CONSERVATORS ENDORSE SISTINE RESTORATION
LEAD: An international group of leading conservators of Italian paintings has given its unanimous and strongly enthusiastic approval to the current restoration of Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel in Rome.
After a visit to Rome at the invitation of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, the group reported yesterday that ''the new freshness of the colors and the clarity of the forms on the Sistine ceiling are totally in keeping with 16th-century Italian painting and affirm the full majesty and splendor of Michelangelo's creation.

DAILY NEWS LOSES RACE BIAS CASE
LEAD: After nine weeks of bitter courtroom drama, a Federal jury found yesterday that The Daily News racially discriminated against four of the newspaper's black editorial employees between 1979 and 1982.


Format Is Criticized
LEAD: The Masters is too important a tournament to be decided in a sudden-death playoff, Seve Ballesteros said yesterday.
He thinks the format should be changed to an 18-hole test if there is a tie after regulation play. ''I said it in 1979, so nobody can accuse me of crying because I lost,'' he said. ''Anybody can win one hole.

Car Bomb Kills Driver in East Beirut
LEAD: Lebanese security officials inspecting the wreckage of a car that exploded in the Christian section of Beirut yesterday.
Police said the driver, a Lebanese soldier, was killed when the bomb exploded in his moving car.
A Lebanese Army explosives expert said the time bomb had been planted under driver's seat.

LEAD: BASEBALL  BALTIMORE (AL) - Placed Don Aase, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list with tendinitis in his right shoulder.
SAN DIEGO (NL) - Placed Rich Gossage, relief pitcher, and Stan Jefferson, outfielder, on the disabled list.
Jefferson, with a badly swollen left ankle, was put on the 21-day disabled list.

On Fixing Constitution And Spilling Gravy All Over the Preamble
LEAD: Warren E. Burger retired last year as Chief Justice of the United States to devote full time to his chairmanship of the commission that is leading the celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution.
He still retains chambers at the Supreme Court, and the other day he paused while working there to discuss the accomplishments and frustrations of the bicentennial effort thus far and to look back on some of his years on the Court.


WIDOW'S PROBLEM: TO BE OLD AND POOR
LEAD: POVERTY among the elderly in the United States will increasingly affect women, many of them widowed and living alone, a new report predicts.
By the year 2020, of 2 million elderly poor people living alone, 1.5 million will be widows, the report said.


An A.M.A. Drug Issue
LEAD: Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, is trying to get a bill passed that would sharply limit the number of prescriptions that can be filled by physicians who sell drugs.
And he asserts that the American Medical Association has opposed passage of the prohibition although it says it opposes the practice.


SOME IN JAPAN FEAR NEW FALL IN DOLLAR
LEAD: Some Japanese economists and currency traders voiced deep concern today that a continued fall of the dollar could harm both the Japanese and American economies.
They said further decline could discourage Japanese investment in United States Government bonds and help spur inflation in the United States.


Misconduct Found In Guinness Case
LEAD: A London high court judge ruled today that an $8.4 million payment authorized by the former chairman of Guinness P.L.C. to another company director during a takeover last year was unlawful.

LEAD: IN the first quarter of 1987, electric utilities edged ahead only seven-tenths of 1 percent, to rank as the poorest performer among Standard &amp; Poor's 83 industry groups.
By contrast, the advisory service's 500-stock index - a broadly diversified mix of issues - rose 20.5 percent.

Shareholders Back NCR 'Poison Pill'
LEAD: The NCR Corporation's shareholders rejected a challenge to their ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan yesterday at their annual meeting in Dayton, Ohio.
About 26 percent of the votes cast favored the proposal by the California Public Employees Retirement system to rescind the poison pill.
About 62 percent voted against the proposal.

LEAD: Citing evidence of only minor infractions, the House ethics committee today unanimously cleared Representative Fernand J. St Germain of charges that he used his influence to amass a personal fortune.

'KOCH ON CALL' WITH CUOMO AS GUEST
LEAD: AS call-ins go, it had its limits; only four citizens got through.
Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo talked mostly to each other. ''Koch on Call,'' on Channel 5 last night, was not explosive television, but it did give us a feeling of reassurance.
What shape are the state's two leading officials in?
The Mayor looked firm and the Governor looked earnest.

LEAD: A new and sometimes dark current is running between New York and Philadelphia lately, and it quickened here Tuesday when two of The Hateds came to town at once.

CONCERT: WOLFF LEADS NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY
LEAD: IT is rather common for a moderately talented young conductor to make a strong impression when he appears as a guest with one of the world's great orchestras.
Except in rare instances when they take a dislike to an uncommonly arrogant or incompetent novice, musicians on that level have a corporate pride that works to the benefit of the leader.


Rams Name Macarchuk
LEAD: Fordham took a step toward rebuilding its basketball program yesterday by signing the former Canisius coach, Nick Macarchuk, to a five-year contract.
Sources close to the program said the agreement would make the 45-year-old Connecticut native the highest-paid coach in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

Dr.

MUSIC: HORST RICKEL PIECES
LEAD: HORST RICKEL'S Sunday-evening program of original compositions at Roulette, entitled ''The Five Winds,'' was alternately frustrating and fascinating.
Mostly frustrating as sheer music - an audience listening to Mr.
Rickel's determinedly sparse sounds (mostly long drones, rattles, snorts and whistles) at home, on a radio or recording, with no visual counterpart, would have found little to engage the attention.

AMR's Profits Increase 44.2%
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 44.2 percent, to $19.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $13.8 million, or 20 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenues increased 3.4 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.46 billion.

Seeking Benefit From 2 Wrongs
LEAD: A couple of illicit athletic training practices have been drawing special attention from medical researchers lately.
One is blood-doping, which, while frowned upon in sports, can't be considered a war crime.
As a result of some new Army research, the day may not be far off when American soldiers sent on high-intensity missions in hot climates are given infusions of their own red blood cells to increase their stamina and, at the same time, help them keep cool.


PPG Profits Rise 25.6%
LEAD: PPG Industries said its first-quarter earnings rose 25.6 percent, to $86.9 $69.2 million, or 59 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1986.
It cited a modestly larger market share, acquisitions and currency transactions.
The Pittsburgh-based manufacturer said sales for the three months ended March 31 totaled $1.26 billion, up 10.5 percent from $1.14 billion a year ago.


PARTY PANELS GET CRITICISM FROM JUDGES
LEAD: In an unusual public protest, several judges and Democratic district leaders have strongly criticized judicial screening panels of the Manhattan Democratic organization as ideologically biased and politically controlled.

LEAD: Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earth-moving machines, said today that it lost $84 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $111 million, or $1.13 a share, a year ago.

LEAD: The Nippon Steel Corporation said it had entered a multiyear agreement with Calgene Inc. of Davis, Calif., to jointly develop a vegetable oil with industrial applications, including steelmaking.
Calgene specializes in the application of recombinant DNA technology to plants.

LEAD: Lawyers for a Marine guard accused of espionage at the United States Embassy in Moscow today denied the charges against him and asserted that he was being made a ''scapegoat'' for the negligence in the State Department.

Last week, Mr.
Goldwater told a Kingman, Ariz., high school student who had invited him to a May 23 graduation that he would be unable to attend because he was having knee surgery.

FOE OF APARTHEID URGING DEFIANCE

Hotel Fire Trial Is Delayed
LEAD: A judge has agreed to delay the trial of three men charged with setting the Dupont Plaza Hotel fire that killed 97 people.
Superior Court Judge Laura Nieves agreed Tuesday to reschedule the trial from May 19 to Aug. 24 to give the defense more time to examine the evidence.
The defendants, Hector Escudero Aponte, 35 years old, Armando Jimenez Rivera, 29, and Jose Francisco Rivera Lopez, 40, all hotel employees, have been charged with 96 counts of murder and one count each of arson and conspiracy.

STAGE: BARBARA COOK IN SONG AND MEMORIES
LEAD: IT'S not just Barbara Cook, now appearing in concert at the Ambassador, who has traveled a long way from the 1950's Broadway of ''Candide'' and ''The Music Man.'' As the passing decades have matured this one-time ingenue, so they've diminished the musical theater in which she made her name.
But for everything that has changed, Miss Cook's creamy soprano remains remarkably intact: it's still a lovely instrument whose uncomplicated personality seems as sunny as the happy days that musical comedies used to celebrate.

LEAD: There's nothing like downing a few at the bar while watching a basketball game on TV to stir a tippler to dreams of glory.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: NEW wood glues and ''all-purpose adhesives'' have revolutionized bonding and repairing techniques.
These glues and adhesives - the words are now used almost interchangeably - are easy to use and make it possible to join materials that once were almost impossible to bond.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1987
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The U.S. economy is showing signs of fragility, after performing better than expected in the first few months of 1987.
The Goverment reported that industrial output in March fell 0.3 percent, its biggest drop in 10 months, and that retail sales rose a paltry 0.2 percent.
Most private analysts are expressing increasing fears about a financial and political climate that they believe could eventually tip the world economy into recession.


N.A.A.C.P. Announces Plan for Baseball

Benjamin Hooks, head of the N.A.A.C.P., speaking in New York.
He said the civil-rights organization had begun an effort to influence hiring policies in major league baseball.

By offering to rid Europe not only of Soviet and American medium-range missiles, but of shorter-range missiles as well, the Soviet leader has left the


PIANIST REGAINED FAME IN 70'S
LEAD: Erwin Nyiregyhazi, a Hungarian-born American pianist who dropped out of sight for decades and then made a remarkable comeback in the 1970's, died of cancer Monday in Los Angeles.
He was 84 years old.
Mr.
Nyiregyhazi enjoyed a considerable career as a child prodigy in Europe, and then as a young virtuoso in Germany and the United States in the 1920's.

Correction
LEAD: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday, about the Borg-Warner Corporation, incorrectly described the status of the GAF Corporation's request for confidential data from Borg-Warner.

Bernard Jankelson, a dentist and a pioneer researcher in cranio-mandibular orthopedics and the study of head pain traceable to jaw malfunction, died here Monday.

Slain Police Officer Buried in Connecticut
LEAD: The coffin of Daniel Scott Wasson being carried to a grave yesterday in Milford.
More than 500 police officers from New England and New York attended the funeral service.
Officer Wasson was shot to death Sunday after stopping a car.
A suspect, Thomas Hoyesen, has been charged with murder. (AP)


Grace Posts Profit in Period
LEAD: W.R.
Grace &amp; Company reported yesterday that it earned $47.8 million, or $1.13 a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a $3.1 million loss a year earlier.
Sales in the period were up 14.1 percent, to $962.6 million, from $843.4 million.

BOOKS THAT CAN INSPIRE AND INSTRUCT
LEAD: GARDENING books are variously constructed.
Some are meant to instruct, explain and explore; some philosophize, reflect and theorize, and in some the text is mainly meant to accompany pretty pictures.
Whatever their purpose, most books about gardening openly address a captive audience, that indefinite, unspecified ''you'' to whom author and publisher make grandly optimistic promises.


U.S. JUDGE OVERTURNS LAW ON FAMILY LIFE PROGRAM
LEAD: A Federal district judge ruled today that key provisions of a 1981 law designed to discourage adolescent sexual activity were unconstitutional because they violated the requirement for separation of church and state.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Profit Reported By Inland Steel
LEAD: Inland Steel Industries, the nation's No. 4 steelmaker, said yesterday that it earned $62.5 million, or $2.02 a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a $22 million loss a year earlier.


WORLD'S MARKETS TURN CALM
LEAD: The jittery stock, bond and currency markets calmed today after a comment by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d that ''a further decline of the dollar'' could be ''counterproductive.''


THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: A FEW floors above lived Greta Garbo, who in her day used to sit, swathed in a burnoose, on the sands of the Lido with Gayelord Hauser.
Or was it Capri?
In any case, Garbo was nowhere to be seen.
Nor, despite a fondness for things Venetian, was Susan Gutfreund. ''She called in with a stiff neck,'' said Laurence D.

LEAD: As high school seniors braced for word from college admissions offices this week, many college officials reported record numbers of applications this year despite a continuing decline in the number of 18-year-olds.

Economic Scene; The Strains With Japan
LEAD: THE United States Government appears almost certain today to go through with its plan to impose 100 percent tariffs on up to $300 million in Japanese imports in retaliation for the purported dumping of semiconductors in third markets.

ART: ANNETTE LEMIEUX IN 2 MIXED-MEDIA SHOWS
LEAD: ANNETTE LEMIEUX'S work is not easy to get into in the visual sense.
Both segments of her double exhibition - at Josh Baer Gallery (270 Lafayette Street) and Cash-Newhouse (170 Avenue B, at 11th Street) - have, upon first encounter, the appearance of rather tightly selected group shows.
The individual pieces range from strategically altered objects and photographs to paintings that combine abstraction with either appropriated photographic imagery or overly meaningful words (''Godspeed,'' ''Mother'').


N.B.A. Notebook; Florida Expansion May Face a Delay
LEAD: Will the National Basketball Association's third expansion franchise be awarded to Orlando, Fla., or to Miami?


American Express Net Off 21.4% in First Quarter
LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that its net income fell 21.4 percent in the first quarter.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Henry Marshall, a wide receiver for the Kansas City Chiefs, was fined $40,000 in Federal Court in Kansas City yesterday after having pleaded guilty to two counts of failing to file Federal income-tax returns for 1982 and 1983.
Marshall, 32 years old, was placed on probation for three years and ordered to perform 320 hours of community service.


IN MEXICO, THE GRAFT LOOSENS ITS GRIP
LEAD: ''The phenomenon of corruption is like the garbage,'' Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza said. ''It has to be removed daily.
We can't make it disappear altogether, but our objective is to lessen its presence within Mexican public administration.''


Market Place; Mutual Funds' I.R.A. Rush
LEAD: MANY investors who placed their money in tax-deductible Individual Retirement Accounts for 1986 favored mutual funds as a reflection of the booming stock market.
The nationwide I.R.A. rush built to a crescendo just before Wednesday's qualifying deadline and financial institutions kept their offices open - some until midnight - as they wooed accounts.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Part of a chart printed yesterday with an article on the threat to European economies from the falling dollar was mislabeled.
The top of the chart showed the economic growth rates of West Germany, Britain, France and Italy, not their export performance.
That was shown, and correctly labeled, in the bottom of the chart.

A SASSY GUIDE TO THE STATUES HANGING OUT IN CENTRAL PARK
LEAD: THERE is a rumor - neither confirmed nor denied by city officials - that some pigeons from out of town, seeking a spot for their annual convention, have turned down Central Park because they find the statues dull.


REAGAN PLANS TO CONSULT ALLIES
LEAD: President Reagan said here today that he would consult with allied leaders at an economic summit meeting in Venice in June on the Soviet proposal to eliminate not only medium-range missiles, but also shorter-range missiles from Europe.


JUDGE UPHOLDS SECORD ON BANK SECRECY
LEAD: A Federal judge today refused to order Maj.
Gen.
Richard V. Secord to waive the secrecy of foreign bank accounts that are linked to the Iran-contra affair - a decision that could seriously hinder the work of Congressional investigators.


Jazztet at Sweet Basil
LEAD: Benny Golson on saxophone and Art Farmer on fluegelhorn will lead their six-piece Jazztet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785).
Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.


Builder to Examine 2 Queens Towers
LEAD: Saved from demolition on Monday with minutes to spare, the towers and entryway of the 102-year-old trolley station in Woodside, Queens, may become part of a new shopping center at that site, Borough President Claire Shulman has announced.

S.I. Man Is Indicted In Woman's Death
LEAD: A Staten Island man was indicted in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with three murders, including the execution-style slaying of a woman who was abducted last year.


19 Films Chosen to Vie For Top Cannes Award
LEAD: Entries from France, Italy, the United States and Britain dominated the 19 films announced today to compete for the Golden Palm Award for best film at the 40th Cannes Film Festival May 7 to 19.


S.A.T.'S ARE BIASED AGAINST GIRLS, REPORT BY ADVOCACY GROUP SAYS
LEAD: High school girls get lower scores than boys on the Scholastic Aptitude Test because the tests are biased against girls, according to a report released yesterday by an advocacy group that monitors standardized testing.


HERBERT BLUMER
LEAD: Herbert Blumer, an emeritus professor who was a longtime chairman of the Department of Sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, died Monday.
He was 87 years old.
Professor Blumer was a sociological scholar of the 20th century.
Before joining the Berkeley faculty in 1952, he taught for 11 years at the University of Chicago, where he earned his doctorate in sociology.

'Sleight' Postponed
LEAD: The opening of the Broadway show ''Sleight of Hand'' has been postponed until May 4, from its original date of April 26.
The play will open at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street.
The opening was postponed by the producer, Suzanne J. Schwartz, to ''give the company a few more days to perfect the show,'' said the press spokeswoman for the show, Patt Dale.





RESTORED APARTMENTS: ELIGIBILITY IS DEBATED
LEAD: In Harlem, the South Bronx, Bedford-Stuyvesant and many other New York City neighborhoods, nearly 5,500 apartment buildings sit stripped and abandoned.
For more than a decade, they have symbolized the decline of once-vibrant residential communities.


MARKETS CLOSED TODAY
LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets will by closed today in observance of Good Friday.
The credit markets will also be closed, as will most foreign stock markets.
Government offices and most business, however, will be open.


ALBANY LAWMAKERS FUME OVER FIGHT ON ETHICS CODE
LEAD: State legislators today vigorously defended a proposed code of ethics in government that was vetoed Wednesday by Governor Cuomo, saying it had been depicted unfairly by the Governor and by groups unfamiliar with its history.

The Critical Mass in City Jails
LEAD: New York City's big jail on Rikers Island appears headed for a perilously hot summer and fall.
Severe crowding, unrelieved despite huge investments in jail expansion, are already building pressure dangerously.
Worse, the jail population is expected to grow faster than building plans can bring relief.

LEAD: O. K. Armstrong, a teacher and journalist who served two terms in Congress, died Wednesday at his home here.
He was 93 years old.

He's Just 'Bo,' as in 'Reggie' and 'Babe'
LEAD: Conversations temporarily cease.
Visits to the rest room are delayed.
Vendors find it convenient to be situated at the head of an aisle, where they are afforded a closer view of the field.
No one looks hungry or thirsty, anyway.
All eyes in Royals Stadium are watching Number 16 walking deliberately to home plate, twirling a bat as if it were a drum major's baton.

LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 7.1 percent from the first quarter of 1986.
Another major telephone company, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, posted a 3.4 percent decline for the same period.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: IF your idea of a big night on the town includes donning a billowy Hawaiian shirt sporting palm trees, sipping frothy pastel-colored drinks with names such as Pensacola Passion, Dr.
Voodoo and Kissimmee, and munching on pot stickers ($7.95) and Key West satays ($13.25), Panama City awaits.
This reggae-pulsed, cartoon-colored bar and restaurant on the Upper East Side is among the hottest new yuppie ports-of-call.


Foes of Chicago Mayor Lose
LEAD: In sharp contrast to the opposition raised on the City Council to Mayor Harold Washigton's proposals in his first term, the Council voted overwhelmingly today to remove two of Mr.
Washington's foes from powerful committee posts and replace them with his supporters.
By a vote of 40 to 9, Alderman Edward Burke, head of the Finance Committee, was replaced by Alderman Timothy Evans and Alderman Theris Gabinski, head of the Zoning Committee, was replaced by Alderman Danny Davis.


Tutu and Ministers Tell Botha of Defying Ban
LEAD: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and 46 Anglican ministers wrote to President P. W. Botha today to endorse civil disobedience against a Government decree outlawing organized protest against detention without trial.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on March 29 about Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's conduct of the Baby M trial described the legal history of surrogate motherhood incompletely.
A Michigan ruling in March 1986 declared a couple the legal, biological parents of an unborn child being carried for them by a surrogate mother.
The embryo had been conceived through fertilization in vitro and carried to term by the surrogate mother.

With an Appendix, ''What Literate Americans Know,'' by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph Kett and James Trefil. 251 pages.
Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

Editorial Feud at Washington Times
LEAD: Ever since The Washington Times began publication five years ago with financing provided by associates of the Rev.
Sun Myung Moon, head of the South Korean-based Unification Church, the newspaper has periodically fought against speculation that the church was influencing its editorial policy.


Gains at Lotus And Microsoft
LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales of core products and gains in overseas sales, the two leading personal computer software companies - Microsoft and Lotus Development - reported record revenues and earnings today.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Jeffrey Schanzer and Mark Howell, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242).
Jeffrey Schanzer and Mark Howell are improvising guitarists, exploring the areas opened up for the instrument by rock's Jimi Hendrix and free music's Derek Bailey.
Mr.
Schanzer's band will include the saxophonist Marty Ehrlich, who has been proving his mettle in a variety of jazz situations.


Two-Car Family
LEAD: Romance in the workplace is nothing new, and neither are marriages.
But for Wally and Robin Dallenbach, both auto racers, last weekend at Road Atlanta did mark something novel.
For the first time, both were racing at the same track, and longtime pit-side observers say they can't recall a previous appearance at a major event of spouses competing on the same card.


WEINBERGER SAYS THE WALKERS GAVE SOVIET MUCH KEY DATA
LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the John A. Walker Jr. spy ring had given Soviet officials information on a wide range of highly sensitive subjects, including terrorist threats.


REPAIRS TO F.D.R. DRIVE TO REQUIRE 27 MONTHS OF MIDTOWN DETOURS
LEAD: Reconstruction of the sea wall along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from 42d to 54th Street will force extensive lane closings and detours for 27 months, the City Transportation Comissioner, Ross Sandler, announced yesterday.
The work is to begin Monday.


Mark IV-Conrac
LEAD: Mark IV Industries and the Conrac Corporation said their boards had approved a definitive merger agreement.
Mark IV of Williamsville, N.Y., will acquire Conrac of Stamford, Conn., for $27.50 a share, or about $185 million.
The purchase price represents an increase from the previous offer of $25 a share.

FMC to Appeal Dismissal of Suit
LEAD: The FMC Corporation said it would appeal a Federal Court ruling that dismissed its lawsuit against Ivan F. Boesky, Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company and others.
The $260 million lawsuit, filed last December, alleged misuse of information and price manipulation relating to FMC's $2 billion recapitalization completed last year, it said.

RESTAURANTS
LEAD: IF this were a baseball column - actually, it is not dissimilar in the way it chronicles the fragile fortunes of highly competitive teams - the following yarn would recount the dramatic story of Le Chantilly, a three-star powerhouse back in 1978 that hit an extended slump three years later.
Last season, a despairing front office brought in a new manager in hopes of rekindling the old flame.

PRESS MARAVICH
LEAD: Peter (Press) Maravich, the father and former coach of Pete Maravich, college basketball's leading scorer, died at Highland Park Hospital Wednesday night.

4 Killed in Suspicious Fire in Albany
LEAD: Firefighters outside burned-out two-story house after a quickly spreading fire took the lives of two adults and two children.
The victims were identified as Alvin Keene; his girlfriend, Brenda Jackson; their 3-year-old daughter, Laquasha, and Ms.
Jackson's nephew, DeMarco Curtis, 2.
Officials said the fire was deliberately set.

LEAD: Irene Reid, formerly a singer with the Count Basie band, is performing through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750).
Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday.
There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.


WOOD SHAPES UP AS TEST FOR CAPOTE
LEAD: Capote was beaten 9 1/2 lengths while finishing behind Gone West, Shawklit Won and Gulch in the Gotham Stakes 13 days ago.
But he has been made the morning-line favorite to beat them, and five others, in the $595,500 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct tomorrow.


Trio at Cafe Lido
LEAD: The trio of James Williams on piano, Harvie Swartz on bass and Eliot Zigmund on drums will perform tonight and tomorrow at Garvin's Cafe Lido, 15 Waverly Place (533-4151).
Music begins at 8:30 P.M.; there is no cover or minimum.

MUSIC: AFRO-AMERICAN 'SPIRITUAL HERITAGE'
LEAD: THE repertory of Afro-American spirituals, to which tribute was paid Sunday night in Carnegie Hall in a new suite for chorus, orchestra and soloists called ''The Spiritual Heritage,'' has been an ornament to a formal concert life enriched by the participation of black American singers.
Spirituals have been to Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price and Kathleen Battle what Neapolitan songs were to Caruso, Gigli and Di Stefano: music in which glorious voices could mingle with a folk idiom of looser disciplines and more spontaneous expressiveness.

LEAD: Rangers Fall in Six Games  The Rangers were eliminated from the National Hockey League playoffs by Philadelphia.
The Islanders-Capitals series is tied at 3-3.

LEAD: The best hitter in baseball was sitting near his dressing stall the other day when a clubhouse attendant approached cautiously and asked him to autograph a couple of baseballs.

LEAD: Housing construction fell 3.2 percent in March, the biggest decline in six months, the Government reported today.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would scrap its often controversial executive-bonus system in favor of a stock-option plan, but not before paying its chairman, Roger B. Smith, about $1.8 million in salary and bonuses for 1986.


GURUS HIRED TO MOTIVATE WORKERS ARE RAISING FEARS OF 'MIND CONTROL'
LEAD: In their zeal to become more competitive, American employers have turned increasingly to motivational gurus who say they can change how employees think.
But now employers are encountering resistance from workers who assert that many of the training programs use ''mind control'' techniques or promote values alien to their religious views.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds increased $333.4 million, to $237.16 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 93 institutional funds were down $836.1 million, to $64.82 billion.
Assets of the 196 general-purpose funds were up $1.78 billion, to $65.60 billion.


Tania Leon to Conduct
LEAD: Tania Leon will conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic Chamber and Percussion Ensembles in a program of works by Hispanic-American composers in the Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section, tomorrow afternoon at 2.
The performance is the final one in a three-concert series intended to introduce children and their families to a wide range of music in an intimate space, at reasonable cost.


NAVY HEAD ORDERS A LOOK TO FUTURE
LEAD: The new Secretary of the Navy, James H. Webb Jr., said today that he had ordered senior Navy admirals and Marine Corps generals to assess within 60 days where their services now stand and where they should be in 10 years.


Plant Use Declined In March
LEAD: American factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.2 percent of capacity in March, down from 79.7 percent in February and the lowest level in four months, the Government reported today.

Pakistan Shoots Down An Afghan Warplane

Machinists' Union Cool to United Bid
LEAD: The machinists' union at United Airlines said that it was ''unlikely'' to join the pilot union's $4.5 billion takeover proposal for the airline.
The machinists told the pilots' union that they envisioned problems with employee ownership, particularly in not being able to strike for seven years under the pilots' proposal.

LEAD: Fifteen employees of Wall Street firms, including brokers and a senior partner, were arrested by Federal agents yesterday and charged with selling cocaine and trading the drug for stocks, information and lists of preferred customers.

Gilbert and Sullivan
LEAD: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players present a double bill of ''Trial by Jury'' and ''The Sorcerer'' at Symphony Space this weekend, tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 4 P.M.
Admission is $15 to $25; $10 to $20 for the elderly.
Symphony Space is at 95th Street and Broadway; information: 864-5400.


Peak Competition
LEAD: The third annual Pillar Mountain Classic is history, but less than a month after an obscure amateur named Rick Lindholm captured the 1987 title, Andy Lundquist, the tournament chairman, is already laying grandiose plans for next year.
In an effort to attract a recognizable pro, Lundquist is lining up a free salmon-fishing vacation and other inducements, and he'll need every one of them to tempt a regular away from the sunny climes of the PGA Tour.

Calling for I.R.S. Aid
LEAD: Further on the matter of taxes, as the midnight Wednesday deadline drew closer, the Internal Revenue Service found the calls to its toll-free assistance program increasingly desperate and disparate.
Apparently a lot of people who fear they owe the Government money wait until the last-minute and make heavy use of the assistance service to figure every possible angle and deduction.

TRANSACTIONS
LEAD:  COLLEGES


The Editorial Notebook; It's Not Tia-Wanna Anymore
LEAD: Peer south from Otay Mesa in this southernmost part of California and you can see the future.
Scrub grass and bare canyon stretch to the border.
Then, suddenly, on the hilly Mexican side, the vista is transformed into city.
Twin 40-story hotel towers rise from an urban center.
The receding hillsides bristle with thousands of tents, shacks and concrete block houses.


Ayer Helps Recruit Priests
LEAD: N.W.
Ayer may have lost the Army account, but it hasn't given up recruiting.
Its latest client is the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit, which needs priests.


Don't Be Afraid of 'Da'
LEAD: The 1979 NATO decision to put medium-range American missiles in Europe unless the Russians pulled theirs out is now coming full circle.
Mikhail Gorbachev said yes, his would go.
The major European allies then said something would have to be done about the huge Soviet advantage (estimated to be 9 to 1) in shorter-range missiles.


NEW JOBS EASE PAIN AT ALLY
LEAD: LESS than a month after the morale-destroying loss of the $25 million Federal Express account, Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising anounced yesterday that it had picked up three other pieces of business with combined billings in the neighborhood of $20 million.

Philips Discusses Medical Venture
LEAD: Philips Gloeilampen Fabrieken N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, said it was talking with the General Electric Company about a cooperative agreement between its medical unit and G.E.C.'s medical subsidiary, Picker International Inc.


Lockheed Net Dips Slightly
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation today reported first-quarter earnings of $86 million, or $1.30 a share, a small decline from earnings of $87 million, or $1.32 a share, a year ago.


UNION STILL ON STRIKE AT ABC
LEAD: Members of the Writers Guild of America who work for CBS voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a contract proposed by CBS and end a six-and-a-half-week strike against that network.


JUDGE UPSETS LAW ON GIVING REALTY DATA
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled invalid a New York City law that forces some property owners to reveal how much money they make from their buildings.

BLOC WAS PREPARED TO CRUSH SOLIDARITY A DEFECTOR SAYS
LEAD: Soviet, Czechoslovak and East German troops were twice poised to invade Poland in the 16 months before the Polish Government crushed the Solidarity movement, according to an account by a defector from the Polish general staff.


61 for Jordan, 23 in a Row
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 61 points tonight to become the second player in National Basketball Association history to score 3,000 points in a season.


BIC SAYS THERE ARE 42 SUITS
LEAD: The Bic Corporation said yesterday that it has 42 lawsuits outstanding that were brought on behalf of people burned or killed by fires allegedly caused by malfunctioning disposable butane lighters made by Bic.


STAGE: BEIJING ACROBATS
LEAD: THE art of the acrobat is exactly that in the hands of its Chinese practitioners.
And the Beijing Acrobats troupe now touring the United States is well within that time-honored tradition.


CITATION FOR EX-CHAIRMAN
LEAD: The Pulitzer Prize Board awarded Joseph Pulitzer Jr. a special citation ''for extraordinary services to American journalism and letters during his 31 years as chairman of the Pulitzer Prize Board and for his accomplishments as an editor and publisher.''

CONNECTICUT RESIDENTS ARE AT TOP IN INCOME
LEAD: Residents of Connecticut had the highest average income of those in any state in the country in 1986, displacing Alaska residents in the No. 1 spot for the first time in 14 years, the Government reported today.

LEAD: Jesse Barfield's run-scoring single snapped a sixth-inning tie and Jimmy Key tossed a two-hitter over six innings tonight to outduel Roger Clemens and give the Toronto Blue Jays a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

SOVIET COMPLAINS SHULTZ WAS UNABLE TO BARGAIN

F.B.I. INQUIRY FOCUSES ON ROCKETS FOR SHUTTLE
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating whether Morton Thiokol Inc. committed fraud in supplying the Government with faulty booster rockets that led to the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger, according to court papers made public today.

Tony Williams Quintet
LEAD: Tony Williams, on drums, is leading a quintet - with Billy Pierce on saxophone, Wallace Roney on trumpet, Mulgrew Miller on piano and Charnett Moffett on bass - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037).
Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.


RJR Nabisco Rises 6.8%; Philip Morris Up 22.2%
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 6.8 percent, to $220 million, or 84 cents a share, from $206 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenue increased 2.6 percent, to $3.49 billion from $3.40 billion.

LEAD: The no-hitter that Milwaukee's Juan Nieves hurled against Baltimore on Wednesday night guaranteed him headlines but no immortality.
Here are the pitchers in modern major league history who've thrown two no-hitters and who, having been retired at least five years and thus made eligible for the Hall of Fame, have never been elected.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD: Friday  HAYDN EASTER WORK  Haydn's ''Seven Last Words of Christ'' is a series of solemn musical meditations that the composer wrote for a Good Friday observance.
It was originally scored for instrumental ensemble and later arranged variously for string quartet and piano, string quartet and soloists, and orchestra with chorus and vocal soloists.

Shamrock to Sell Coal Subsidiary
LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said that it had once again agreed to sell its coal subsidiary to the Arch Mineral Corporation for $135 million.
The two companies had reached a similar agreement last July regarding the Diamond Shamrock Coal Company, but in October Diamond Shamrock said they canceled the deal because they ''were unable to reach mutually acceptable terms.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 17, 1987
LEAD: THE ECONOMY
The President's budget director warned the Fed not to raise interest rates, saying such action could cause a recession.
The Reagan aide, James C. Miller 3d, seemed to be positioning the Administration to blame the Fed if a recession occurs in 1988, an election year.
Paul A. Volcker has indicated that the Fed might have to consider pushing up rates to combat the dollar's slide.


Brigitte Haudebourg
LEAD: Brigitte Haudebourg, a French harpsichordist, will play works by Rameau, J. S. Bach, Martinu, Couperin and Domenico Scarlatti in a recital Sunday at 2 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.
Miss Haudebourg studied piano as a child with Marguerite Long and Jean Doyen, and harpsichord at Paris's National Conservatory with Marcelle Delacour and Robert Veyron-Lacroix.


Neil Effman, Airline Official; Developed Pan Am Shuttle
LEAD: Neil Effman, a former executive with Trans World Airlines for 25 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday while on vacation in Mexico.
He was 52 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

'To Be a Priest,' A Channel 13 Documentary
LEAD: ''To Be a Priest'' is reverential, although in these disputatious times that may be a relief.
The Vatican speaks; all over the world, critics grumble.
The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, has nothing to do with that.
It looks at the life of a contemporary parish priest.
Sometimes this is slow going, but stay with it because there are rewarding moments.

Treasuries Continue Recovery
LEAD: The rebound in prices of Treasury debt issues continued yesterday, with intermediate maturities closing with some of the best gains of the day.
The shortening of maturities by investors increased the demand for Treasury bills as well, causing their rates to decline further.

LEAD: Business sales climbed a record 4.4 percent in February from weak January levels, while inventories rose a small two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

JERSEY AIDE TIES HOSPITAL NEGLECT TO DEATHS OF 3
LEAD: The New Jersey Public Advocate said today that ''extreme negligence'' on the part of physicians and employees at three state psychiatric hospitals led to the deaths of three patients over the last year.


REGAN, IN TALK, BACKS REAGAN
LEAD: In his first speech since resigning as White House chief of staff in February, Donald T. Regan said President Reagan knew nothing about the reported diversion to the contras of money from American arms sales to Iran.


Getting to Know You
LEAD: Before the Rangers ever had a chance to get acquainted, their season ended last night with a 5-0 thrashing by the Flyers on their home ice.


STRAWBERRY, METS TURN ON THE POWER
LEAD: Power. The Mets have it. The Mets flaunt it. Dave Johnson loves it.


French Offer to Saudis
LEAD: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today that France was ready to offer Saudi Arabia the latest industrial and military technology as part of a drive to forge a close economic partnership by the end of the century.
Mr.
Chirac made the offer at a lunch for King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who was making a 24-hour visit to Paris, his first official trip to France since becoming monarch in 1982.


Moody's Cuts Mellon Rating
LEAD: The debt rating of the Mellon Bank Corporation and its subsidiaries was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.
About $1.5 billion of long-term debt is affected.


CONSTITUTION CELEBRATION AT LIBRARY
LEAD: The 200th birthday of the Constitution of the United States is having its biggest New York celebration at the New York Public Library.
Starting tomorrow, an exhibition of nearly 200 items, including original documents, portraits and maps, will go on view in the classic interior of Gottesman Hall in the library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue.


Fanfani Forms Cabinet In Italy; June Vote Seen
LEAD: Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani today told Italy's President he can form a Government, which political sources said would take Italy to early general elections in June.


Kemp Now 'Bona Fide'
LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp has become the first Republican Presidential contender to qualify for matching public funds.

4.2% Canadian Inflation
LEAD: Higher prices in Canada for most consumer goods and services pushed up the annual inflation rate to 4.2 percent in March, from 4 percent in February, Statistics Canada said today.
The federal agency said that higher costs for gasoline, cigarettes and housing contributed to the overall increase, the second consecutive monthly rise.

Sri Lanka-I.M.F. Talks
LEAD: Sri Lanka and the International Monetary Fund have broadly agreed on economic reforms, but tough negotiations will be necessary to win approval of loans of $240 million, a Government official said today.
A senior official of the Finance and Planning Ministry said an I.M.F.-World Bank team would be in Colombo next month to start talks on details of a three-year reform of the island's economy.

Italy Wine Exports Hurt
LEAD: Italy's wine-doctoring scandal produced a sharp fall in exports last year, the Foreign Trade Institute said today.
It said total exports of wine and vermouth fell 35.8 percent, to 242 million gallons in 1986, from 396 million gallons in 1985.
Several countries imposed curbs on Italian wine imports following the scandal early last year, when 23 people died after drinking the cheap wine, adulterated with wood-based methyl alcohol.

Mauritius-Boeing Deal
LEAD: Air Mauritius has leased a second Boeing 747 SP jumbo jet and will take delivery of two Boeing 767-200 long-range airliners in 1988, the airline's general manager said today.
The second-hand 747, which was acquired on a renewable one-year lease, made its first scheduled flight, to Munich, West Germany, earlier this month, he said.

LEAD: Dixons Group P.L.C., which won control of the Cyclops Corporation after a protracted takeover battle, said it might sell Cyclops's Busy Beaver Building Centers Inc. unit, which operates 11 hardware stores.

Correction
LEAD: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum's acquisition of a photograph collection described the transaction incorrectly.


Cracking Down On Duck Dealing And Bunny Sales
LEAD: ''What's next?'' Huando Torres, a busy undercover agent these days, asked his partner as they pulled away from the pet shop.


Argentina's Easter Rebellion
LEAD: Sooner or later, some diehard officer in Argentina was bound to be loopy enough to believe that his country truly needed and wanted a fresh smack of military rule.
Coups have long been the tradition, and not since 1930 has a civilian president completed his term.
Proof that times are changing resounds in the country's response to an attempted rebellion in provincial Cordoba.

SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 42.


U.S. WILL TEST BOMB DETECTOR FOR AIR CARGO
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration this spring will conduct tests of an advanced detection system designed to keep bombs or other explosive devices from being loaded into the cargo holds of airliners.


Citrus Disease in Florida
LEAD: Citrus canker, a disease that ruins fruit and weakens trees but does not harm humans, has been found in Florida for the first time since January.
But Kevin Kiefer, a supervisor of the Citrus Canker Project, says the infection of 10 trees in residential areas does not mean the blight is spreading.
The new cases were found on Anna Maria Island and in south Bradenton.


Railroad to Settle Discrimination Suit
LEAD: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company has agreed to buy about $33 million in goods and services from black and Hispanic companies to settle a discrimination lawsuit, according to court documents.
The settlement, in which the railroad does not admit guilt, is the first resulting from a 1979 lawsuit filed against three railroads by the Chicago-based Organization of Minority Vendors


Maybe More for Bettors
LEAD: Officials of the New York Racing Association expressed optimism about reducing the takeout on parimutuel wagers at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga.


'Pygmalion' Postponed
LEAD: The opening of the Broadway show ''Pygmalion,'' with Peter O'Toole and Amanda Plummer, has been postponed to April 26 from April 21.
The revival of the Shaw play, which will be at the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street, is being produced by the Shubert Organization, Jerome Minskoff and Duncan C.

BACTERIA PRODUCTION PROCESS COULD SPEED AIDS RESEARCH
LEAD: Scientists say they have developed a way to make bacteria produce a key protein from the virus that causes AIDS, a development that could help speed research on drugs to combat the virus.


'Month of Sundays' to Close
LEAD: ''A Month of Sundays,'' a comedy by Bob Larbey, will close after this evening's performance at the Ritz Theater, 219 West 48th Street.
The play, directed by Gene Saks and starring Jason Robards, will have run for four regular performances and 19 previews.

FOR THE HOMELESS: A NEW IDEA
LEAD: An architect has designed his own low-cost solution to the problem of homelessness: a small weatherproof plywood shelter with windows, a mattress and a place to hang a hat.


New Ford Frame
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it was developing an aluminum space frame for its Probe V concept car, using extruded stretch-formed aluminum.
Ford said the frame could lead to new techniques for building production cars.
The frame will reduce vehicle weight and cost while maintaining structural integrity and crashworthiness, the company said.

CHESS AT NEW YORK OPEN: 'IT'S LIKE A WAR'
LEAD: ''I could've been a contender,'' Asa Hoffmann said. ''I could've been a grandmaster.'' Instead, Mr.
Hoffmann is a hustler, the Fast Eddie Felson of the knight and rook set.


Malaysia Dooms Traffickers
LEAD: A Malaysian court today convicted two men of drug trafficking and sentenced them to death.
The national news agency, Bernama, said Nordin Abu Bakar, 36 years old, a salesman, and Lim Kong Seong, a former technical school student, were charged under a law that carries a mandatory death sentence.


METS' BATS ARE FINALLY MEEK
LEAD: For the first time in nine games this season, the Mets failed to hit a home run tonight.
And, for the first time in four games, they failed to win.

LEAD: The Sharon Steel Corporation, once a major part of the financial empire of Victor Posner, the Miami financier, asked a Federal bankruptcy court in Erie, Pa., yesterday for protection from creditors.

Now the quietly effective Canadians, already the largest commercial landlord in New York, are negotiating to capture another mammoth chunk of the Manhattan market as well.

Profits Surge At Manville
LEAD: The Manville Corporation, citing improved conditions in its principal markets, said its first-quarter profit more than doubled, to $42.9 million, or $1.52 a share, from $17.5 million, or 47 cents a share, in the 1986 period.
Sales climbed 6.7 percent, to $475 million, from $445.3 million.

Tough Stance By Europeans
LEAD: The European Community is ready to insure that the Japanese exports effectively excluded from the United States by 100 percent tariffs are not diverted to it, a spokesman said today.


Don't Hang Up Modular Housing
LEAD: How can costs of housing construction be brought within the reach of moderate-income New Yorkers?
Modular or prefabricated units, turned out en masse by factories in the city, offer one answer.
But realizing it requires the cooperation and careful planning of city officials, factory owners and unions - especially unions.

CUOMO'S RISKY STRATEGY
LEAD: Although Governor Cuomo's confrontation with the Legislature stems from a genuine desire to obtain a tougher code of government ethics, it also stems, in the view of both lawmakers and some administration officials, from just plain anger and a calculated strategy that the dispute will strengthen the Governor politically.

HAVANA REPORTS 3 CUBANS DEAD OF AIDS AND SETS UP ISOLATION UNIT
LEAD: In its first extensive report on AIDS in Cuba, the Government said today that three Cubans had died from the disease and that it had created a special isolation unit for people discovered to be infected by the AIDS virus.


The Crunch in Submarine Warfare
LEAD: The Navy's fleet of attack submarines is caught between the Devil and a deep red ink ocean.
Soviet submarines, once far inferior in stealth and technology, are rapidly catching up.
And the Navy's attempt to regain its lead with an expensive new design, the SSN21 Seawolf, may help plunge the Navy into a severe budget crunch in the mid-1990's.

He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 18, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL
2-5,20  President Reagan imposed a tariff of 100 percent on some Japanese-made computers, television sets and power drills.
Mr.
Reagan said he was trying ''to enforce the principles of free and fair trade.''
Page 1
In Sri Lanka, guerrillas killed 107 civilians on three buses and two trucks.

LENSES TO CHANGE EYE COLOR
LEAD: SOME people are content with the color of their eyes.
Some are not.
Once upon a time, that was that.
Then along came tinted contact lenses.
The first ones, a generation ago, had a brightly colored iris painted on them.
They did not catch on, except with movie actors, because the colors looked unnatural and people had trouble adjusting to hard plastic lenses.


Wells Fargo Fee Settlement
LEAD: A judge has approved a settlement in which Wells Fargo &amp; Company has agreed to partly refund bounced-check fees to thousands of customers.
The settlement also calls for the bank to provide $1 million for consumer education in financial management, and allows the bank to raise its $10 charge for overdrafts next year.


Correction
LEAD: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about the rescheduled opening of the Broadway show ''Sleight of Hand'' gave an incorrect date.
The play will now open May 3 at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street.


G.M. Cites Need To Compete Better
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation believes it must become more competitive with other auto makers in the next five years or stop building cars in the United States, a senior G.M. official was quoted as saying.
The Detroit Free Press quoted Alfred Warren, G.M.'s industrial relations vice president, as saying, ''We've got about three to five years to either get our act together or get out of the business.


HIJACKER OF '76 T.W.A. FLIGHT BURROWS OUT OF FEDERAL PRISON
LEAD: A Croatian nationalist serving a life sentence for a trans-Atlantic airline hijacking in 1976 apparently burrowed his way out of a Federal prison 60 miles northwest of New York City yesterday, setting off a nationwide manhunt.


Air Force Halts Money to Northrop
LEAD: The Air Force has suspended $25 million in monthly payments to the Northrop Corporation for work on a guidance system for the MX missile.
The action came in a dispute concerning late deliveries of an electronic system, known as inertial measurement units, according to Maj.
Barry Glickman, an Air Force spokesman.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Bird Outduels Jordan: Larry Bird scored 38 points to lead the Boston Celtics to a 108-105 victory night over the Chicago Bulls last night in Boston.
The Bulls' Michael Jordan scored 17 points and missed the last 18 minutes with an apparently minor thigh injury.
Jordan, who scored a regular-season career-high 61 points Thursday night, was forced out because of a bruise suffered in the 117-114 loss Thursday night to Atlanta.

Davis's 'Second Strike'
LEAD: Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' all-star guard, has been suspended for cocaine use, General Manager Jerry Colangelo said in Phoenix yesterday.
Colangelo said that Davis admitted he had become involved with cocaine again and would re-enter a drug-treatment program.


Nukes Are Not Tanks
LEAD: Europe's fear of eliminating short- as well as intermediate-range missiles from the Continent is based on the fallacy that their nuclear warheads are weapons, like battleships or tanks.
They aren't, because they can't be used by rational leaders except to deter their use by others.

HART TO SEEK RULING ON USE OF '88 FUNDS FOR '84 DEBT
LEAD: Gary Hart's campaign manager said today that the campaign organization would ask the Federal Election Commission whether money raised for Mr.
Hart's 1988 campaign could be used to help pay off the $1.3 million debt from his Presidential bid in 1984.


ART, DANCE AND MUSIC TO MERGE IN A 'RIVER'
LEAD: Its theme may be social disruption, but ''Interrupted River'' is the product of creative harmony.
The new dance, with choreography by Jennifer Muller, receives its world premiere Tuesday night when Ms.
Muller's company, the Works, opens a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater.


New Drug Problem
LEAD: The San Francisco Giants announced yesterday that Eddie Milner, the 31-year-old outfielder acquired Jan. 8 from the Cincinnati Reds for Frank Williams, a pitcher, had voluntarily entered a medical-counseling program for treatment of a drug problem.
Al Rosen, the Giants' general manager, said said the outfielder, who was batting .222 with one run batted in, had been placed on the 21-day disabled list, but was expected to need 28 days for treatment.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Chemlawn Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said that because of an offer by Ecolab Inc. for Chemlawn shares at $36.50 each, it had postponed its annual meeting, which had been scheduled for April 23.
No new date was set.
The offer is to expire April 20.

Orpheus Replaces I Musici
LEAD: I Musici, the Italian chamber group, will not appear Monday night at 8 at Carnegie Hall because one of the musicians is ill.
Appearing instead will be the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which will perform works by Haydn, Mozart and Bartok.
The guest soloists are David Jolley, a french horn player, and Charles Neidich, a clarinetist.

LEAD: The decision by the United States Patent and Trademark Office to allow inventors to patent new forms of animal life is likely to touch off a fierce national debate that will pit the need of companies to protect a valuable industrial development against the moral concerns of ethicists, religious leaders and animal rights groups.

ISLANDERS ARE JOYFUL FOR NOW
LEAD: The Islanders had earned another reprieve.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''People don't look up to chess players in this country.
The public thinks all chess players are short, fat and wear glasses.'' - Asa Hoffmann, chess player for fun and modest profit.  [ 24:2. ]


RICHARD WILBUR IS NAMED NATION'S POET LAUREATE
LEAD: Richard Wilbur, a man of letters who has won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, the applause of theatergoers for his lyrics to the musical ''Candide'' and the praise of scholars for his translations of Moliere, was named today the poet laureate of the United States.


ROBERT H. BETHKE
LEAD: Robert H. Bethke, a former chairman and chief executive officer of the Discount Corporation of New York, died of cancer Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 71 years old and lived in Armonk, N.Y.


Effort to End S.A.T. Testing At Brown U. Is Turned Back
LEAD: Brown University students today narrowly defeated a nonbinding referendum calling on the school to drop the Scholastic Aptitude Test as an admission requirement.

Tokyo Sees Violation Of Rules
LEAD: Charging that the American decision to impose tariffs violated international trading rules, Japanese officials today called on the United States to withdraw the measures.


Pension Payments By LTV Allowed

ARGENTINA'S ARMY MOVES TO HEAD OFF OFFICER REBELLION
LEAD: The Argentine Army, declaring its loyalty to the Government of President Raul Alfonsin, moved today to end a rebellion by officers opposed to the prosecution of military officers on human rights charges.


Helicopter Crashes in Idaho
LEAD: A chartered helicopter carrying state Fish and Game officers on a survey of bighorn sheep crashed in a rugged wilderness area, and the pilot is feared dead, the authorities said today.
The pilot's identity was not immediately known.
Two department officers who were flying as passengers suffered injuries when the helicopter went down in the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness.

Mt. Etna Eruption Kills Two
LEAD: Ashes, gases and tons of rocks showered tourists on Mount Etna today, killing an 8-year-old French boy and his mother and injuring seven people, officials said.
The police in this city on Sicily's eastern coast said all nine were among a group of tourists who were caught in a brief eruption while walking near the volcano's summit.

PLANE CRASH KILLS PILOT AS 6 FLEE BURNING HOME
LEAD: A private plane trying to land in fog and drizzle at Westchester County Airport yesterday crashed into a home and exploded six miles short of the runway.
The pilot was killed, but six people in the home escaped seconds before it erupted in a fireball.

Wickes Liability
LEAD: Moody's Investors Service said it might downgrade $1.9 billion of the Wickes Companies' debt, citing the potential liability from the huge amounts of apparently substandard carpeting sold by Wickes's newly acquired Collins &amp; Aikman subsidiary.
Moody's noted that Wickes's auditor, Arthur Andersen &amp; Company, had indicated it would qualify its opinion on the company's financial statement for the year ended Jan.

Night to Remember
LEAD: The words on a 14-by-18-foot billboard outside the Spectrum in Philadelphia bore last night's theme: ''We'll never fill your shoes.
Thanks for everything Doc.'' The words were surrounded by 50,000 signatures of Julius Erving's fans.
It was Dr.
J's last regular-season home game after 11 years with the 76ers, and a sellout crowd of 17,967 was present.

Good Friday, A Quiet Prayer and Hope
LEAD: Worshipers yesterday at St.
Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue as Christians around the world joined in observing the most solemn day in the church year.
It is followed closely by the most joyous of Christian holidays, Easter Sunday. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)


EUROPE, TOO, POSTS 'NO DUMPING' SIGNS FOR JAPANESE FIRMS
LEAD: WESTERN EUROPE, like the United States, is using far more than words in its trade disputes with Japan.
Europe, in fact, seized the weapon of duties against Japan well before Washington decided to impose high tariffs, which went into effect Friday, on some Japanese electronic goods in retaliation for the purported ''dumping'' of computer chips at unfairly low prices.


DEER ARE THE DINNER GUESTS
LEAD: Some of the 60 deer that live at Heckscher State Park dining on corn left by park employees.
The 3 P.M. feeding has become a daily attraction for local residents, but it ends today. ''Once the weather gets warm and all the people start coming here, we won't see the deer,'' said the park superintendent, Fred O'Neill.


The TV Evangelists Thrive on Skepticism; What Calvin Stood For

LEAD: Mary Pride Schuler, the daughter of William Moughon Schuler of Birmingham, Ala., and Mary Fountain of Charleston, Ore., was married yesterday to Dr.
William Winkenwerder Jr., a son of Mr.
Winkenwerder and Martha Loew, both of Asheville, N.C.
