I AM CINDERELLA'S STEPMOTHER AND I KNOW MY RIGHTS
LEAD: I have been asked to verify for those to whom it is not immediately apparent that since the following is a work of fiction (inspired by the recent suit against the movie based on Sylvia Plath's ''Bell Jar'') ''written by'' a person who never existed, the events referred to in it could not have taken place.


Iran Reports New Raids on Iraq
LEAD: Iran asserted today that its troops and allied Kurdish irregulars had killed 1,500 Iraqis in hit-and-run attacks in the Kurdistan mountains, where a smoldering guerrilla war is heating up.


SWEDES IN NEW JERSEY
LEAD: ALTHOUGH no one seems to mind that the first Swedish settlers in New Jersey did not arrive 350 years ago, the state will participate in New Sweden 88, a celebration of 350 years of Swedish settlement in Delaware and New Jersey.


RECIPES TO KEEP IN HAND FOR THOSE TASTY ASPARAGUS SPEARS
LEAD: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful.
It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane.
All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette.
But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven.


Outdoors; Canada Increases Its Support for Salmon
LEAD: CANADA is giving greater recognition to the economic role played by its Atlantic salmon sport fishery, a development that delights the Atlantic Salmon Federation, a nonprofit conservation organization with branches in that country and the United States.


Hhway Math
LEAD:  To the Editor:


HOSPITAL FEES SOAR UNDER NEW SYSTEM
LEAD: A NEW hospital-payment system intended to contain costs has raised rates an average of 18 percent for inpatient treatment and has sometimes produced charges of more than $9,000 for an overnight stay.


NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; Designing By Committee
LEAD: FOR nearly 30 years, Seattle has been trying to build a downtown public square and, later, a shopping mall.
Critics say that the effort has become a textbook example of the problems that are inherent in urban planning.


CENTRAL AMERICA'S ARMS BUILDUP: THE RISK OF GUNS WITHOUT BUTTER
LEAD: As Central America undergoes the most rapid military buildup in its history, with forceful American participation, civilian government leaders and diplomats are concerned about prospects for weak governments that must deal with the vastly strengthened armies in their countries.


WHEN ALL IS NOT ENOUGH
LEAD: IN a world where few drivers can remember life before cruise control, automakers are scrambling to develop new amenities to win over well-off buyers who are used to being pampered.


THE MOST ITALIAN OF SPIRITS
LEAD: In Italy, mornings are for cappuccino, but in northern Italy, they're also for a tiny cup of syrupy espresso with a shot of fiery grappa, the most Italian of spirits.


CRIME
LEAD: LAST JUDGMENT by Richard Hugo (Stein &amp; Day, $16.95) is a very fine book.
Its prologue goes back to the German invasion of Poland in 1939 and the theft of an unknown da Vinci painting.
Switch to the present, and the apparently unrelated mass murder of a family in London. ''I am the incubus of pure terror,'' says the killer as he pulls the trigger.


Q. &amp; A.: Stephen G. Breyer; WITH UNIFORM SENTENCING - SAME CRIME, SAME TIME
LEAD: TOWARD the end of 1985, the United States Sentencing Commission took up the task of making punishment for Federal crimes more uniform, effective and fair.
Last week it recommended ranges of sentencing for 43 categories of crimes, based on a statistical analysis of present sentences.
Convicts would no longer be paroled, more time would be served for drug-related offenses and prison would be prescribed for many white-collar crimes under guidelines that become binding on Federal judges Nov.


EQUALIZERS CHIP IN WITH INTELLIGENCE
LEAD: MORE AND MORE these days, machines are taking over the tasks that some people aren't smart enough to do themselves.
If you don't know how to add, all you need is a pocket calculator; and if you don't know how to spell, a modern typewriter can help you out with some computerized orthography.
That kind of handy automation has lately come to audio in the form of self-regulating equalizers.


SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers.
Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.


Next Week; What Do Giants and Jets Need In the Draft?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


IS THE LABOR PARTY AN ENDANGERED SPECIES?
LEAD: BY midweek, politicians were streaming out of the capital for Britain's protracted ''Easter hols,'' and that may be the best news the Labor Party and its leader, Neil Kinnock, have received all year.
Recent polls showed Labor 10 to 13 points behind the Conservatives, but barely holding onto second place over the Alliance of Liberals and Social Democrats, which hopes to displace Labor as one of the two major parties.


Tech Transfer
LEAD:  To the Editor:


'FREQUENT FLIERS' CRYING FOUL AS AIRLINES CHANGE THE RULES
LEAD: For the past seven years Raymond W. Zrike went out of his way to fly Trans World Airlines, and last month it was about to pay off: he passed the 90,000-mile mark, enough to get two free first-class round-trip tickets to Europe.


ROONEY IS FUNNY THING AT FORUM
LEAD: MICKEY ROONEY stars in ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' which is making a fast stop at the Westbury Music Fair during its current national tour.


WRITING THAT ANGRY LETTER
LEAD: There is a glutted file in this department where copies of travelers' letters of complaint accumulate.
Some are heartrending, some are amazing; all are angry.
The opposite of the little black box that emits applause sounds when the lid is lifted, this file drawer seems to give off steam and sounds of fury when opened.


Argentina Thwarts Military Rebellion
LEAD: When an Argentine Army officer refused last week to be questioned in court about allegations of human rights abuses, he precipitated a serious challenge to the three-year-old civilian Government of President Raul Alfonsin.


CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


TIGHTENING THE REINS IN BALLISTIC MISSLE RACE
LEAD: IN South America, Argentina and Brazil are to be the proud new owners of ballistic missiles.
On the subcontinent, India leads Pakistan in the race to obtain powerful missiles.
Asian nations that rim the Pacific - the Koreas, Taiwan, Indonesia - are climbing the technical ladder toward mastery of missile technology.


MINING A CD CATALOGUE
LEAD: AS COMPACT DISKS BE-come plentiful enough so that record companies have to compete for buyer attention, an illuminating insight into CD marketing is provided by the first installment of reissues from the Vanguard Recording Society.


HART JUMPS IN, RIVALS UNDISMAYED
LEAD: PERCHED on a rock in Red Rocks Park, Colo., last Monday, Gary Hart became the third official candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''I make this race because I love my country and I want America to do better and move forward,'' the former Senator from Colorado said.
He promised a campaign of ideas.


ENROLLMENT OF MINORITIES IN COLLEGES STAGNATING
LEAD: Two decades after colleges and universities began opening their doors to substantial numbers of minority students, the effort to diversify American higher education appears to have stagnated.

NEW ORLEANS, AND ALL THAT JAZZ
LEAD: What Lincoln Steffens wrote of Paris well describes New Orleans, our belle ville at the bottom of America: ''A loose merger of many, very many small provincial communities, each of which is pleasantly or offensively clannish.''

LEAD: LORNA Altemus was shopping for a new Jeep when she came upon a magazine article comparing the Suzuki Samurai with several other four-wheel-drive vehicles.


Play IT AGAIN, SAM
LEAD: EVAN EISENBERG'S ''THE Recording Angel: Explorations in Phonography'' (McGraw-Hill) seems to be the first full-length book on the implications and effects of recording on music.
It's bursting with ideas, taking up topics from the ties between ritual and music to the compression that 78-rpm records brought to the classic blues.


Headliners; Voted In
LEAD: The Bronx, whose political leadership has lately hinged more on the ballots cast by grand jurors than on those of ordinary voters, got a new Borough President last week.
City Council members from the borough chose Fernando Ferrer for the post, which was vacated last month when Stanley Simon resigned from the office as he was about to be indicted various charges.

I cannot change a tire.
Nor can I differentiate between the carburetor, if cars still have such things, and the radiator, air filter, gear box or condenser.
In a crisis, when the hood of the car is sprung open, revealing the grayish-brown tangle of hoses and boxes and releasing the thick, warm odor of melting rubber,

PUTTING A PRICE ON ANGER OVER IMPORTS
LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN retaliated last week against Japanese trading practices that, the Administration said, violated a 1986 computer chip agreement.
He imposed tariffs that may double the price of some color television sets, computers and power tools.
Retailers said consumers should feel little effect, except for those who buy laptop computers.

LEAD: The family of a 34-year-old exercise physiologist, hospitalized at the Westchester County Medical Center in a vegetative state, has asked a state appeals court for permission to remove a feeding tube - an act that his family said he had indicated he would favor.


THE PAST INTRUDES UPON A WEDDING LIST
LEAD: JACKIE, our youngest daughter, will be married this summer.
Just as Jackie is the youngest of 5, I was the youngest of 6, and my mother was the youngest of 11.
So when I sit down to write the invitations for Jackie's wedding, I remember again what being the youngest daughter of a youngest daughter meant to me.

TRIALS OF A TEMPORARY BACHELOR
LEAD: FOR just about the whole first week, everything around here was in apple-pie order.
The three of us all get up at different times to go to work and, like Dagwood Bumstead, at top speed, washing-shaving-toothbrushing-dres-sing zap!!, out the door, but nobody was ever late because clean clothes and toiletries were in good supply and easy to find.

Dial Sets Record
LEAD: IN a performance heightened by controversy, Joe Dial soared 19 feet 4 3/4 inches yesterday at the Kansas Relays in Lawrence, Kan., to break his American pole-vault record.


MAKING OLD WOOD NEW AGAIN WITH CHEMICAL PAINT STRIPPER
LEAD: STRIPPING paint or varnish from a valued piece of wood furniture is a time-consuming, tedious job no matter what method is used.
However, in many cases it is the only way to restore the original beauty of the natural wood, and it is an essential preparatory step before you can stain or bleach the wood.

LEAD: NOT too long ago, shopping along Greenwich Avenue in stately old Greenwich, Conn., was a strictly local affair.
The merchants were familiar figures in the town of 60,000, and the only businesses owned by outsiders were Woolworth's and the telephone company.


THE TERRIFYING NORMALACY OF AIDS
LEAD: DISNEY'S EPCOT CENTER in Orlando, Fla., is a technological tour de force and a conceptual desert.
In this permanent World's Fair, American industrial giants have built their versions of an unblemished future.
These masterful entertainments convey but one message, brilliantly packaged and relentlessly expressed: progress through technology is the solution to all human problems.

New York Youth Dies on Trip
LEAD: A New York City teen-ager died this week, apparently of alcohol poisoning, during a school trip to the Soviet Union.
The youth, Damon Walsh, 16 years old, was found dead in his Leningrad hotel room Friday by a chaperone, said Jerry Aldredge, dean of resident students at St.
Johnsbury Academy here.


An Older Father
LEAD: When his son is a teen-ager, Richard Taylor will be in his 80's.
The chances of his being at his son's graduation from high school, not to mention college, are minimal.
No service was done to little Aristotle Eli when he was born to a man close to 70 and a woman in her early 20's.
Rather than being a loving, nurturing event, the birth of Aristotle is another example, albeit a subtle one, of the narcissism of our time.

Honor for Bowler
LEAD: A Brooklyn-born bowler who has earned $1,207,707 since joining the Professional Bowlers Association tour in 1970, will be inducted tomorrow into the P.B.A.
Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio.
Mark Roth, who is second in career earnings by less than $60,000 to Earl Anthony, will be honored for performances that include winning 32 tour events, leading the tour in average score for five years, most recently in 1981, and being selected as P.B.A.

A SETTING FIT FOR A SHOGUN
LEAD: THE FIRST WORD I HAD OF the plan to create a new space for Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum came three years ago from a Buddhist priest I met at the Miidera (also known as Onjoji), the imposing temple complex that overlooks Lake Biwa, east of Kyoto.
I had gone there, as I had long intended, to pay my respects at the grave of Ernest Fenollosa (1853-1908), the American scholar who did so much not only to introduce Japanese art to the West but to persuade the Japanese, then in the throes of modernization, to preserve their traditional arts.


TWO TYPES OF AUTO-FOCUSING
LEAD: EVERYONE'S talking about automatic focusing these days, and quite a few photographers think it is the greatest invention since flexible film.
But I suspect that few purchasers of auto-focus cameras know how it works, or recognize that there are several kinds of auto focusing, depending on the type and brand of camera.


DANCE: THE WENDY PERRON TROUPE
LEAD: WENDY PERRON is a quietly arresting performer who moves through a dance with a look of in-turned concentration and great physical delicacy and adroitness.
Her dances are like that, too, with a sure, sometimes fierce intelligence driving them along.
They curl into space like flowering vines, but a closer look reveals that the vines and tendrils are steely sinew.

Golf Round Clock
LEAD: IT'S been almost a year since Mark Matthews played 724 holes of golf in a hectic 24 hours at the Rockwood Golf Course in Fort Worth, Tex., a feat that raised $10,000 for charity last June.
Now the 25-year-old Matthews has gotten his reward.
He has been notified that his effort has been certified and accepted as a world record by the Guinness Book of World Records.

LEAD: IRANIANS in Southern California rarely stay up to watch Johnny Carson these days.

Afshar's ''Sima-E-Ashena,'' an hour-long Persian-language show of news, commentary and interviews.

The Crash of '87
LEAD: Each week brings fresh evidence for prophets of economic doom: Brazil defaults on its foreign debt . . .
The monthly U.S. trade deficit hits $15 billion . . .
The dollar falls to new lows against the yen . . .
President Reagan succumbs to pressure for retaliation against Japan.
And for the first time, responsible officials like Fed chairman Paul Volcker openly speculate about a world financial crisis.

LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Dealing With the Law of the Land'' (Travel, Feb. 15), Nicholas D. This kind of arrogance makes the blood of many believing Muslims boil.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  A LIFE IN MOVIES: An Autobiography.
By Michael Powell. (Knopf, $24.95.) The author of this intelligent and superbly written autobiography, the British film director Michael Powell, is known in this country chiefly for the cult ballet movie ''The Red Shoes'' (1948), though some consider the subtly erotic tale of Anglican nuns in the Himalayas, ''Black Narcissus'' (1947), and the benignly decadent, self-reflexive ''Peeping Tom'' (1960) even better.

NEW LIFE FOR EARLY MUSIC
LEAD: MANY RECORDINGS of pre-Classical music used to be sold in what amounted to plain brown wrappers with such plain brown titles as ''Monody, ca. 1600 - Research Period VII'' (and many, though by no means all, of the performances were monochromatic, too).
If this left little doubt about the high-mindedness attached to the whole operation, it also probably discouraged casual purchases, limiting the audience to those already in the know.

Separating Illusion From Reality In War on Cancer
LEAD: On paper, the National Cancer Institute appears to be making progress.
The survival rate for bladder cancer was 53 percent in 1950 compared with 77 percent in 1982.
Improvements also have been reported for patients with breast cancer, lung cancer, colon and rectal cancer and other malignancies.

HOW BOTH SIDES GAIN FROM MOSCOW TALKS
LEAD: IT would be difficult enough for the Soviet Union and the United States to agree on reducing nuclear arms if their negotiators could simply lock themselves in a windowless room and deal dispassionately in the intricate calculus of complex weaponry.
But the outside world intrudes; political emotion, theatrics and imagery also have seats at the bargaining table.

ON LANGUAGE
LEAD: BY NO MEANS WAS IT really teed up for him. . . .'' That phrase, teed up, was used by then-White House chief of staff Donald T. Regan in testimony before the Tower Commission.
I defined it here to mean ''spelled out, as if to a child or someone unfamiliar with the language; explained so that understanding is easy.

LEAD: IT is 8 o'clock in the morning, and the assignment editors and the producers of Cable News Network troop into the conference room for their regular morning meeting.
There are no pretensions here.
The table is too small, so some of the people grab outlying chairs and a few stand.
Those who want coffee bring their own - if they can find clean mugs.

LEAD: IN a nutshell, the problem in Kennebunkport, Me., was that anyone planning to be buried in the town's last open cemetery had to get in line and wait.
Even Vice President Bush.

LONDON ON A PEDESTAL
LEAD: When I first saw the view from my office in London, I felt as if I had inherited a great painting, and in a sense, I had.
For when I look south across a sweeping bend of the Thames, I can see the New Palace of Westminister, home of the Houses of Parliament - a filigreed Gothic ramble marked at one end by soaring Victoria Tower and at the other by the familiar Clock Tower of Big Ben.

Verbatim; What Good Is Jail?
LEAD: ' After spending my life in the city, including 20 years in police, I say what the hell good is jail?
It costs too much and we get almost nothing for it, except they don't do a crime while they're in the box.
And that's all we get. '  - Richard J. Koehler, New York City Correction Commissioner, discussing the city's overcrowded prisons.


GOULD AND THE CD: MADE FOR EACH OTHER
LEAD: GLENN GOULD WOULD probably have loved the compact disk.
He was nearly as interested in new methods of recording as he was in the piano; for him, recordings were not merely an appendix to concerts, but a satisfactory replacement for them.

Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
LEAD: During the last two weeks members of the New York news media have shown me their true colors.
While reading the various headlines, I wasn't sure if Gooden was a mass murderer, a key witness in the Iran-Contra affair, or a celebrated AIDS patient.
Whatever the case, the Big Apple's journalists have turned their pens on the Doctor: spewing venom rather than ink.


Q/and A
LEAD:  Europe by Ship  Question:Do you have information on the Polish liner Batory which sails from Montreal to Poland? - J. N., Hudson, Fla.
Answer:Passengers who want to cross the Atlantic on the Stefan Batory had better do so this year.
A spokesman for Polish Ocean Lines said that it had been decided to discontinue the vessel's trans-Atlantic schedule after its four crossings in 1987.

COULD VEBLEN EXPLAIN TODAY'S OPERA?
LEAD: CONSPICUOUS CONSUMPTION is nothing new at the Metropolitan Opera, which was founded, after all, as an amusement of New York's leisure class and until well into this century was almost entirely funded by a handful of bankers and other barons of business.
In that dim past, the show of wealth was most evident not onstage, but in a select sector of the audience where the instinct to display fine feathers was as strong as any peacock's.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE

Armchair Shopping For Homes
LEAD: ROY and Cathy Lloyd's three-level town house in Alexandria, Va., was shown on Washington's Channel 7 one chilly Sunday morning in January.
That afternoon, 24 people trekked through the Lloyds' two-bedroom home during an open house that had been promoted on the television program that morning.
On Monday, more prospective buyers came to look and on Tuesday, a few more trickled in.


Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
LEAD: I am writing to protest some of Dave Anderson's remarks in his column on Dwight Gooden (''Now Mets Know About Gooden,'' The New York Times, April 2).
Mr.
Anderson asks, ''Has cocaine forever changed his body chemistry that created that spectacular 24-4 season?'' and then engages in a good deal of speculation on that question.


MISTAKE ON RELEASE STIRS NEW JAIL DEBATE
LEAD: THE jail-population problem in Nassau County, which has bounced in and out of the Federal courts as well as political arenas since 1981, came to the fore again last week when it was learned that 16 prisoners, convicted of felony charges, were inadvertently freed as part of a Federal court-mandated early release program.


ALLANTE HAS A LOT TO SAY
LEAD: MORNINGS, I am not good.
But sometimes you do have to get up to meet a worthy adversary, in this case the dentist.
So I growled and grumbled in my empty house, and then I went out to the car, which nearly spoiled the whole day.
The car said, ''Good morning.''


FULL COATS GLOW IN APRIL SHOWERS
LEAD: AS usual, April has brought its share of rainy, windy days.
But the gloom of the weather has been offset by the fresh array of voluminous, richly colored raincoats that women are wearing, most of them every bit as breezy as the elements.


RECIPES TO KEEP IN HAND FOR THOSE TASTY ASPARAGUS SPEARS
LEAD: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful.
It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane.
All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette.
But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven.


New York Car Exhaust Test Assailed as Ineffective and Hampered by Fraud
LEAD: Despite repeated warnings from Federal environmental officials, New York State's system for testing car emissions remains one of the most ineffective in the nation and in some cases is hampered by fraud, according to Government documents and interviews with Federal and state officials.


Debate Silenced In South Korea
LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea had a simple solution to the conflict over how to select a leader to replace him: He suspended the debate over constitutional changes that would decide the issue.
But there were some signs last week that his move might only deepen resistance to his rule.

Faith, and Freedom
LEAD: Holy Week: the week of Easter, and also of Passover, a week to think of renewal and freedom, as good a week as there is to believe anew that faith can move mountains.
In a cathedral in Cape Town and in a mansion in Moscow, people gathered for religious services seemed to believe it.

'GREAT MOMENTS,' REMEMBERED FONDLY
LEAD: I write to express my full enjoyment of the Long Island Opinion Page Article ''Great Moments (Well, Almost) in L.I.
History''  [ March 22 ] .
It was a delightful spoof of the Constitution, history and Long Islanders, with special emphasis on their high opinion of themselves - not fully deserved in many cases.


LAW OF THE LAND
LEAD: To the Editor: To what purpose did Nicholas D. Kristof write ''Dealing with the Laws of the Land''?
I was surprised that someone who lives abroad would come to such an immature view of respect for the law (and therefore culture) of another country while traveling.
The gist of the article seemed to be that the victim of a crime should have remorse for having a thief proseuted under the legal system under which he (the thief) lives.


Uncertainties of a Chemical-Filled World Bring Fear to a Suburb of Denver
LEAD: Parents in the suburb of Friendly Hills here believe toxic chemicals from a nearby aerospace complex entered their drinking water, causing sickness and death among their children.
But state and Federal Government agencies say they have found no evidence of unusual health problems in the area.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: To non-weavers, the term interlacing sounds a bit cryptic.
The noted textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen and the writer Betty Freudenheim unravel it in INTERLACING: The Elemental Fabric (Kodansha International, $60), a richly illustrated volume that, in contrast to so many books on design, has a distinctly anthropological bent.


Tougher Line Is Urged in Sri Lanka After Attack
LEAD: Sinhalese groups called on the Government today to take a tougher line against Tamil terrorism, a day after 126 people were killed in a guerrilla attack.

LEAD:  REVOLUTION AS ILLICIT LOVE  Sometimes a writer exhilarates us with the sheer voluptuousness of his imagination.
Ronald Paulson sees the female figure of Liberty in the art of the French Revolution as combining Venus, a virgin state, a charitable woman, a sentimental love object and the mother of the new order.

TAILORING THE DATA BSE TO THE DATA
LEAD: TWO years ago, a data base management program called Reflex was released, and I was rather taken by it.
First of all, it was easy to use, and I'm certain that far more software is bought than is ever used, quite simply because learning how to run it is an overwhelming task.
But I also liked the program because it surpassed the usual data base manager in its ability to manipulate and analyze the information that it stored.

THE WINNERS WHO CAME FROM BEHIND
LEAD: WHEN world championships are instituted, American selection procedures tend to be haphazard.
In 1937 Ely Culbertson selected his own team to play in Budapest, and the United States women's team arrived with just three players.
In 1960 the first American women's team in a Team Olympiad included a player who had never before played with any of her teammates.

AVOIDING THE FOOT-IN-MOUTH SYNDROME
LEAD: STORIES abound about the ways American companies have messed up when they advertised to foreign audiences. ''Finger lickin' good,'' Kentucky Fried Chicken's slogan, once came out as ''eat your fingers off'' in Chinese.
And many Asians interpreted Pepsi's ''come alive generation'' as a call to bring back the dead.

Miss Dickenson, a licensing technician for the New England life insurance company in Boston, attended Boston University, of which her fiance is a graduate.

THE THIRD DEGREE AT THE BORDER

A SEARCH FOR SERVICES FOR HANDICAPPED BOY
LEAD: The article in your March 22, 1987, issue, ''Expense Rising for Education of Disabled,'' leaves the reader with the impression that Westchester County provides an abundance of expensive services to the preschool, handicapped population.
I am a parent of an 18-month-old boy with Down's Syndrome and was astounded to find that I was unable to secure county-funded services for him until he was 12 months old.

LEAD: The question is really ''How big a problem is racism in the nation?'' Sports mirrors the larger society.
The presence of the Abdul-Jabbars, Robinsons and Strawberrys in sports, as well as black superstars in other fields, may give one the impression that racism is a dying monster, but it is not.
The monster changes form but does not die.

Part and Parcel
LEAD: On the grounds of the rambling suburban estates that burgeoned around the turn-of-the century, the outbuildings were, more often than not, designed in styles similar to the grander main house.
As a growing number of these estates are now being subdivided into more managable packages of land, many of the utilitarian structures - like barns, grain houses, stables and chicken coops - have been renovated to become main houses themselves.

Sanibel Island
LEAD: To the Editor: In the article on Sanibel Island (Travel, March 8) the author states that Cross Creek, the settlement Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings made famous in her writings, is ''nearby'' the Everglades.
That's roughly equivalent to saying, in terms of mileage, that Washington, D.C., is nearby to New York.

'LES MISERABLES': THE DISTINCTIVE AND STIRRING VERSION IS STILL VICTOR HUGO'S
LEAD: THERE WERE PEOPLE who told me ''Les Miserables'' was going to be wonderful and people who told me it was going to be terrible.
The truth - or my reactions, at least - turned out to lie somewhere in the middle.
If the lyrics were often little more than doggerel, and if the score often seemed the musical equivalent of doggerel, there were compensations in Colm Wilkinson's rightly acclaimed Jean Valjean, in a few of the supporting performances, in the scenery and lighting, and, every now and then, in a genuinely striking dramatic effect.

It makes me feel important.

LAW OF THE LAND
LEAD: To the Editor: Mr.
Kristof's piece on criminal justice in foreign lands claims foreign visitors bring with them their ''mental baggage'' of justice standards to be appplied to the host country, to the point where it may justify intervention in the enforcement of a Draconian sanction.
He raises a host of issues that all people traveling abroad, especially to countries with considerably different cultural and/or economic circumstances from his own, should contemplate.

IT'S TIME TO CONSIDER A KEOGH - FOR '87
LEAD: IF you are a self-employed professional, or a homemaker or salaried worker with a sideline business, a Keogh plan is one of the most attractive ways to accumulate money for retirement.
Similar in concept to a corporate retirement or profit-sharing plan, a Keogh plan allows you to make tax-deductible annual contributions to it, and the earnings accumulate tax-free until they are withdrawn at retirement.

LEAD: IT is as if the Syrians had never left.

12 Die on Jordan School Bus
LEAD: Twelve passengers on a school bus were killed and 22 were injured when the bus overturned during an outing in the Mujib Valley, the official Jordanian press agency said today.
The victims of the accident Friday were teachers and students of a boys' secondary school in Dhiban, 30 miles south of Amman.


Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
LEAD: A few thoughts concerning Dwight Gooden. 1.
The Mets' organization should be rebuked for letting a gem become tarnished. 2.
Davey Johnson, the manager, should be dismissed - or at least given a stern reprimand - for being blind to the plight of his star pitcher.
It's impossible to believe that he was looking when Gooden was having pitching problems.

LEAD: Here is how Governor Cuomo has attacked, and legislators have defended, the ethics bill approved overwhelmingly by both houses but vetoed last week by the Governor.

TEXACO'S CHAPTER 11 THWARTS PENNZOIL
LEAD: Texaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in a move intended to keep Pennzoil from seizing any assets.
Facing a court decision that it must post a $12 billion bond as it appeals a jury award to Pennzoil for interfering with Pennzoil's deal to buy Getty, Texaco said it had no choice after Pennzoil rejected a $2 billion settlement offer.

HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
LEAD: You'll hear plenty about the dearth of black managers and executives, but let's not forget that there is also still bias in fielding teams.
If many black athletes are superstars, then many must also be excellent or good journeyman players.
But at the journeyman level, blacks are often not well represented, as they should be if skill were all that mattered.


RECIPES TO KEEP IN HAND FOR THOSE TASTY ASPARAGUS SPEARS
LEAD: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful.
It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane.
All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette.
But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven.


Ranks of Volunteer Firefighters Thinned by Changing Society
LEAD: When a 100-year-old farmhouse caught fire recently on a secluded hill over Lake Louise, the siren in this township's fire hall wailed its melancholy summons.
But the five men who responded were too little and too late.
By the time reinforcements from nearby departments arrived, flames had consumed the house, leaving little more than charred beams and rubble.

A SIMPLE EFFORT WILL CONTROL THE WEEDS
LEAD: IF the grass is about three inches tall, start the mowing ritual; be sure cutting blades are sharp and the motor is in good condition.
Forsythia in bloom signals application of pre-emergent weed controls to prevent crabgrass and other aggressive lawn weeds from sprouting; also use this form of weed control on service areas and flower borders to prevent nuisance weeds from growing this summer.

COLLECTING WITH A TOUCH OF GLASS
LEAD: IT is fragile, durable, decorative and practical - and part of America's past.

RECITAL: JOSEPH SMITH
LEAD: IN an art that has come to equate importance with size, Joseph Smith is an attractively reticent pianist.
Playing at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, Mr.
Smith made Beethoven's early F minor Sonata a model of Classical grammar, managing to be expressive without ever inflating a relatively contained format beyond its natural boundaries.


Life With Trixie
LEAD: TRIXIE IS NOT THE FIRST dog I had after I became an adult, or even the second.
I got the first one almost 15 years ago, and named her Mary.
She was a gray-furred, blue-eyed Weimaraner.
She fell asleep by sucking my thumb until she nodded off.
From the day my girlfriend and I carried her from San Francisco to Santa Cruz in a napkin, Mary lived with me - for 10 years.

WHO IS TO SAY WHAT'S RIGHT INTEACHING ETHICS?
LEAD: It's hard to find anyone these days who opposes the teaching of values in the public schools.

VIEWS OF A KALEIDOSCOPIC CITY
LEAD: Take a bus tour of a foreign city, and you will see its principal attractions in an afternoon.

Parties With a Purpose
LEAD:  Roman Celebration  April 20 - The American Academy in Rome, in a magnificent Italian Renaissance mansion, has fostered some of the most illustrious talents in American arts and letters since its founding in 1894 as a center for advanced studies.
Three composers who spent some of their formative years at the academy - Aaron Copland, Elliott Carter and Lukas Foss - will be honored at a black-tie benefit for the institution at the Equitable Center.


DELAWARE JOINS 3 STATES IN BIG LOTTERY
LEAD: Twice a week, on Wednesday and Friday, Ike Williams leaves his job in Delaware and drives 21 miles to Jayco Liquors in this border town.
A teetotaler, he ignores the rows of bottles.
Instead, like thousands of other Delaware residents hoping to strike it rich, he comes here to buy Maryland lottery tickets.

INFINITY IS BIGGER THAN ALL OF US
LEAD: IN ''Past Tense,'' the first volume of his diaries, Jean Cocteau says that ''Gide has never experienced the discomfort of infinity.'' It's a rather catty remark, but it rings true.
It reminds me of a photograph I saw of Gide: he was at the opera in Paris, sitting in the orchestra, and over his beautifully domed bald head he had draped a silk scarf.

MUSIC: JUILLARD QUARTET AND HAYDN
LEAD: ONE of Haydn's most fully characteristic works - therefore unique, original and lacking ostentation - is the series of slow instrumental ''sonatas'' on the seven last words of Christ.
The cycle was composed about 1786, and later published in arrangements, including one for string quartet that the Juilliard Quartet has often performed.

MUSIC: 'PLANCTUS MARIAE'
LEAD: THE ''Planctus Mariae,'' as offered at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine Good Friday afternoon, re-enacts the lamentations of the three Marys at the foot of Jesus's cross.
This modern version of a 14th-century church drama has been realized by W. L. Smolden and uses four players - the Virgin, Mary Jacobi, Mary Magdalen and John.

Louis Cardinals whaled a grand slam off Jesse Orosco that buried the Mets once and for all, 12-8.


Candidates are Striving to Establish THE Image
LEAD: THIS is the period known as ''the invisible primary,'' the stage of the Presidential campaign when candidates run almost no television commercials and receive no votes.
It is the time for battling for staff, struggling for campaign money and skirmishing for the hearts and hands of the party activists who do the unheralded work of democracy.

GOOD BUYS DOWN UNDER
LEAD: As Australia rises in popularity as a place for Americans to visit, the land Down Under has become -coincidentally - a better and cheaper place for shopping.
The attractive prices on Australian-made goods, which until a few years ago were not particulary valued, is a result of the Australian Labor Government's devaluation of the Australian dollar.

Jazz
LEAD: Oliver Jones did not undertake a full-time jazz career until 1980, when he was 46 years old.
By then he had spent the better part of two decades as accompanist and musical director for a Jamaican singer, Kenny Hamilton.

MAKING OLD WOOD NEW AGAIN WITH CHEMICAL PAINT STRIPPER
LEAD: STRIPPING paint or varnish from a valued piece of wood furniture is a time-consuming, tedious job no matter what method is used.
However, in many cases it is the only way to restore the original beauty of the natural wood, and it is an essential preparatory step before you can stain or bleach the wood.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  MIND TOOLS: The Five Levels of Mathematical Reality.
By Rudy Rucker. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) For those who gave up college mathematics for what seemed more liberal arts, Rudy Rucker's new book, ''Mind Tools,'' is a dazzling refresher course.
As in past works, like ''The Fourth Dimension,'' he rekindles the wonder that can come from contemplating logarithms, exponential curves and transcendental numbers.

Spending Habits
LEAD:  To the Editor:


RECIPES TO KEEP IN HAND FOR THOSE TASTY ASPARAGUS SPEARS
LEAD: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful.
It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane.
All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette.
But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven.


ONE OF THOSE DAYS? IT'S BETTER NOT TO PLAY
LEAD: WHAT do you do on a day when you have an awful premonition that things are going to go wrong?
Don't play.
Yes, that's right - don't play.
Because a feeling like that is invariably a valid foreboding, no matter whether it originates in unsynchronized biorhythms or any other way of being out of sorts.

LEAD: I'VE rehearsed my acceptance speech a thousand times.
It's a mix of humility, awe and gratitude, laced with professionalism and childish innocence.
It's still your basic ''I'd like to thank the members of the Academy who voted for me, my producer, my director, and my mother'' - with a focus on the film I was privileged to star in, the cast, the crew and, of course, the caterer.

THE PALESTINIAN CAMPUS
LEAD: IT WAS THE WEEK BEFORE STUDENT-COUNCIL elections at Bir Zeit University, on the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
Rival factions were trying to wrest control of the council from a coalition backing Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
The campus was plastered with campaign posters depicting Jerusalem surrounded by barbed wire; fat Jews eating skinny Palestinians with forks and knives; grenades, fists and guns embedded in the map of Israel.

LEAD:  BOXING
Honeyghan Keeps Titles: Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain won a unanimous 12-round decision over Maurice Blocker of the United States in London yesterday to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight championships.
The victory, in his second title defense, lifted Honeyghan's record to 30-0.

MUNICIPALLY BASED LAND-USE CONTROL IS CALLED A FAILURE
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S municipally based system of land-use control has badly failed our people.

Correction
LEAD: A chart in Travel Advisory on April 5 misstated room rates for Holiday Inn hotels in London because of incorrect information supplied by the hotel chain.
The usual Holiday Inn-Mayfair rates are $:91 to $:110 ($147.60 to $178.40) a night for a room for two; the usual Holiday Inn-Marble Arch rates are $:85 to $:120 ($147.60 to $194.65).


A PLACE TO WORK, A PLACE TO REST
LEAD: MY workshop is a special place.
It is removed from the rest of the house in a corner of the basement away from casual traffic.
It is comfortable and familiar.
It is my place.
It has all kinds of things that are used in home and car repair - wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers, tape rules, assorted nails, screws, nuts and bolts, pliers and some power tools.

THE SEVENTH, THE EIGHT AND THE DECIDING GAME
LEAD: IT was hockey, but as the skaters skimmed slowly into quadruple overtime, the scene resembled the gradual disintegration of a marathon dance contest.

Even the ice seemed to respire, as if in weariness, and long glaring puddles formed at random on its surface.

LEAD: It's not the ordinary home-court advantage.
That's why it was so important that Atlanta get it.

LEAD: The body of a 36-year-old minister, apparently the victim of a burglary, was found yesterday afternoon in his living quarters behind a storefront church in Brooklyn, the police said.


THE STAGE: 'PLAIN BROWN WRAPPER'
LEAD: KEITH REDDIN, who made a splash a couple of seasons ago with ''Rum and Coke,'' has taken to concocting watered drinks.
His ''Plain Brown Wrapper,'' now being served up on the stage of the Nat Horne Theater, consists of five skits that together take about an hour.
Their main ingredient is sex of a one-liner sort; they don't deliver much of a kick.

LEAD: Two giant pandas arrived safely in New York City this weekend after a flight of more than 20 hours from China.

LEAD: Glenn Hubbard's fielding error at second base with two out in the ninth inning enabled Chris Brown to score from third and give the San Francisco Giants a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

A Frequent Flyer Explains the Thrill

LEAD: In Florida the State Senate and House of Representatives passed bills last week authorizing a new tax package that would include a 5 percent sales tax on advertising in all media.

GUSTAV OSWALD LIENHARD, 81
LEAD: Gustav Oswald Lienhard, who guided the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as it became the country's richest source of grants in the field of health care, died of cancer Friday at his home.
He was 81 years old and lived in Edison, N.J.

LEAD: This will not begin with the phrase ''the long and short of it.'' Nor will there be any references to ''lofty ambitions'' or ''measuring up.''

LEAD: Abused and other vulnerable children and the chronically ill elderly have been illegally denied services by the Reagan Administration, which has withheld millions of dollars in congressionally approved aid, according to a report made public today by a House panel.

LEAD: FAMILY relationships are getting more attention in the treatment of anorexia nervosa, an eating disorder that primarily affects teen-age girls and young women.
Mental health experts say that families can help alleviate conditions that contribute to the disease.

LEAD: Representatives of National Football League players and owners are scheduled to meet here Monday to begin what could be long and arduous negotiations leading to a new collective bargaining agreement.

LEAD: The last California condor known to be in the wild was captured today for a captive-breeding program intended to save the giant birds from extinction, the National Audubon Society said.

LEAD: Soviet industrial output grew by 2.5 percent in the first quarter of the year from the comparable period of 1986, the Politburo has been told.

Small-Claims Attitude
LEAD: To the Editor:


Submerged Ship on Register
LEAD: The C.S.S.
Georgia, a 10-gun ironclad that helped guard Savannah from the Union Navy during the Civil War, has been added to the National Register of Historic Places even though the vessel lies 30 feet underwater.
She was scuttled in the Savannah River in 1864 when Gen.
William T. Sherman's troops captured Savannah.

LEAD: A human-rights group has protested the barring from the United Nations building of a woman who is seeking compensation for families of the victims of a 1972 massacre in Burundi.

Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION: Bo Jackson's sensational start this season revived memories of another running back from a college in the South who had to choose between baseball and football, Charley Trippi.
How much success did Trippi have in pro football?
Did he ever play in the major leagues in baseball?
Trippi never played in the majors after he chose football over baseball and he never regretted it because he made it to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1968, 13 years after he retired.

LEAD: The medium-range missile treaty is all but wrapped up; short-range missile reduction is a sweetener just tossed in the deal; a space exploration treaty awaits signing at a summit; the old ABM treaty will be saved in the next year when a new treaty is agreed on to permit space-shield testing.

LEAD: Five of the nation's largest investment banking firms have joined forces in an effort to persuade the Government to bar the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, from the newest and one of the most lucrative mortgage underwriting markets.


COLUMBIA SUES LAWYERS IN EVICTION
LEAD: Columbia University has filed suit against two attorneys, charging that they abused the judicial process in their attempt to overturn the eviction of a woman from a university-owned building.


ANTONY TUDOR, CHOREOGRAPHER, DIES
LEAD: Antony Tudor, one of the foremost choreographers of the century and widely considered the master of the psychological ballet, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan.
He was 78 years old.
Mr.
Tudor, choreographer emeritus of the American Ballet Theater at his death, revolutionized ballet with his introduction of strong psychological motivation in choreography, reflecting the influence of Freudian thought.


DERBY PICTURE MUDDIER THAN EVER
LEAD: At offices and taverns around the country during the next two weeks, people who usually pay no attention to horse racing will be asked to cough up a dollar or two and pick from a hat the name of one of this year's Kentucky Derby entrants.


Egypt Oil Plan Draws Drillers
LEAD: American and West European companies will participate in a new tender by the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation for oil exploration in Egypt's western desert.


THE LATE, LATE SHOW
LEAD: SO there was Harry Lime, clawing his way up the sewer stairs for the millionth time, but it was time to press the remote-control gadget and get back to the real life-and-death struggle, not in war-ravaged Vienna but in hockey-crazed Maryland.


The Editorial Notebook; New York's Old, and Fat, Constitution
LEAD: Instead of celebrating this 200th year of the United States Constitution, scholars and legal experts are ''cerebrating.'' Meanwhile, the New York State Constitution, which is older and longer - at times unfathomably longer - doesn't even warrant a public seminar on its 210th birthday, which happens to be today.


KRISHNA CONVICT FILES LAWSUIT
LEAD: A Hare Krishna follower who is serving a life prison term for the murder of another member of the sect has sued state prison officials, asserting that they have denied him the right to worship according to his religion.


Lucky Stores Chooses Grey
LEAD: Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, which until recently had the $15 million Vons Grocery Company account, has been named agency for both the Northern Food and Southern Food divisions of California's Lucky Stores Inc.
The account should bill around $30 million, the agency said.


In Arms Control, a Quiet Success
LEAD: After four years of secret talks, the United States and six allies have put a new obstacle in the path of proliferating nuclear capabilities.
They agreed to strong controls on the export of missiles and missile technologies that can be used to deliver nuclear weapons.
This is a real arms control achievement at a critical time.


GORBACHEV REMARKS ARE DENIED
LEAD: United States and Soviet officials denied today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev seriously suggested to visiting American legislators that the United States set up separate areas for blacks and other minorities.


DUGOUT MISHAP FELLS TUDOR
LEAD: John Tudor was sitting in the St.
Louis Cardinals' dugout, minding his own business today when Barry Lyons, the rookie catcher for the Mets, came running over, chasing a foul pop fly.
That led to a bizarre accident that disabled Tudor for three months or more.
It was the kind of accident that sometimes alters careers and championships.


Hotel Cuts Use of Kitchens In Ohio Poisoning Outbreak
LEAD: The Dayton Marriott Hotel closed most of its kitchens for the weekend to try to stop an outbreak of food poisoning.


FROM BOTH PARTIES, SUPPORT FOR JERSEY'S 'WORKFARE'
LEAD: When Governor Kean proposed last winter that all able-bodied welfare recipients in New Jersey be forced to go to school and seek employment, he expected sharp criticism.


WHY MYSIFY THE BUDGET?
LEAD: What's a cut in a Federal program?
What's an increase?
If you put these two questions to the average person, they probably would tell you that a cut is when some program is to get less money this year than it got last year.
Or, in the case of an increase, more money this year than last year.
If you pressed the person, he or she might adjust these numbers for inflation - that is, a cut or an increase in real terms compared to last year.


CONCERT: BERNSTEIN'S 'MASS'
LEAD: IT often happens that musical works requiring unusually large (or simply unusual) performing forces must be scaled down in order to circulate beyond the big institutions and special occasions for which they are made.
Wagner's music dramas are given all the time with reduced orchestrations; big Parisian operas were routinely cut to workable lengths for other audiences.


PRICES OF METALS RISE AMID FEARS OF INFLATION
LEAD: These are the times that swell the hearts and fill the pockets of gold bugs, that hardy band of investors in precious metals who thrive on economic misery.
While Wall Street may mock gold as a ''sterile investment'' or ''barbaric relic,'' the recent sharp rise in gold and silver prices has given investors in stocks and bonds much to worry about.

LEAD: Two Israeli soldiers and three Palestinian guerrillas were killed today in a shootout after the Palestinians cut through a Lebanon border fence and crossed into northern Israel, an Israeli Army spokesman said.


Asian Growth Averages 6%
LEAD: The economies of 17 Asian members of the Asian Development Bank grew an average of 6 percent in 1986, the same as in 1985, the bank's annual report said.

LEAD: Big season openings have a special magic, and American Ballet Theater's eight-week spring engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House is one of the biggest of the dance year.
Glamorous types will mill about the Met lobby tonight for Ballet Theater's opening.
Last-minute worries and triumphs will preoccupy those who put the ballet on the stage.


PRIVATE AMERICAN-ART MUSEUM TO OPEN IN ILLINOIS
LEAD: For a cultural institution, the Terra Museum of American Art has had a meteoric career.
The latest entry in what seems to be an increasing trend toward private museums, it started out seven years ago with a highly personal selection of paintings - dating mainly from 1850 to 1900 - installed in a former florist's shop in nearby Evanston.


SMOKING CURBS POSE CHALLENGE FOR BUSINESSES
LEAD: Less than three weeks before strict new antismoking rules are to go into effect, offices, restaurants and other businesses throughout New York State are grappling with a change that could have a profound effect on both those who smoke and those who don't.


What Will Bonn Do?
LEAD: For some time, a feeling has been growing in the Reagan Administration that West Germany will probably not allow the extradition of a Lebanese, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, to this country to face charges of air piracy and murder in connection with the hijacking of an airliner to Beirut in 1985 and the death of a United States Navy diver who was among the passengers.


Business and the Law; Legal Ties With China
LEAD: IN two weeks, Xi-Qing Gao, a 33-year-old associate at a large New York firm, is scheduled to be sworn before a judge to practice law in the United States.
Last summer he became the first citizen of China to pass the New York Bar examination.


Barge Called a Hazard To the Gulf of Mexico
LEAD: Although the owners of a barge loaded with 3,100 tons of industrial waste from Islip, L.I., have agreed to move it from an oil rig where it was moored, the vessel will be a hazard as long as it's in the Gulf of Mexico, the Mayor of a barrier island said yesterday.

LEAD: Pat Tabler drove in three runs with a pair of singles and a bases-loaded walk to help the Indians to an 8-7 victory over the Orioles and a douleheader sweep today.
Cleveland won the first game, 3-0, on Greg Swindell's six-hitter.

LEAD: It wasn't as momentous as the splitting of the atom, but the world should note that a contest to acclaim the best chicken soup was held the other day.
No lives were lost.
No governments fell.
The sun also rose the next morning.

Correction
LEAD: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Thursday misstated a bankruptcy judge's ruling on salaries of Texaco Inc.'s officers.
Judge Howard Schwartzberg ruled that the salaries of Texaco's top 20 officers were not to exceed $2,000 each for the 11 days before Texaco's bankruptcy filing April 12 but that there would be no restrictions during bankruptcy.

ERNEST PAGNANO
LEAD: Ernest Pagnano, a popular New York dance teacher and former member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and Harkness Ballet, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at his family's home in Harwich, Mass.
He was 41 years old.
Born in Provincetown, Mass., Mr.
Pagnano trained with Niles Marsden in Providence, R.I., and at the Boston Conservatory before moving to New York, where he studied at the Joffrey Ballet School.

LEAD: Thirty-six years after arriving in the United States from Germany, a Long Island man was deported last night to the Soviet Union, where he faces a death sentence as a Nazi war criminal who commanded an Estonian concentration camp in World War II and supervised the mass execution of Jews.

Schlumberger Profit Plunges
LEAD: Schlumberger Ltd., the oilfield service and electronics company, said today that its first-quarter earnings plunged 96 percent, reaching $5 million, or 2 cents a share, from $148.2 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenues fell 24.8 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.46 billion.
The company blamed the oil industry's slump.

Erving Honored Again
LEAD: Thousands of Philadelphians poured from the streets and buildings to watch and join a lunchtime ''Thank You, Dr.
J'' parade yesterday in honor of Julius Erving, the star of the 76ers who is retiring at the end of this season.
The police put up barricades along the route while the 37-year-old Erving and his wife, Turquoise, brought up the rear of the parade in an open 1928 Packard Roadster.

LeMond Shot
LEAD: Greg LeMond, the only American to win the Tour de France bicycle race, was reported to be in fair condition at a Sacramento, Calif., hospital yesterday after suffering a shotgun wound in a morning hunting accident. ''He should recover from all injuries and they should not affect his performance as an athlete,'' said Dr.


Reporting Rape
LEAD: Rape may be ten to fifteen times more common than official Government figures reflect, according to a national study of college-age women.
The study found that 38 per thousand of the women had been raped within the previous six months.
Comparable figures for women of college age from the National Crime Survey, a Federal project that relies on public surveys, are 2 to 4 per thousand, depending on the exact age of the woman.


Precious Metals Surge Amid Dollar Weakness
LEAD: Silver futures surged upward yesterday, with prices rising as much as the 50-cent limit for daily trading.

Mr.

Yes, Patent Life
LEAD: Can animals be patented?
Ridiculous, intuition suggests, but today the U.S.
Patent and Trademark Office will rule otherwise.
Researchers who add genes to animal embryos by gene splicing may apply for patents, just like any other inventors.
Will private greed and scientific hubris now engender a misbegotten Garden of Eden, crawling with mutant beasts and their Frankenstein-like owners?

LEAD: A Queens judge, rejecting a motion by John A. Zaccaro, ruled yesterday that the real-estate broker had to stand trial on charges of attempted extortion and bribe-seeking stemming from an investigation into the awarding of cable-television franchises in Queens.

SABLE, BEAVER AND FOX: LUXURY TOUCHES FOR FALL
LEAD: Bands of mink or sable circle the hipline or hemline of many new fall dresses.
Stoles and jackets are bordered in fur, and some of the most sumptuous coats shown in the last few weeks were Carolina Herrera's navy cashmeres lined in sable.
Why the fur explosion? ''I really wanted to call attention to the legs,'' said Bill Blass, who almost always has some fur in his fall collections, but this time had more than usual.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A dispatch yesterday from Portland, Ore., about politics and the annual Mayor's Ball there, misidentified the beneficiaries of last year's ball.

CARLOS BAKER, 77, A PROFESSOR AND HEMINGWAY BIOGRAPHER
LEAD: Carlos Baker, a Princeton University professor who wrote the authorized 1969 biography ''Ernest Hemingway: A Life Story'' and a 1952 book-length study, ''Hemingway: The Writer as Artist,'' died Saturday at his home in Princeton.
He was 77 years old and had retired from teaching in 1977.


Maldives to Get Storm Aid
LEAD: The United States and Britain have promised aid to the Maldive Islands after a storm caused $12 milion in damage this month.
No deaths or injuries were reported.
The British High Commission here said Britain had given $400,000, and the United States Embassy said it was donating $25,000 worth of food, materials for shelter and medical supplies.

S.E.C. Bars Three Brokers

The S.E.C. said Jan E. Brooks, a principal and director of Brooks until October, had agreed in a consent decree to a four-year suspension from trading.

Goldome's Leader Cites Benefits in Stock Sale
LEAD: Ross B. Kenzie heads Goldome, the largest mutual savings bank in the United States.
That means it is owned by its depositors.
But that system is going out of fashion and Goldome is joining many other mutual savings banks in switching to ownership by stockholders.

LEAD: A coalition of environmentalists, fishermen and others worried about Louisiana's coastal erosion have announced a plan to save the state's lush wetlands, which scientists say are disintegrating at the rate of 50 or more square miles a year.

LEAD: Dostoyevsky once remarked that no cause was worth the murder of a single child.

They are so intoxicated by the purity of their separatist cause that last Friday they systematically massacred 127 civilians, including tiny children.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.  What is the clear, tart liquid that sometimes forms on the top of yogurt?
A.
This liquid is whey, the thin watery part of milk that separates from the curds, the thicker, white portion, when milk is fermented to make yogurt, according to Michel Saintain, a researcher at the Dannon Yogurt Company.


Steel Output Up 1.6%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.727 million tons last week, an increase of 1.6 percent from the previous week's 1.699 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 80.3 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 79 percent in the previous week.

Our Towns; Need Something In a 66 Waist? No Problem, Sir
LEAD: For a while, pot bellies were on the run.
The wise guys at the health spas started passing the word that the last few pot bellies in the suburbs had been sighted and were about to be eradicated.
Decent, hard-working men who had moved out here specifically to drink beer by the pitcher and grow a belly suddenly felt ashamed, as their bellies lost prestige.

LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a person who buys securities he knows are unregistered and who brings other buyers into the deal may sue the seller for his own losses and avoid liability for the losses of the other buyers.

Coke Preserves Office
LEAD: The 26th-floor executive suite from which the late Robert W. Woodruff controlled the Coca-Cola Company is being re-created downstairs at the company's headquarters.
The office, which contains hundreds of mementos from Woodruff's six decades with the soft drink company, including stints as president, chairman and board member, had been left as it was in March 1985, when he died.


Soviet-China Talks End With 2 Sides at Odds
LEAD: The Soviet Union and China completed weeklong talks today on normalizing relations, but diplomats said they remained at odds over the problems of Afghanistan and Cambodia.

SEKO WINNER IN BOSTON
LEAD: A little more than six miles remained in today's 91st annual Boston Marathon, and Toshihiko Seko was discouraged.
The head winds were too strong, he said.
Too many good runners remained in the leading pack.


Transamerica's Net Up Sharply
LEAD: Buoyed by strong results in most of its core businesses, the Transamerica Corporation today reported first-quarter earnings of $108.1 million, or $1.45 a share, up sharply from $42.9 million, or 57 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenues rose 24.8 percent, to $1.76 billion, from $1.41 billion.


NUCLEAR AGENCY SET TO INVESTIGATE ITS TOP OFFICIALS
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today announced a series of internal investigations and policy changes following allegations that top commission officials may have had improper contacts with electric utility companies.

LEAD: A video news release distributed last spring opened with dazzling aerial photography of the Statue of Liberty.

Chinese Rules on Gold
LEAD: China announced restrictions on gold prospectors today in an attempt to halt smuggling, which is estimated to keep $90 million worth of gold out of the national Treasury each year.
The China Daily newspaper reported that the Metallurgical Industry Ministry had issued regulations that ban gold processing by individuals and restrict the number of places where prospectors can seek gold after receiving authorization.

TANZANIA, BARREN OF MUCH, STILL IMPLANTS THE THREE R'S
LEAD: Millions of adult Tanzanians, gathering under shade trees, in private homes and in other makeshift classrooms, have learned to read and write.
By doing so, they have helped to weave a success story of sorts in this impoverished country's tapestry of failures.


Tandem Discloses New Hardware
LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc., based in Cupertino, Calif., announced two new computer systems and a new desktop laser printer.
The 32-bit LXN multi-user system is Tandem's first based on the Unix operating system developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, with prices starting at $18,012 per unit.


Coleco Loss Of $8.9 Million
LEAD: Coleco Industries today reported a first-quarter loss of $8.9 million, in contrast to earnings of $5.7 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago.
Interest expense of $12.6 million was $6.7 million higher than for the period a year ago, Coleco said.

MUSIC: DUPRE'S 'STATIONS'
LEAD: MARCEL DUPRE'S compositions for organ have neither the irresistible tunes we find in the works of Charles-Marie Widor nor the harmonic invention and spiritual intensity that distinguishes the best music of Olivier Messiaen.
Nevertheless, devotees of the 20th-century French organ repertory will find much to admire in Dupre's work, which combines chromaticism and polytonality in a manner that seems both antiquated and


GENETIC DISCOVERIES RAISE PAINFUL QUESTIONS
LEAD: ETHICISTS have warned about the quandaries genetic testing would produce since the time about 20 years ago when doctors were first able to learn a child's gender before its birth, or determine whether it had Down's syndrome.
Now a fast-growing battery of tests that can spot genetic susceptibility to an ever longer list of ailments is forcing doctors, ethicists, prospective parents and others to face divisive and complex choices.


Careers; Providing Counseling In Groups
LEAD: THE outplacement industry has a problem.
Companies that are unable or unwilling to pay for individual outplacement for thousands of dismissed middle managers now rely on group outplacement, a trend that dismissed managers do not like.

LEAD: They flew first-class from Beijing.
They were whisked from Kennedy International Airport to the Bronx Zoo in the dead of night with the delicacy and secrecy befitting foreign ambassadors.

Andrei B. Severny, 73, Top Soviet Astronomer
LEAD: Andrei B. Severny, a leader in Soviet astronomy and an authority on the physics of the sun and the stars, died April 4, the Soviet press has announced.
He was 73 years old.
Dr.
Severny had been director of the Crimean Astrophysical Observatory since 1952, and was one of the pioneers of setting up astronomical observations on artificial satellites in orbit around the earth.


4 TAYLOR DANCERS CREATE WORKS FOR THE TROUPE
LEAD: It all began when Paul Taylor walked into the rehearsal studio last fall, called out the names of four of his dancers and asked each of them to create a dance.
The results will be seen during the Paul Taylor Dance Company's four-week season at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, which opens tonight.


Congress's Trade Mood
LEAD: Unlike other visiting leaders from abroad, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan will apparently not address Congress when he comes to Washington next week.

LEAD: The management and dancers of American Ballet Theater have reached an agreement on a new three-year contract.

Bridge: Diluted 1 No-Trump Bidding Has Been Gaining Popularity
LEAD: Three decades ago almost every American expert used the traditional 16-18 point no-trump opening.
Nowadays, however, a substantial minority, perhaps a quarter, choose a weak no-trump, and those who stay with the strong variety tend to dilute it to 15-17 or 15-18.

2 EXTEND DISCOUNT FARES BUT PRICES WILL INCREASE
LEAD: Continental and Eastern airlines said yesterday that they would extend their discount ''maxsaver'' fares through the summer, but at higher prices and with generally tighter restrictions.
The effect, analysts and competitors said, would be an overall increase of about 10 to 12 percent in the most heavily discounted fares.

Texas Air Stake In Maine Carrier
LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation agreed to acquire 50 percent of Bar Harbor Airlines and arrange for the sale of Provincetown-Boston Airline Inc. to Bar Harbor, officials said.
Texas Air, the nation's largest airline holding company, would provide additional capital to Bar Harbor, based in Bangor, Me., in the form of convertible debt, the company said.

LEAD: Justice can never catch up with the crimes of the Nazis.
But we must take whatever opportunity arises to hold even a small part of those horrors up to the light of justice.
Otherwise we would fail our inescapable obligation to the victims of Nazism: to remember.

NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-15  The Argentine Army chief resigned less than 24 hours after a rebellion of infantry officers ended peacefully.
The resignation paves the way for a shake-up of the entire army high command.
Page A1  By resolving the military mutiny, President Raul Alfonsin achieved a triumph that was a watershed in Argentina's long and often frustrating struggle for democracy, officials said.

Amdahl Profits Rise Tenfold
LEAD: The Amdahl Corporation, a mainframe computer maker, reported first-quarter earnings today of $25.2 million, or 51 cents a share, more than 10 times the $2.4 million, or 5 cents a share, reported a year earlier.
Sales rose 59 percent, to $318.5 million, from $200.2 million in last year's first quarter.

Charles P. Young Offers to Buy Sorg
LEAD: The Charles P. Young Company, a printing subsidiary of the Service Resources Corporation, said it was interested in acquiring for $22 a share the common stock of Sorg Inc. that it does not already own.
The company, which emphasized that the offer was a friendly one, said Patrick Rooney, chairman of Young, had met with Roy Cardia, president and chief executive of Sorg, to discuss a transaction.


NBC NEWS'S 'TRILLION FOR DEFENSE'
LEAD: THE title explains it: ''A Trillion for Defense: What Have We Bought?'' A lot of hardware, ammunition and weapons systems, the NBC News special answers, although not always sensibly or well.
Interservice rivalries, improper purchasing procedures and a lack of policy planning hurt the process.
The criticisms are not new, but the special, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, presents them in fresh, timely fashion.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A Trenton dispatch last Thursday about a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling on AIDS regulations misstated the number of justices who supported it.

Chicago Teams Say No to History
LEAD: It's a bit unorthodox, but 63-year-old Soldier Field in Chicago - the home of the Chicago Bears since 1971 - was designated a national historic landmark on March 24.
And if the Department of the Interior has its way, other stadiums may soon receive the same recognition.


Commerce Aide Resigns
LEAD: Contending that the sanctions against some Japanese goods could be dangerous and that the United States is doing a ''half-baked job'' of promoting its exports, the director of the Commerce Department's local office here said today that he had submitted his resignation.


OCEAN SEDIMENTS TELL TALE OF GREEN ANTARCTICA
LEAD: THANKS to a companion ship that lassoed giant icebergs and towed them out of the way, a research vessel has drilled through the sea floor off Antarctica and extracted detailed samples recording the continent's complex, even verdant, past.

STAGE: 'HEART THAT EATS ITSELF,' ON KAFKA
LEAD: THE most striking image in Theater for the New City's production of Rosalyn Drexler's play, ''The Heart That Eats Itself'' is the ashen face of the veteran actor George Bartenieff.
Portraying the tubercular Franz Kafka in his final hours, Mr.
Bartenieff gazes stoically from his bed, his gaunt face a mobile, enigmatic mask that clenches in spasms of agony, then eases into feverish reveries.

FOOD NOTES
LEAD:  Guide to Good Eating


Herald Tribune Plans Centenary Supplement
LEAD: As part of its commemoration of its centennial celebration, The International Herald Tribune will publish a 160-page magazine insert, 215,000 copies of which will be circulated Sept. 16.


Sosnoff Seeks Help In Caesars Bid
LEAD: The New York investor Martin J. Sosnoff has asked other Caesars World Inc. shareholders to help him in his battle for control of the Los Angeles-based gambling concern.
Mr.
Sosnoff wants Caesars shareholders to remove the four inside directors from the nine-member board, to repeal certain antitakeover measures and to block any recapitalization that would involve additional debt without prior shareholder approval.


SIR PETER HALL RELISHES NEW COMMERCIAL ROLE
LEAD: In 1960 Peter Hall, a hot young director out of Cambridge University, transformed a summer stock theater at Stratford-on-Avon into the Royal Shakespeare Company.
Thirteen years later he succeeded Laurence Olivier at the rival National Theater as it struggled to complete a new home that was still $35 million and four years from opening.

Japan Hunts for 'Science'
LEAD: Japan recently announced the end to five decades of commercial whaling.
Yet now it plans to send its whaling fleet to the Antarctic - through a giant loophole in the whaling treaty.


Breakthrough
LEAD: Shelley Verses, a 26-year-old native of Stamford, Conn., has become a soigneur for a French professional bicycling team.
And if the job description sounds a bit demeaning -soigneurs must truck baggage for the riders, offer them first aid, prepare and deliver their sandwiches and high-energy food during races, ease their way at hotels and give them massages - Verses has no complaints.

WINE TALK
LEAD: THE pitchman on Milton Berle's television show in the 50's, Sid Stone, is remembered for a spiel: ''Ya say you're not satisfied?
Ya want more for your money?
All right, just a minute.
Tell ya what I'm gonna do.'' The ''tell ya'' preceded inside dope about a bargain.
So let me ''tell ya'' about Chilean wines.


Hagopian Laments Trend to Mega-mergers
LEAD: American business is in trouble, and the agency industry along with it, because of the current obsession for making quick money, Louis T. Hagopian suggested yesterday.
He then called on agencies to help restore normalcy by returning to their role as builders of businesses.


Financial Corp. Hires Consultant
LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America, parent of the nation's largest savings and loan association, said it had hired Kaplan, Smith &amp; Associates Inc., a financial consulting firm, to advise it in any merger talks.


Katharine Graham Book Is Being Republished
LEAD: A controversial biography of Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company, is being republished seven years after Harcourt Brace Jovanovich withdrew it from circulation because of what it said were numerous errors of which it had not originally been aware.

Indoor Bounce For Football
LEAD: Pro football of a peculiar sort will be played indoors this summer in the Washington, Denver, Pittsburgh and Chicago areas.

Jackson for a 40-piece orchestra, include his 16-minute impressionistic ''Symphony in One Movement,'' a Chopinesque ''Nocturne'' for solo piano, the sharply percussive Latin-flavored ''No Pasaran,'' and ''Solitude,'' a piece inspired by the Duke

Jets Lack Trade Bait
LEAD: Because of their huge number of injured players, the Jets do not have enough bait to trade for a higher choice in next week's college draft, the team's player personnel director said yesterday.
So the Jets probably will not choose until the 21st pick.
Mike Hickey, who runs the team's draft, explained that ''injuries are a factor in trades and we have too many injured players.

Boxing Changes Made
LEAD: Jose Torres, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that, starting in mid-May, a boxing manager and a promoter who are related to one another will no longer be permitted to be associated with a match involving a fighter to whom both have rights.
Torres said that a fighter in that instance would then have the option of securing another manager or negotiating on his own with the promoter.

Bridge: 'Borel,' Program for I.B.M.'s, Is a Source of Modified Deals
LEAD: Ideas whose time has come sometimes appear in different countries simultaneously.
The most famous example is the independent development of calculus in the 17th century by Isaac Newton in England and Gottfried von Leibniz of Germany.


15 Poles Vanish in Bavaria
LEAD: Fifteen Poles on an Easter bus tour to West Germany have disappeared, leaving the driver and tour guide for the return journey to Poland, the Bavarian border police said today.
A spokesman said the 15 Poles disappeared in Munich during the holiday weekend and it was not yet clear whether they would apply for asylum or spend a few weeks in the West before returning home.

LEAD: THE demand in Europe for research equipment and products in genetic engineering is surging, and many American companies, bolstered by a weak dollar and a technological headstart, are aggressively marketing their wares in Europe.

LEAD: The morning line from Iowa looks grim for Mr.
Hart, but that could be misleading.
A lot of campaigning is left before the Presidential caucuses there next February.
But Bonnie Campbell, chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, who was in town this week, the best-organized candidate in Iowa is Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona.

LEAD: The swift drop in the value of the dollar has added heavily to the cost of operating United States military forces abroad, senior officials in the Defense Department say.

LEAD: WITH more criminals being released on probation, understaffed law enforcement departments have begun to use electronic monitoring devices to keep track of them.
The program, only two years old, might also have an influence on sentencing practices, some court analysts believe.

FILM: 'PADRE NUESTRO'
LEAD: BENEATH the austere compositions of ''Padre Nuestro'' beats an operatic heart.
The eccentric, alluring Spanish movie, which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street, begins in the Vatican with a witty and humane conversation between the down-to-earth Pope, who is rather possessive about his connections to heaven, and an important cardinal who has learned he has less than a year to live.

ARTHUR O. CHOATE Jr.
LEAD: Arthur Osgood Choate Jr., a retired general partner and executive committee chairman of Clark Dodge &amp; Company, investment bankers, died Sunday at Jupiter Hospital in Jupiter, Fla.
He was 75 years old and lived in Hobe Sound, Fla., and Manhattan.


CITICORP AND HANOVER REPORT LOWER PROFITS
LEAD: Citicorp and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday, citing their placement of billions of dollars in Latin American loans on a cash basis.
