Gone West Will Skip Kentucky Derby
LEAD: Gone West, who won the Gotham Stakes April 4 and was beaten just a head despite trouble in the Wood Memorial last Saturday, will not contest the Kentucky Derby May 2, his trainer said today.


CUTTING A RULE, NOT FROGS
LEAD: Many high school students would like to avoid dissecting frogs in biology class, but not many are prepared to make a Federal case of it.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1987
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The Supreme Court upheld a state curb on hostile takeovers for companies incorporated in that state.
The 6-to-3 ruling, which sustained an Indiana law, was an important victory for companies seeking takeover protection.
Under the law, a company could deny voting rights to those making tender offers or to any investors who increase their holdings above a certain level.


PENTAGON LINKING SECRET ARMY UNIT TO CONTRA MONEY
LEAD: The Pentagon said today that it recently discovered that a secret Army unit disbanded in 1983 had set up a Swiss bank account that may later have been used illegally to finance arms for the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: To the Editor:


SEARS NET RISES 47.4% IN QUARTER
LEAD: Benefiting from a sharp improvement in all divisions, Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday reported a 47.4 percent jump in its first-quarter net income on an 11.6 percent sales rise.


HIGH COURT BACKS STATE ON CURBING HOSTILE TAKEOVER
LEAD: In an important victory for companies seeking protection from takeovers, the Supreme Court for the first time today upheld a state law that restricts hostile offers for companies incorporated in that state.
M Reversing a Federal appellate decision, the Court ruled that the 1986 Indiana law, which resembles laws in Ohio, Pennsylvania and several other states, violated neither the Federal Williams Act of 1968, which regulates tender offers, nor the Commerce Clause of the Constitution, which bans state obstruction of interstate commerce.

Fund Group Sues Chase Manhattan
LEAD: A mutual fund trade group said it had sued to block further sales of a new Chase Manhattan Bank account with returns linked to the stock market.
The Investment Company Institute said it had filed the suit in Federal District Court in Washington on the grounds that the Chase Market Index Investment account unveiled last month violated Federal law prohibiting banks from underwriting and selling securities.

SENATE VOTES FAIRNESS BILL

Paralyzed Officer Flown to Colorado for Therapy
LEAD: Sheila Norris holding her grandson, Conor Patrick McDonald, as his father and mother, Steven and Patti Ann McDonald, left in a helicopter on the first leg of a trip from Bellevue Hospital to Denver.
Officer McDonald was paralyzed when he was shot last July in Central Park by a teen-ager.
It is hoped that after several months of therapy at Craig Hospital, which specializes in head and spinal injuries, he will be able to breathe without a respirator.


A MAINE MILKMAN WHO'LL FEED THE CAT OR REPLACE A FUSE
LEAD: BOB GARLAND guides a blue pickup with a wooden milk rack along the early-morning streets of this blue-collar town of 2,250 in central Maine.
He has taken the route thousands of times for nearly 50 years and is a fixture here, almost as much a part of the landscape as the Kennebec River or the paper mill.

A Real Toll Call
LEAD: George Argyros, the Seattle Mariners' owner, who is trying to sell the team and buy the San Diego Padres, has been fined $10,000 for a congratulatory phone call to Larry Bowa, the Padres' manager.
The fine, levied by the baseball commissioner, stemmed from a conversation between Argyros and Bowa on Thursday following the Padres' 10-inning, 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Mr.
Williams, who oversaw the merger of First Atlanta and First Wachovia in December 1985 to form a bank with assets of $18.7 billion, said today that he had accomplished his objectives.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: HOCKEY  Soviet Union Beats Czechoslovakia: In Vienna, the Soviet Union scored a major victory in defense of its world championship yesterday by beating Czechoslovakia, 6-1.
The Soviet team leads the standing with 8 points on a 4-0 record.
Sweden is second at 3-1.
Finland defeated the United States, 5-2.


TIME RUNS OUT ON THE BREWERS' MARVELOUS STREAK
LEAD: A fly ball that had been turned into a diving catch during the stretch that made Milwaukee famous fell to the warning track dirt tonight and bounced against the outfield fence.
A ground ball not unlike those that had extended Brewer rallies during the two previous giddy weeks was turned into an inning-ending double play.

New 'Starlight' Record
LEAD: ''Starlight Express,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical at the Gershwin Theater, set a new Broadway box-office record for the week that ended Sunday. ''Starlight'' took in $606,081.64, according to a spokesman for the show, Bill Evans, the highest grossing week in Broadway history.
The new record surpasses two others set by the show since it opened on March 15.

LEAD: ''I'm sorry,'' the receptionist said to the caller, saying what all good receptionists say: ''Mr.

Budget Deficit In U.S. Lower
LEAD: The Government said today that its March budget deficit was $28.01 billion, down from $30.14 billion in March a year ago.
The deficit in February this year was $28.37 billion.


Ethics Law Rerun
LEAD: To the Editor:


Savagery on the Subcontinent
LEAD: The killing of Sinhalese men, women and children by militant Tamils in Sri Lanka has virtually coincided with the slaying of Hindus by radical Sikhs in India's troubled Punjab state.
These recent incidents, perpetrated by youths with a dark vision of the future, have severely shaken the philosophical self-image of the Subcontinent as a nursery of nonviolence and passive resistance.


Yen Rise Cuts Honda Profits
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said today that the rise of the Japanese yen against other currencies sharply reduced its earnings for both the fourth quarter and the fiscal year.

Take Yes for an Answer on Missiles
LEAD: Not a chance!
That's what Western experts said about President Reagan's 1981 proposal to eliminate all medium-range missiles in Europe.
Too one-sided, they scoffed; Moscow would never accept it.
The Russians would have to destroy 1,300 SS-20 warheads compared with 300 for the United States.

FOR THE OWNERS OF CHANTERELLE, SUCCESS WITHOUT CELEBRITY
LEAD: DAVID WALTUCK'S description of his adolescence in the Bronx sounds like a scene from a Woody Allen movie.
There he was at the family dinner table, faced with his mother's ''not very inspired'' steaks and potatoes and occasional matzoh balls, and all the while his mind was filled with stories he had been reading about the legendary chefs and great restaurants of France.

LEAD: Karl Linnas, under sentence of death for war crimes in the Soviet Union and deported Monday night from the United States, was returned to his native Estonia tonight.

LEAD: A Federal judge today delayed until Sept. 8 the trial of a reported Colombian cocaine smuggler, Carlos Lehder Rivas, and warned defense attorneys, who had asked for a nine-month continuance, that they were unlikely to get another delay.
The trial was to have begun May 18.
Mr.

JUSTICES SEEM TO WIDEN DEATH PENALTY
LEAD: In a decision that may lead to much wider use of the death penalty, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that some accomplices in crimes leading to death may be executed even if they did not personally kill or intend to kill.


LOTS OF SPOTS AND POLKA DOTS
LEAD:  1.
A Different Diameter The man who is tired of striped ties might want to try dots -polka dots as big as pennies.
The dots are in shades of red, blue and raisin on a yellow ground.
Other color combinations are available, with backgrounds of tan, blue, green, pink, burgundy or navy.
The ties cost $27.50 at Paul Stuart, Madison Avenue at 45th Street.


POINDEXTER IS GIVEN IMMUNITY
LEAD: The Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair voted officially today to compel the sworn testimony of Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter by giving him immunity from prosecution based on his Congressional testimony.


NASA WILL DELAY '88 SHUTTLE FLIGHT
LEAD: The space agency said today that it was delaying for several weeks the first launching of a space shuttle since the Challenger explosion because it was adding two major tests to the schedule.

Japan Trading Inquiry
LEAD: The nation's two largest futures exchanges said they were studying the possibility of improper trading practices by some Japanese brokerage houses.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said it had been aware of questionable practices ''for some time.'' The investigations center on whether Japanese brokers have used private, noncompetitive trading to reduce margins, the amount of money they are required to set aside to cover potential losses from trading.

The Bronx Coo
LEAD: New York City has tunnels, bridges, highways, cars, subways, buses and ferries.
Theaters, movies, museums, opera companies, dance companies and clubs ranging from the intime to the ridiculous.
Small wildlife: rats, roaches, squirrels and a sky's worth of pigeons.
Big wildlife: lions, tigers and elephants.


More Service Workers
LEAD: In advanced countries, 60 percent of the workers are employed in service industries such as transport, while farm and factory employment is shrinking, the International Labor Organization said today.


New Strikes in Yugoslavia
LEAD: A new wave of strikes has broken out a month after a partial pay freeze touched off industrial unrest, press reports and factory officials indicated today.
The Tanyug press agency reported strikes at two of the nation's largest industrial enterprises - Smederevo, the iron and steel center with a work force of 10,000, and a rolling stock plant in Kraljevo that employs 4,500.

But Pitino, whose surprising success at Providence College has made him the front-runner for a Knick job, said his interest was more than casual.

France Honors World War I Unit From Harlem
LEAD: Former Representative Hamilton Fish Sr., left, shaking hands with Haywood Butts, who served with him and William Layton, right, in the 369th Infantry Regiment in France.
Mr.
Fish was one of a few white officers in the New York National Guard unit, known as the Hellfighters of Harlem.
The regiment was honored yesterday at the 369th Armory, on Fifth Avenue near 143d Street, by Georges Fontes, the French Secretary of State for War Veterans, who presented a wreath.

GORBACHEV IS CRITICAL OF ICBM'S
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, accused the United States today of adopting negotiating stances on intercontinental nuclear weapons that would harm Soviet security.


Former Official Recovering
LEAD: Arthur F. Burns, the 82-year-old former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and former Ambassador to West Germany, was reported in stable condition at the Johns Hopkins Hospital today after undergoing triple bypass heart surgery.
Hospital officials declined to discuss his condition at the request of family members.


DOW SOARS 66.47 POINTS, TO 2,337.07
LEAD: Wall Street suddenly shook off a bad case of nerves about interest rates and inflation yesterday, and stock prices rallied so powerfully that the Dow Jones industrial average nearly equaled its best point gain ever.

Real Estate; How Small Companies Find Space
LEAD: WHEN Michael Dolan and Eric Chan came to New York this year in search of offices for the industrial design partnership they had just formed, they expected to find space in a week or two.
After they spent weeks inspecting more than 50 sites, however, they were still without a place.


Which Dirty Words? When?
LEAD: Vagueness is the classic tool of oppressive censorship - a tool now wielded by a surprising censor, the Federal Communications Commission.
The F.C.C., in recent years a pioneer of deregulation, now has abruptly warned broadcasters that it will apply new rules to future decisions about ''decency'' on the airwaves.


Amoco Profits Drop by 21.5%
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits declined 21.5 percent, to $260 million, or $1.02 a share, from $331 million, or $1.28 a share.

THE RISE AND FALL OF A VEGETARIAN FAMILY
LEAD: A FEW years ago, my husband became a vegetarian.
This confused our son, then a first grader, who burst into the kitchen to tell me the news.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Monday, with an article about weakness in the outlook for capital spending, mislabeled two components.
The chart, showing fixed investment in the nation, depicted structures, the smaller part, and producers' durable equipment, the larger part.

Tokyo Stock Record
LEAD: Encouraged by yesterday's rally on Wall Street and the yen's depreciation against the dollar, stock prices set a record today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
The Nikkei Stock Average, comprising 225 issues, rose by 202.75 yen to close the morning trading session at 24,088.85 yen, passing the psychological barrier of 24,000 yen.


105 SRI LANKANS DIE AS BOMB RIPS INTO BUS STATION
LEAD: A powerful bomb ripped apart the main bus station at rush hour Tuesday night, scattering shattered bodies and the bloodied fragments of vans and buses across more than a hundred square yards of a busy bazaar.


FANS PAYING PRICE FOR YANK TELECASTS
LEAD: The word around town, to paraphrase a beer commercial, is SportsChannel.
It's a word that's making some people unhappy.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-16


SOME IN ESTONIA GREETED NAZIS IN '41 AS LIBERATORS
LEAD: When Hitler's Army invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941 and, in a matter of weeks, overran the Baltic states, annexed by Moscow only the previous year, the Baltic populations generally greeted the Germans as liberators.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: A SPORT OF NATURE. By Nadine Gordimer. 341 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.


9-YEAR-OLD NIGERIAN IS FOUND AT KENNEDY WITH HEROIN CACHE
LEAD: A 9-year-old boy from Nigeria, arriving alone at Kennedy International Airport, was discovered carrying three pounds of heroin hidden in a small trunk, and Federal authorities expressed concern yesterday that overseas drug rings might now be using young children to smuggle narcotics into this country.


U.S. BOND PRICES END HIGHER
LEAD: Treasury bond prices gyrated wildly yesterday, falling sharply early in the day but recovering during the afternoon to end the day with modest gains.


PROJECT WOULD EXTEND OFFICE TOWERS TO NINTH AVENUE
LEAD: A subsidiary of Lazard Freres &amp; Company is seeking approval from New York City to build a 32-story office tower at Ninth Avenue at 33d Street.


IN CLEVELAND, A SAVORY MICROCOSM OF TRUE SLOVENIAN CUISINE
LEAD: In the post-Easter lull, Azman &amp; Sons Market is once again turning out 500 pounds of sausage a week, shipping some of the freshly stuffed garlicky klobase to transplanted Clevelanders with gastronomic yearnings.
Around town, youngsters are polishing off what is left of the 240 nut rolls called poticas (and pronounced po-TEE-tsas) prepared by an assembly line of women for the


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: IT was not until my last year in college that students could live in a coeducational dorm.


DEBUNKING MYTHS OF THE MALE SHOPPER
LEAD: FORGET the image of the male grocery shopper of the 1950's: sent to the store for a can of peaches, he came home with a sheepish look and a jar of chocolate-covered ants.
Working women and job-sharing at home have changed all that.
Men are going to the grocery store in record numbers, and while some still break out in a cold sweat just walking through the automatic door, far more are at ease in the aisles and thoroughly capable of distinguishing between a mango and a papaya.

LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had agreed to sell its United Gas Pipe Line Company, which has 9,800 miles of pipeline and assets of $1.2 billion, to the LaSalle Energy Corporation.
Occidental said the sale would be a stock transaction but did not give any details.

LEAD: Troops from seven NATO countries will conduct maneuvers in eastern Turkey during June, NATO's Supreme Allied Headquarters in Europe announced today.

B.P. Stockholders Back Standard Bid
LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said its shareholders had voted in favor of the company's $7.4 billion bid for the minority shares in its American subsidiary, the Standard Oil Company.
The vote took place at a special shareholders meeting.
British Petroleum announced last month that it would offer $70 a share in cash for the 45 percent of Standard Oil that it does not already own.


Angell Critical Of U.S. Policy
LEAD: Wayne D. Angell, an Administration-appointed governor of the Federal Reserve Board, complained today that the White House, by exhorting Japan and other countries to stimulate their economies, was undermining the Fed's efforts to prevent inflation.


ALFRED T. GIFFORD
LEAD: Alfred T. Gifford, a founder of Country Miss, a successful producer of women's apparel, died of a respiratory ailment Sunday in the San Pablo Hospital while on vacation in San Juan, P.R.
He was 69 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.


Strauss to Leave HBM/Creamer
LEAD: Hal Strauss, 55, having built up HBM/Creamer enough to make it attractive to a British buyer, has now resigned, intent on finding some partners so that he can build another agency group.


Third Hudson Ferry Starts
LEAD: A third Hudson River commuter ferry, between the foot of East Jersey and Front Streets and Pier 11, south of Wall Street, started yesterday, The service, run by Tradebase International Inc., will make the trip six times each way weekdays, the company said.
On Saturdays, the ferry will make five trips each way.


Yields Up On C.D.'s
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, while bank money market accounts held firm.

Afraid of Babies in Queens
LEAD: The suspicious fire at a prospective foster care home in Queens inspires astonishment.
People in Fresh Meadows, transcending the usual grumbles of other neighborhoods, oppose providing even the most elemental social services in their community.
What is there to fear from a half-dozen infants?
New York City urgently needs decent care for increasing numbers of abandoned, abused and neglected children.


F.A.A. REACTING TO MISTAKES, WILL STUDY CONTROLLER ERRORS
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration, reacting to a sharp increase in mistakes by air traffic controllers this year, today announced the formation of a group to study the operational errors.


A SHAPER OF MET'S JAPANESE GALLERIES
LEAD: ''You can count the serious collectors of Japanese art in this country on one hand,'' said Barbara B. Ford, associate curator of Asian art at the Metropolitan Museum. ''It's pitiful how little interest in it there still is here.
But I hope we're going to redress it.''

COURT CASE: HOW IT BEGAN
LEAD: It was around 2 o'clock in the afternoon of May 13, 1978, when Warren McCleskey and three other armed men went into the Dixie Furniture Store near downtown Atlanta, ordered the customers to lie on the floor, tied up the employees and began searching for money.

Prosecutorial Politics
LEAD: Look: you do something nice for somebody, he does something nice in return.


2 EHTICS PANEL OFFICIALS MAY SHUN INQUIRY ROLE
LEAD: The two top officials of the statewide ethics commission established by Governor Cuomo said yesterday that they were unlikely to participate in the panel's investigation because they were troubled by the resignation of the former head of the commission, Joseph A. Califano Jr.
Two other leading figures have left the commission staff, leaving it now with two lawyers and three secretaries, according to members of the commission.


CORRECTION BOARD CHIEF DEFENDS CITY'S ACTIONS DURING RIKERS UNREST
LEAD: The head of the board that oversees New York City jails sharply disagreed yesterday with a report that criticized correction officials for giving in to rebellious inmates on Rikers Island last October.


Bridge: New York Expert Has Given His Version of Majority Rule
LEAD: Majority rule was an easy concept for the ancient Greeks, a harder one for modern democrats and totally esoteric for bridge players.


Taking Several For the Team
LEAD: An apparent epidemic of wild pitching in collegiate baseball has been traced to an outbreak of wily batting.
According to a survey by Collegiate Baseball, the official publication of the American Baseball Coaches Association, batters in unprecedented numbers are being hit by pitched balls this season, especially in California.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Edberg Upset: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded second, was upset by a countryman, Ulf Stenlund, yesterday, 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the second round of the $513,000 Monte Carlo Open.
Edberg followed top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany and the defending champion, Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, to the sidelines.

Boy Awaits 3d Transplant
LEAD: A third liver transplant was scheduled early today for Ronnie DeSillers, who was struggling to recover from complications arising from the earlier transplant operations, hospital officials said.
Doctors said the 7-year-old boy was suffering from infection and pneumonia.
The child's liver function diminished Wednesday, a day after he underwent surgery to stem internal bleeding and infection.

STAGE: 'THE MEETING'
LEAD: DICK ANTHONY WILLIAMS and Felton Perry bring so much energy and passion to their roles as Malcolm X and the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. in ''The Meeting'' that they almost make this static play get up and move.
And Taurean Blacque as Rashad, Malcolm X's bodyguard, is forceful enough to make one wish Jeff Stetson, the playwright, had not moved him offstage during the long confrontation between the two principals, which is the heart of the play.

LAKERS LOOK STRONG, AND CELTICS ARE GETTING THERE
LEAD: With the 16-team National Basketball Association playoffs getting under way tonight, it would be easy to predict another championship matchup between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Boston Celtics.
Not only did the Lakers of Magic Johnson, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and James Worthy win their sixth straight Pacific Division title, but their 65-17 record was best in the league.

LEAD: Polish Government officials accused an American diplomat today of spying and backed up the charge with a videotape purportedly showing the man as he turned over money, code tables, and computer programs to a Polish contact.

Running the Lights
LEAD: To the Editor:


2 Children Die in Collision
LEAD: Two children were killed and another was seriously injured Tuesday when they were thrown from a car and crushed by a tractor-trailer truck, the state police said.
The car was struck from behind by one tractor-trailer and another ran over them.
Garth Poole, 6 years old, and Shane Laurange, 9, both of Chatham, were killed, the police said.


Justus Lawrence, 83, Army's Chief Publicist
LEAD: Justus Baldwin Lawrence, the Army's chief public relations officer in Europe in World War II, died Tuesday at New York Hospital of cardiopulmonary failure, his office announced yesterday.
He was 83 years old.


A Question of Values
LEAD: To The Home Section:


Union Pacific, Santa Fe Gains
LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation yesterday reported a 18.4 percent gain in first-quarter earnings, while the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation posted a 54 percent rise.


That Jordan Debt
LEAD: Gary Hart is not the only Democrat who is trying to retire old campaign debts.
Hamilton Jordan, who was President Carter's White House chief of staff, is burdened with a debt from his unsuccessful bid for the Democratic Senate nomination in Georgia last year.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article and a headline in some copies yesterday about a New York regulation barring insurance companies from testing for the AIDS virus misstated the policies that would be affected, and quoted Governor Cuomo incorrectly on the subject.
It also gave an incorrect address for the Gay Community Services Center, where the Governor spoke.


Ex-School Official Sentenced
LEAD: A former deputy superintendent of the city's public school system was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for taking sexual liberties with students on the promise of better grades when he was the principal of their high school.
Five students at Kelvyn Park High School said they had engaged in sex with the principal, James Moffat, in his office from 1982 to 1984 because he promised to help them with their grades.


Chaney Is Dismissed
LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers dismissed their head coach, Don Chaney, yesterday.
The team finished with the league's worst record, winning only 12 of 82 games.
No team had done that badly since 1972-73, when the Philadelphia 76ers went 9-73 en route to becoming the worst team in National Basketball Association history.

Computer Cost Cut
LEAD: The American Telephone and Tele-graph Company, responding to price cuts in the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer line, said it would reduce the prices of its PC's by up to 38 percent.
The cuts affect the A.T.&amp; T. PC 6300, the PC 6310 and the PC 6300 Plus computers.
For example, a 6300 with 640,000 bytes of internal memory and two floppy disk drives would cost $1,565, down from $2,020.

Thiokol Denies Charge
LEAD: Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the space shuttle's solid rocket boosters, denied a charge yesterday from one of its former engineers that it had created a ''slush fund'' from Government payments intended to increase quality control in the company's rocket manufacturng plant.


Hinckley Parents Deny Paying for Testimony
LEAD: Spokesmen for the family of John W. Hinckley Jr. and the mental hospital where he is confined today disputed reports that Mr.
Hinckley's father paid for a psychiatrist's courtroom testimony.

Europe's Equivalent Of the 800 Number
LEAD: International Freephone yesterday announced in Paris its Green Number Service, which would be to Europe what the 800 number has been to the United States and could be a shot in the arm for the direct-marketing industry.


Mattingly's Laboratory
LEAD: Don Mattingly is nearly himself again.
With only 1 hit in his first 16 times at bat this season, he had been struggling at .063.
Worse, he was lunging at pitches, as off-balance as a tightrope walker about to fall.
He even struck out three times in one game; he struck out only 35 times all last season.

Paine Webber To Buy Back Stock
LEAD: Paine Webber Group Inc. said its board had approved a plan to buy back up to two million shares of its common stock, depending on market conditions.

COLUMBIA REPORT CITES RACIAL UNREST
LEAD: After a monthlong investigation into a campus fight between several black and white students, Columbia College has concluded that ''racial harassment'' occurred and has found one white male student guilty of verbal abuse.


Dog Is Rescued From Ledge
LEAD: Park employees bent the rules to rescue a dog who fell 75 feet into a 200-foot gorge and was stranded, unhurt, on a ledge for 27 hours.
The dog, named Oreo, was retrieved Tuesday morning from the gorge at Letchworth State Park, where officials do not usually try to rescue animals.
Oreo, who belongs to Margaret Rambler of Castile and her 11-year-old son, Jason, was retrieved after a state park police officer and a park employee lowered themselves into the gorge by rope.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL equity deals are one of the fastest-growing segments of the global capital markets, jumping fivefold last year to more than $11 billion.

'THE BOMB FACTORIES' ON ABC
LEAD: ''THE BOMB FACTORIES'' persuades us that nuclear-weapons plants have safety problems.
It leaves us unclear, though, about the size, shape and nature of the risk.
Some technical information in the ABC News documentary is difficult to absorb; some of its targets seem too easy.
The documentary, on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, is ambitious and smartly done, but occasionally its reporting grows confusing.


BALLET: NEW CAST IN 'BEAUTY
LEAD: NEW dancers moved into Sir Kenneth MacMillan's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' in a performance by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday.
It was an evening of quiet but substantial pleasure.

Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''The capital sentencing decision requires the individual jurors to focus their collective judgment on the unique characteristics of a particular criminal defendant.
It is not surprising that such collective judgments often are difficult to explain.
But the inherent lack of predictability of jury decisions does not justify their condemnation.

Victories Stripped
LEAD: The executive council of the International Ice Hockey Federation voted, 8-3, in an emergency meeting yesterday to strip West Germany of its two victories, over Canada and Finland, for using an ineligible player in the world hockey championships in Vienna.
The player, Miroslav Sikora, 29 years old, has been suspended indefinitely.

Norwest Notes
LEAD: The Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1997 at a price of 98.659 to yield 9.46 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Noncallable for life, the notes yield about 1.28 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

JAPANESE MOVE INTO FOREIGN FUTURES
LEAD: Japan's Ministry of Finance announced yesterday that for the first time it would permit domestic Japanese financial institutions to use foreign futures and options markets to hedge their investment portfolios, perhaps as early as next month.

IN VAST WAREHOUSE, FAMILY CARVES OUT AN ELEGANT HOME
LEAD: NOBODY would ever accuse the Toledanos, voracious collectors, of doing things in a small way.
Ben C. Toledano, a lawyer with an ample girth and an appetite for modern Southern literature, buys four copies of every book by Walker Percy or Eudora Welty, one for each of the Toledanos' children.
His wife, Roulhac - who has renovated homes in New Orleans, written about New Orleans architecture and now runs an antiques shop here - said that they ''just entertain hugely.


NEW FORM FOR NEWS ANALYSTS
LEAD: ''THE JENNINGS/KOPPEL REPORT'' is something new: The anchor for ''World News Tonight'' and the interlocutor for ''Nightline'' sit on a stage and talk about issues.
The issue tonight, on ABC at 10 o'clock, is Ronald Reagan.
Where has he been, and where is he going?
The bigger issue, though, is where is television going?

Federal Judges Are Found Not Gilty
LEAD: In the past six years, more than 20 percent of the appointees to the major Federal courts have been millionaires.
Two years earlier, during the Carter Administration, the figure was 5 percent.
The dramatic difference between the Carter and Reagan appointees may be partly due to the different constituencies of the Democratic and Republican parties from which judicial candidates typically emerge.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Our bathrooom tiles were painted blue by the previous owner.
The original tiles were white and, although old, seem in good shape.
The blue paint is chipping off where it gets wet, and we want to remove it all.
Are we better off using a paste paint remover or a heat gun?
A.
I favor a semipaste remover that is water washable and nonflammable.

Soviet Planes Off Florida
LEAD: Four Soviet warplanes have been intercepted by Florida Air National Guard jets in the last week as they flew over international water, officials said today.
An intercept is visual contact with aircraft that enter without notice into the United States air-defense identification zone, which extends 300 miles out.


The Hall's Big Hit
LEAD: Rick Cerone of the Yankees and Charlie Puleo of Atlanta are the only Seton Hall alumni on current major league rosters, but if they stick around a while longer, they may well be getting company.
The school has a right-handed-hitting first baseman who turned heads as the Big East freshman of the year in 1985, missed the end of last season with a broken arm suffered in a basepath collision and has come roaring back with flourishes.


AT 50, HARLEM RIVER HOUSES IS STILL SPECIAL
LEAD: Nearing its 50th anniversary, the Harlem River Houses project wears its age softly.
A veil of springtime green floats like a cloud over its courtyards, where the plane trees long ago grew higher than the seven small red-brick apartment buildings around them.


MAGIC, MUSIC AND MATH
LEAD: THE idea that the heavenly bodies make a sort of celestial Music of the Spheres, and that music can serve as a gateway or bridge to realms beyond the world of the senses, was already very old in Plato's time.
It has been reasonably refuted time and again, but it is still with us, and not merely as an anachronism.

COURT, 5-4, REJECTS RACIAL CHALLENGE TO DEATH PENALTY
LEAD: The Supreme Court, dashing the hopes of opponents of the death penalty, ruled 5 to 4 today that a state's capital punishment system was constitutional despite the fact that killers of white people are far more frequently sentenced to die than killers of blacks.


Silver Rises Above $8 On Sales Halt by Peru
LEAD: Silver futures soared above $8 an ounce yesterday for the first time in nearly four years, propelled by Peru's announcement that it was halting foreign sales of the metal.


MUSIC: PAT IRWIN PIECES
LEAD: PLAYING guitar, bass, keyboards, saxophone and other instruments and deftly juggling elements of surf music, funk, garage-pop and noise-band dissonance in his playing and composing, Pat Irwin was a mercurial presence on the New York rock scene of the early 80's.
The bands he helped found, the Raybeats and Eight-Eyed Spy, resembled each other only in that both had an aversion to the predictable and the ordinary.

Allegheny to Sell Food-Service Unit
LEAD: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation said it had agreed to sell its major food-service unit for $500 million.
The announcement caused its stock to shoot up $4.375 a share, to $10.375, or more than 70 percent, in over-the-counter trading.


Head of Health Plan Accused of Illegal Payments
LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Miami today indicted the president of a major prepaid health plan on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and making unlawful payments to obtain business from a labor union.

LEAD: Harrison Jacob Goldin's political future never looked brighter than it did at the start of 1987.
All signs pointed to his finally making a bid for the elusive prize of the mayoralty of New York City.


Colgate Profits Increase 14.4%
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 14.4 percent, to $56.41 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $49.32 million, or 70 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

Meeting Set on Jobs
LEAD: Representatives from several black organizations in New York will meet with Mets officials today to discuss the team's minority hiring and business policies.
The meeting is an outgrowth of a national campaign announced last week by Benjamin Hooks, president of the N.A.A.C.P., in which the organization hopes to meet with each of baseball's 26 teams and devise an affirmative action program that would raise the number of black executives.

Maybe a finial has fallen off your silver coffeepot.
Where can you go for replacement silver, repairs and new parts?

Michael and Jessica, You Have Company
LEAD: Jessica, after six years of finishing second, finally made it to the top.
Robert disappeared from the top 10 entirely.
And Jonathan was third, with a bullet.


Iran Gives American 10-Year Sentence for Spying
LEAD: Iran has sentenced an American engineer to 10 years in prison, saying he had spied for the Central Intelligence Agency, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

LEAD: About 100 years after it disappeared from New York, the lynx, a shy, reclusive cat, will be reintroduced to the state by a team of wildlife scientists, who believe that it is an important component of the wilderness.

JOHN J. O'NEILL
LEAD: John J. O'Neill, a former New York City police inspector who supervised the computerization of the Police Department's fingerprint records in the 1960's, died of heart failure April 15 at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 71 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.


Judge Acted Bravely in the Baby M Decision; Rights and Wrongs
LEAD: To the Editor:


German Shipyard Order
LEAD: The German shipyard Lloyd Werft said today that it had won a $7.5 million order from Klosters Cruisers S.A. to refit the 70,000-metric-ton cruise liner Norway.
The announcement came as the Queen Elizabeth 2 ended sea trials after her $155 million refitting at the shipyard, the most costly in commercial shipping history.


RECITAL: KIRKPATRICK SINGS
LEAD: IN Weill Recital Hall Monday night, Elizabeth Kirkpatrick gave a recital devoted to the conservative American art-song tradition.
It is a genre largely underappreciated, partly because some proponents overrate it, but more fundamentally because it is out of tune with the times.
Several generations of American composers in this century set out to do what Europeans had already done and (for the most part) quit doing - namely, to supply large amounts of lyric poetry with music for voice and piano, to be sung comprehensively to a comprehending audience.


Giuliani Asks Congress to Define Insider Trading
LEAD: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, asked Congress today to pass legislation that would define illegal insider trading, saying it would help him in prosecuting criminal cases.


YANKEES WIN 9TH IN A ROW
LEAD: The game had ended in another victory, but the Yankees remained subdued and serene as they packed their bags for a lengthy trip.
Willie Randolph, their captain, says they are consumed by a quiet confidence these days, that this is merely business as usual.
Not far away, players sat at a table, eating postgame meals and discussing the game in tones that were barely audible.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A map on Tuesday showing Paul Revere's route, with a dispatch about a re-enactment of his ride, carried an incorrect scale.
The length shown equaled four miles, not two.

The ensemble has undergone several personnel changes in the past few years; it now consists of Donald Weilerstein and Peter Salaff on violin, Atar Arad on viola and Paul Katz on cello.

Short Interest on Big Board Rises 3.8%, to 470.6 Million Shares, a Record
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 17.1 million shares, or 3.8 percent, in the month ended April 15, to a record 470.6 million shares.
The previous high of 469.1 million shares was set Nov. 14, 1986.
Short interest for the period a year earlier was 318.3 million shares.

New Zealand Paper Sale
LEAD: A publishing group partly owned by Rupert K. Murdoch will buy The Press, a leading New Zealand paper, to become the country's biggest media group.
The purchase, announced Tuesday by Independent Newspapers Ltd. of Wellington, which is 40 percent owned by Murdoch's News Ltd., leaves only one independent major daily in New Zealand, The Otago Daily Times.

LONG DELAYS SEEN
LEAD: A panel of the nation's leading physicists will report Thursday that so many breakthroughs are required to develop laser and particle beam weapons for the proposed ''Star Wars'' anti-missile system that it will take a decade or more of intensive research just to determine whether the job can be done.


More North Sea Oil
LEAD: About 60 percent of the oil and gas reserves in the North Sea have yet to be recovered, according to the North West Europe Annual Petroleum Review, published by the stockbroker James Capel &amp; Company.
Of a total 26.2 billion barrels of oil, only 9.5 billion barrels had been extracted at the end of last year by Britain, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands and West Germany, leaving 16.6 billion barrels still in the ground.

AUCTIONS
LEAD: SCORES of gem collectors and dealers have visited Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in recent weeks to preview the jewelry to be up for sale on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M.
Most of these shoppers have come either to see the necklace, bracelet and brooches that belonged to Ingrid Bergman, or one of the rarest types of stones ever auctioned - a purple-red diamond.


Disney Profit Jumps 76%
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company, benefiting from higher attendance at its theme parks and a strong lineup of movie releases, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 76 percent, to $91.2 million, or 66 cents a share, from $51.8 million, or 38 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenue increased 29 percent, to $766.3 million, from $592.4 million.


PLANS FOR PHILADELPHIA MUSIC FESTIVAL
LEAD: Philadelphia's American Music Theater Festival will expand into international territory next fall, but the company's American works still provide a strong center of interest.
Chief among the latter is a production of Harry Partch's ''Revelation in the Courthouse Park,'' a theater piece incorporating 16 instruments homemade by the composer from hubcaps, lightbulbs and bottles.


Rep. Leach Adopts Infant
LEAD: Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, and his wife, Deba, have adopted a baby girl.
They took her home Tuesday but still had not selected a name by today, said Mr.
Leach's press secretary, Andy McLeod.
The Leaches have a son, Gallagher, 5 years old.


FRANCES LINDLEY, 75, AN EDITOR
LEAD: Frances Lindley, a senior editor at the publishing house of Harper &amp; Row, died in her sleep Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 75 years old.

LEAD: Cheryl Miller, who led the United States women's basketball team to a gold medal in the 1984 Olympic Games and dominated the college game in four years at Southern California, will miss this summer's Pan-American Games after having had knee surgery.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo signed legislation here today intended to keep low-cost hydroelectric power flowing to upstate companies, send relatively inexpensive nuclear power downstate and create jobs statewide.

Our Towns; Suburban Blight: $1 Million Homes On a Dead-End
LEAD: North Murray Avenue is a lovely, secluded winding lane where the most well-to-do of this well-to-do suburb live.
Two years ago, Frank Joy bought a 16-room mansion on 9.5 acres for $3 million.
In January 1986, he announced plans to use eight of those acres to build eight new million-dollar homes.

Libya Releases a Scot Held 5 Years in Spying
LEAD: A Scottish engineer given a 12-year jail sentence in Libya in 1982 for ''economic espionage'' has been released and plans to return home soon, the Foreign Office said today.


Isaac Pacht, Prison Reformer And Former California Judge
LEAD: Isaac Pacht, a prison reformer and former judge who helped revise the California Penal Code, died Saturday.
He was 96 years old.

LEAD: The Rangers have signed an agreement to become the National Hockey League parent team for Denver's prospective International Hockey League franchise, to be known as the Colorado Rangers.

LEAD: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer maker that has been recovering after several quarters of heavy losses, said yesterday that its chairman, Irving Gould, would replace Thomas A. Rattigan as chief executive.

AUTO SALES RISE 3.8%; FORD LEADS
LEAD: Sales of domestically made new cars rose 3.8 percent, to 201,141, in the middle 10 days of April, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.


Morgan Grenfell Names A New Top Executive
LEAD: John Craven, the much-traveled investment banker named yesterday as the new chief executive of the Morgan Grenfell Group, acknowledges that he is facing ''quite an undertaking.''


STUDY CONTRADICTS STEREOTYPE OF ALCOHOLIC WOMAN
LEAD: New evidence contradicting the stereotype that women with drinking problems are middle-aged homemakers has been offered by a study of women and alcoholism in the New York metropolitan area.
The study found that more than half the women being treated for alcoholism are 18 to 34 years old, and that nearly half are employed outside the home.


SUMMER HOME RENTALS ARE UP AND MORE COSTLY
LEAD: With travel agents, airlines and hotels reporting strong advance bookings to Europe for the summer, the summer rental industry on Long Island and the Jersey Shore might be expected to be bracing for a second consecutive disappointing season.

ART: MET'S NEW JAPANESE GALLERIES
LEAD: FOR the second time this year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has inaugurated galleries, and for the second time, the museum cannot adequately fill them.
The Sackler Galleries for Asian Art that open to the public tomorrow are much smaller and more modest than the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for 20th-century art, and the art in them, being from one country, is more of a piece.


EXPLORING THE LIMITS OF DANCE
LEAD: ''It's a very slippery piece,'' Lisa Kraus said with relish, talking of her new dance. ''We've made a sort of a vehicle for dancing dark and powerful emotions.
And it's been a challenge.
I spent over a year making and throwing things away.'' Making and throwing things away is an important part of the creative process fostered by Movement Research Inc., as is the understanding of the slipperiest of esthetics.


Good Food Magazine Names New Publisher
LEAD: Robert E. Young, 51 years old, who joined Triangle Publications' Good Food magazine last year as associate publisher, advertising, has now been raised to publisher.
He will not replace anyone and will continue to report to Frank G. Wolf, group publisher of Seventeen and Good Food.

A Democrat Whose Forte Is Funds
LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the former House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., were discussing their diets.
Linda Robb, daughter of President Johnson, was telling former Senator George McGovern a story about ''Daddy'' and his chauffeur.
Representative Les Aspin was plunging shrimps into cocktail sauce.


Correction: Issues By Nassau County
LEAD: A report yesterday about Nassau County bonds misstated the terms and lead underwriter.
The Long Island county is offering $87.7 million of unlimited tax bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.


FILM: IN 'LINK,' A CHIMP WITH A ROVING EYE
LEAD: IT'S the season of the chimp.
Last week brought us a screenful of the cute critters in ''Project X,'' and starting today the Thalia SoHo is offering Richard Franklin's smart-monkey movie, ''Link.'' Link may not be King Kong, but he's one champ chimp.
As played by a primate named Locke (trained by Ray Berwick, who was responsible for the flights of Hitchcock's ''Birds''), Link is an ape-of-all-work in the isolated mansion of an anthropologist (Terence Stamp).


Profits Fall At 3 Oil Companies
LEAD: ARCO Inc., the Standard Oil Company and Ashland Oil Inc. reported lower quarterly profits yesterday, reflecting the continuing impact of last year's steep decline in oil prices.
The Diamond Shamrock Corporation reported a net loss.


Mathias Polakowitz Is Dead; Pen Name Was Paul Mathias
LEAD: Mathias Polakowitz, who under the name Paul Mathias was a foreign correspondent for Paris-Match magazine and who covered the 1956 revolt in his native country, Hungary, died of cancer on April 9 in Paris.
He was 65 years old.

LAMBORGHINI GOES TO CHRYSLER

Arms Talks Resume in Geneva
LEAD: Maynard W. Glitman, chief United States negotiator on intermediate-range nuclear missiles, left, with Alexei A. Obukhov, Soviet deputy chief arms negotiator, yesterday in Geneva as talks resumed after a one-month break.
Mr.
Glitman said yesterday that the United States would introduce additional verification measures for a proposed treaty on medium and short-range missiles.


ART: SHOW OF WORKS BY TOM WESSELMANN
LEAD: SPRING has sprung and so, at the Queens Museum, has Tom Wesselmann.
This is no flight of journalistic fancy: Mr.
Wesselmann has been showing signs of self-renewal for some time.
Having made his name more than two decades ago with his smart-alecky investigations of what Mario Amayo has called ''the purgatory between reality and illusion,'' he seems now to have settled down with illusion.


Manhole Blast Hurts Worker
LEAD: A Consolidated Edison worker suffered serious facial burns yesterday when a manhole he was about to examine exploded in Rego Park, Queens, fire officials said.
The worker, Emanuel Ayala Jr., 22 years old, of Queens, and his partner were responding to a report of a manhole fire at 61-40 Woodhaven Boulevard about 1 P.M., a Con Edison spokeswoman, Laurie Hanson, said.

SKYDIVER SAVED IN MIDAIR
LEAD: A skydiver went into a 200-mile-an-hour free fall to reach an unconscious colleague Saturday, then managed to open her parachute seconds before she would have struck the ground after a 13,500-foot fall.


MARGARET ISRAEL, 57, AN ARTIST
LEAD: Margaret Israel, an artist whose mixed-media constructions and collages were highly praised for combining the fancy and innocence of folk art with a modern sophistication, was killed Wednesday in Manhattan in an accident while riding her bicycle.
She was 57 years old.


CPC's New Chairman
LEAD: James R. Eiszner. president and chief executive of CPC International Inc., was named to the additional post of chairman.
Mr.
Eiszner, 59 years old, succeeds James W. McKee Jr., 64, who plans to retire Sept. 1.
CPC, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., produces Hellman's mayonnaise, Mazola margarine and Skippy peanut butter.


THE DAUNTING GANDHIS AND A DAUNTLESS CHALLENGER
LEAD: With a potential scandal and countless other headaches, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is receiving a constant thrashing from critics in Parliament.
His critics have seldom had it so good.

LEAD: AS American Ballet Theater's new staging of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' acquires new casts, it is natural for expectations to be fulfilled and surprises to occur.

THE U.S. CASE AGAINST THE ESTONIAN
LEAD: Karl Linnas, who was deported this week to the Soviet Union under death sentence for war crimes, smiled as he handed a Jewish girl and her doll into the red Volvo bus that carried her to a Nazi killing ground, according to a witness who testified in Mr.
Linnas's trial.

ARGENTINE OFFICERS RESISTED GENERALS
LEAD: The command structure of the Argentine Army virtually collapsed in the midst of the rebellions that erupted in the last week, according to reports here.


FILM: 'EXTREME PREJUDICE'
LEAD: ACTORS get leaner and meaner when they work for Walter Hill.
The sun shines down with an angrier glare.
The gunfire is sharper, the insults more ambitious, and the only gentle sounds are those of womenfolk, as they (vainly) importune their tough guys to stay.
In this hard-boiled universe, nothing is too nasty: not a bomb inside a bunny rabbit, or a point-blank surprise shot to someone's forehead, followed by the off-handed comment ''I liked him, too.


MUSICIANS IMPROVISE TO A GLOBAL BEAT
LEAD: RAVI SHANKAR, the sitarist from India who is performing tonight at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, says Americans who ask him about his music make the same comparison over and over again; they tell him it reminds them of jazz.
Mr.
Shankar heard Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong first hand in the 1930's, when he visited America as a teen-ager with his older brother Uday Shankar's dance troupe, and he finds the comparison superficial at best.


NAKASONE SUFFERS A SEVERE SETBACK AS JAPAN'S LEADER
LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone suffered a severe political defeat tonight when an emboldened opposition forced him to set aside his plans for a new sales tax.


LeMond Recuperating
LEAD: The father of cycling champion Greg LeMond said yesterday that his son, wounded in a hunting accident this week, will not defend his title in the 24-day Tour de France.


JUSTICE DEPT. INVESTIGATES NUCLEAR AIDE
LEAD: The Justice Department today opened a criminal investigation of Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, effectively removing the commission from the case.

JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR A GENETIC TEST
LEAD: A judge cleared the way today for an historic experiment in which genetically altered bacteria will be released into the environment for the first time.


Disaster in Phoenix
LEAD: Perhaps the worst thing about the Phoenix Suns' drug scandal, involving at least half a dozen present and former pro basketball players, is that it comes as no surprise.
If drug availability is a river in the rest of society, it's an ocean in professional sports.
After two members of the Houston Rockets were expelled from the league for cocaine abuse, their teammates described relentless pressure from dealers and the fortitude required to resist.


ART: SHOW OF NEW SCULPTURES BY JUAN HAMILTON
LEAD: THE new sculptures by Juan Hamilton at the Robert Miller Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, have a paradoxical presence.
It would be difficult for anyone not previously tipped off to say at first glance either who made them, what they are made of, or in what particular discipline they are rooted.
It might even be difficult to say from what culture they come.


GROUP EXHIBITIONS SHOW OFF NEW TALENT AND STRIKING STYLES
LEAD: GROUP exhibitions organized by commercial galleries and by this city's various corporate and alternative spaces might be seen as the filler or the white noise of the art world.
Only intermittently reviewed, they are ever with us; the more you look for them, the more you find.
They are the backdrops against which one-person exhibitions stand out, as well as the crowded stages on which most young artists make their debuts.


New Yorker Leaves Bates
LEAD: The New Yorker, yes, The New Yorker is returning to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, after a five-and-a-half month absence at Ted Bates Advertising.
According to Steven T. Florio, publisher, Bates was unable to come up with a good print campaign over that time so he decided to return to Lord, Geller, after smoothing over the personality conflict with Dick Lord, the chairman, which he acknowledges was the reason for the split in the first place.


CARDINALS' COX 3-0; HERR HURT
LEAD: A freak injury spoiled the 1986 season for Danny Cox, but he is making up for it in a hurry.

DEATH PENALTY RULINGS: OPENING NEW ERA FOR APPEALS
LEAD: For opponents of the death penalty, who lost two important Supreme Court rulings this week, both by 5 to 4, the best, if somewhat bleak, hope of saving many of the nation's 1,900 death row prisoners is to continue procedural challenges in case-by-case trench warfare.
At a news conference here today, black leaders and other opponents of capital punishment strongly denounced the decision Wednesday.

International Controls Gets Bid
LEAD: The International Controls Corporation, a manufacturer of aerospace and electronic devices, received a $32-a-share buyout offer from its president, Arthur Goldberg, and Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.
The company's stock jumped 24 percent, or $6.50, to $33.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Hockey  First Victory for U.S.: The United States gained its first victory at the world ice hockey championships in Vienna yesterday, winning by 6-4 from a West German team that was stripped of two earlier victories.
The International Hockey Federation, the sport's governing body, overturned West Germany's upset victories over Finland and Canada after ruling that a Polish-born defenseman, Miloslav Sikora, was ineligible to play for his adopted country because he had played in a junior tournament for Poland.


Boxing Notebook; Tyson Clicks in New Arena
LEAD: Mike Tyson's first major product endorsement will be for Eastman Kodak.

DANCE: 3 BY PAUL TAYLOR COMPANY
LEAD: PAUL TAYLOR offered a feast for the eyes on Wednesday night when the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented three works from its repertory at the City Center Theater.
The program demonstrated that Mr.
Taylor is an unusually versatile choreographer and that his dancers are talented and good-looking.


Vintage and Modern Films
LEAD: For fans of the vintage and the most-up-to-date in film and video, two festivals are now under way.


ODYSSEY OF THE UNWANTED TRASH GOES ON
LEAD: The garbage without a country, in a barge floating for the last three days in international waters in the Gulf of Mexico, eluded United States officials today, who said the barge was being towed toward Mexico.


5% Sales Tax Placed On Florida Advertising
LEAD: In Tallahassee, Fla., the Legislature yesterday passed a tax bill that includes a 5 percent sales tax on advertising originating in the state and entering the state.
Governor Bob Martinez quickly signed the measure into law.


TRANSIT AUTHORITY DENIES CHARGE
LEAD: A State Senator charged yesterday that 300 new buses for New York City have potentially dangerous front axles, but the Transit Authority denied any serious problem and said it had ordered 300 more buses with the same axles.

LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky leaving court in New York after pleading guilty to one count of conspiracy in the insider-trading scandal.

ERVING WON'T LOOK BACK
LEAD: It was about this time last year that the telephone rang unexpectedly early at the sprawling home of Julius Erving, stirring the man of the house from a much-needed slumber.


Financing Seen For United Offer
LEAD: The pilots' union of United Airlines said that Salomon Brothers Inc. was highly confident of its ability to sell $1.5 billion of junior securities in connection with the union's offer to buy the airline from UAL Inc.
The union said it had engaged Salomon Brothers to act with Lazard Freres &amp; Company as financial advisers and to obtain financing for a purchase.


HOUSE TRIMS $2 BILLION FROM '87 SPENDING BILL
LEAD: The House of Representatives this morning voted to cut a supplemental appropriation bill for this year by $2 billion to bring it in line with the ceiling set by Congress for 1987.


ISRAELIS ON P.L.O. TALKS: DREAD, ANGER, SATISFACTION
LEAD: Israeli leaders are watching the group that the Palestine Liberation Organization considers its parliament with an unusual mixture of anger, dread and satisfaction.

TAYLOR IS LAID TO REST NEAR SOLDIERS OF 3 WARS HE FOUGHT IN
LEAD: Gen.
Maxwell D. Taylor, one of the nation's best-known soldiers, was laid to rest today close to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery.
That tomb contains the remains of soldiers from the three wars in which he had seen combat.

Taxi Fare Rise Won't Lure Many New Drivers
LEAD: To the Editor:


Truth and Fairness in Sentencing
LEAD: Two people are convicted of bank robbery.
Neither has a prior criminal record.
Neither has a high school education, a job or close ties to family and community.
One offender is sentenced by a tough ''law and order'' judge to nine years in prison; if he behaves while in jail, he will likely be released on parole after serving just three years of the sentence.

RAISED MONEY FOR OFFICE SEEKERS
LEAD: Marvin Rosenberg, a textile manufacturer and close friend of the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, for whom he served as chief fund-raiser, died yesterday at New York Hospital.
He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Bethea Apparent Suicide
LEAD: Larry Bethea, a former defensive lineman for the Dallas Cowboys, died today of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound within hours of being identified as a suspect in two armed robberies, the police said.
He was 30 years old.

OUTDOOR
LEAD: Although paddling your own canoe has merit, there is no need to neglect the sport if you don't own one.
In most areas, there are those who will rent one to use on the stream of your own choice.


FILM: 'MY DEMON LOVER,' GOTHIC TALE IN GOTHAM
LEAD: ''MY DEMON LOVER'' is about a young man who turns into a wild animal in the presence of the opposite sex, and it's a movie to bring out the beast in us all.
Its hero and heroine, Kaz (Scott Valentine) and Denny (Michelle Little), are as painfully cute as their names, with Denny, when she first appears, wearing a bowler hat and jauntily toting a loaf of French bread.


U.S. TELLS OF GOAL ON WASTE STORAGE
LEAD: The Energy Department said today that it had tentatively set the year 2007 as the target date for selecting possible sites for a permanent nuclear waste repository in the Eastern United States.


Thompson Loses Top Executive
LEAD: ANOTHER high-level executive of J. Walter Thompson has left the company.


Pitino Warming to the Suns
LEAD: Rick Pitino's heart may be with New York, but he is pricing homes in Arizona.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds increased $1.63 billion, to $238.77 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 93 institutional funds were up $506 million, to $65.32 billion.
Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were up $823.1 million, to $66.43 billion.


GUILTY PLEA ENTERED BY BOESKY
LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky, the speculator at the center of Wall Street's insider-trading scandal, pleaded guilty yesterday to a single criminal charge -conspiracy to ''make false, fictitious and fraudulent statements'' to the Government.


War Wins on Disqualification
LEAD: The fans at genteel Keeneland Race Course rarely boo, but they howled today when War was led into the winner's circle after the $227,900 Blue Grass Stakes.
They knew that War, who finished second but then was placed first through the disqualification of Alysheba, had been only the third-best colt in the race.

The U.N. Today: April 24, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


BROADWAY
LEAD: WHEN Will Shakespeare meets New Vaudeville, the zaniness is all.


2 More Victims Found In Collapse of Bridge
LEAD: The police today identified two more victims of the collapse of a New York Thruway bridge April 5.
Their bodies were recovered by divers Wednesday.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A television review Wednesday of an NBC show, ''Our Planet Tonight,'' misidentified an actor.
He is Mitchell Laurance, not Matthew Laurance.


Beaten, and Badly
LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers, playing an 82-game schedule, finished 53 games out of first place in their division this year, a deficit equivalent, for instance, to 104 games over the course of a major league baseball season.
Here are the most thoroughly whipped teams in N.B.A. history when games behind are expressed as a percentage of the total number of games played.


SRI LANKA BOMBS REBEL BASES A 2D DAY
LEAD: Government planes bombed suspected Tamil guerrilla bases in northern Sri Lanka for the second day today, according to officials and Tamil groups.


CRITIC OF SOVIET PSYCHIATRY GIVEN PERMISSION TO LEAVE FOR THE WEST
LEAD: Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist who spent six years in prison camps for reporting on the Soviet use of psychiatric treatment to imprison political dissidents, has been given permission to emigrate to Switzerland, the official press agency Tass announced today.


Airlines Warned of Sanctions
LEAD: A group of senators warned the airline industry today that it faced possible renewal of regulation or heavy Government-imposed penalties for inferior service.


Corrections
LEAD: A Washington dispatch by The Associated Press on April 8 about a meeting between American and Angolan officials misstated the legal standing of Angola's southern neighbor, Namibia.
The territory is ruled by South Africa in defiance of the United Nations.

T.W.A. Cuts Loss; Delta Posts Gain
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. reported yesterday that it lost $54.8 million in the first quarter, an improvement from its $169.6 million loss in the comparable 1986 quarter.
Delta Air Lines posted a profit of $26.4 million, or 54 cents a share, in contrast to a $6.4 million loss last year.


L.M. Ericsson Gets French Company
LEAD: The French Government said today that it would sell its Compagnie Generale Des Constructions Telephoniques to a Swedish-French consortium led by L.M.
Ericsson A.B., the Swedish telecommunications group.


BOND PRICES WEAKEN SLIGHTLY
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices weakened slightly yesterday in a day of conflicting signals from the domestic economy and foreign-exchange markets.

HOUSE APPROVES ARMS PLAN BANNING MOST NUCLEAR TESTS
LEAD: The House of Representatives, despite the opposition of the Reagan Administration, approved two arms control provisions today that would ban all but the smallest underground nuclear tests and require adherence to the unratified strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979.

Continental Illinois Search
LEAD: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that its board was beginning a search for a chairman and chief executive to replace John E. Swearingen.


DOLLAR DIPS BENEATH 140 YEN
LEAD: The dollar broke below 140 yen this morning, trading at 139.05 yen, despite hectic intervention by the Bank of Japan.


Control Data Has Profit
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation today reported its first quarterly profit in more than two years.
The computer maker earned $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, in the first three months of 1987, in contrast to a $21.2 million loss a year earlier.
The last time it was in the black was the third quarter of 1984.


Arms Control Details
LEAD: There's a certain Alice's Tea Party quality to the debate developing on arms control as serious prospects emerge for agreement.
Soviet officials accuse the West of having bluffed all along, since it is having such a hard time deciding what it really wants now that it may have to take what it asked for.


MACK TRUCK AND AUTO UNION REACH A SETTLEMENT
LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc. and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative settlement today that could save about 5,600 jobs in New Jersey, Maryland and Pennsylvania.


PLAN FOR REAGAN LIBRARY AT STANFORD IS DROPPED
LEAD: Bowing to growing pressure from students and the faculty, the trustees of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation said today that they had abandoned plans to build a library honoring President Reagan on the campus of Stanford University.


WIFE OF ANTI-RACIST CLERIC IS ATTACKED
LEAD: The wife of a prominent Dallas minister was in a coma today, one day after her husband found her beaten, choked and unconscious in the garage of their home.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: As expected, Herb Brooks, who coached the United States Olympic team to the gold medal in hockey in 1980, was hired by the Minnesota North Stars yesterday, signing a two-year contract for undisclosed terms. . . .
Matt Prescott, the leading rusher on Rutgers' football team last season with 606 yards on 155 carries, will be sidelined next season because of a knee injury suffered in spring practice Wednesday that will need at least a year of rehabilitation, according to Coach Dick Anderson.


New York Arts Awards
LEAD: More than 50 writers, poets and playwrights will receive fellowships this year from the New York Foundation for the Arts.
This is the third year for the awards, which carry a $5,000 stipend for each recipient.
The fellowships are among a total of 248 given to New York State artists this year by the foundation.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD: Friday  2 BY MENOTTI  Gian Carlo Menotti, who is composer, librettist, director, conductor and arts administrator all rolled into one, has now staged two of his operas - ''Amelia al Ballo'' (1937), written when Mr.
Menotti was 23 years old, and ''Tamu-Tamu'' (1973), with a libretto in both English and Indonesian - for performances this weekend at the Juilliard School.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Subversion Case Dropped


Casey 'a Very Ill Man'
LEAD: William J. Casey, who resigned as Director of Central Intelligence in January after surgery to remove a cancerous brain tumor, appears too ill to undergo questioning about the Iran-contra affair, a friend reports.


'Music as Satire'
LEAD: The Downtown Chamber and Opera Players will present a program entitled ''Note From the Underground: Music as Satire'' at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, 344 East 14th Street, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8.
The program will include William Walton's ''Facade,'' to poetry by Edith Sitwell; Paul Bowles's ''Music for a Farce''; the world premieres of ''Self-Reference,'' a parody on modern dance and opera by David Finkelstein, and ''The Tangoed Web,'' by Marshall Coid, with the stilt-dancers Friends in High Places.


MISSILE DEFENSE: NEW TURN IN DEBATE
LEAD: By placing the date for the possible deployment of an advanced anti-missile system well into the next century, a panel of leading physicists has highlighted the stark change that the nation's vision of a futuristic defense has undergone in recent months, scientists and arms control experts say.


Let's Try an American Kind of Glasnost and Call It 'Openness'
LEAD: To the Editor:


SCAASI: JUST RIGHT FOR THE 80'S
LEAD: When Arnold Scaasi walks into a charity ball in New York - which he might do several times a week - he greets the chairwoman and tells her how beautiful she looks in her Scaasi dress.
Then he circles the room, smiling and saying hello to everyone he knows while mentally counting the Scaasis.
The count often goes into double digits.


FILM: 'ANNEE DES MEDUSES'
LEAD: AH, civility.
Where but on the French Riviera could the concept of mother-daughter toplessness be greeted with such heavenly nonchalance?
Christopher Frank's ''Annee des Meduses,'' which opens today at the Paris, is about a beautiful, voluptuous teen-ager (Valerie Kaprisky) and mother (Caroline Cellier) who vacation together in an atmosphere of utterly casual exhibitionism.

Spring Cleaning in the Bronx
LEAD: In his five years as a Bronx City Councilman, Fernando Ferrer was known for competence as a legislator and loyalty to the borough's powerful Democratic machine.
Now, in only a few days as Bronx Borough President, he has shown commendable independence.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 1987
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The economy expanded at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance in three years.
However, analysts said the economy was still growing very modestly.
They noted that the improvement reflected an unexpectedly large rise in inventories, mainly of cars and trucks, and they predicted that the buildup would hurt the economy in the present quarter as manufacturers cut production to reduce their stocks.


Thinking About The Chief
LEAD: Every morning when he is home, Al Campanis drives a few miles to the house of his mother, where breakfast is awaiting him.


ASSET SALES HELP LIFT BANKAMERICA'S PROFIT
LEAD: Buoyed by large asset sales, the BankAmerica Corporation reported first-quarter earnings of $67 million, or 34 cents a share, up slightly from $63 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier.
More important, the bank continued to narrow its operating losses in comparison with the two previous quarters, excluding extraordinary gains and charges.


'Barbara Cook' to Close
LEAD: ''Barbara Cook: A Concert for the Theater,'' is scheduled to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Ambassador Theater.
The one-woman show under the direction of Wally Harper will have run for 13 previews and 13 regular performances.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: ''I Love a Piano,'' Parsons School of Design auditorium, 66 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (741-8950).
Sixteen top-flight jazz pianists are to play a marathon of solos and duets tomorrow and Sunday at the Parsons auditorium to raise money for a piano scholarship in the New School's Jazz Department, which is now completing its first year.

Brooklyn Tours
LEAD: A walk tomorrow through Williamsburg is the first in a series of spring tours in Brooklyn that will be sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center.

LEAD: Proposals to eliminate medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles from Europe have prompted an unusual debate among arms control experts about how best to deter war and reassure Western European nations of the American commitment to defend them in the event of an attack.

Loss at Western Union
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation said today that it lost $18.8 million in the first quarter, compared with a $13.4 million loss a year earlier.
Revenues fell 23.2 percent, to $204.6 million from $266.4 million.
Western Union provides a variety of communications services and has interests in communications satellites.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I saw it fall down like a deck of cards.
There was no explosion.
It just went.
I saw people screaming and running off the top of the building.
I heard metal bending.''  - Steve Russo, in Bridgeport, Conn.  [ B4:1. ]


FRIENDS AND SPIES IN 'A PACK OF LIES'
LEAD: THE British play ''Pack of Lies,'' written by Hugh Whitemore (''Stevie''; television's ''Concealed Enemies''), is with us once again.
It will be shown on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M.
The London stage production starring Judi Dench and Michael Williams was a substantial hit.
But a Broadway production in 1985 with Rosemary Harris and Patrick McGoohan withered rather quickly, despite a brilliant performance by Ms.

Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

LEAD: More than a dozen foreign-born residents of the United States who have been accused by the Federal Government of lying about their involvement in Nazi war crimes could face deportation to the Soviet Union, a Justice Department official said today.

FILM: 'DYSLEXIA IN 'THE HOUSEKEEPER'
LEAD: ''THE HOUSEKEEPER,'' based on Ruth Rendell's Edgar-winning suspense novel, is neither good enough to support Rita Tushingham's carefully considered performance as a closet psychotic nor bad enough for one to accept its mindless horrors for their own entertaining sake.


Seminole Chief Denies Guilt in Panther Case
LEAD: A Seminole chief pleaded not guilty today to two Federal misdemeanor counts in the 1983 killing of a Florida panther on the tribe's reservation.


'TRICKY' BUILDING METHOD AT SITE OF COLLAPSE
LEAD: The construction technique used for the high-rise apartment building that collapsed yesterday in Bridgeport, Conn., poses special challenges for construction crews, experts said.


U.S. DROPS SUBVERSION CASE AGAINST FIVE OF SEVEN ARABS
LEAD: The Justice Department today withdrew charges of political subversion here against five of seven Palestinians it had accused of fostering the actions of a terrorist group.


ROBERT M. DOWLING, CLOTHIER WHO POPULARIZED SANFORIZING
LEAD: Robert M. Dowling, a clothing executive who popularized the Sanforizing process in the 1940's and 1950's, died Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y.
He was 86 years old.

GOLDIN CLASHES WITH THE MAYOR ON CITY HOUSING
LEAD: Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin clashed yesterday over New York City's efforts to create permanent housing for the homeless.
Mr.
Goldin accused the Mayor of failing to renovate available apartments in city-owned buildings, and Mr.
Koch dismissed the criticism as uninformed and politically motivated.

LEAD: Seven-year-old Ronnie DeSillers, fighting infection, pneumonia and an inflamed pancreas, came through a third liver transplant ''with flying colors'' today after his mother told him ''you can't keep a winner down.''

RESTAURANTS
LEAD: DINERS who have a difficult time digesting $20 bowls of pasta at Upper East Side restaurants should venture downtown some evening to TriBeCa, where several impressive and affordable new Italian establishments have taken root.
One of the most original I have found recently is four-month-old Arqua, named after a village in northeastern Italy that was the home of the 14th-century poet and philosopher Petrarch.


COUPLE IS HELD ON SMUGGLING OF U.S. MONEY
LEAD: A Colombian couple were arrested yesterday at Kennedy International Airport after Customs inspectors found $226,256 hidden in their belongings, including $41,900 in a teddy bear being clutched by their 4-year-old son, Federal authorities said.

A Spring Market
LEAD: More than 150 dealers are expected to take part in an annual spring market on Sunday at Heckscher Park, off Route 25-A, Main Street, Huntington, L.I.
Proceeds from the market will benefit its sponsor, the Huntington Historical Society, which operates two museums, a library and a yearly program of exhibitions.


Hearing for Spencer
LEAD: Brian Spencer, the former Islander player who has been charged in a slaying in Florida, will have a bail hearing this morning in West Palm Beach.
At the hearing, the state attorney will have to divulge some of the prosecution's evidence before Spencer can be denied bail.
The 37-year-old Spencer is awaiting trial on charges arising from the kidnapping and fatal shooting of 29-year-old Michael Dalfo.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Nana Vasconcelos and Arto Tuncboyaci, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (242-3374).
If an instrument can be tapped, scraped, shaken, hit or rung, it's likely that one of the two master percussionists at this concert can make music with it.
Nana Vasconcelos, a Brazilian, is well known to fans of jazz and new music around New York; along with his arsenal of percussion instruments, he uses his own body - clapping hands, tapping cheeks, singing in an open-toned tenor and a sweet falsetto - for even more sounds.


Yes, College Without Bankruptcy
LEAD: To the Editor:


Defend America With Foreign Aid
LEAD: What does Secretary of State George Shultz think is the No. 1 problem facing U.S. diplomacy?
Answer: The foreign affairs budget now before Congress.
It's a budget full of vexing choices: whether to emphasize military security or economic developmental needs . . . whether to focus foreign aid on Israel and Egypt or spread it around more .

Caterpillar in Talks On Scottish Plant
LEAD: A Caterpillar Inc. manager said the company was negotiating to sell its worker-occupied plant in suburban Glasgow to a Scottish company headed by Sir Monty Finniston, a former chairman of the British Steel Corporation.
The proposed purchase hinges on Caterpillar reaching an agreement with its workers to end their occupation of the tractor plant, which is located in the southern suburb of Uddingston.

Texas Court Denies Requests by Texaco
LEAD: A Texas appellate court today turned down a request by Texaco Inc. to reverse its Feb. 12 decision upholding a trial court's verdict that Texaco unlawfully interfered with the Pennzoil Company's plan to merge with the Getty Oil Company in 1984.
A ruling in Texaco's favor had been considered highly unlikely by legal experts in


A CUT-RATE AIR FARE IS CHALLENGED
LEAD: ONE of the most successful new tickets offered by airlines is the ''maxsaver,'' an extremely low fare with an unusual catch: it is nonrefundable.
Since airlines started selling the ticket in January, travel associations have credited it with increasing the number of air passengers by 15 percent.
Travel agents say the biggest problem is that there are not enough of the tickets to go around.


Fortunato Acquitted In Jersey Bribe Case
LEAD: A state jury yesterday acquitted a former state Assemblyman, Angelo J. (Buddy) Fortunato of charges he took $2,000 in bribes to get turnpike authority jobs for two men.

LEAD: The Korean Symphony Orchestra of New York, under the direction of Kyung Hum Shim, will play works by Mozart, Brahms, Bizet and Mendelssohn at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8.

'Moulin Rouge'
LEAD: ''A Night at the Moulin Rouge'' will be presented tonight at 8 at the Triplex, 199 Chambers Street (869-2922, or Teletron at 947-5850), by the Lesbian and Gay Big Apple Corps Symphonic Band and the Hot Lavender Swing Band, with the Wicked Step Sisters tap dancers.
The program includes Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' Offenbach's ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' overture (with can-can dancers) and other works by French and American composers.
