Lesson in Legal Spelling
LEAD: If you cannot spell subpoena, do not ask for one, a judge told two lawyers.
The lawyers, Michael R. McIntosh and Edward Heller, of Kansas City, Mo., filed a request for a subpoena in connection with their representation of two people involved in an accident.
But Federal District Judge Sherman G. Finesilver denied their request, largely because they had written ''subpeona'' in their motion and in a supporting memorandum.

Richard E. Spalding performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church.

Spencer Granted Bail
LEAD: Brian Spencer, a former Islander, was granted $50,000 bail in a West Palm Beach, Fla., court, where he faces a trial for first-degree murder.
Bail in capital cases is rare in Florida.
But a state judge allowed the bond after Spencer's former teammate Gerry Hart testified that he would not hesitate to have Spencer live in his house near Boca Raton, Fla.


Senator Urges U.S. to Level Embassy Building in Moscow
LEAD: Senator Lawton Chiles said today that unless the State Department demolished the new American Embassy in Moscow, Congress should force it to do so.


Kirov Sets Jersey Dates
LEAD: The Kirov Ballet has added two performances to its coming North American tour.
The performances, at the Hollybush Festival on May 17 and 18, are to be at 8 P.M. at Wilson Concert Hall on the campus of Glassboro (N.J.) State College.
Tickets are $75 for the ballet, or $125 for the ballet and a post-performance reception.

PRICES INCREASED 0.4% IN MARCH FOR CONSUMERS
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed indicator of inflation, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today.
On an annual basis, the increases so far this year translate into an inflation rate of 6.2 percent.

Eccentric Folk-Pop
LEAD: The disk jockey Vin Scelsa will be the host for a triple bill of eccentric folk-pop, called ''For People Who Have to Get Up Early in the Morning,'' tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880).
Featured will be They Might Be Giants, Uncle Bonsai and A Rage to Live.
They Might Be Giants cram puns and paradoxes into manic songs; Uncle Bonsai, two women and a male countertenor with a guitar, itemizes the vagaries of romance and junk culture.

VW's U.S. Plant In 2-Week Closing
LEAD: Feeling the pressure of a 40 percent decline in car sales this year, Volkswagen of America Inc. said it would close its United States car assembly plant for two weeks to adjust inventories, idling 1,650 workers.
So far this year, the unit has sold a total of 13,218 American-made cars, down 40 percent from the 21,943 sold during the comparable period last year.

TENNESSEE CONGRESSMAN IS INDICTED
LEAD: Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Tennessee today on charges of conspiring with two former bankers to commit mail, bank and tax fraud.


Counts Reduced In Donovan Case
LEAD: A Bronx judge has reduced the number of felony counts in the larceny and fraud trial of Raymond J. Donovan, the former Labor Secretary, and seven co-defendants to 10, from 123.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday misstated the KSZ Company's revised recapitalization plan for Resorts International Inc.
KSZ proposed paying $220 million for Resorts' Paradise Island operations and offered to negotiate a higher price.
The revised plan did not change the amount of cash and stock being offered to holders of Resorts' class A and B stock.

Brazil's Trade Surplus
LEAD: Brazil's trade surplus in March totaled $136 million, down from $1.14 billion in the comparable period last year, the official Banco de Brasil said today.
In a news conference, the director of the bank's foreign trade department, Roberto Fendt, attributed March's weak performance to strikes by workers.

Patient Kills Herself After Giving Up Baby
LEAD: A psychiatric patient who apparently was despondent after placing her 2-week-old son in foster care Thursday jumped to her death from an eighth-floor window at Queens Hospital Center hours later, the authorities said yesterday.


RAGE, ROOTLESSNESS AND GUNS, THE FORMULA FOR A MASSACRE
LEAD: Multiple murders of strangers, like the rampage Thursday in Palm Bay, Fla., are not unique to American society.
But the incidents in the United States often involve more victims because guns are readily available to a pathological individual with an urge to express a murderous rage.

LEAD: Before intermission, the Philadelphia Orchestra concerts on Tuesday resembled too closely the unimaginative affair that is so often criticized when a visiting orchestra comes to Carnegie Hall.

Local Inflation Increases As Clothing Costs Rise
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index for the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, spurred by higher costs for spring and summer clothes.


MASS SLAYINGS AND TOLL: MCDONALD'S CASE BIGGEST
LEAD: The worst bloodbath by a lone assailant took place on July 18, 1984, at a McDonald's restaurant in San Ysidro, Calif., when a dismissed security guard, James Huberty, shot and killed 21 people, many of them children.
He was later shot dead by a police marksman.


Chamber Society to Tour
LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will travel to Australia next month for a two-week tour that begins in Sydney on May 13.
The group will play music by the Australian composer Malcolm Williamson and by Ned Rorem and Elliott Carter.
This is the second Australian tour by the society, which is the ensemble in residence at Alice Tully Hall.

Devils' Chief Resigns
LEAD: Bob Butera resigned as president of the Devils, but he will remain with the club in a part-time managerial and consultant role.
John McMullen, chairman of the Devils, said the team would appoint a new president in the next 10 days.


CONGRESS IS TOLD INDOOR POLLUTION IS GRAVE THREAT
LEAD: Indoor air pollution, now virtually unregulated, constitutes a more dangerous public health problem than outdoor air pollution, scientists and health officials told a Senate panel today.


Reagan to Answer Questions
LEAD: President Reagan, who does not plan to hold a formal news conference in April, will be questioned briefly by six reporters Tuesday, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today.
He said a transcript of the 15-minute session with the jouranlists would be made available immediately to the rest of the White House press corps.

Drug Inquiry Widens
LEAD: A grand jury that indicted five current and former Phoenix Suns players will subpoena players from other National Basketball Association teams, The Phoenix Gazette reported.
The newspaper did not identify the other players, but said the grand jury was trying to determine whether players had used or trafficked in cocaine with Suns players.

Lilliputian Politics in Huge Indonesia
LEAD: President Suharto called it a ''festival of democracy,'' but his landslide victory in Indonesia this week was about as spontaneous as a regimental parade.
All competing parties favor his re-election to a fifth term, all are financed by his regime, all endorse his nebulous ''Pancasila democracy'' meant to bind together a huge, sprawling nation of over 175 million people.

GENE-ALTERED BACTERIA RELEASED IN A HISTORIC EXPERIMENT OUTDOORS
LEAD: Genetically altered bacteria, life forms designed by scientists to suit agricultural needs, were released outdoors today for the first time in what scientists called a historic experiment.


M.T.A. Orders a Divestment
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority ordered the $88 million pension fund of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday to divest itself of all stock in companies that conduct business in South Africa and Namibia within 90 days.
The authority also instructed its appointees to the board of the joint pension fund of the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority and the Transport Workers Union to propose a similar divestment for that $46 million plan.


Vietnam War Resister Enters 2 Guilty Pleas
LEAD: An opponent of the Vietnam War who spent 17 years underground has agreed to plead guilty to a Federal felony charge and a state assault charge stemming from protests in 1969 and 1970, his attorney said.


THE QUIET PUB: A NEW IRISH LAMENT
LEAD: By closing time, with the stars shining coldly above the dark road to Sligo, Jack McNally was lingering over a cup of coffee at one end of the bar in his warm, inviting pub.
Down at the other end, his wife, Millie, saw to drawing the final pint of stout for the one regular customer in the place, a quiet man named T.


A SOUTH AFRICA COURT CURBS CENSORSHIP
LEAD: A South African court today overturned key aspects of the Government's emergency censorship provisions that curb the press and outlaw campaigns for the release of political detainees.


DREXEL SPECIALIST GROUP DEFECTS TO PAINE WEBBER
LEAD: In another damaging blow to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a group of seven Drexel professionals specializing in financing for technology companies have defected to the Paine Webber Group, executives at both firms said yesterday.


THE ENIGMA OF V.S. NAIPAUL'S SEARCH FOR HIMSELF IN WRITING
LEAD: Shortly before he turned 18, V. S. Naipaul, a ''boy traveling to be a writer,'' left his native Trinidad for the first time and went to England to continue his education at Oxford University.
Since then, his life and his art have been a series of journeys - arrivals and departures - as he has tried to find his way and his place in several worlds.


CATTLE RUSTLING MAKING A COMEBACK AS TOUGH TIMES HIT TEXAS
LEAD: The ancient trade of cattle rustling, once relegated mostly to Hollywood westerns, is staging a comeback across Texas.

LEAD: Two members of the Philadelphia Eagles said that some of their teammates on the 1981 squad apparently attended a drug party the night before the club lost to the Giants in an opening-round playoff game, according to a published report.

Journalist Told by Cambodia That Ailing Mother Has Died
LEAD: Dith Pran, the journalist whose four-year ordeal under the Khmer Rouge and escape in 1979 were portrayed in a film, ''The Killing Fields,'' said yesterday that the Cambodian Government had told him by cablegram that his ailing mother had died.

ISLANDERS SINK AS FLYERS RISE
LEAD: To date, the style of game that carried the Islanders, at heart an ordinary team, into this playoff round was an ordinary style.
It was not a particularly vivid style, nor did it demand or accomodate much flair.
When the Islanders dumped the puck toward the opponent's goal and chased in after it, they created their own inelegant sort of forechecking, and they usually managed to rattle the opposing goaltender enough to eke out a victory.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Arias to Play Skoff: Jimmy Arias and Horst Skoff of Austria will meet today after scoring quarterfinal victories yesterday in the Monte Carlo 0pen.
Arias advanced when Kent Carlsson of Sweden, seeded seventh, felt dizzy in the second set and had to retire from the match.
Arias had taken the first set, 6-0, and the score was 2-2 in the second when Carlsson withdrew.


WRIGHT ACCEPTS A LOSS TO WIN A SPENDING BILL
LEAD: It was nearly midnight Thursday and Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, was stretched out on a sofa in the House lobby.

Second of Five Babies Dies
LEAD: The tiniest of the four surviving quintuplets born March 2 died in her mother's arms today.
The infant, Kindrea Leigh Jenkins, died of what a hospital spokesman said was ''multiple major organ failure.'' The five babies were born March 2, about 10 weeks prematurely, to Wayne and Robin Jenkins.
One died the next day.


Florida Weighs Curbs on Guns
LEAD: Florida's Legislature is debating whether to remove local control over who may carry concealed guns and establish a statewide policy making it easier to carry concealed firearms.

LEAD: When the banjo player struck up ''Dixie,'' nearly 100 Georgians rose to their feet and joined in song.

Mendelssohn Strings
LEAD: The Mendelssohn String Quartet will play the New York premiere of Shulamit Ran's String Quartet tonight at 9 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
The program will also include Schubert's Quartet in G minor and the Quintet in C (Op. 163) with Bonnie Hampton playing the second cello.
Admission is $10.


Armenians Remember the 1915 Massacre
LEAD: Survivors of the massacre of Armenians in Ottoman Turkey 72 years ago praying yesterday after placing a wreath on a tree outside the Diocese of the Armenian Church in America.
From the left were Atamant Balekejian, Harmine Bogosian, Zareh Kapikian, rear, and Serfouhie Chakerian. (NYT/John Sotomayor)


GOETZ LOSES LAST-MINUTE ATTEMPT FOR TRIAL DELAY
LEAD: Defense attorneys for Bernhard H. Goetz lost a last-minute bid yesterday to delay his trial or have the charges dismissed.
They also said they were seeking several witnesses who were on the subway train on Dec. 22, 1984 -when Mr.
Goetz shot four young men -but who were never called to testify before a grand jury.


3 ADMIT SETTING HOTEL FIRE THAT KILLED 97 IN SAN JUAN
LEAD: Three hotel workers pleaded guilty today under a plea bargaining agreement to Federal charges of setting a fire on New Year's Eve that killed 97 people and injured 150 more at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

Bridge; Hours After Match Is Over, Outcome May Be in Doubt
LEAD: Bridge is one of the few games in which the result is frequently in doubt a considerable time after the players have left the scene.
The scoring procedure may take an hour or more, and challenges to its accuracy can modify the results for several hours after that.


WOMEN ARE STEALING A MARCH ON SHORT SKIRTS
LEAD: Although nobody has used the word, the miniskirt is definitely back.
For the first time since the 1960's, women who follow fashion are shortening their skirts, or rolling them up at the waist to see how they look and feel with more leg showing.

LEAD: In the eyes of the Roman Catholic Church and in his own heart, the Rev.
Vaclav Maly is no less a priest than he was when he was ordained 15 years ago.
But to the Czechoslovak authorities, he is not a priest, having lost his state license eight years ago after he signed petitions for human rights.

Making Inequity Acceptable
LEAD: Is it really a ''potentially irrelevant factor'' - whatever that may mean - that in the state of Georgia from 1973 to 1978 those who murdered white people were 11 times more likely to receive the death penalty than those who killed blacks?


18 HURT IN BUS BOMBING NEA U.S. BASE IN ATHENS
LEAD: At least 16 Americans and 2 Greeks were wounded today in a bomb attack on a bus taking them to the United States air base in Athens.


Japan's Vehicle Output
LEAD: Japan's vehicle production in March rose 4.1 percent from a year earlier, to 1.14 million, the first year-to-year gain after five successive monthly declines, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.
The March output rose from 1.03 million vehicles in February.
Production consisted of 720,040 cars, 419,081 trucks, and 5,057 buses.

LEAD: The stock market ended sharply lower yesterday, capping a week shaken by wide point swings in the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average that unnerved investors and traders alike.


EX-U.S. ENVOY TO SALAVADOR MAY GO TO COSTA RICA
LEAD: Deane R. Hinton, a tough-talking diplomat who helped shape United States policy toward El Salvador when he was Ambassador there in the early 1980's, will soon return to Central America as Ambassador to Costa Rica, according to officials here and in Washington.


RADIO STATION CENSORS ITSELF AFTER F.C.C. ACTION
LEAD: A radio station threatened with criminal prosecution for broadcasting a graphic play about homosexuality says that it has pulled possibly sensitive programs off the air and may sue the Federal Communications Commission.


Soviet Dissident Arrives in Switzerland
LEAD: Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist who spent six years in labor camps for criticizing Soviet Government policies, leaving plane after landing yesterday in Zurich.
With him was his 9-year-old son, Aleksandr.
Mr.
Koryagin was imprisoned for accusing authorities of sending sane dissidents to mental hospitals.

A CORRECTION
LEAD: A picture caption April 19 with an article on proposals to increase housing aid to the elderly in New York City misidentified Barrington Wright, the chief administrator of the city's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption program.


REINVENTING THE CITY
LEAD: Alexander Cooper's office does not have a drafting board.
What it does have is a square black table, a large leather swivel chair, picture books of the architecture of Sir Edwin Lutyens and McKim, Mead &amp; White and a bulletin board displaying photographs of the old Pennsylvania Station, plans of the cities of Detroit and Washington and announcements about current sculpture shows.

He went directly to a multi-colored video display terminal, punched a few numbers into a keyboard, looked up at the screen and walked away smiling.

The Star Wars Chip: Use It or Lose It
LEAD: President Reagan is fond of saying that the Russians are tough bargainers.
They are, and thus they must see what's happening to Star Wars, his key bargaining chip in the strategic arms talks.
He's on the verge of losing it.
Mr.
Reagan's vision of a Strategic Defense Initiative may never be achievable in space but it has packed a powerful diplomatic punch.


THE PITFALLS OF WORKING PAST RETIREMENT
LEAD: AFTER 47 years of work, Mary C. Kelly of West Hartford, Conn., retired from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a comfortable life of gardening and travel.
But a few months later, she was back at work: ''I was bored, and the money comes in handy,'' she said.
Today, Mrs.
Kelly, 69, and another returned worker share a job at the Travelers Companies as co-directors of the Retiree Job


U.S. WILL OVERSEE LIBERIAN FINANCES
LEAD: In this land on the west coast of Africa where ''eating money'' - stealing public funds - is a time-honored tradition, the United States has accepted a rare invitation to play financial diet doctor.


Limits to Lawsuits In War and Peace
LEAD: Whatever misjudgments it commits and injuries it causes, the Government cannot be sued without its consent.
And while Congress has provided limited consent, two Federal courts last week confirmed that especially where the military and its contractors are concerned, the limits are broad and the consent narrow.


ON CAMPUS, A BOON IN GIVING
LEAD: COLLEGES are asking alumni, the public and corporate supporters to dig deeper into their pockets than ever before, and their enthusiastic response is resulting in an academic fund-raising boom in Connecticut.


ADAMS CUP TO NAVY
LEAD: Navy's heavyweight varsity crew won the Adams Cup today, beating Pennsylvania by the minuscule margin of four-tenths of a second.
Harvard finished third.


Anger and Arson In Queens
LEAD: When the Jewish Child Care Association of New York announced last year that it planned to establish a foster home for adolescent girls in the predominantly white community of Fresh Meadows, Queens, it immediately encountered angry opposition.
Residents said that such use of the property would cause real estate values to drop and could endanger their children.


RAILROAD STRIKES: MAKE THEM ILLEGAL
LEAD: With memories of the January strike and its hardships still in our minds, the unions threatened to strike the Long Island Rail Road again.
This threat created anxiety among all railroad users, who desperately searched for alternative transportation.
Fortunately, the strike did not materialize; it was settled by negotiations before the deadline.


Once Again, the Search for a Developer
LEAD: WITHIN the city's Public Development Corporation, a new request for proposals is in preparation for a developer to produce and rent out the first private building in the downtown office district in Jamaica, Queens, a central element in 15 years of revitalization effort.


4 Injured Crewmen Rescued From Tug in Middle of Pacific
LEAD: In a dramatic international rescue effort, four American crewmen who were injured in a tugboat fire in the middle of the Pacific were transferred Friday to a Japanese freighter by paramedics who had parachuted to their aid.

LEAD: AMONG life's most endearing cliches is the sight of a little girl in lace.
Can even the most barnacle-encrusted soul resist the munchkins pictured here?
Not likely.


Bird's-Eye Solutions for Low-Level Ills
LEAD: DEVELOPERS in Westchester are taking to the skies to solve some of the problems that are hard to solve on the ground - and within a few months, they may even get help from satellites.


BOARD WON'T HIRE TEACHERS IN SPAIN
LEAD: After two years of recruiting bilingual teachers from Spain, the New York City Board of Education has decided not to hire from Spain this year but to recruit more teachers from Puerto Rico and, for the first time, from the Dominican Republic.


PANDA PAS DE DEUX IN BRONX
LEAD: A couple of giant pandas, which have not been known to live voluntarily in New York, flew in from China for a visit last week.
At the same time, state officials disclosed plans to reintroduce the lynx to the wilds of New York, from which the small wildcats departed when loggers moved in a century ago.

DETECTIVES ON HOMICIDE INQUIRY FIND $18 MILLION DRUG CACHE
LEAD: Two New York City police detectives who went to an Elmhurst, Queens, apartment Friday wanted only to ask some questions about a recent homicide.
Instead, they discovered a drug cache with a street value of $18 million and arrested three men described by the authorities as high-level cocaine dealers.

4.3% G.N.P. GROWTH DRAWS FEW CHEERS
LEAD: The economy grew at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance since 1984.
Still, the news had economists scowling rather than cheering.
They say the increase came mainly from a buildup in inventories that could cause manufacturing to slow, dragging down future growth.

STARGAZERS
LEAD: The edge of change is the natural habitat for the leaders in any field.
They mnake it their business to know, before the rest of us, who is likely to touch our lives.
So we sought out leading figures in some of New York's most notable disciplines, from law enforcement to dance, and asked them to do some stargazing -- to predict who, in their respective fields, will make a difference in the future of New York.


The Editorial Notebook; Crime Peril? Or Paranoia?
LEAD: After Bernhard Goetz pulled a gun and shot down four young men he believed were about to mug him on a subway train on Dec. 22, 1984, his case quickly evolved into a Rorschach test.
Crime victims, civil libertarians, gun owners - each could find satisfaction, outrage or vindication in the case.
The various reactions attest to the ambiguity of what actually happened.


Q and A
LEAD:  Security Deposit  Question: We recently bought a building in Brooklyn with a commercial space on the ground floor that we are using and two rental apartments above.
One apartment is rent-controlled and does not have a lease or security deposit; the other, which is not rent controlled, also has no lease.


MALAYSIAN LEADER TIGHTENS HIS HOLD
LEAD: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad consolidated his hold over his divided party today, and Malaysians were waiting to see whether he would dismiss his opponents or seek to heal the rifts.


New Look at 'Star Wars': Back In the Future?
LEAD: Even the supporters of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative concede that an antimissile weapons system of lasers and particle beams sounds futuristic.
But they insist that the technology can be developed to deploy ''Star Wars'' in this century.
Last week, a panel of leading American physicists disputed that forecast, saying it will take at least a decade of testing just to determine whether the weapons will work.

Dominican Capital
LEAD: To the Editor: On April 12 the Travel section, under the heading Dominican Republic, listed Ciudad Trujillo.
For a new generation of Dominicans, such a mistake may be offensive.
I am certain you know that after the assassination of the despot the name of the capital was returned to the historical and certainly better sounding Santo Domingo.

Dr. Seuss and Butter Orientation
LEAD:  To the Editor:


AT PLAY IN THE BACKYARD OF THE PSYCHE
LEAD:  TRUST ME  By John Updike. 302 pp.
New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.
I ONCE read that if the universe, having come to the end of its explosion, collapses on itself, time will run backward.
On no good grounds I imagine this as meaning that suburbs will grow new, then raw, and will then recede; that surgeons and scientists will daily master the use of cruder instruments; that every life will be shadowed by the inevitable onset of callowness, childhood and dreaded infancy.


STAGE: 'EXTENDED WINGS' USES FLIGHT AS A METAPHOR
LEAD: ''THERE are things about the world I can learn only from 5,000 feet above it,'' writes Diane Ackerman in ''On Extended Wings,'' her poetic memoir about learning to fly an airplane.
The author's intense philosophical wonderment permeates Sara Brooks's stage adaptation of the work at the No Smoking Playhouse.

DINNER AT 8. WHEN'S THE REVOLUTION?
LEAD:  THE SHRAPNEL ACADEMY  By Fay Weldon. 186 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.


A HARPSICHORDIST, A SOPRANO, AN ORGANIST AND A PIANIST PLAY LOCAL RECITALS
LEAD:  Brigitte Haudebourg
Brigitte Haudebourg plays the harpsichord with flair, expertise and the grand manner of a virtuoso.
Not for her the tinkling, timid interpretations of too many early-music specialists with their desiccated, self-conscious and excruciatingly correct trills.
She is a musician first, a scholar second; her performances are extroverted and often very exciting.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the article ''Stepping Up to 11,300 Feet'' (Travel, Feb. 15), the author identifies the ''stellar jay'' and the ''Ingleman spruce.'' The bird, which is named for Georg Wilhelm Steller, is correctly called a Steller's jay.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  RUNAWAY.
By Lucy Irvine. (Random House, $18.95.) Very early in Lucy Irvine's account of how she dropped out of schools and into communes, hitched rides through Britain, Western Europe and the Middle East, scrounged meals and relied on the kindness of strangers, this reader got the uncomfortable feeling that hers was less the tale of an adventuresome young woman than that of a disturbed adolescent.

LEAD: A proposed law guaranteeing leaves of absence for new parents is likely to cost business substantially less than the multibillion-dollar figure cited by the bill's principal opponents, Government researchers told a Senate panel this week.

SPACES AND PLACES
LEAD: New York City long offered real estate developers the opportunity to circumvent certain zoning restrictions if, in exchange, they would provide public amenities on the sites of major developments.
Now, after some experience, architects have a much better sense of what attracts people than they did in the 1950's, when Lever House and the Seagram Building were among the only skyscrapers in town with outdoor space dedicated to public use.

Quake Hits Philippines
LEAD: An earthquake shook the capital and other areas of the island of Luzon on Saturday night, sending thousands of people into the streets in panic, the authorities said.
No injuries or damage were immediately reported.
The Government said the quake struck registered 5.5 on the Richter scale.

Victories Restored
LEAD: WEST GERMANY'S hockey team, which had two victories taken away in the world championships in Vienna last week, had the victories temporarily restored yesterday.
The International Ice Hockey Federation took the victories away because West Germany, in its first four games, used Miloslav Sikora, a Polish-born defenseman who competed for Poland in a junior hockey tournament.

IT'S A BUSY TIME FOR TROWEL AND SPADE
LEAD: THE native dogwoods need attention since blooms are expanding and leaves will soon follow; use one of the mancozeb-based fungicides applied according to the label rate; make a second and third application at 10-day intervals.
On dwarf conifers, use a pruning shears or sharp lawn clipper to cut in half the new growth to keep these needled evergreens in their compact shapes.

POSTINGS: Regulation Fee;
LEAD: New York City is telling landlords to pay up.


3 Killed as Crane Collapses
LEAD: Three workers were killed today and another was injured when a 12-story crane collapsed,, the police said.
The four ''apparently rode the crane down as it fell and jumped off when it got close to the ground,'' said Sgt.
G.
S.
Beck of the Dallas police.
He said one of the workers was crushed by the crane, which was being dismantled when it fell.


CASTING A WARY EYE ON WASHINGTON
LEAD: WALL STREET may not think much of the way business is done in Washington, but their comments - at least in public - tend to be diplomatic.
If tact befits players in a politically regulated industry, nobody seems to have sold the idea to Mark L. Melcher.
The 47-year-old native Iowan, first vice president and director of Washington research for Prudential-Bache Securities, writes an acerbic Potomac Perspective column advising clients of what's afoot in the political realm that could affect their investments.


PUTTING ONE'S HOUSE AND LIFE IN ORDER
LEAD: I AM beginning to think that selling a home is an unsettling experience in every sense.
About two years ago I mentioned to my children that when I reached 55, I would sell our house and make a few changes in my life.
I had been a widow for a number of years; they had established themselves out-of-town, and it seemed wasteful to be taking up so much space by myself.


REGENTS BACK A PLAN TO CUT THE DROPOUT RATE
LEAD: After two years of study and discussion, the State Board of Regents has given preliminary approval to a plan for reducing the high school dropout rate.


FALLING AWAY, HERE AT HOME
LEAD: ''WHAT'S next?'' my daughter asks.
Her soft, expressive face has that wooden look I have seen once, or twice, in the last few months when she has spoken of her own death, so I know that she is asking me: Is this the place we have come to, now?
It is.
She is 23.
She has adrenal cancer.
Adrenocortical carcinoma is rare, with only about 150 cases a year.


IN THE WINGS, 'NOH, NOH, NANETTE'?
LEAD: THE FABULOUS EAST HAS CAP-tivated American audiences for more than a hundred years - often through the most blithely fanciful presentations.
This season, several revivals recall milestones in this long affair with Orientalia. ''The Mikado,'' the English import that triggered the craze in 1885, is currently on Broadway (this time imported from Stratford, Ontario); it features such merry anomalies as a British patter song sung by kimono-clad officials and a Japanese tea ceremony using Victorian tea service.

THE FUTURE LOOKS FAMILIAR
LEAD: A speculative foreigner in the city, in the second half of the 1980's, I stand on the deck of the ferry, at the top of the skyscraper, in the green of the park, in the melee of the midtown street, and looking around at the tumultuous presence of New York, I think it can never have been New Yorkier than it is today.


IN SEARCH OF A DRUG-FREE WORKPLACE
LEAD: WHEN prospective employees are interviewed at Simmonds Precision in Tarrytown, they are asked to take a drug test.
Simmonds, a manufacturer of highly sophisticated electronic instruments for the aircraft industry, has made it a condition of employment that potential Simmonds employees be tested, by urinalysis, for drug abuse.


BROOKLYN HEIGHTS
LEAD: IN 1823, Hezekiah Pierpont, the first developer of Brooklyn Heights, attracted buyers to the bluffs overlooking the East River by advertising ''a home in the country with all the convenience of the city.''

AFTER FEASTING IN '86, GIANTS GET LEFTOVERS
LEAD: THE REWARDS for the Super Bowl champions were great: parades, celebrations, parties, appearances, endorsements, commercials, autograph parties, dinners, autobiographies and more.


A Gloomy Report About Robberies
LEAD: At first the news sounds hopeful: From 1973 through 1984, the national robbery rate declined by 15 percent.
This, however, was because of a decline in unsuccessful attempts, in which a robber accosted a victim but failed to get any loot.
The rate of successful robberies remained unchanged.
Altogether, there were on average 1.2 million incidents a year.


Paying The Devil
LEAD: With push-button phones, I no longer ''dial a number,'' I ''mash'' it.
I learned this term in Washington, when, on an elevator, I was asked to ''mash'' the button for the fourth floor.

A Dream Come True
LEAD: WHEN BUSINESSMAN Eugene M. Lang delivered the commencement address nearly six years ago to the sixth graders at his former grammar school, and spontaneously promised to pay their college tuitions, he didn't know what he was getting into.
Lang has so far spent $125,000 on the students of P.S. 121 in East Harlem - arranging writing workshops and cultural trips, hiring tutors and mentors.


STUDY CHARTS MOTIVES FOR CHARITABLE GIVING
LEAD: Historically, many American foundations began small and were nurtured by their benefactors until they grew into sturdy institutions.
But that ''acorn theory of philanthropy'' may no longer hold, according to a new study that sees worrisome implications for the future.

NEW YORK'S SPINNING LITERARY CIRCLES
LEAD: A writer's life may be one of dreary solitude, but the Literary Life - ah, the Literary Life promises glamour, fame, a seat next to Hemingway as he scribbles immortal prose in a Paris cafe.
The myth is so alluring it can survive even the most scaled-down atmosphere.
On a typical New York night, for instance, David Leavitt, Meg Wolitzer and Gary Glickman - all novelists in their 20's and the best of friends - are likely to be having dinner at their favorite restaurant, a dingy, hole in the wall in the West Village.


Representative Ford Indicted
LEAD: The Butcher brothers, the financiers whose now collapsed empire once included 27 financial institutions in Tennessee and Kentucky, never hesitated to think big.
Neither, according to Federal prosecutors, did Representative Harold E. Ford, a Memphis Democrat.


MAY DAY SURPRISES FOR FREE AGENTS
LEAD: THE first day of May means different celebrations to different people.
In some places, they have a parade of dancers around the Maypole.
In the Soviet Union, they stage a parade of military might.
On the first day of May this year, major league baseball will add a new celebration to the world's calendar of May 1 events: the return of chastened free agents to their former teams.

LEAD: GROWING up in Greenwich in the 30's and 40's, Lawrence J. Pugliese knew little about drugs. ''To me, they were something your parents got at the drugstore when you were sick,'' he said.

Mr.
Deaver, a longtime friend of President and Mrs.
Reagan, also accused Whitney North Seymour Jr., the prosecutor, or independent counsel in his case, of ''prosecutorial vindictiveness.

Headliners; Out of the Club
LEAD: Joe Hunt, leader of a California group called the Billionaire Boys Club, is no longer a boy and, as of last week, unlikely to become a billionaire.
After a five-month-long trial, Mr.
Hunt was convicted murdering Ronald Levin, a Beverly Hills man who duped him in a business deal.
Mr.
Levin's body has not been found.


CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA OFFERS MODERN PROGRAM
LEAD: FEW organizations with the reputation of Musica Sacra would dream of devoting an evening entirely to works composed within the past 25 years.
This chorus could easily have sold out Avery Fisher Hall Friday night with music by Bach or Handel - maybe even Carl Orff or Charles Ives - but opted instead for the more difficult task of fighting for the music of our own time, with a correlative drop in attendance.


A PILGRIMAGE OF TASTES AND SIGHTS
LEAD: Siculus coquus et Sicula mensa - a Sicilian cook and a Sicilian table -was a proverbial aspiration of the gourmet in classical Rome, and throughout subsequent centuries travelers to Sicily have lavished praise on the island's food, but it is not always easy for the contemporary tourist to understand why.


HONG KONG
LEAD: May and June are bad months for sea monsters in Hong Kong, but not so bad for humans.
The dragon boat races are a lavish spectacle designed to scare away local sea monsters and fish, but they lure tourists and Hong Kong residents to the harbor.
The boat races are among Hong Kong's endearing anomalies, a reminder that the territory has not lost its soul in the process of building a financial district and a subway that works.

A June 7 wedding is planned.


AFTER YEARS OF WARNING, JERSEY HAS SUDDEN TRASH CRISIS
LEAD: A BARGE with 3,100 tons of Long Island garbage has been haunting ocean waters from Islip as far south as the Gulf of Mexico in search of a place to dump.
Long-distance truckers are hauling waste from the metropolitan region to dumps as far away as West Virginia, Michigan and Ohio.

HOW AUTO-FOCUSING WORKS
LEAD: CANON EOS, Minolta Maxxum, Nikon N2020, Olympus OM77-AF, Pentax SF1 and Yashica 230-AF; these are the SLR cameras that represent the vanguard of auto-focusing technology.
Based without exception on passive, phase-detection sensors, which distinguish between sharp and fuzzy edges of objects seen through the lens, they evidence a remarkable consensus among camera designers.

'' He writes songs that fans and waves of imitators take to heart; at the same time, he's openly theatrical, self-consciously conjuring with appearances and artifice, a series of shifty ''I's.


Concern About Inflation Rises
LEAD: Two important measures of the economic condition reported hefty increases last week.
One, a 4.3 percent expansion in the nation's output of goods in services for the first three months of the year, was quickly discounted by most analysts.
The other, a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in consumer prices in March, was more heavily weighed.

In days gone by, country yokels would buy ''a pig in a poke'' and would find to their dismay that instead of a piglet in the bag, there was a cat.
Sometimes this scam would come unstuck because someone ''let the cat out of the bag.

'What Makes A Landmark?'
LEAD: Since enactment of New York City's landmark legislation in 1965, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has brought 51 historic districts, with 15,000 buildings, and 700 individual structures under the protection of the law.
Considered by some owners the ultimate architectural distinction and by others a nuisance, designation has expanded to include street clocks and even magnolia trees.

The Curse of Memory
LEAD: One of the bad things about getting old is that you start living in the past.
You keep remembering homey little luncheonettes where gross corporate towers now loom.
You remember buying the morning papers in midtown on the way home from a show.
You wonder why they don't play more James Taylor and Judy Collins on the radio.

LEAD: For five years, Kea Tawana has been building an ark with material from abandoned buildings in Newark's Central Ward.

A NEW CHANCE FOR 'TENDER LAND'
LEAD: THE NEW PRODUCTION OF Aaron Copland's opera ''The Tender Land,'' opening Friday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is more than a revival.
There have been only a few scattered productions of a revised version made by Mr.
Copland and his librettist, Erik Johns, since the premiere of the original version in 1954, so the reputation of ''The Tender Land'' rests wholly on critical reviews of the first performances, which were mixed.


FRESH SHAD MIGRATES INTO THE MARKET FROM COASTAL RIVERS
LEAD: FRESH shad, which began to appear in local markets about four weeks ago, is a sure sign of spring.
As the weather warms, this fairly large member of the herring family migrates north into coastal rivers to spawn.
The shad, a traditional springtime delicacy, makes itself available for harvest.

LEAD: THE wrong woman was named a divisional winner in last Monday's Boston Marathon, according to the Boston Athletic Association, which organizes the event and used a new computer to keep track of the finishers.
It was the second such error reported by the association, which declared Carolyn Cappetta of Concord, Mass., as the correct winner of the women's 50-59 age division.

53 Veterans Win Long Battle
LEAD: Fifty-three Filipino war veterans have won a 41-year battle for United States citizenship.

LEAD: In the year since the Chernobyl disaster, nuclear power has undergone its most critical appraisal since the invention of the reactor in 1942.

It is run with an eye for true quality.

IS NATURE JUST A FORM OF PRIVATE PROPERTY
LEAD: UNDER A radical new policy that it adopted last week, the Patent and Trademark Office now will consider patenting all forms of animals on earth, with the exception of homo sapiens.

A UTOPIAN SCULPTOR STEEPED IN TRADITION
LEAD: IN HIS QUIET WAY, JOEL FISHER HAS been trying to reinvent sculpture.
His two current shows include standing, seated and walking figures.
There are still lifes, reliefs and objects that seem to have been cast from everyday life.
His sculptures suggest numbers, letters and signs.
The works glide effortlessly between ancient and modern, figurative and abstract, art and nature.

Broadcast TV
LEAD: ''Shoah'' (in Hebrew, ''Annihilation''), Claude Lanzmann's huge oral history of the Holocaust is unlike any other Holocaust film ever made.
This isn't a conventional documentary composed of newsreel footage from the archives.
Everything is of the present - the faces of the ''witnesses'' as well as the tranquil, neatly tended landscapes that once were the death camps.

FADED GLORY, VANISHED HOPES By John Logue. 230 pp. Boston: Little, Brown &amp; Company. $16.95.    DREAMS of bygone glory dominate the lives of a diverse group of Alabamians in John Logue's intriguing novel, set in the capital city of Montgomery in 1967. The populist Governor, Jesse Stuart, recalls his youthful hopes that his gifts as a baseball hero would lift his family from rural poverty. A cynical newsman, Jack Harris, yearns for the passion and commitment that had distinguished his coverage of the famous bus boycott. A black clergyman, James Boone Jr., guiltily regrets his loss of faith; his parishioner, Arabella Jackson, whose son has died in Vietnam, wants to bury him on a beloved hillside, now annexed to the city's whites-only cemetery. In covering this dramatic story, Jack Harris runs into an even more explosive one: the Governor is secretly selling criminal pardons to secure his family's fortune before news of his mortal illness becomes public.   There is material here for several novels. Mr. Logue, who is the creative director of Southern Living magazine, nicely catches the inky ambiance of the newsroom before the computer terminal took over, and he has created a persuasive narrative voice for Jack Harris, the editor-narrator. Yet the author allows Harris to tell only portions of the story, disconcertingly shifting in and out of third-person narration in ways that sever the dramatic links his complicated tale requires. Moreover, perhaps his experience as the author of three mystery novels has led Mr. Logue to take technical shortcuts in which violent action substitutes for acuity in characterization.   The story is set precisely in January 1967, yet the mood of the novel seems distinctly late 1970's. Harris walks in front of Martin Luther King Jr.'s church on Dexter Avenue, musing about ''a movement now as forgotten as the river,'' without mentioning the great Selma march past that very spot not two years before. Boone complains that the burial of a black soldier shouldn't cause an uproar because ''nobody here wants to think about this war anymore,'' a sentiment that seems totally wrong for Alabama in 1967. Similarly, the police are stern with the surprisingly small number of redneck opponents of the soldier's burial and astonishingly courteous to the black mourners.   As the soldier's family watches his internment, an angry white family scrambles in the clay to remove a coffin from the adjacent plot. Having failed to rouse a violent protest, they have obtained a court order allowing them to open the grave rather than allow their mother to be buried near a Negro. Despite the historical discontinuities of the mood, Mr. Logue has written a powerful epitaph for the social conflict that still gripped Alabama in 1967.

LEAD: Spring college celebrations in two states grew into confrontations with the police as thousands of students and others, many intoxicated, threw rocks and bottles, smashed windows, stomped cars and started bonfires.


BUGGY WHIPS OF THE INFORMATION AGE
LEAD: THE skunk cabbage was peeking through last year's matted brown leaves and coltsfoot bloomed in the meadow.
In the space of 24 hours, nature had shrugged off winter and announced that, yes, finally spring had arrived.
This was no day to hang around computers.
Better to go riding.
I popped off to the tack shop to replace a broken set of reins neglected over the dreary winter months.


P.L.O. Session Ends After Concessions by Arafat
LEAD: A meeting of reconciliation for rival factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization nearly collapsed here Saturday night after Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, balked at giving his opponents a more visible role in the guerrilla organization's leadership.

A FINANCIAL BATTLE TO MAKE TV SERIES
LEAD: Hollywood studios usually jump at the chance to make a network television series.
But last year, the 20th Century-Fox Corporation turned down one for NBC called ''Rags to Riches,'' deciding that it was a bad financial bet.

8.1% Rise in Tool Orders Is Called Disappointing
LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools climbed 8.1 percent, to $165.2 million, in March after a slight decline in February, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.
However, when measured against figures from March 1986, orders were down 23 percent.


END BELIEVED NEAR FOR U.S. SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON JAPAN
LEAD: President Reagan is expected to tell Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone this week that the United States may be able to end trade sanctions against Japan by the end of June, according to Administration officials.


FALWELL SAYS HE MAY QUIT PTL CLUB
LEAD: The Rev.
Jerry Falwell said he may step down as early as Tuesday as head of the troubled evangelical television ministry, the PTL Club.

MUSIC: THE PHILHARMONIC UNDER ANDREW DAVIS
LEAD: THE music of 20th-century Britain has hugely profited from the fervent ministrations of British musicians and the British musical press.
What we may be seeing is an intensely patriotic attempt to transfer pre-eminence in diplomacy and economics -now lost - to affairs of the soul.
If the empire no longer rules the corporeal world, they seem to be saying, let us lead it in sensibility.

Ceremonies Held in Guernica On 50th Anniversary of Raid
LEAD: Ceremonies today marked the 50th anniversary of the bombing of Guernica by German planes during the Spanish Civil War.

LEAD: If Demons Begone wins the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes May 16 and the Belmont Stakes June 6, he will earn $6 million.


CARDIALS WEAR OUT METS, 7-4
LEAD: The Mets' brain trust shrugs off the suggestion, but the statistics present the kind of evidence that even Perry Mason would have trouble refuting: When the team's starting pitchers have worked with four days' rest (11 starts), they have compiled a 3.04 earned run average; when they have worked with three days' rest (six starts), their earned run average is 8.68.


Further Drop in Bonds Feared
LEAD: As investors fled or avoided the bond market last week, dealers tried to lure them back by slashing prices of all government coupon issues.
But their efforts, which helped produce the highest yields in two years, coupled with a falling dollar and soaring precious metals prices, increased the fears of inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market.

RECITAL: LANDES, PIANIST
LEAD: GARAH LANDES, a Manhattan School of Music graduate who studies with Earl Wild, has a more interesting sense of the piano's coloristic possibilities than some of his contemporaries, and his recital of Bach, Prokofiev and Liszt at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon disclosed a strong musical grasp as well.

LEAD: The nuclear-reactor accident at Chernobyl a year ago spewed radiation into the atmosphere for only a few days before it was choked off, but the effects on human health will continue to unfold well into the next century.

Market Place; Methods Differ At 2 Top Funds
LEAD: AMONG common stock funds administered by commercial banks, the nation's two top performers during the first quarter of 1987 used different investment approaches.

Fumbling Forward on Federal Crime
LEAD: In the 1984 omnibus crime bill, Congress gave up to a commission part of its power to make law.
The idea was that a group of experts, transcending politics, could revise sentences for Federal crimes better than Congress.
So far, the sentencing commission has disappointed those hopes.
Congress ought to reconsider its delegation of authority.

LEAD: LaFonda Fay Foster has been sentenced to death for her role in the murders of five people last spring, becoming the second woman sentenced to death in Kentucky this century.

Ms.
Foster, 23 years old, and Tina Hickey Powell, 28, were convicted March 9 of the killings last April.

Symbion Board Ousts Jarvik
LEAD: Symbion Inc. said Friday that its board had terminated Robert Jarvik's employment as chairman and chief executive.
It added that the action did not result from a recent tender offer by the Warburg, Pincus Capital Company for $2.5 million shares at $3.50 a share.

LEAD: The dollar opened here today at 137.70 yen, a record low since the yen was revalued after World War II.

Switch-Pitcher
LEAD: Coasting on a 10-run lead the other day, Greg Fine of Delaware Valley High School in Everittstown, N.J., caused some double-takes when he began warming up for the fifth inning against rival Dunellen.
If memory served, Fine had just pitched four shutout innings as a lefty.
Now he was throwing right-handed, and the Dunellen bench didn't quite know what to make of it.

REJUVENATION OF NO. 8404: NEW LIFE FOR A SUBWAY CAR
LEAD: Late in February a blotched and battered subway car bearing the number 8404 was banished from the J line.
It had racked up 896,482 miles in more than 20 years of service but lately had become a rolling example of Murphy's Law: doors malfunctioned, brakes failed, motors died.

LEAD: As a little-league hockey player in Stow, Mass., Cindy Curley broke ranks with her teammates on the choice of an idol.
Instead of Bobby Orr, then breaking records as a defenseman at Boston Garden, Curley chose Bobby Clarke, one of the bare-knuckle players who carried the Philadelphia Flyers to the Stanley Cup.

A DEBATE IN CHINA OVER STOCK TRADING
LEAD: Before the Communist victory in 1949 exorcised almost all traces of capitalism from China, this city boasted of having the biggest stock market in Asia.
Now, as the nation tentatively rediscovers the need for capital markets, Shanghai has a new stock exchange - one that lists four stocks and two bonds.

Outdoor Party at Riverside Park
LEAD: Young children playing with even younger goats at the Spring Carnival, near West 91st Street.
The festivities included the dedication of $15,000 worth of new playground equipment, a jazz band and plenty of food. (NYT/Dith Pran)


TALKING WITH THE ELDERLY
LEAD: THE aging person with mental impairment can become isolated from the rest of the world.
Families and friends have a sense of being shut out from someone they once knew so well.
Where there was once intimacy, a door has swung shut.

UAL Meeting
LEAD: Richard J. Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., scheduled a news conference in Manhattan Thursday after the company's annual meeting of stockholders.
It would be Mr.
Ferris's first such meeting since United Airlines' pilots offered three weeks ago to buy the huge carrier for $4.5 billion.
UAL said the carrier was not for sale.


SENATOR GORE? IS HE THE ONE MARRIED TO TIPPER?
LEAD: In the capital, Albert Gore Jr., the handsome young Senator from Tennessee who is the latest entry in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination has been written about so much that Newsweek labeled the phenomenon 'Gore chic.'


Bonn Divided on Missiles
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl failed to reconcile differences within his coalition today over its approach to a Soviet proposal to abolish short-range missiles in Europe.

LEAD: Mayor Thomas W. Bucci said today that the prospects of finding survivors in the wreckage of a collapsed apartment complex here were ''bleak'' and that officials would probably decide next Saturday whether to continue the rescue efforts.


Sovran to Buy Bank Company
LEAD: The Sovran Financial Corporation said it had a definitive agreement to merge with the Nashville-based Commerce Union Corporation in a stock swap valued at more than $600 million.

STAGE: 'THE ART OF WAR'
LEAD: THE old Saturday movie serials were seldom more fun than ''The Art of War'' by George F. Walker, a Candian playwright, playing at the New Theater of Brooklyn.
Every quick episode closes with someone in peril and the comedy ends with a breakaway by the bad guys that suggests there might be a sequel.

HUNDREDS ARRESTED AT C.I.A. IN PROTEST ON FOREIGN POLICY
LEAD: Three days of protests against Reagan Administration policies in Central America and South Africa ended today with the arrest of hundreds of demonstrators who sat down in front of entrances to the Central Intelligence Agency in the morning rush hour.


OLD SOLDIERS OF 2 CAMPS TALK OF PEACE
LEAD: Seven Soviet generals and admirals, men who have spent their lives planning and fighting wars, are at the end of a highly unusual visit to Washington, where they spent a week talking peace with Americans who once wore stars on their shoulders.


KINGS HIRE RUSSELL AS COACH
LEAD: Bill Russell returned to coaching yesterday after an absence of 10 years.
The 53-year-old Russell, who played for 11 National Basketball Association championship teams in his 13 seasons with the Boston Celtics, and coached two of them, was named yesterday as coach of the Sacramento Kings.
He is to become president of the team eventually.

Bowing To Racism
LEAD: The great achievement of American society since World War II has been to turn away from the racism that marked our history.
Unfairness of all kinds remains.
But we have made extraordinary progress in ending official racism: the expression in law of racial hatred and fear.

WELFARE SYSTEM UNDER CRITICISM OVER RED TAPE
LEAD: A social worker at a City Hall hearing yesterday told a tale of indifference and blundering by New York City agencies as she struggled to reunite a former drug addict with her five children, who had been in the city's foster-care system for as long as eight years.


SIR RUDOLF BING REPORTEDLY IN ENGLAND
LEAD: Sir Rudolf Bing, the former director of the Metropolitan Opera who disappeared after being judged incapable of handling his own affairs, turned up in northern England today, according to his lawyer.

LEAD: The police opened fire with birdshot today in a running hourlong battle with 350 protesting students on the University of Cape Town campus.


MORTGAGE AUCTION BY U.S. CALLED OFF
LEAD: The Reagan Administration abruptly called off an auction of mortgages it holds on low-cost housing today after a Federal official warned that the sale could lead to displacing low-income families from their homes.

LEAD: The 113th Kentucky Derby this Saturday will be called just that, but could the 118th or 123d be something along the lines of the Ken-L-Ration Kentucky Derby?


How About an Informal U.S.-Japan Inc.?
LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is arriving here at a time of unprecedented American-Japanese tensions.
On both sides, the irritation is real.
The Japanese feel victimized, the Americans feel exploited and resentment is reciprocal.
Americans should not underestimate the continuing Japanese sense of national vulnerability.

2 Airlines Drop Mileage Switch
LEAD: American Airlines Inc. and United Airlines Inc. said they had scrapped plans to raise the mileage requirements for frequent fliers who want free trips to Hawaii.


Chess: Short Overcomes Ljubojevic With an Ingenious Assault
LEAD: Nigel Short began the I.B.M.
International Tournament in Reykjavik, Iceland, by firing a six-game salvo that put him so far ahead of the field that he could float leisurely to victory with draws - and even one loss - in his last five encounters.
The 22-year-old British grandmaster scored 8-3 to take the $12,000 first prize.

Lewis in Comeback
LEAD: ''I'm not dead and I'm not old,'' said Carl Lewis after turning in a remarkable series of long jumps in his first outdoor meet this season.
The 25-year-old Lewis, competing in the Mount San Antonio College Relays in Walnut, Calif., Sunday, following arthroscopic surgery on his left knee last September, soared beyond the 28-foot mark six times.


Once Is Enough
LEAD: Irena Kirszenstein Szewinska of Poland is one of history's great track and field athletes.
Over her long career as a sprinter, hurdler and long jumper, she won seven gold medals in five events at four Olympics.
She broke 10 world and 12 European records, and she won 10 European and 21 Polish titles.

LEAD: A portraitist in the tradition of the silhouette artists of the 18th and 19th centuries will be at the Museum of American Folk Art Shop Friday and Saturday to cut visitors' profiles from black paper and mount them on white card stock.

Correction
LEAD: A Washington dispatch yesterday about Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign misstated four items of polling data.
A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month interviewed 394 likely Republican primary voters (not registered Republicans), with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points, not three.

LEAD: Five members of the Supreme Court posed tough questions today to a Government lawyer who argued for stripping a Clifton, N.J., man of his citizenship for lying about his background both before and after he immigrated to the United States in 1947.

EVE OF U.S. TRIP: NAKASONE PACKS GIFTS AND WOES
LEAD: Politically battered at home at a time when his country faces rough challenges abroad, Yasuhiro Nakasone is scheduled to leave Wednesday on his sixth trip to the United States as Prime Minister.

WALDHEIM BARRED FROM ENTERING U.S. OVER ROLE IN WAR
LEAD: The Justice Department today put President Kurt Waldheim of Austria on a list of people barred from entering the United States.
It cited evidence that Mr.
Waldheim had ''participated in activities amounting to persecution'' of Jews and others in Greece and Yugoslavia during World War II.

LEAD: Soviet negotiators said today that American nuclear warheads for West German short-range missiles would have to be eliminated as part of an agreement on missiles in Europe, American officials said today.

Rescue Effort Continues as a Victim of Bridgeport Building Collapse Is Buried
LEAD: The coffin of Scott Ward being carried to Our Lady of Assumption Church in Fairfield, Conn., before funeral.
The 17-year-old, killed when high-rise building under construction col-lapsed, had been working on spring vacation to earn money for college.
Rescuers continue searching for other victims.
Fifteen bodies have been recovered; 13 workers are missing.


Super Hasty on the Supercollider
LEAD: A sudden interest in high energy physics is sweeping state capitals from coast to coast.
The reason is the superconducting supercollider, the new atom smasher endorsed by the Reagan Administration.
Though only one state can win, at least 26 are lobbying to be its site.
New York, Illinois and Texas are spending millions on surveys and formal proposals.

FLY MIMICS ATTAKCING SPIDER TO SAVE ITS SKIN
LEAD: A PRINCETON University biologist was watching one of nature's predator-prey dramas unfold in the desert of Arizona.
A jumping spider stalked a fruit fly on a leaf.
As the spider shifted its back legs for the pounce, the fly spread its wings and flapped them up and down.
The spider froze, waved its legs at the fly and then beat a retreat.


Pilot in Angola Identified
LEAD: The State Department said today that the American whose private plane was shot down recently by Angolan Government forces had been identified as Joseph F. Longo of Greensburg, Pa.
He was apparently flying from the Ivory Coast to Johannesburg to deliver the plane, a Beechcraft F-33 Bonanza.
When Angola announced last week that it had shot down the plane over Cunene Province, it said the pilot might have been on a spying mission for South Africa.

LEAD: Michael K. Deaver is considering a plan to defend himself against perjury charges by arguing that his mental state at the time he is accused of making false statements was impaired by his use of prescription drugs, according to people with knowledge of his case.

BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 28, 1987
LEAD: MARKETS  The dollar rebounded in hectic North American trading, after being pummeled in Asian and European dealings.
The currency was lifted by supportive comments from President Reagan and a collapse in precious metals that eased fears of inflation.
Some analysts predicted near-term stability for the dollar, although many remain bearish for the longer haul.


'FAST COPY,' MAGAZINE-STYLE PROGRAM
LEAD: ''FAST COPY'' is an entertainment program that looks like a news program, or maybe it's the other way around.
In other words, it's ''infotainment,'' or popcorn news, and as such, it's not bad at all.
Meanwhile, even if it's not trying to, ''Fast Copy'' is slyly raising a question: Does television need reporters?

HEMINWAY MERRIMAN
LEAD: Heminway Merriman, a lawyer and former executive of Scovill Inc., a manufacturing concern in Waterbury, Conn., died of a heart attack Friday at King Edward VII Memorial Hospital in Bermuda.
He was 74 years old and lived in Watertown, Conn.


MICHIGAN EDUCATOR TO HEAD PRINCETON
LEAD: Princeton University will announce Tuesday that Harold T. Shapiro will resign as president of the University of Michigan to become the next president of Princeton.

LEAD: Their world is shrinking.
All that matters is their next shift of hockey, and then the one after that.
Once again, the Islanders face elimination from the playoffs, an ordeal they underwent three times against the Capitals and will experience Tuesday night at the Spectrum.


Grenades Thrown in Manila At U.S. Advisers' Compound
LEAD: Grenades thrown from a passing vehicle exploded inside the compound of American military advisers in suburban Manila today, a Philippine officer said.
No casualties were reported.
Several hours before the attack, the military said that dissident troops had abandoned plans to seize two garrisons in suburban Manila, and that troops remained on alert in case of another coup attempt before the


Technologies Proposals Rejected
LEAD: The United Technologies Corporation's shareholders rejected proposals that the company divest itself of an operation in South Africa and adopt equal-opportunity guidelines at its plant in Northern Ireland.


EGYPT, ANGERED, SHUTS P.L.O. OFFICES
LEAD: Egypt closed offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Cairo and Alexandria today in an angry reaction to harsh criticism from the P.L.O.'s legislative body, which concluded its session here Sunday.


S.&amp; P. Is Studying Drop on Mitsubishi
LEAD: About $1.3 billion of AAA-rated debt issued by the Mitsubishi Corporation is under review with negative implications, S.&amp; P. said.
Also placed under review was the triple-A rating for the company's planned $600 million Eurobond issue.

Federated to Buy 12 Allied Stores
LEAD: The Allied Stores Corporation said it was selling the 12 stores in its Blocks Inc. division to Federated Department Stores Inc. for $55 million.
Federated said it planned to operate the stores - 10 Blocks stores in Indiana and Ohio and two Herpolsheimer's stores in Michigan - as part of its Lazarus department store division.

BREAKUP OF HOUSING FOR POOR IS BACKED IN INTEGRATION MOVE
LEAD: A group of poor blacks, the City of Dallas and the Reagan Administration have agreed, with the approval of a Federal district judge, that 2,600 public housing units in the city's most infamous slum should be destroyed and that many of the tenants should be dispersed throughout the Dallas metropolitan area.


Venezuela Seeks Loans
LEAD: Finance Minister Manuel Azpurua Arreaza says he plans to go to Japan in May to obtain loans for public sector investments, according to reports published today.
He did not say how much money Venezuela would request.

Forest Food
LEAD: Walking in the woods recently, a friend found a patch of brownish trout lilies, some yellow violets and blooming squirrel corn, bloodroot with big white flowers and white and purple trillium.
Also, white toothwort, lavender hepatica, dwarf ginseng and wild ginger, walking fern on mossy limestone boulders and flat-leaved sedges pollinating.

Policy on Horses Weighed
LEAD: The Bureau of Land Management is considering a policy change that would allow the killing of surplus wild horses and burros 90 days after they are put up for adoption.
Five years ago, the bureau Director, Robert Burford, placed a moratorium on destruction of surplus, healthy wild horses.


The Dollar's Down. Why Not the Deficit?
LEAD: The villain, almost everyone agreed back in 1985, was the overvalued dollar.
It had priced American goods out of world markets and it had burdened the economy with an elephantine trade deficit.
The dollar has since fallen by about 40 percent.
It now buys less abroad than it did in 1980, a year in which the foreign accounts were virtually in balance.


A Spring Tapestry in Shadow
LEAD: A pedestrian on 42d Street near First Avenue passing the image in silhouette of a tree in bloom.
The sunny weather should give way to clouds with periods of rain today.
High temperature is expected to be in low 50's. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


Chip Sales Seen Rising
LEAD: Worldwide semiconductor sales, which amounted to $26.4 billion in 1986, will grow by 17.5 percent this year and 16.6 percent next year, the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group, predicted today.


Oilers Top Jets, 4-2, To Sweep Series
LEAD: Reijo Ruotsalainen scored a goal and assisted on two others in a three-goal first period as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 4-2, tonight to wrap up the National Hockey League's Smythe Division championship.

Steel Output Falls 0.3%
LEAD: Steel production fell three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,721,000 short tons, in the week ended Saturday, from 1,727,000 short tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Production so far in 1987 was at 25,708,000 tons, down 12 percent.


BRITAIN OPENS FERRY INQUIRY
LEAD: An investigator said today that the man responsible for closing a British ferry's forward doors was dozing when tons of water poured through the opening and the vessel capsized off Belgium, killing nearly 200 people.

L.I. Skateboard Bill Passed
LEAD: The Islip Town Council today outlawed skateboarding on sidewalks in business districts.
Edward Wankel, a deputy town supervisor, said skateboarders posed a danger to pedestrians and motorists in the downtown areas, where most skateboard accidents occur.
The new ordinance also requires skateboard users to wear reflective clothing at night.

U.S. Warning To Canada
LEAD: Canadians were warned today that the United States would not sign an agreement liberalizing trade with Canada unless the Canadian Government agrees to cut back on the extensive subsidies it grants to industries exporting to the United States.

LEAD: Charges of indecent assault and battery against the former president of Westfield State College, Francis J. Pilecki, were dropped today in Superior Court after a judge heard that a civil settlement had been reached between the official and the student he was accused of abusing.

LEAD: The Price Communications Corporation said it had entered into a contract to sell seven radio stations in four cities to Fairfield Broadcasting Inc. for $120 million.

French Unemployment
LEAD: French unemployment, the Government's most pressing concern, rose one-tenth of 1 percent from February to a seasonally adjusted record high of 11.1 percent at the end of March, the National Statistics Institute said today.
The record unemployment represents 2.67 million people.

HIGH-FASHION LEATHER ACQUIRES GENTEEL IMAGE
LEAD: The upward mobility of leather as an ingredient of fashion has been underscored repeatedly in new fashion collections all over the world.
Once the symbol of rebellion, the black leather jacket was identified with James Dean in ''Rebel Without a Cause'' and Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One,'' as well as their host of imitators.


Webster Leaves Ranger Job
LEAD: The troubled and confusing coaching regime of Tom Webster ended yesterday.
The inner-ear disorder that Webster first suffered 18 days after his appointment as head coach of the Rangers last November limited his National Hockey League coaching record to five victories and four ties in 16 games, the shortest tenure in the history of the organization.


Protest by Afghan Refugees
LEAD: A Soviet flag being burned by a group of Afghan refugees in Karachi, Pakistan.
The demonstration marked the anniversary of a coup in 1978 in which pro-Soviet leftists took power.
The Soviet Union has about 120,000 soldiers in Afghanistan to back the Government. (Reuters)


JOIN FORCES, KOCH URGES 150 MAYORS
LEAD: Mayor Koch today asked 150 mayors of large cities and towns to withhold endorsing Presidential candidates for the 1988 election until next fall, in the hope of developing a bipartisan urban agenda to be presented to Republican and Democratic candidates.

MUSIC: ORPHEUS GROUP AND ALICIA DE LARROCHA
LEAD: ALICIA DE LARROCHA is a living paradox - a strongly individual musician who somehow contrives to make one listen to what the composer is saying rather than to her own virtuosity.
Although by no means self-effacing as an interpreter, the Spanish pianist can immerse herself so deeply in the music that her artistic personality seems to exist only to highlight and focus the score's excellences.

LEAD: A special study has found that the policies of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and those devised by Japan and West Germany in response to his appeals would do next to nothing to improve the world economy, according to officials familiar with the work.


Striped Bass Ban Lifted for Hudson
LEAD: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation announced yesterday that recreational fishing for striped bass would again be permitted in the Hudson River.
Fishing for stripers was halted on May 8, 1986, because of pollutants in the river.

LEAD: A group of retired baseball players announced plans yesterday to build a retirement center for former players that would be the core of a development that is to include a baseball stadium, instruction clinics and a hotel to attract visiting fans.
One preliminary estimate put the cost at $50 million to $100 million, and its likely location is in central Florida, perhaps in the city of Lakeland.

Gasoline Prices Steady
LEAD: Gasoline pump prices have stabilized, with less than a quarter-cent change during the last two weeks, according to Trilby Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter.
The national average price for all grades of gasoline at both full- and self-service pumps was 96.31 cents a gallon for the two-week period ended last Friday.

Growing Nuclear Arsenal
LEAD: A new study says the United States has produced more than 60,000 nuclear weapons since 1945, a number that, on average, works out to four warheads a day, seven days a week.
And during the Reagan Administration, the historical average has been topped.


JAMES R. WITHROW Jr.
LEAD: James R. Withrow Jr., a senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton &amp; Irvine, died of a heart attack Thursday at a friend's home in Manhattan.
He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.


UPDATING WORDSTAR
LEAD: UNTIL recently there was no sport in picking on WordStar, the classic word-processing program.
Doing so was cruel, sort of like booing the Pittsburgh Pirates.
They used to be great once, but now they are remembered mainly for their funny hats.

LEAD: BROADWAY openings once epitomized cosmopolitan glamour.
But the audience for the premiere of ''Pygmalion'' at the Plymouth Sunday could have used some sartorial help from Henry Higgins.

LEAD: In an unusual challenge to the Government, a British newspaper ignored a court ban today and published details of a book asserting that British intelligence agents plotted against Prime Minister Harold Wilson.

Wild Metal Shifts Led By Silver
LEAD: The precious metals markets went through their most volatile day in years yesterday in a session driven by the changes in the dollar's value.
Silver prices were especially wild, swinging by an astonishing $4 an ounce.

Ceremony Marks Birthday of General Grant
LEAD: West Point cadets marching in front of the General Grant National Memorial yesterday at Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
The ceremony marked the 165th anniversary of the birth of Gen.
Ulysses S. Grant, a West Point graduate who commanded the Union Forces during the Civil War and was President of the United States.


John Silkin Dies in London; Was Labor Cabinet Minister
LEAD: John E. Silkin, a former Cabinet minister and veteran Member of Parliament for the Labor Party, died Sunday at his home here.
He was 64 years old and no cause of death was given.


Careers; New Stress On Public Affairs
LEAD: THE public affairs departments of corporations are taking on new importance.
They now embrace what used to be called public relations and government relations.

Gavin Quits ARCO For Univisa Satellite
LEAD: John A. Gavin, former United States Ambassador to Mexico, is resigning as a vice president of ARCO to become president of Univisa Satellite Communications.


Boeing Income Slides 20.3%
LEAD: The Boeing Company today reported lower first-quarter earnings compared with a year ago and predicted a decline for the entire year.
Boeing attributed the decrease to increased research and development costs and to lower profit margins in government and commercial business.

GAF WITHDRAWS BID FOR BORG

LeMond Released
LEAD: Greg LeMond, the star cyclist, was released Sunday from a hospital in Sacramento, Calif., six days after he was wounded in a hunting accident.
LeMond, 25 years old, was wounded by a shotgun blast last Monday as he hunted with his brother-in-law, Patrick Blades, about 20 miles northeast of Sacramento.


PAKISTAN, CITING RISE IN AIR RAIDS, SEEKS TO LEASE U.S. RADAR PLANES
LEAD: Pakistan has made an urgent request to lease American radar aircraft to defend against border raids by warplanes based in Afghanistan, Administration officials said today.


TREATING ECTOPIC PREGNANCY
LEAD: ECTOPIC pregnancies, in which the fertilized egg develops outside the uterus, have been successfully terminated in nine women without surgery using direct injection of prostaglandin into the oviduct, according to a recent account in the British medical journal Lancet.


What the World Needs
LEAD: To the Editor:


CUOMO TO SEEK TAX OR FEE RISE FOR ROAD COSTS
LEAD: Just five days after a broad state income-tax cut became law, Governor Cuomo announced today that he would propose an increase in other taxes or fees.


Ammirati Abandons Reebok Account
LEAD: Ammirati &amp; Puris, one of the hot New York ad agencies, has quit the $15 million Reebok account, saying its creative people were getting burned out trying to satisfy the client's demands.


Oil Rig Count Up by 15
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States this week totaled 765, up 15 from the previous week, the Hughes Tool Company reported today.
The nationwide count totaled 750 last week, the Houston-based maker of oil tools said.
The rig count, considered to be the baromoter of drilling activity, totaled 855 at this time last year.


U.S. RULES FAULTED IN CARE OF ELDERLY
LEAD: The Federal Government lacks standards for recruiting, hiring or training home health aides, contributing to problems ranging from poor patient care to outright abuse, a Federal official and others said today.

Cosby and the Muppets Win Peabody Awards
LEAD: ''The Cosby Show'' and Kermit the Frog and his Muppet pals were among the winners today of George Foster Peabody Awards for distinguished broadcasting in 1986.


S.E.C.'s Role Being Studied
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission will decide Wednesday whether to ask Congress to give it the authority to regulate commercial banks engaged in the securities business.


MEESE INVESTIGATION OF EDUCATION DEPT. REQUESTED
LEAD: The chairman of a House subcommittee has asked the Justice Department to investigate 10 regional civil rights offices of the Department of Education where employees admitted last July that they backdated discrimination complaints and pressed witnesses to withdraw charges of discrimination.

Ex-Governor Gubbrud Of South Dakota Dies
LEAD: Archie M. Gubbrud, who doubled state aid to education in his tenure as Governor of South Dakota from 1961 to 1965, died of lung cancer Sunday at McKennan Hospital here.
He was 76 years old.


Casey Still Hospitalized
LEAD: William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, remained in a hospital where he was being treated for pneumonia, but a spokeswoman declined to release any further information today. ''The family has requested no statements be given,'' said Renee Paley, director of communications at Glen Cove Community Hospital.


AFGHANISTAN ADMITS CEASE-FIRE'S FAILURE AND CRITCIZES U.S.
LEAD: The Government, celebrating the ninth anniversary of Communist control, acknowledged today that it had failed to achieve a cease-fire in the Afghan civil war.


Tokyo Stock Prices Tumble
LEAD: As the yen soared to new highs against the dollar today, prices on the Tokyo stock exchanges plunged, marking the worst single-day drop ever.


PITINO PREFERS FRIARS TO KNICKS
LEAD: Rick Pitino, who last week was considered all but certain to be the next head coach of the Knicks, said yesterday he would sign a new contract with Providence College before the end of this week.


OFFICER IN GRAFT TRIAL CALLED NAIVE BY LAWYER
LEAD: The lawyer for one of the 13 police officers accused of corruption in the 77th Precinct scandal in Brooklyn said in court yesterday that his client was a naive man and that he had been corrupted by another officer who was trying to avoid prosecution.


Sanction Off In Tyson Bout
LEAD: Jimmy Binns, legal counsel to the World Boxing Association, said yesterday that his organization was withdrawing its sanction of the Mike Tyson-Pinklon Thomas heavyweight title bout if it is held, as planned, in Nevada.
