Leonard Fuller Sr., 96, Dies; Radio Pioneer and Inventor
LEAD: Leonard F. Fuller Sr., a radio pioneer who held 24 patents for his inventions, died Thursday at his home.
He was 96 years old.


Taking Stock Of Pro Teams
LEAD: It may be a while before you can take a flier on the Yankees or sell the Mets short on the New York Stock Exchange.
But five months after the Boston Celtics made financial history by selling their shares to the public, other clubs have disclosed plans to make similar offerings, and still more are waiting in the wings.


First-Rate
LEAD: Rickey Henderson's nine home runs as a first-inning leadoff batter set an American League record last season and fell just two short of Bobby Bonds's major league mark.
Henderson has already hit three more such homers in 1987 and may catch Bonds, the major leagues' career leader in the category, before the year is out.


Drexel Assails Suit by Staley
LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it had asked a Federal court in Chicago to dismiss a suit brought against it by Staley Continental Inc.
The Staley suit contends that after being rebuffed in overtures for a leveraged buyout, Drexel deliberately sold into a November 1986 Staley stock offering that the company eventually had to withdraw.

Compaq Profits Soar
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its earnings for the first quarter more than doubled to a record $20.2 million, or 56 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 27 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
For the three months ended March 31, the company, which is based in Houston, said that revenues rose 47 percent, to $211 million, from $144 million in the period a year ago.


VIOLINISTS GIVE TEACHER, 70, A PARTY
LEAD: Somewhere in the world there may have been a celebrity violin recital last night, but there can't have been many.
Most of Dorothy DeLay's students were otherwise engaged.


GIANTS ARE AT FOES MERCY, FOR A CHANGE
LEAD: If you think you know who the Giants will choose on the first round of today's National Football League draft, please let the Giants know.
Their front office is resigned to the fact that because the Super Bowl champions get the 28th and last pick, they are at the mercy of the teams that pick ahead of them.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has solicited bids for the final design of America's $14.5 billion manned space station, sending a request for proposals to the nation's leading aerospace companies.

GOETZ CALLED A POWDER KEG BY PROSECUTOR
LEAD: The prosecutor in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz told a Manhattan jury yesterday that the defendant shot four young men on the subway in 1984 not because he feared they would rob him, but out of a ''twisted self-righteous sense of right and wrong.''


So Far To Ithaca
LEAD: Fear of attack by 3,100 tons of Long Island garbage brought the Mexican Navy into action on the weekend.
Ships, planes and helicopters under orders to keep the garbage out of Mexican waters apparently discouraged the assault, for when last heard from the garbage was meandering around the Gulf of Mexico, and possibly headed for the United


U.S. Aides Voice Pessimism On Chance of Mideast Parley
LEAD: Administration officials said today that they saw little prospect that an international peace conference on the Middle East could be convened soon.


BAYONNE LEFT DRY AS MAINS BREAK
LEAD: Two water mains ruptured early today, cutting off water for nearly all of the city's 65,000 people and forcing the closing of some businesses and all public and parochial schools.


PENNZOIL AND 25 OTHERS WILL MONITOR TEXACO
LEAD: The United States trustee in the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy case today appointed 26 Texaco creditors, including the Pennzoil Company, to monitor the activities of Texaco.
These creditors, along with Texaco, will help decide on a plan of reorganization for it.


Why the Dollar Ought to Drop
LEAD: Some say the dollar is too weak.
Others say it is too strong.
In either case, the dollar's steady march downward that began two years ago has now brought it back to 1980 levels.
Paul R. Krugman, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology international economist and former staff member of the Council of Economic Advisers, argues that the dollar will - and should - continue to sink.


ROLES AND DOLLARS AT STAKE IN SOAP-OPERA CLIFFHANGERS
LEAD: On May 15, if Hollywood rumor is to be trusted, Pamela Ewing of CBS's ''Dallas'' will be a victim in a fiery car crash, ending the season near death and wrapped in bandages.
An hour later, most of the cast of the same network's ''Falcon Crest'' will sink from sight into San Francisco Bay, not to be heard from until the new fall season.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs' Andre Dawson, who had nine hits, including three doubles and three home runs, along with 11 runs batted in, was named the National League Player of the Week. . . .
Wally Joyner of the California Angels, who batted .480 with five home runs and 13 r.b.i., was cited as American League Player of the Week.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Horse Racing  &gt;Desirous Wins at Aqueduct: Desirous, with Angel Cordero Jr. riding, beat the favored Self Image and Eddie Maple to post a half-length victory yesterday in the $31,000 Fides Purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward at Aqueduct.
It was six more lengths back to the third-place Stated.

MAKEUP VIDEOS TO TAKE OUT
LEAD: ''When you have your makeup done, your eyes are closed half the time,'' said Katie Ford, ''so you don't know what's happening.
You have to go back and find out what they did.
With this video, you can just play it and see everything.'' ''It's like a refresher course,'' said Cynthia Gibbons.
The two women were at the Estee Lauder counter in Bloomingdale's on Friday, waiting for experts to make them up and record the process on video cassettes they could buy and take home.

THE STAGE: 'STARMITES,' A MUSICAL
LEAD: WHEN ''Starmites'' had its premiere in 1980 at the Ark Theater Company, it was clearly the tiniest -and the most intentionally amusing -of intergalactic epics, a musical spoof that could bring smiles to the faces of the most ardent star warrior or trekkie.
While its big screen cousins have gone on to a cycle of sequels, the small-stage ''Starmites'' remains singular.

New Mexico Issue
LEAD: New Mexico yesterday priced a $35 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation.
Yields range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6 percent in 1992 and 6.75 percent in 1996.
Backed by the full faith and credit of the state, the issue is rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.&amp;P.

Ketchum May Close Deal for Hicks &amp; Greist

Accused Spy Leaves Libya
LEAD: Robert Maxwell, a Scottish engineer freed by Libya last week from a 12-year jail sentence for ''economic espionage,'' flew out of Tripoli today, the Libyan news agency said.
Mr.
Maxwell, 38 years old, left the Libyan capital with his wife and son on a Maltese airliner, according to the report monitored here by the British Broadcasting Corporation.


ORNAMENTS WITH A PAST
LEAD: 1.A Useful Decoration This metal chocolate mold, made in Dresden, Germany, before World War II, makes an unusual kitchen wall decoration.
If you are more ambitious, it can also be used for making pretty chocolates.
Patterned with fish and manufactured by the Anton Reiche Company, the mold is 9 by 4 inches and costs $85.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a dispatch April 16 from Santiago, Chile, on human-rights lawyers misattributed remarks that the ''best reply'' to Government accusations of aid to Communists was ''our history and the international respect that we have won.'' The speaker was Enrique Palet, the executive secretary of the Vicariate of Solidarity, and not Luis Toro, a lawyer on the Vicariate staff.


'WE LOVE LUCY,' PASTICHE FROM 50'S
LEAD: OBVIOUSLY, Lucille Ball will be on television forever.
It is a cultural fact of life. ''I Love Lucy'' began in 1951, ran six years and never ranked less than third among all programs.
Then Miss Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz, did a series of specials; some of those will be around forever, too.
Witness ''We Love Lucy'' on Channel 5 at 8 o'clock tonight.


Pressure Too Great
LEAD: The pressure of breaking a United States college baseball winning streak might finally have been too much for the Point Park Pioneers, Coach Mark Jackson said. ''With all the publicity, it makes it harder,'' he said. ''Every team is out there gunning for you.
Every game is the World Series for them.


LAXALT JOINS G.O.P. RACE FOR PRESIDENT
LEAD: Former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, who built a reputation as President Reagan's closest friend in Congress, announced today that he was a candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: Ellington Observance One of America's greatest composers, Duke Ellington, was born 88 years ago today.
He died May 24, 1974.
His first composition was ''Soda Fountain Rag,'' inspired by his after-school job as, to use an old phrase, a soda jerk.
His last was the musical ''Queenie Pie,'' which he did not complete.


Soil on Troubled Waters
LEAD: There has always been value in trash for those who know where to find it.
Nowadays there is also value in disposing of trash, if one can find a place to put it.
The National Waste Corporation finds itself with an embarrassment of trash, floating about the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico on a barge.
Its fate remains unclear, but it serves as a warning that more such embarrassments are likely in the absence of sound planning.


3 FILMS CITED BY JUSTICES
LEAD: The three films cited in the Supreme Court's decision yesterday on the Reagan Administration's right to label works as ''political propaganda'' were ''If You Love This Planet,'' ''Acid From Heaven'' and ''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery?'' All were produced by the National Film Board of Canada, and all deal with nuclear or environmental issues.

If the Missiles Go, Peace May Stay
LEAD: The rapid movement toward an arrangement that would remove both Soviet and Western intermediate-range missiles from the European theater has caused great concern - even among longtime advocates of arms control.
As one who originally encouraged the ''zero-zero option,'' and was forced from office partly for advocating the idea, I urge my nervous friends in Europe and America to embrace it.

MUSIC: ALL-FINNISH CONCERT
LEAD: TIME has generally been a good editor.
In this age of historical re-examination, the process of unearthing lost works by long-gone composers has become a flourishing business.
Private archives, neglected library shelves and an attic or two have yielded to inquiring musicologists a good number of finds that have then found their way to the concert stage, and, in many cases, onto recordings.

LEAD: Virtually all fiscal analysts agree that more revenue is needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

Could this be the beginning of a trend among Democratic Presidential candidates, and others?

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: CONVERSATION overheard (and scrawled on a slightly soggy cocktail napkin) by Joe Brescia, a late-night reveler about town.
The place is Tunnel, an in-vogue club in Manhattan.
There, in the wee hours of a recent morning, a young man in up-to-date attire bumps into a leather-jacketed, long-haired man.


Guilty in 3 California Deaths
LEAD: A man arrested after a bungled jewel robbery led to a siege at a jewelry store on Rodeo Drive in Beverely Hills last June entered surprise guilty pleas today to 12 charges.
The defendant, Steven Livaditis, 23 years old, pleaded guilty to three counts of murder, five of robbery, one count of burglary and three counts of kidnapping.

COURT BACKS ST. BART'S IN TOWER LEGAL BATTLE
LEAD: St.
Bartholomew's Church can continue its long and costly battle to build a skyscraper on its Park Avenue property, under a ruling yesterday by the State Court of Appeals.


Hemmed In
LEAD: A woman buying clothes these days is justified in feeling disoriented.
Designers show raised hemlines for fall, harking back to miniskirts of the 1960's.
The new short skirts are said to be a sign of prosperity.
A woman in a classically tailored suit, with yards of leg showing, is all set, noted one commentator, for a visit to her broker.


WEATHER AND SCOTT GIVE METS SHIVERS
LEAD: The Mets, playing dreadfully and having plunged into third place Monday night for the first time in 53 weeks, wasted no time yesterday in calling off last night's game with the Houston Astros.
It was rescheduled as part of a twilight-night doubleheader July 24.


Texas Wins an Order Lifting Fines in Prison Reform Suit
LEAD: Officials announced Monday that the state had been granted an order calling off fines that could have totaled $800,500 a day in a long-running case over prison reform.

Leads Are Lacking In Waite Kidnapping
LEAD: Unofficial, unconfirmed messages from Lebanon continue to report that Terry Waite, the kidnapped envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, is alive and well, the Archbishop's office said today.


Nelson May Quit
LEAD: A feud has developed between Herb Kohl, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, and Don Nelson, the coach, and it will probably result in Nelson's leaving the team after this season, The Milwaukee Journal reported yesterday.

LEAD: Convergent Technologies Inc., the troubled computer manufacturer that is based in San Jose, Calif., today reported a first-quarter loss of $11 million in contrast to a profit of $2.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

LEAD: The Justice Department's yearlong deliberations over whether to approve a recommendation that President Kurt Waldheim of Austria be barred from the United States was largely spent investigating information that he submitted to rebut charges against him, department officials said today.

Shamrock Units Split Tomorrow
LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said its exploration and production unit would be renamed the Maxus Energy Corporation on Thursday when it becomes independent from Shamrock's refining and marketing unit.
The split-up of the two units was announced in February.
Maxus Energy, with $2.6 billion in assets, will be the nation's largest oil and gas company and its shares will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol MXS, the company said.


JOINT STAND ELUDES ALLIES ON ELIMINATING MISSILES
LEAD: Western European foreign and defense ministers today expressed ''serious concern'' at the Soviet superiority in short-range missiles, but failed to adopt a common position on a Soviet proposal that they be eliminated.


New Majority Leader For Assembly Named
LEAD: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller today appointed James R. Tallon Jr., a Binghamton Democrat, to the position of majority leader.


Japanese Recovery Sign
LEAD: Japan's leading economic indicator continues pointing to a possible recovery in the near future, but Government economists caution that the yen's renewed upswing may do more economic damage.
The Economic Planning Agency said today that the leading indicator for February, the latest reporting month, stood at 66.7, falling from 75 the previous month.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Let me say in all simplicity, but with unequivocal clarity: I have a clear conscience.''  - President Kurt Waldheim of Austria.  [ A1:4. ]


Apparent Drug Relapse
LEAD: Tony Collins, a running back for the New England Patriots, has apparently suffered a drug relapse and has been checked into a rehabilitation center by the team, according to a report in The Boston Globe yesterday.


DETROIT CRIME FEEDS ON ITSELF AND YOUTH
LEAD: In a city where officials say there are more guns than people, crime influences almost every decision.
It determines when people leave home, what routes they drive, where they walk.
Crime is a conversational ice-breaker, like the weather or the Detroit Tigers.


STAGE: 'LUCKY SPOT' BY BETH HENLEY
LEAD: THE poor Depression-era hicks who inhabit Beth Henley's new play, ''The Lucky Spot,'' may be losers, but they wax more poetic than anyone who ever trod Tobacco Road. ''The people are so lonely you can smell it rotting on them,'' says Hooker (Ray Baker), the most notorious gambler and rake of Pigeon, La.


PLANNING FORESTS FROM LAB CULTURES
LEAD: IN a laboratory here, tall redwoods from little test tubes grow.


J. RUSSELL McSHANE
LEAD: J. Russell McShane, a former president of the New York University Alumni Association, died April 19 at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J.
He was 77 years old and lived in Glen Ridge, N.J.


No to a Fast-Food, Fast-Sex, High-Crime 42d St. Historic District
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bridge: A Mystery Double Was Sign Of an Expert Player at Work
LEAD: Suppose that a player passes originally, keeps passing and finally doubles a three no-trump contract reached without interference.
What do you conclude?
Presumably you are trying to point your partner in the direction of a specific lead.


Unisys Contract
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation said it had received a computer contract, which could be valued at more than $50 million, from the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.
The 10-year agreement provides for a new banking terminal system for the worldwide branches of the Hongkong bank.


Isn't It Spring Yet?
LEAD: The Brooklyn Bridge was framed by a fog that enveloped Manhattan's building tops as overcast skies and a breezy high temperature of only 44 degrees set a wintry tempo.
The weather today is expected to be much the same, with sunny skies in morning giving way to clouds. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


INQUIRY BY WALSH SAID TO SCRUTINIZE HIGH U.S. OFFICIALS
LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that his investigation covered ''high Government officials'' as well as others and gave his strongest indication to date that he would seek indictments.


A CHEF-S-EYE VIEW OF TOASTER OVENS
LEAD: TOASTER ovens, like microwave ovens, are handy supplementary appliances that have become increasingly popular.
They might have been made just for single people, who put a premium on simplicity in their cooking and cleanup; with a toaster oven, you don't have to work with a full-size oven to prepare a small dish.


Tonka Names Overseas Chief
LEAD: The Tonka Corporation announced yesterday that it had named James D. Miller president of its new unit, Tonka Toys International.


DEMOCRATS SEEK U.S. INQUIRY INTO FUND-RAISING ACTIVITIES
LEAD: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee filed a complaint today with the Federal Election Commission against conservative fund-raising groups controlled by Carl R. (Spitz) Channell.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: Yesterday with scarcity of new tax-exempt issues on the calendar and rates in the municipal market holding at about the same as levels the previous day, New Jersey brought to market a $299 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank.
Last week some major sales were postponed because of extremely volatile market conditions.


Chemical Holders Approve Takeover
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation said that 98.6 percent of the shares voting at its annual meeting had approved the previously announced takeover of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc.
Walter Shipley, Chemical's chairman, said the merger would create a bank holding company with assets of about $80 billion.

What are they saying about coffee and tea? ''Potentially harmful stimulants.'' Salt and sugar? ''Detrimental if overused.'' Fried and fatty foods? ''Unhealthy in the extreme.'' Dietary fiber and bran flour?

Administration Split on Dollar
LEAD: AS Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone arrives in Washington for his crucial talks with President Reagan, there are uncertainties and divisions within the American camp on the matter of greatest immediate concern to the Japanese: the yen-dollar exchange rate.


India's Boom Leaves One State in Dark Ages
LEAD: About 300 million Indians are said to be living below the poverty line, but Government statistics still portray a trend in which poverty is gradually being reduced.
Such hopeful projections run up against a harsh reality for millions of people here.


Citicorp Rates Up at Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were up at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper with maturities of 91 and 182 days.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper yesterday at an average rate of 6.827 percent, up from 6.605 percent last week.


SOME SHADES OF MEANING
LEAD: The Supreme Court, in upholding a ''propaganda'' label for films produced by foreign governments, acknowledged that the term is widely perceived as carrying a negative connotation.


Dollar Helps Bonds
LEAD: Bond prices ended sharply higher yesterday, helped by the strengthening of the dollar in the world currency markets, especially against the Japanese yen.


Professor Is Said to Weigh Journalism Post at Columbia
LEAD: A journalism professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is considering an offer to become dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, according to officials at both institutions.


SHORTER SKIRTS SET OFF A CLOSET IDENTITY CRISIS
LEAD: I SEE short skirts are coming back.
This should make my husband happy.
The first time he met me, I was wearing a skirt so short that if I had reached for something on a closet shelf it would have constituted a crime in some states.
My hair was almost as long as my dress.
In the years since, the trend toward shorter hair and longer skirts has often filled him with a deep sadness.


Theater Group Leader From Ethiopia Defects
LEAD: The theater manager for an Ethiopian folkloric group said today that he had defected to the United States because he could no longer function in a country where all artistic endeavors are controlled by the state.

IN CHINA, BEAUTY IS A BIG WESTERN NOSE
LEAD: WU FEN is a vivacious 21-year-old law student with sparkling black eyes.
She wishes, however, that her eyelids folded like those of Westerners.
So Miss Wu is going to have an operation to add a fold in each eyelid and make her eyes look rounder.

LEAD: John S. Dyson - an industrialist, a candidate for the 1986 Democratic senatorial nomination in New York, ex-chairman of the State Power Authority and a former state commissioner of commerce and of agriculture - is a man for all seasons.
So he spends a good part of those seasons on hillsides tending his vines here in Dutchess County.

LEAD: Asked to compare Masterful Advocate with Roving Boy, Joe Manzi bit his lower lip, replacing one painful twinge with another.

LEAD: Norby Walters, the agent at the center of an F.B.I. investigation into reported threats against athletes, says that at one time he had representation agreements with 7 of the 28 first-round picks in yesterday's National Football League draft.


Livestock Posts Gains And Grains Are Mixed
LEAD: Prices of most live-cattle and pork futures rose yesterday.
Soybean futures advanced while the grains were mixed.
And oil futures edged higher.

LEAD: Two police officers were cleared Monday of wrongdoing in the death of Otis Bernard Miller, a 35-year-old transient who was the fourth black man in five months to die in confrontations with white police officers here.

CANADIENS LEAD, 3-2
LEAD: Ryan Walter scored on a 15-foot wrist shot with 2 minutes 39 seconds remaining to give the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight and a 3-2 lead over in the four-of-seven-game Adams Division final.


Reagans to Be at AIDS Event
LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will join the actress Elizabeth Taylor at a fund-raising dinner for AIDS research on May 31, officials said Monday.
The dinner, to be held in Washington, is expected to attract an audience of politicians and Hollywood celebrities.
It is being given by the American Foundation for AIDS Research, a nonprofit organization.

LEAD: The leadership of the troubled PTL television ministry said today that it had cut off the salary of the Rev.
Jim Bakker, who resigned last month in a scandal over a sexual encounter.
The leadership declared that he would not be allowed to return to the ministry he founded here.

BODDICKER'S 1-HITTER DOWNS ROYALS, 3-0
LEAD: Mike Boddicker pitched a one-hitter tonight, yielding only a sixth-inning single to Willie Wilson, and Nelson Simmons had three hits as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-0.


Preparations for Nakasone's Arrival Today
LEAD: First Secretary Toshiro Ozawa, top seated, and his staff working in operations room of the new Chancery of the Japanese Embassy in Washington.
They were preparing for today's arrival of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.
The trip will be Mr.
Nakasone's sixth to the United States. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)


Judge Voids More of Pretoria's Emergency Rules
LEAD: A provincial court justice today overturned emergency regulations that prohibited protests and appeals on behalf of people detained without charge.


Amoco May Sell Some Dome Assets
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation, which has agreed to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada for $3.8 billion (United States), said it might sell some of Dome's assets. ''Selloffs are a possibility,'' Amoco's chairman, Richard Morrow, said after the company's annual meeting. ''They have to be considered, but financing the deal does not hinge on this possibility.


The Meaning of Meow
LEAD: Americans keep 56 million cats as pets and spend an estimated hour a day ''interacting'' with them.
Many do so for a powerful reason: Cats appear to supply the affectionate companionship that may be lacking from other humans.
But whatever goes on in people's heads when they cuddle and coo with their pets, the interaction means something different to the cat.


DEALER IN CONTEMPORARY ART
LEAD: Xavier Fourcade, internationally known as a dealer in contemporary art and the founder and owner of the Xavier Fourcade Gallery in New York, died of pneumonia yesterday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
He was 60 years old.


H.R.A. TOLD TO AID 10 FAMILIES
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York City had failed to provide social services that would have kept the children of 10 poor families out of foster care.


WRIGHT IN F.S.L.I.C. REVERSAL
LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright, suffering an embarrassing reversal, announced today that he now favors a much larger bailout of the nearly depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation than he had previously sought.


MAN SLAIN BY MOTORIST IN MIDTOWN
LEAD: A pedestrian was stabbed to death on 42d Street in Manhattan yesterday morning after he accosted and scuffled with a motorist whose van may have grazed him as he tried to cross the intersection at Eighth Avenue, the police said.


JUDGE QUESTIONS DEPORTATION OF 2
LEAD: A Federal district judge has questioned the Government's attempt to deport two Palestinians because they were reported to belong to a Marxist faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization.


STATE DEPT. FAULTS SOVIET DEMAND ON BONN MISSILES
LEAD: The State Department today criticized a Soviet demand that American warheads for West German missiles be destroyed as part of missile accord in Europe.

LEAD:  The Economy

LEAD: THE LAMBERTS.
George, Constant and Kit.

Mr.
Verlaine, the New York rocker, poet, founder of Television and an imposing influence on post-1977 guitarists, has been living and recording in Britain.

LEAD: The Government of Belize said today that it would not allow a barge filled with 3,100 tons of garbage from Islip, L.I., to enter its territorial waters.
The decision prolongs the vessel's monthlong search for a dumping ground.

LEAD: A purple-red diamond weighing less than one carat was sold yesterday for $880,000 at Christie's in Manhattan to Theodore Horovitz, a Geneva merchant in precious stones.

CONCERT: JAPANESE FLUTE MASTER
LEAD: KOMUSO (priests of nothingness) was a Japanese name for the wandering Zen monks who refined the playing of the shakuhachi, or bamboo flute, during the 17th and 18th centuries.
One of the first albums of traditional shakuhachi music released in America was called ''A Bell Ringing in an Empty Sky.''

LEAD: The state's highest court has suspended Bronx Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand while it decides whether to remove him from office on charges of abusing his judicial authority during an affair with a female law assistant.

I do not want to paint them, but would like to cover them to give the appearance of a smooth plastered ceiling.
Can I plaster over them or cover them with wallpaper that will conceal the seams, or do you have other suggestions?

FANTASY AS A WAY OF LIFE
LEAD: IN past years, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House was the bellwether of decorating trends, innovative solutions and practical tips.
And no matter how fanciful, many of the rooms had some relationship to the world in which most of us live.
Elaborate exercise spaces pinpointed concerns about fitness and health, complex electronic installations mirrored our passion for new technology and magically outfitted small rooms reflected real-life concerns about organizing tiny spaces.


Painful Reminder for Ojeda
LEAD: A week ago Tuesday, on the mound at Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh, Bob Ojeda felt the sensation that nearly all pitchers eventually feel.
The sensation existed long before the age of the five-day rotation, the arthroscopic surgical procedure and the identification of the rotator cuff.


RECITAL: DAVID JOLLEY, HORN PLAYER
LEAD: WHAT makes David Jolley one of the better French horn players around today is the graceful sensibility of his work.
Mr.
Jolley, who offered a recital Tuesday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall, has an impressive technique but eschews flashy gestures for more subtle and satisfying forms of musical persuasion.


Nuclear Test Set for Today
LEAD: The sixth announced nuclear weapon test of the year, a major blast up to 10 times the force of the Hiroshima atomic bomb, is scheduled to occur Thursday in the desert.

Argentine Officer Gives Up
LEAD: An army major who has been a fugitive since leading a mutiny two weeks ago surrendered to federal authorities today in the western city of Cordoba, officials said.
The officer, Ernesto Barreiro, set off the uprising in Cordoba when he refused to appear in court to testify in connection with charges he tortured leftist suspects when chief interrogator at La Perla detention camp from 1976 to 1980.

LEAD: Word theat the French Government may sponsor a salvage expedition to the wreck of the Titanic is causing concern in Congress, which last year passed a bill calling for an international agreement to preserve the ocean liner's resting place.

Kodak Says Profit Tripled
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its first-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $178 million, or 79 cents a share, from $48.6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Sales rose 13 percent, to $2.66 billion, from $2.35 billion last year.

Construction Contracting Up
LEAD: Construction contracting, led by an increase in highway projects, rose 10 percent in March, reversing two months of declines, according to a survey released yesterday. by the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.
The survye put the value of new construction at $251 billion, compared with $227.6 billion.

First and Foremost
LEAD: First-round picks may get all the attention on the N.F.L.'s draft day, but as a group they deserve it.
Of the 23 offensive and defensive starters (including 4 defensive linemen as well as 4 linebackers) elected by their peers to The Sporting News's all-pro squad last season, 11, or virtually half, had entered the league as an opening-round choice.

LEAD: More than one factor may have contributed to the collapse last week of an apartment building under construction here, an investigator said today after representatives of the city and of contractors and insurers met for the first time to coordinate the testing of the rubble still being trucked from the disaster site.


Chips Are Up At Georgia
LEAD: It's a familiar sight and, depending on where your rooting interests lie, a sometimes exasperating one.
After a runner bulls his way through the line and is tackled by a swarm of defenders, an official steps forward to peel back the tangle of bodies and retrieve the football, which he then carefully positions on the field at the precise spot that - in his best guess - marks the extent of its forward motion.

LEAD: The 40-nation Disarmament Conference here is moving toward the abolition of chemical weapons, according to Western and Soviet-bloc diplomats.

LEAD: Ronnie DeSillers, a 7-year-old Florida boy who received three liver transplants after an outpouring of support from thousands of Americans, including President Reagan, died today while awaiting a fourth transplant.


Trade Surplus For Germany
LEAD: West Germany today reported another strong monthly trade surplus.
Economists were surprised at how well exports fared despite the appreciation of the mark against the weakened dollar.

Commodore Has a Profit
LEAD: Commodore International, the troubled personal computer manufacturer, today reported net income of $1 million, or 3 cents a share, for the third quarter ended March 31.
The results compared with a loss of $36.7 million in the comparable period a year ago.
Sales dropped 7 percent, to $169.5 million, from $182.3 million in the third quarter of 1986.

Republic-Interfirst Merger Approved
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board approved an application by the Republicbank Corporation to acquire the Interfirst Corporation, creating a $28 billion banking concern that would be the largest in Texas.
Republic and Interfirst, which are both based in Dallas, are currently the second- and third-largest banking organizations in Texas, with $14.4 billion and $13.6 billion in domestic deposits, respectively.


On Barring Waldheim
LEAD: In its yearlong deliberations over what to do about Kurt Waldheim, the Reagan Administration was well aware that political benefits could flow from a decision to bar the Austrian President from entering the United States, according to a senior White House official.

AUSTRIA, AFTER BAN ON WALDHEIM, ACTS TO LIMIT DAMAGE TO U.S. TIES
LEAD: The Austrian Government moved today to limit damage to its relations with Washington after President Kurt Waldheim was barred from the United States.

LEAD: Appearing recently at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in Greenwich Village, Governor Cuomo announced a proposed ban on AIDS testing for health insurance.
He also spoke of Peter Vogel, former vice chairman of the state's Advisory Council on AIDS and chairman of the Governor's Task Force on Gay Concerns.

Hansen's attorney said.

LEAD: Ray Knight, the Baltimore Orioles' third baseman, was in satisfactory condition at St.
Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday with a mild concussion.

Daiwa Buys Seat in Toronto
LEAD: The Daiwa Securities Company of Tokyo has bought a seat on the Toronto Stock Exchange for $361,000 Canadian (about $270,000 United States), becoming the first Japanese securities firm to do so.
It also said today that it planned to open a new Canadian brokerage house later this year.

LEAD: Scott Young, a right wing on the United States team playing in the World Hockey Championships in Vienna, has been suspended from international play for 18 months after failing a postgame drug test.

MET SAYS ITS POPULAR CAT IS PROBABLY FAKE
LEAD: One of the most popular sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a 15-inch-high Egyptian bronze cat that was believed to have been a coffin for a mummified cat, was declared yesterday by museum officials to be ''in all probability a modern forgery.''


PHILLIES BEAT EXPOS BEHIND RAWLEY, 5-0
LEAD: Shane Rawley became the first Philadelphia pitcher to pitch a complete game this season, limiting Montreal to six hits tonight as the Phillies beat the Expos, 5-0.

Bio-Technology General Corp. is offering $20 million of 7 1/2 percent convertible senior subordinated notes due 1997 at 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.
The notes are convertible into the company's common stock at an initial price of $13.20 a share, which is subject to adjustment and reset.

GOODEN IS RELEASED FROM DRUG CENTER
LEAD: Twenty-seven days after he began treatment for cocaine abuse, Dwight Gooden left the Smithers center yesterday.


NASA and Chile Carve Up Easter Island
LEAD: To the Editor:


Robert Favre Le Bret Dead; Founder of Cannes Festival
LEAD: Robert Favre Le Bret, founder and longtime president of the Cannes Film Festival, died Tuesday in Switzerland, a week before the festival celebrates its 40th anniversary.
He was 82 years old.


New-Home Sales Fall; Median Price a Record
LEAD: Sales of new homes slumped 3.6 percent in March, led by a big drop in activity in the Middle West, while the nationwide median sales price climbed to a record $101,500, the Commerce Department said today.


TV MINISTRY'S RESCUERS FACE WORLDLY AND SPIRITUAL CRISIS
LEAD: Like a team brought in to rescue a foundering Wall Street corporation, the directors of the PTL television ministry set out this week to restore the confidence of their investors, the tens of thousands of faithful who helped collect $129 million last year.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1987
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The House approved a restrictive trade bill amendment, reflecting disarray over the direction of a new trade policy.
The measure, proposed by Representative Gephardt, requires retaliation according to a rigid formula against countries such as Japan, whose large trade surpluses with the United States have grown, in part by shutting out American products.


FREDERICK A. WYCKOFF
LEAD: Frederick A. Wyckoff, a retired New York City real-estate executive, died of a heart attack Monday in Lakewood, N.J.
He was 79 years old and lived in Lakehurst, N.J.


NEW SOVIET AID TO SYRIA REPORTED
LEAD: Western diplomats believe that the Soviet Union will provide Syria with more advanced weapons and reschedule the Syrian debt under an agreement last week between President Hafez al-Assad and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


G.O.P. HOPEFULS STRESS ISRAELI TIE DESPITE POLLARD
LEAD: Republican Presidential hopefuls appeared today before a Republican-oriented Jewish group, saying that United States-Israeli relations remained unchanged despite the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case and urging even closer strategic cooperation between the two countries.

GUS JOHNSON, EX-N.B.A. STAR WITH BALTIMORE, IS DEAD AT 48
LEAD: Gus Johnson, who brought National Basketball Association fans to their feet with his backboard-shattering dunk shots, died of brain cancer Tuesday night at Akron City Hospital in Ohio.
He was 48 years old.


YANKEES RELIEVERS CRUMBLE
LEAD: Their major concern has been hitting, but tonight the Yankees lost a game when their pitching failed miserably.
Dave Righetti could not hold a five-run lead in the late innings, and the Yankees ultimately lost it in the ninth when Gino Petralli's pinch-hit single off Cecilio Guante gave the Texas Rangers an 8-7 victory at Arlington


PISTONS SWEEP BULLETS, 97-96
LEAD: Rick Mahorn sank one of two free throws with four seconds remaining, giving the Detroit Pistons a 97-96 victory over the Washington Bullets and a three-game sweep of their first-round National Basketball Association playoff series.


HIGH POINT'S DIVERSIFIED FURNITURE
LEAD: A RECORD 45,000 furniture buyers, many in rubber-soled shoes, were off and walking last Thursday through the miles of corridors in the Southern Furniture Market showrooms here.
The nine-day semiannual market, which ends tomorrow, was especially bullish as buyers, more interested in placing orders than in browsing, encountered one of the most diverse selections of furniture seen here in recent years.

Expulsion for Weapons Set
LEAD: After two days of assemblies that drew more than 40,000 students and parents, the Detroit Board of Education has voted to expel students who carry weapons into high school.
The board voted Tuesday to approve a policy that students in the 7th through 12th grades who were found guilty of carrying guns or other lethal weapons would be expelled from regular schools.

Sound Credit
LEAD: As any theatergoer knows, wristwatches have been beeping for several years now.

NEW YORK INTENDS TO EXPAND POLICE TO FULL STRENGTH

Fireworks Bring Queries
LEAD: A fireworks display last night over the Hudson River in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution prompted numerous telephone calls to the police in New Jersey and New York, the authorities said.
The display, sponsored by Maxwell House and launched from its coffee-factory property in Hoboken, N.J., produced numerous calls to the police in both Hoboken and Manhattan from people who were uncertain of the cause of the noise, the police said.

HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON GEPHARDT AMENDMENT TO TRADE BILL
LEAD: Following is the 218-to-214 roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today approved a trade bill amendment by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri.
The measure calls for retaliation against countries that maintain large trade surpluses with the United States.
Casting a ''yes'' vote for the amendment were 201 Democrats and 17 Republicans.

CONCERT: EARLY MUSIC ORCHESTRA
LEAD: THE more one hears Handel on period instruments, the more one realizes how individual and particular are the orchestral pieces that have sometimes seemed cut in a generic pattern.
The familiar Concerto Grosso in A (Op. 6, No. 11) begins with one of those dotted-rhythm movements that one thinks of as severe and majestic; grins of delight must have spread around Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening when the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra gave forth instead a gentle jogging or rocking sound, nimble on its feet, moving by whole measures rather than single beats.

LEAD: John Manos was scared and angry when he first heard that a drug rehabilitation center was going up across the street from his shoe store in Flushing, Queens.
But when youths from the center showed up one day to shovel the snow off his walk, he began to feel differently.

DEAVER CHALLENGES A GRAND JURY
LEAD: The grand jury that indicted Michael K. Deaver has continued to meet and call witnesses, apparently in an attempt to bolster the perjury case against the former White House aide, Mr.
Deaver said today.

ACQUITTALS OF 5 INDIANS BASED ON ANCIENT RELIGIOUS RIGHTS
LEAD: A jury of the Yakima Indian Nation here has acquitted five of its members charged with violating the tribe's salmon fishing regulations.

GOETZ ACCOUNT OF SHOOTING 4 GIVEN ON TAPE
LEAD: For more than two hours yesterday, the voice of Bernhard H. Goetz - high pitched and nervous, sometimes choked with emotion - filled a courtroom, as prosecutors played a 28-month-old tape on which Mr.
Goetz described how, and why, he shot four young men on a Manhattan subway train.


Multiplier Effect
LEAD: To the Editor:


7 Years After Deaths, Boat Hits New Bridge
LEAD: A shrimp boat slammed into a concrete bumper protecting the new $240 million Sunshine Skyway Bridge today on the eve of its reopening.
It was seven years ago that another vessel struck the old bridge, sending 35 people to their death.


DATA BACK ESTROGEN THERAPY
LEAD: Women who undergo hysterectomy with the removal of both ovaries face double the usual risk of heart disease if they do not receive estrogen supplements, a study has concluded.


15-Vehicle Collision Closes Williamsburg Bridge for 4 Hours
LEAD: Firefighters surveying wreckage of chain-reaction collision involving 15 vehicles, three of which burst into flames.
One person was slightly injured.
The accident closed the bridge four hours.
Officials said it began when a truck lost its brakes as it was traveling in the right lane of the outer roadway, from Brooklyn to Manhattan.


Bridge: Program From British TV Shows High-Stakes Game
LEAD: In the past two decades there have been several efforts to present bridge on television in this country, but with limited success.


DUKAKIS OPENS PRESIDENTIAL QUEST STRESSING HIS RECORD AS GOVERNOR
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts set out this morning on his quest for the Presidency with a dash to make his declaration in five states.

American Civilian Killed in Ambush in Nicaragua
LEAD: Benjamin Ernest Linder, an engineer, working recently at a hydroelectric project in Nicaragua.
The official Sandinista newspaper said he died Tuesday in a rebel ambush.
Several American organizations have been sending aid and volunteers to the Sandinistas.

Refugees Are Not Subsidies
LEAD: President Duarte of El Salvador has asked President Reagan to give temporary refuge to half a million Salvadorans living illegally in the United States.
If President Reagan agreed, he would blow a loophole the size of St.
Louis through the new Immigration Reform and Control Act.


DR. GEORGE KHOURY
LEAD: Dr.
George Khoury, who had been chief of the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of the National Cancer Institute since 1980, died of complications related to lymphoma Saturday in Bethesda, Md., where he lived.
He was 43 years old.


Key Apple Officer Will Head Spinoff
LEAD: William V. Campbell was the first executive recruited by John Sculley after he joined Apple Computer Inc., and as executive vice president for sales and marketing he has been said to epitomize the chief executive's teamwork approach.
Soon Mr.
Campbell will start assembling his own team.

Europe Jobless Dip
LEAD: Unemployment in the 12-member European Community fell in March to 16.8 million from 17 million in February because of an improvement in the weather, the group's statistics agency, Eurostat, said today.
